webTitle: Review:  True History of the Kelly Gang by Peter Carey

fields.headline: Remaking Ned
fields.standfirst: Robert Edric  salutes an  outlaw imagination in Peter Carey's new book, True History of the Kelly Gang
fields.trailText: Robert Edric salutes an outlaw imagination in Peter Carey's new book, True History of the Kelly Gang
fields.body:
True History of the Kelly Gang

Peter Carey

349pp, Faber, £16.99
Buy it at BOL

Pushed centre stage with neither a definite nor an indefinite article for moral or theatrical support, True History of the Kelly Gang signals the first of its many deceits. Peter Carey's skills, passions and obsessions are all fully on display in this long-awaited take on colonial Australia's most enduring myth. Ned Kelly, cattle thief, bank robber and folk hero, was hanged at the age of 25 in Melbourne jail in 1880. Carey tells his story in the first person, in a narrative - recalling Ondaatje's Billy the Kid, Hanson's Jesse James and perhaps even Burroughs's Dutch Schultz - that his publishers refer to as a dazzling act of ventriloquism.

But this is not the short-lived gimmickry of ventriloquism; it is writing, and though the voice it renders is loud, distinctive and beguiling, the concessions made by Carey to the modern reader create several potential flaws in the construction that, to begin with at least, threaten to undermine the otherwise carefully woven illusion. Happily, Carey is far too accomplished and adventurous a writer to expect anything so simple or so obvious as the suspension of disbelief in the reader. Rather, he makes a valid and sustained plea for accommodation, for readers to bring all they think they know about Ned Kelly - all those half-remembered childhood memories of a man in the heat of an outback summer with a bucket on his head - and then to allow Carey himself to fill in the empty spaces that remain. We are not seriously expected to believe that this is a transcript of Kelly's own work; we are not so easily fooled by the archive sources cited; we are not so swiftly seduced by the atrocious punctuation in a narrative otherwise so finely tuned, plotted and controlled.

What Carey demands of us is what he has been demanding for 20 years: that we trust the narrator of the tale as much as the tale being told, and that we don't unduly concern ourselves as readers with the mode of its telling. Ever since the playful, shape-changing stories of The Fat Man in History, Oscar and Lucinda, Jack Maggs and - supremely - Illywhacker, Carey has been talking out of the side of his mouth and behind his hand. He mumbles and whispers and then turns to face his reader with a look of mock surprise saying: "What? What don't you believe?"

This Ned Kelly is a convincing and intriguing individual; Carey has indulged his appetite for language and imaginative construction in making him so. It does not matter that we are unable to pin Kelly to the facts of his life, only that we are willing and prepared to accept him as Carey reveals him to us, and to trust the kaleidoscopic array of characters and situations and the often startling images employed by Carey to create them. There is wonder here, and awe.

Carey's narrators have always been storytellers in the truest sense. We have always been asked to believe what they are telling us while guessing or half-knowing that it is a well-turned pack of lies. Throughout his career, Carey has concerned himself above all with the image and the identity of his fellow Australians - from the earliest settlers struggling to understand the strangeness and precariousness of their lives and surroundings, to the disappointment and emptiness of contemporary urban man, detached from the vast and legend-filled spaces around him. This is nowhere more evident or more poignant than in those places and lives where only one or two generations might separate these extremes. These are the human spaces Carey inhabits, and at times he seems to have far more in common with his Victorian and Edwardian forbears - with Marcus Clark and Henry Handel Richardson, say - than with any of his more obvious contemporaries.

There is little doubt that Carey the storyteller, Kelly the narrator and the tale being told are uniquely well matched. There is little doubt, either, where Carey's sympathies lie. He cannot be faulted for the shape and colour of the portrait he is painting when Kelly himself - the original Wild Colonial Boy - is telling the tale. History, Carey insists, is just as cruel to those figures it remembers (whether well, badly or indifferently) as to those it decently forgets.

Kelly himself undoubtedly considered his reckless and ignorant bravery wholly justified, and understood as well as any of his later apologists and worshippers that he was the victim of the casually brutal wilderness and times he inhabited. Carey does little to alter this account. What he does achieve is a picture of a fuller, living man, about whom the reader need know nothing before he starts speaking. It is to Carey's great credit that, as the story progresses, the writer of the novel and the narrator of the tale it tells become indivisible. It is equally to his credit that Kelly's trademark ridiculous bucket headgear - my own abiding childhood memory - is not mentioned until 25 pages from the end of his account.

Intriguingly, 10 years ago Robert Drewe published Our Sunshine, a fractured, unsentimental, "poetic" and compassionate first-person account of Kelly, of which Carey himself said: "An important writer meets an important myth and reinvents it in the most sensual, visceral language he has yet produced." I anticipate that Robert Drewe will say exactly the same of Carey's Ned Kelly.

webTitle: The future: Still the final frontier

fields.headline: The future: Still the final frontier
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: The pleasant tingling in my head can mean only one thing. It's time to start the day. Stepping out of my Plexiglas slumber cot, I make my way to the bathroom, where the all-body dry-cleaning pod purrs in anticipation. Punching the auto-pedicure button, I sit back and let the machine do its business while experimenting with the Russian verbs I just learned in my sleep.
fields.body:
The pleasant tingling in my head can mean only one thing. It's time to start the day. Stepping out of my Plexiglas slumber cot, I make my way to the bathroom, where the all-body dry-cleaning pod purrs in anticipation. Punching the auto-pedicure button, I sit back and let the machine do its business while experimenting with the Russian verbs I just learned in my sleep.

Today is Monday, and Monday is that rare thing - a working day. So I select a smart new flexi-garment from my revolving wardrobe (I'll decide later what colour to make it), grab a handful of breakfast pills and head for the jet-car bay. 'Where to, David?' says a pleasant voice as I lock the safety seat and brace myself for the exhilaration of sudden and rapid acceleration.

'The office,' I reply. 'And skip the headlines this morning, Robbie. Ever since the World Harmony Accord, there hasn't been a scrap of news worth listening to.'

Does this scenario sound familiar? If you were a child during the decades immediately following the second world war, it probably describes the sort of life you thought you would be living today - always assuming that an exchange of nuclear missiles hadn't reduced the surface of the planet to a sea of rippling green glass.

Yet this Jetsons vision of a wipe-clean plastic world with cheap atomic energy and automated everything (in the 1962 TV cartoon series, the Jetson family even had a robot to take their dog for a walk) has proved to be laughably inaccurate on almost every count.

Personal aircraft? Food pills? Unlimited leisure time? Total control of the climate? Not only did technology fail to deliver most of the promised goods, but in many respects it took us in the opposite direction, poisoning our food and making the weather wilder than anyone can remember.

The fact is that predicting the relatively near future has always been a hazardous business. And no matter how much care would-be prophets take and how many experts they consult, their visions invariably tell future generations more about the concerns of the society that spawned their work than vice versa. And not only the concerns, but the quaint aesthetics, too.

Do video collectors watch Things To Come, the 1936 William Cameron Menzies film based on the HG Wells novel with a slightly longer name, for its political insights? Read the reviews in the online shopping guides - it's the art-deco rocket ships that sell the tapes today.

If there's no accounting for the taste of future generations, there's no foreseeing their hardware, either. Gizmos and contraptions provide much of the initial appeal of a futuristic work, but when the future arrives, they are just so many sticks with which to beat their author. Items of kit such as the anti-gravity belts and sonic ray guns that propelled the intergalactic swashbuckler Flash Gordon through the 30s have a troublesome habit of not being invented. Meanwhile, the internet, the personal computer and the Sony Walkman - the sort of innovations that really do change the texture of society - are conspicuous by their absence (poor old Flash didn't even have his own email address).

Jules Verne went out of his way to check his science, yet he concluded that humans would be shot to the moon from the muzzles of 900ft cannon. At least Fritz Lang, whose 1926 film Metropolis rashly peopled the world of 2000 with beautiful robots and an oppressed race of subterranean workers, redeemed himself three years later by inventing the '5, 4, 3, 2, 1' countdown to blastoff in the film Woman In The Moon.

It is the fate of any writer of cautionary tales, however, to sail dangerously close to the wind. For if the purpose in predicting the future is to describe a likely outcome of current events - to warn one's contemporaries that, if they carry on behaving as they are, then the results will be precisely as follows - he or she is bound to a short-term vision, with all the risks that this entails.

Only George Orwell got away with it. He wrote a novel with a year for a title and managed to hit the nail on the head despite getting almost all the details wrong. Maybe it wasn't the right nail, but he hit it so hard that 1984 will always be with us.

One response to the problem is to begin with the near future and just keep going. That way, if things turn out wrong in the short-term, you always get another chance to say, 'I told you so.' In 1930, the historian-turned-novelist Olaf Stapledon wrote Last And First Men, a vast history of the human species as set down by one of the last men and transmitted several trillion years backwards in time to us, the first men. Hopelessly flawed in its early chapters (Stapledon fails to foresee the coming war in Europe), this extraordinary book improves in leaps and bounds with the passing millennia, as humans master artificial intelligence and genetic engineering, taking to the air and, finally, to space. At one point, he has humans becoming extinct, only to be reinvented thousands of years down the line by the super-computers that had superseded them.

Arthur C Clarke once described Stapledon as 'the most educated man I have ever met'; on the strength of Last And First Men, he is occasionally referred to as the Father Of Future History. Yet it is his short story Old Man In New World that contains by far the most poignant descriptions of a near future that was never to be.

Written in 1943 and set in the closing years of the 20th century, Old Man paints a touching picture of Britain 25 years after the worldwide communist revolution that Stapledon believed would eventually follow the madness of the second world war, despite the best efforts of the US corporations. As it turned out, of course, it was those very corporations that fixed both our postwar present and our postwar vision of the future.

In 1955, Disney opened the Tomorrowland section of its Californian theme park, Disneyland. Attractions of Tomorrowland included Autopia, 'the freeway of the future', and a huge Rocket To The Moon, alongside such awe-inspiring installations as the Bathroom Of Tomorrow, the Aluminum Hall Of Fame and the Monsanto House Of The Future.

This last structure, sponsored by the future champions of GM food, was built out of a plastic so durable that, on retirement in 1967, it had to be sawn to pieces with hacksaws - a moral tale, if ever there was one. Tomorrowland was the embodiment of Jetson values. But if the plastic house was virtually indestructible, the spirit of optimism born of technological progress proved less so. With the dawning of the Age Of Aquarius, a more spiritually aware generation woke up and saw that the American Dream was something of a nightmare.

The agony of the Vietnam war, the constant threat of nuclear annihilation, the failure of technology to cure most social ills, and its potential instead to cause untold damage to the health of the planet and its inhabitants, led to a wave of disillusionment with both the present and the future.

Almost overnight, the urban space families of future fiction were supplanted by a population of shambling mutants, survivors of the nuclear holocaust to come. And when the nukes failed to go off as predicted, it was simply a case of switching the scenery and replacing the big bang either with some sort of eco-disaster, or with a descent into postmodern social chaos, Blade Runner-style.

Either way, it was downhill all the way for the human species. Fragmentation and tribalism lay ahead, and the only consolation would be a few more electronic goodies for the rich to buy and the poor to steal - goodies which, as everybody knew, would be bound to pack up the very second their guarantees ran out.

All of which presented Disney with a bit of a problem when it decided a couple of years back that it was time to give Tomorrowland a makeover. What were the options? A cyberpunk jungle of patched-up, malfunctioning technology - the sort of thing Terry Gilliam dreamed up for his 1985 film, Brazil? How about a fortified School Of The Future, or a Hospital Of Tomorrow, besieged by superbugs? Not in front of the children.

Clearly, Disney had only one viable option - to return to yesteryear's images of the future. And so in a Garden Of Eden setting that plays to the new anti-urban, anti-technology trends in western society, today's Tomorrowland focuses on past visionaries such as Jules Verne, HG Wells and Leonardo da Vinci.

'We're focusing on dreamlike images rather than updated images of tomorrow,' said a spokesman for the company. In other words, white-knuckle rides are one thing, but the future - the real low-rise, low-hope future of the present - is far too scary to contemplate.

webTitle: The X-Prize: design a spaceship and win $10 million

fields.headline: The X-Prize: design a spaceship and win $10 million
fields.trailText: After calculating that his chances of becoming a Nasa astronaut were 'one in a thousand', Peter Diamandis, an aerospace engineer and Harvard medical school graduate, decided that he would get into orbit under his own steam.
fields.body:
After calculating that his chances of becoming a Nasa astronaut were 'one in a thousand', Peter Diamandis, an aerospace engineer and Harvard medical school graduate, decided that he would get into orbit under his own steam.

In 1997, at the age of 36 and with backing from the city of St Louis, Diamandis launched the X-Prize, a $10m reward to entice non-governmental space-boundinitiatives and 'jump-start' the space tourism industry. The real hurdle to space tourism, according to Diamandis, is in our minds. Free our minds and the rockets will follow.

Inspiration for the X-Prize came from the $25,000 prize won in 1927 by Charles Lindbergh and his aeroplane Spirit of St Louis for crossing the Atlantic nonstop. Before Lindbergh became a household name, pilots were called 'aeronauts' and flying was for daredevils. We have come a long way since then: now we are herded like cattle on to jets and complain if our drinks are not mixed right.

'Lindbergh became the most famous human on the planet, and, most important, he wasn't proving new technology,' says Diamandis. 'He completely changed the mindset of the world with regard to aviation. Aviation went from something very much like space is today - something that's expensive and difficult - to something that was exciting, with great potential, that a 25-year-old kid from New York could do. That's what my life has been all about. Changing the public perception that space is something just for governments.'

To win the X-Prize, all you have to do is send the same passenger-carrying vehicle 100km above the earth twice in two weeks. Fifty miles is high enough to earn Nasa astronaut wings and to see the curvature of the earth, that ball of cobalt oceans and wispy clouds below. To prove to the X-Prize judges that your vehicle is quickly reusable, you must take the trip twice.

As you might imagine, the promise of fame, fortune (though not much in terms of space exploration) and the chance to alter history attracts a wide range of proposals, from the believable to the half-baked. Among the 19 registered X-Prize contenders is an engineer in Portland, Oregon, who has submitted a picture of a flying saucer-like contraption dubbed The Space Tourist, which can apparently take off from your local runway. A team from Buenos Aires has sent in a mysterious rocket and parachute scheme under the dubious name of Gauchito ('The Little Cowboy'). An industrial designer from Toronto, meanwhile, plans on using a hot-air balloon, a rocket-and-parachute combo inspired by a Leonardo da Vinci drawing. They laughed at Da Vinci, too.

Most of the frontrunners propose a piggy-backing method to avoid the cost and hazard of firing a rocket from the ground through the thick lower atmosphere. The renegade aircraft designer Burt Rutan, known for Voyager - a super-lightweight plane that in 1986 completed the first nonstop, round-the-world flight without refuelling - has already successfully tested half of his system: a seagull-like high-altitude plane that can carry a little rocket ship to 40,000ft, before letting it shoot off into the mesosphere.

Kelly Space & Technology, a Nasa contractor, proposes using a 747 Jumbo jet to tow a returnable rocket ship to 20,000ft before lift-off.

A Russian initiative, led by space programme pioneer Varley Novikov, uses a carrier aircraft to hoist the rocket, while the Cheshire-based Starchaser Industries (one of three UK bids) has a jet-powered, missile-shaped vehicle with rockets that kick in at the second stage.

By 2003, according to the stoically optimistic Diamandis, we should have a winner. If some of this sounds a little too much like a sky-bound adaptation of the 60s TV cartoon show Wacky Races, heed Diamandis's warning: mock not the underdog.

'Lindbergh was nicknamed "the flying fool" for going with one pilot and one engine,' he says. 'The favourite, by far, was this fellow named Admiral Bird, who had spent $100,000. He failed on take-off.'

Among the 19 registered X-Prize contenders is an engineer in Portland, Oregon, who has submitted a picture of a flying saucer-like contraption dubbed The Space Tourist, which can apparently take off from your local runway. A team from Buenos Aires has sent in a mysterious rocket and parachute scheme under the dubious name of Gauchito ('The Little Cowboy'). An industrial designer from Toronto, meanwhile, plans on using a hot-air balloon, a rocket-and-parachute combo inspired by a Leonardo da Vinci drawing. They laughed at Da Vinci, too. Most of the frontrunners propose a piggy-backing method to avoid the cost and hazard of firing a rocket from the ground through the thick lower atmosphere. The renegade aircraft designer Burt Rutan, known for Voyager - a super-lightweight plane that in 1986 completed the first nonstop, round-the-world flight without refuelling - has already successfully tested half of his system: a seagull-like high-altitude plane that can carry a little rocket ship to 40,000ft, before letting it shoot off into the mesosphere. Kelly Space & Technology, a Nasa contractor, proposes using a 747 Jumbo jet to tow a returnable rocket ship to 20,000ft before lift-off. A Russian initiative, led by space programme pioneer Varley Novikov, uses a carrier aircraft to hoist the rocket, while the Cheshire-based Starchaser Industries (one of three UK bids) has a jet-powered, missile-shaped vehicle with rockets that kick in at the second stage. By 2003, according to the stoically optimistic Diamandis, we should have a winner. If some of this sounds a little too much like a sky-bound adaptation of the 60s TV cartoon show Wacky Races, heed Diamandis's warning: mock not the underdog. 'Lindbergh was nicknamed "the flying fool" for going with one pilot and one engine,' he says. 'The favourite, by far, was this fellow named Admiral Bird, who had spent $100,000. He failed on take-off.'

webTitle: Space in our time: a brief history of space travel

fields.headline: Space in our time: a brief history of space travel
fields.trailText: 50s
fields.body:
50s

October 1957: USSR launches Sputnik 1, the first man-made object to orbit the earth. November 1957 A dog called Laika orbits the earth for seven days in Sputnik 2.

January 1958: Explorer 1, the first US satellite, lifts off from Cape Canaveral and discovers the earth's radiation belt.

October 1958: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration (Nasa) is set up in the US. The US probe Pioneer 1 reaches a height of 70,700 miles.

January 1959: The USSR launches Luna 1, the first man-made satellite to orbit the sun.

March 1959: The US Pioneer 4 passes within 37,000 miles of the moon.

September 1959: Luna 2, carrying a copy of the Soviet coat of arms, becomes the first man-made object to hit the moon.

October 1959: Luna 3 photographs some 70% of the far side of the moon.

60s

April 1960: The US launches Tiros 1, the first successful weather satellite, and Discoverer XIV, the first camera-equipped spy satellite.

April 1961: The USSR launches Vostok 1. It carries Yuri Gagarin, who becomes the first man in space when he orbits the earth once.

May 1961: Mercury Freedom 7 carries Alan Shepard into a sub-orbital space, making him the first American in space.

August 1961: Gherman Titov, aboard Vostok 2, undertakes the first day-long space flight.

February 1962: John Glenn becomes the first American to orbit the earth.

July 1962: US satellite Telstar 1 beams the first live transatlantic telecast.

December 1962: US Mariner 2, the first successful planetary spacecraft, flies past Venus.

June 1963: Soviet cosmonaut Valentina Tereshkova becomes the first woman in space. She orbits the earth 48 times.

July 1964: US Ranger 7 relays the first close-up pictures of the moon.

March 1965: Soviet cosmonaut Aleksey Leonov undertakes the first space walk. It lasts 12 minutes.

June 1965: Edward White II makes the first US space walk - duration 22 minutes.

July 1965: US Mariner 4 returns the first close-range images from Mars.

November 1965: Launch of Soviet Venus 3. Four months later, it becomes the first craft to hit Venus.

December 1965: Frank Borman and James Lovell make 206 orbits around the earth, proving that a trip to the moon is possible. American astronauts make the first space rendezvous with another craft.

February 1966: Soviet Luna 9 is the first spacecraft to soft-land on the moon.

March 1966: Soviet Luna 10 is the first spacecraft to orbit the moon.

June 1966: Surveyor 1 is the first US spacecraft to soft-land on the moon.

August 1966: US Lunar Orbiter 1 enters moon orbit, and takes the first picture of the earth from such a distance.

April 1967: Vladimir Komarov is the first person to die in space.

September 1968: Launch of Soviet Zond 5, the first spacecraft to orbit the moon and return.

October 1968: Apollo 7 is the first manned Apollo mission. It orbits the earth once.

December 1968: Apollo 8, carrying Frank Borman, James Lovell and William Anders, is the first manned spacecraft to orbit the moon.

January 1969: Soyuz 4 and 5 perform the first Soviet spaceship docking, transferring cosmonauts between vehicles.

July 1969: Neil Armstrong and Edwin Aldrin make the first manned soft-landing on the moon, and the first moonwalk, using Apollo 11. Mariner 6 returns to earth high-resolution images of the Martian surface.

70s

April 1970: Apollo 13 is launched, but suffers an explosion. Its moon landing is aborted, and the crew return safely.

September 1970: Soviet Luna 16 is launched, conducting the first successful return of lunar soil samples by an automatic spacecraft.

November 1970: Luna 17 lands on the moon with the first automatic robot, Lunokhod 1, driven from controls on earth.

April 1971: The Salyut 1 space station is launched by the USSR.

June 1971: Soyuz 11 carries the first crew to occupy an orbital station. On June 29, they die on re-entry.

July 1971: David Scott and James Irwin drive the first moon rover.

March 1972: The US fires Pioneer 10 towards Jupiter with the intention of familiarising alien life with humans.

July 1972: The first probable black hole is discovered.

May 1973: Launch of US Skylab Workshop.

June 1974: USSR launches Salyut 3, its first military space station.

December 1974: USSR launches Salyut 4, its first civilian space station.

July 1975: The American Apollo 18 and Soviet Soyuz 19 dock - it is the first international spacecraft rendezvous.

September 1976: Viking 2 lands on Mars and finds ice.

December 1978: Two Pioneer spacecraft reach Venus.

September 1979: Pioneer 11 flies within 13,000 miles of Saturn.

80s

March 1982: The USSR obtains the first Venusian soil analysis.

April 1982: The Soviet Salyut 7 space station is launched.

May 1982: Soviet cosmonauts begin a 211-day occupation of a space station, a new record.

August 1982: Voyager 2 completes its fly-by of Saturn.

November 1982: The space shuttle Columbia deploys two satellites, its first operational mission.

April 1983: The space shuttle Challenger lifts off for its first mission, which marks the first American space walk in nine years.

June 1983: Sally K Ride becomes the first American woman in space.

November 1983: The space shuttle Columbia carries the European Space Agency (ESA) Spacelab-1 into orbit. Its crew includes the German Ulf Merbold, the first ESA member in space.

January-November 1983: The Infrared Astronomical Satellite finds new comets, asteroids, galaxies and possible planets.

February 1984: Bruce McCandless takes the first untethered space walk.

December 1984: Soviet/International Vega 1 and 2 are launched, dropping probes into Venus's atmosphere before continuing to Halley's Comet.

January 1985: The Sakigake probe is launched by Japan's Institute of Space and Aeronautical Science, and makes a rendezvous with Halley's Comet.

April 1985: The space shuttle Challenger carries the ESA Spacelab-3 into orbit.

July 1985: The ESA launches the Giotto spacecraft from an Ariane rocket.

October 1985: Spacelab D1 becomes the first joint German/ESA mission.

January 1986: Voyager 2 flies past Uranus. The space shuttle Challenger explodes shortly after liftoff.

February 1986: The core unit of the Soviet space station Mir is launched.

May 1989: The space shuttle Atlantis is launched, deploying the spacecraft Magellan, bound for Venus.

October 1989: The US Galileo spacecraft sets off for Venus and Jupiter.

90s

April 1990: The space shuttle Discovery deploys the Edwin P Hubble Space Telescope.

August 1990: Magellan arrives at Venus.

February 1992: The US spacecraft Ulysses flies around Jupiter on its way to the sun.

February 1994: A Russian cosmonaut flies on a US space shuttle for the first time.

February 1995: The US space shuttle Discovery prepares to dock with the Russian space station Mir. It is the first shuttle mission to be flown by a female pilot.

March 1995: Cosmonaut Valery Polyakov returns to earth after a 438-day mission aboard Mir, setting a new space endurance record.

December 1995: Galileo reaches Jupiter.

March 1996: Shannon Lucid becomes the first female astronaut to crew a space station.

November 1996: A Russian spacecraft bound for Mars ignites prematurely and crashes into the ocean off Chile carrying 270g plutonium.

July 1997: Pathfinder lands on Mars, the first landing on the red planet since the Viking missions in 1976.

January 1998: Launch of joint ESA/Nasa Cassini mission to explore Saturnian system. Lunar Prospector arrives on moon in search of information that could one day help scientists plan a lunar base.

March 1998: Lunar Prospector discovers ice on the moon.

July 1998: Japan launches a probe to reach Mars in 2003.

October 1998: John Glenn, now a 77-year-old senator, returns to space aboard the space shuttle Discovery.

November 1998: Assembly work begins on the International Space Station.

May 1999: A shuttle docks with the International Space Station for the first time.

July 1999: Colonel Eileen Collins becomes the first woman to command a shuttle mission.

00s

July 2000: Russia launches a living quarters module, its contribution to the International Space Station.

October 2000: A 10-day mission to the International Space Station marks the 100th shuttle flight.

November 2000: The first permanent crew sets up home aboard the International Space Station.

fields.headline: Space 2001
fields.standfirst: In the 60s, it seemed we would all be plunging helter-skelter into space quite soon. In Kubrick's landmark film, 2001: A Space Odyssey, a Hilton hotel orbits the earth. It's only a matter of time - that was the assumption from HG Wells to Dan Dare. The reality in the year 2001 has turned out rather differently. Julian Borger finds the millionaires and visionaries who still dream of making their own space odyssey
fields.trailText: In the 60s, it seemed we would all be plunging helter-skelter into space quite soon. In Kubrick's landmark film, 2001: A Space Odyssey, a Hilton hotel orbits the earth. It's only a matter of time - that was the assumption from HG Wells to Dan Dare. The reality in the year 2001 has turned out rather differently. Julian Borger finds the millionaires and visionaries who still dream of making their own space odyssey.
fields.body:
It has no doubt already come to your attention that the long-anticipated year 2001 has arrived and we are still stuck on earth. No one is planning a space vacation this year, there are no moon bases or orbiting Hiltons. For about $6,000, you can have your ashes rocketed into orbit, but your chances of reaching space alive seem no better than they were a generation ago.

Stanley Kubrick's masterpiece 2001: A Space Odyssey now mocks us for our lack of cosmic achievements. Even science-fiction movies these days are tackier and less ambitious, though perhaps the special effects are better. As for real-life science, computers and biotechnology have gained ground exponentially, yet they have failed to help you, I or Joe Public escape the bonds of our planet.

Space travel is one of the broken promises of our generation. It has stagnated for lack of willpower and money. No one has been to the moon in 25 years. A manned mission to Mars, which once seemed the next logical step, has been postponed indefinitely.

The US-led International Space Station currently under construction one module at a time is an updated but conceptually-similar version of the 70s SkyLab. It will provide a permanently-manned platform in space to carry out experiments, and a way-station for future exploratory missions. But it bears scant resemblance to the spinning behemoth envisaged by Kubrick, with its artificial gravity, its bright red lounge furniture, and guests checking in at reception after flying in on a PanAm space cruiser.

Moreover, space travel remains Nasa's near-exclusive domain, a government monopoly with little room for private endeavour. An attempt to put a fee-paying entrepreneur, Dennis Tito, into space this month collapsed when Mir, the rentable Russian space station, ran out of steam, leaving Tito with a $20 million ticket and nowhere to go. Mir is due to be incinerated in the earth's atmosphere in the next few weeks, and along with it the hopes of a buccaneering US-Russian joint venture called MirCorp, which had hoped to use the 13-year-old spaceship to compete with Nasa. The closest an ordinary citizen can get these days to a near-astronaut experience is to pay $5,000 for a trip in a Russian Ilyushin-76 at the Yuri Gagarin Cosmonaut Training Centre in Star City. The padded plane generates weightlessness by flying up and down at high altitude, like a stratospheric big dipper. Real space tourism seems as dead and remote as Pluto. Kubrick did not live to this sad day, but Sir Arthur C Clarke, the sci-fi novelist who sat down in 1964 to write the original 2001: A Space Odyssey, is still with us, 83 years old and confined to a wheelchair at his home in Sri Lanka, but stolidly determined to live out his fantasy and travel into space before he dies.

Time is clearly running out for Clarke, but his dreams are not as untethered as they may sound. Beneath the outwardly moribund state of space travel, private enterprise is bubbling away volcanically, constantly threatening to break through and change our landscape for ever. Even now, millions of pounds and man-hours are being expended in the hunt for cheaper ways to escape gravity. Spacecraft are being designed, prototypes are being tested and speculative bookings are even being taken. Our space odyssey may not have started on time, but there is reason to believe it is about to begin. Aerospace experts believe sub-orbital trips, taking passengers into space for a few minutes with brief arching flights, will be regularly available to tourists within four years, and that large-scale tourism, complete with spinning hotels, is no more than two decades away.

Right now, the chief obstacle to space travel is a sort of Catch-22 of extra-terrestrial accounting. It costs about $10,000 to launch a payload carrying a weight of one pound into space on a Nasa shuttle. An adult with a bit of baggage would cost more than $2 million and that is without bringing him or her back to earth safely. At that price, there is not much of a market for launchers, especially as the demand for satellites is slowing down. Without a serious market, there has not really been much of an incentive to spend the hundreds of millions of pounds necessary to research and develop the sort of reusable launch vehicle (RLV) that would reduce costs sufficiently to ignite real corporate interest in space.

The Futron Corporation in Washington has calculated that even if a modern-day alchemist found a way to use zero-gravity conditions to turn lead into gold, it would still be impossible to make money at today's launch costs. Futron, which specialises in forecasting trends in commercial space, has conducted a study for Nasa that includes estimates of what it would take to get some of the "emerging markets" in space underway. According to Phil McAlister, a Futron engineer, "Nothing really emerged in any significant magnitude until the price got down to about half of what it is today."

Marco Carceres, another of the emerging breed of space analysts clustered around Washington, argues that to create the conditions for true space tourism, launch costs have to be brought down below $500 a pound. Once that is done, Carceres believes, "Space tourism in one form or another is just about inevitable." The cheap RLV is the Holy Grail of space travel. Once you have one of those, everything else - from orbiting hotels to space travel to lunar factories - will follow. The cosmos will open its door wide and we will all pile in.

The space shuttle was a promising start back when it was first conceived in the 70s, but it is an expensive way of taking things into space, costing five times more per pound than a Chinese rocket. In 1996, the US government and Nasa commissioned Lockheed Martin to develop a new generation of RLV, but funds have dried up with the end of the Cold War and its competitive impulse. Lockheed Martin's RLV project, the X-33, lies in pieces in a California aeroplane hangar after exhausting its $1.2 billion budget. A successor project, VentureStar, is stranded on the drawing-board for lack of funds.

Back in the mid-80s, the Thatcher government was also a player in the RLV quest. The British National Space Centre was established principally to work on the problem. The centre designed the Hotol (horizontal take-off and landing) craft that was to be built jointly by British Aerospace and Rolls-Royce. Hotol would have been a sleek and elegant craft, somewhat reminiscent of the Concorde, powered by revolutionary engines. But as usual with such ambitious ventures in Britain, there was not enough cash to get it off the ground. When the defence secretary at the time, Michael Heseltine, declared the Hotol engine "top secret", the plan was doomed because there was no way of sharing its development costs with European partners.

Since the collapse of these oversized government projects, the stage is set for private enterprise to pick up the torch. All it will take is a flash of engineering insight, some financial backing and the right kind of economic incentives - which is where the X-Prize comes in.

The X-Prize, set up by US aerospace engineer Peter Diamandis, is worth $10 million, and all you have to do to win it is build a craft that will take three people 100km through the planet's atmosphere into sub-orbital flight and bring them back down to earth again. And then repeat the performance within a fortnight. The award is offered by a consortium of private investors and there are 19 teams from five countries in the race.

One of the contenders is a former British Aerospace rocket scientist called David Ashford, who retired 10 years to set up a company called Bristol Spaceplanes, and to design a rocket-driven craft to pierce the atmosphere. He has come up with a sleek-looking plane called the Ascender. The Ascender would use its rockets to thrust itself almost vertically upwards at three times the speed of sound, until it reached the requisite 100km altitude before gliding back to an airfield landing. In all, it would be a 30-minute flight, including two minutes of precious weightlessness for the two crew and two passengers, who would clearly see the blue curvature of the earth below and the blackness of space beyond. And the Ascender would be robust enough to repeat the exercise several times a day.

Ashford points out that all this has been done before, by the US experimental rocket-plane, the X-15, which broke altitude records in the 60s with its sub-orbital flights. With a slightly bigger cockpit, it would have won the X-Prize decades ago, but Ashford argues that rocket-plane technology was shelved in the Cold War race to get into orbit first. "What we've had since then are manned spacecraft powered by ballistic missiles. It's not a safe or natural way of getting into space and no one would have thought of doing it if not for the Cold War," he says. "It's expendable so you can't test it before you use it, and that's why it's so expensive." The X-15 used to cost $2 million per flight, but Ashford believes that with the technological advances in rocket motors and airframes over the past 40 years, that cost could be cut to a fraction.

Ashford gets a lot of respect for his abilities as a designer, but he has so far not been able to transform respect into solid financial backing. He is still working out of a converted children's playroom at home, unlike his chief US rival for the prize, Burt Rutan, who has his own aviation workshop.

In San Bruno, California, a private group has taken an entirely different approach. The Rotary Rocket Company is working on a prototype reusable rocket called the Roton, which as its name suggests is powered by a rotating engine, and equipped with helicopter-like rotors to break its descent through the earth's atmosphere. It has yet to lift more than a few feet off the ground in test flights earlier this year, but its makers remain hopeful it will be rising through the ionosphere within the next 24 months.

Another design, being worked on at the Georgia Institute of Technology, would send a needle-like rocket called the Argus shooting skyward along a 2.4km magnetic track, of the sort that drives friction-free trains, before rocket engines would kick in to take the Argus into orbit.

Whoever wins the X-Prize, the implications are likely to be explosive. By pioneering an affordable way through the atmosphere, the victor will have once and for all pierced the membrane keeping private enterprise anchored to the earth. "Once you have low-cost access to orbit, the construction of a space hotel is a very straightforward piece of engineering," Ashford says. "The best prediction I have is that within 15 years space tourism will be affordable by middle-income people - that means about a million people a year could go. Somebody has got to have a breakthrough, and when it happens it will happen very fast."

If that moment does come, there are no shortage of would-be space hoteliers ready to accommodate us. A string of rival space hotel plans are already in development by would-be "astropreneurs", space tycoons who have made their money on earth and want to buy back the dreams of space adventure they grew up with.

Gene Meyers is a good example. When he was 10 years old, he went to school carrying a lunch-box emblazoned with a colourful picture of an imaginary space station - a great multi-hued wheel spinning among the stars. Among the must-have lunch-boxes of the mid-50s, Meyers recalls, it was either that or a stick-on portrait of Davy Crockett. Meyers liked the space station best.

The design was marketed by Disney, but dreamed up by Wernher von Braun, the German wartime rocket scientist who godfathered the US space programme. Back then, years before Yuri Gagarin was strapped to the top of a Russian rocket, the spinning wheel belonged in the realm of fantasy. But it was inspired by sound physics, and the image stuck in the Californian schoolboy's mind. Thirteen years later, that familiar spinning wheel appeared again, more vividly this time, in Kubrick's landmark film. By this time, in 1968, Meyers was a young engineering graduate, and the spinning wheel was no longer a pure science-fiction fantasy. The Apollo programme was in full swing and the conquest of the moon was only months away.

Meyers went on to become a successful industrial engineer, but saw his cosmic dreams turn cruelly to dust. Now, aged 57, he is determined to make the spinning wheels of his youth a reality in his last few decades. Over the past 10 years, he has established a company in West Covina, California, devoted to the construction of a privately-run space station made out of discarded space shuttle fuel tanks - the great orange bullets on which the shuttles hurtle into space. Once joined together in space, these hulks will serve as a zero-gravity factory, laboratory and - perhaps most lucratively - as a space hotel.

Meyers' company, the Space Island Group, hopes eventually to run an archipelago of way-stations between the earth and outer space. The Space Island brochure and promotional video offers an animator's impression of how Meyers' universe might look, with upgraded shuttles ferrying tourists up to these enormous orbiting islands. They are, of course, familiar, being the spiritual descendants of the double-ringed Hilton in the 2001 movie.

Meyers is not abashed about the similarities. The islands, he promises, are going to be "one of the most striking examples of life imitating art to come down the pike in many a year". He has raised some seed capital and is negotiating a lease on offices near the space shuttle maintenance centre at Palmdale, California. Detailed technical diagrams have been drawn up and contracts are being handed out. He is so confident of success, he has hired a New York designer, Von Robinson, to work on the interiors.

Robinson's main challenge is space-sickness, a disorder brought on by weightlessness that afflicts about 50% of all astronauts, and which would no doubt lay low a higher proportion of space tourists. "It happens when your eyes tell you you're going in one direction, but your inner ear says you're going in another," explains Robinson. The solution, he argues, is to use gradations of colour along the walls to reinforce the visual sense of movement. Space sickness would be limited on the way up to the hotel by the lack of windows in the RLV. Passengers would instead watch a television view of the receding earth screened on the back of the seats in front of them, limiting the sort of sideways head movements that exacerbate space sickness. Robinson has just been in Italy, where he has been negotiating with contacts in the furniture trade about the design of an anti-tip chair for use in partial gravity. "I feel like it's going to happen and I'm proud to be a part of it," he says.

The Space Island project is far from the only venture in cosmic tourism underway at the dawn of 2001. A few hundred miles across the desert in Nevada, a motel mogul called Robert Bigelow is working on a rival project that aims to erect a space station out of inflatable tubular segments, and a huge space cruiser to whisk tourists of the future off on excursions around the moon.

These are just the wealthy market leaders in space tourism. Behind them is growing an embryonic industry-in-waiting, with speculative travel firms accepting refundable down-payments on tickets to the stars, and earnest university courses dedicated to preparing the cosmic hoteliers of the future. What all these pioneers seem to have in common is a vivid memory of the glory days of Apollo and the promise of the Kubrick film, combined with a lot of disposable cash and a bitter sense of disappointment in the slow pace of space exploration since the 60s.

Calls to Bigelow's headquarters are routed through his original company, BudgetSuites of America, specialists in cheap, very terrestrial, accommodation, but you are then diverted to his new venture, the optimistically-named Bigelow Aerospace, which is currently building a new block of offices in the shape of a rocket on the outskirts of Las Vegas. Bigelow spends much of his time criss-crossing the country trying to drum up interest in his ideas.

They had a particular national security outlook. They didn't want Soviets to establish a moon base so they went to the moon, but they didn't have an encore. They didn't know what to do next. They will travel within a passenger pod which would be released into space by the shuttle and then guided inside the core of the rotating space island by a pair of space-tugs. fields.bodyText: It has no doubt already come to your attention that the long-anticipated year 2001 has arrived and we are still stuck on earth. No one is planning a space vacation this year, there are no moon bases or orbiting Hiltons. For about $6,000, you can have your ashes rocketed into orbit, but your chances of reaching space alive seem no better than they were a generation ago. Stanley Kubrick's masterpiece 2001: A Space Odyssey now mocks us for our lack of cosmic achievements. Even science-fiction movies these days are tackier and less ambitious, though perhaps the special effects are better. As for real-life science, computers and biotechnology have gained ground exponentially, yet they have failed to help you, I or Joe Public escape the bonds of our planet. Space travel is one of the broken promises of our generation. It has stagnated for lack of willpower and money. No one has been to the moon in 25 years. A manned mission to Mars, which once seemed the next logical step, has been postponed indefinitely. The US-led International Space Station currently under construction one module at a time is an updated but conceptually-similar version of the 70s SkyLab. It will provide a permanently-manned platform in space to carry out experiments, and a way-station for future exploratory missions. But it bears scant resemblance to the spinning behemoth envisaged by Kubrick, with its artificial gravity, its bright red lounge furniture, and guests checking in at reception after flying in on a PanAm space cruiser. Moreover, space travel remains Nasa's near-exclusive domain, a government monopoly with little room for private endeavour. An attempt to put a fee-paying entrepreneur, Dennis Tito, into space this month collapsed when Mir, the rentable Russian space station, ran out of steam, leaving Tito with a $20 million ticket and nowhere to go. Mir is due to be incinerated in the earth's atmosphere in the next few weeks, and along with it the hopes of a buccaneering US-Russian joint venture called MirCorp, which had hoped to use the 13-year-old spaceship to compete with Nasa. The closest an ordinary citizen can get these days to a near-astronaut experience is to pay $5,000 for a trip in a Russian Ilyushin-76 at the Yuri Gagarin Cosmonaut Training Centre in Star City. The padded plane generates weightlessness by flying up and down at high altitude, like a stratospheric big dipper. Real space tourism seems as dead and remote as Pluto. Kubrick did not live to this sad day, but Sir Arthur C Clarke, the sci-fi novelist who sat down in 1964 to write the original 2001: A Space Odyssey, is still with us, 83 years old and confined to a wheelchair at his home in Sri Lanka, but stolidly determined to live out his fantasy and travel into space before he dies. Time is clearly running out for Clarke, but his dreams are not as untethered as they may sound. Beneath the outwardly moribund state of space travel, private enterprise is bubbling away volcanically, constantly threatening to break through and change our landscape for ever. Even now, millions of pounds and man-hours are being expended in the hunt for cheaper ways to escape gravity. Spacecraft are being designed, prototypes are being tested and speculative bookings are even being taken. Our space odyssey may not have started on time, but there is reason to believe it is about to begin. Aerospace experts believe sub-orbital trips, taking passengers into space for a few minutes with brief arching flights, will be regularly available to tourists within four years, and that large-scale tourism, complete with spinning hotels, is no more than two decades away. Right now, the chief obstacle to space travel is a sort of Catch-22 of extra-terrestrial accounting. It costs about $10,000 to launch a payload carrying a weight of one pound into space on a Nasa shuttle. An adult with a bit of baggage would cost more than $2 million and that is without bringing him or her back to earth safely. At that price, there is not much of a market for launchers, especially as the demand for satellites is slowing down. Without a serious market, there has not really been much of an incentive to spend the hundreds of millions of pounds necessary to research and develop the sort of reusable launch vehicle (RLV) that would reduce costs sufficiently to ignite real corporate interest in space. The Futron Corporation in Washington has calculated that even if a modern-day alchemist found a way to use zero-gravity conditions to turn lead into gold, it would still be impossible to make money at today's launch costs. Futron, which specialises in forecasting trends in commercial space, has conducted a study for Nasa that includes estimates of what it would take to get some of the "emerging markets" in space underway. According to Phil McAlister, a Futron engineer, "Nothing really emerged in any significant magnitude until the price got down to about half of what it is today." Marco Carceres, another of the emerging breed of space analysts clustered around Washington, argues that to create the conditions for true space tourism, launch costs have to be brought down below $500 a pound. Once that is done, Carceres believes, "Space tourism in one form or another is just about inevitable." The cheap RLV is the Holy Grail of space travel. Once you have one of those, everything else - from orbiting hotels to space travel to lunar factories - will follow. The cosmos will open its door wide and we will all pile in. The space shuttle was a promising start back when it was first conceived in the 70s, but it is an expensive way of taking things into space, costing five times more per pound than a Chinese rocket. In 1996, the US government and Nasa commissioned Lockheed Martin to develop a new generation of RLV, but funds have dried up with the end of the Cold War and its competitive impulse. Lockheed Martin's RLV project, the X-33, lies in pieces in a California aeroplane hangar after exhausting its $1.2 billion budget. A successor project, VentureStar, is stranded on the drawing-board for lack of funds. Back in the mid-80s, the Thatcher government was also a player in the RLV quest. The British National Space Centre was established principally to work on the problem. The centre designed the Hotol (horizontal take-off and landing) craft that was to be built jointly by British Aerospace and Rolls-Royce. Hotol would have been a sleek and elegant craft, somewhat reminiscent of the Concorde, powered by revolutionary engines. But as usual with such ambitious ventures in Britain, there was not enough cash to get it off the ground. When the defence secretary at the time, Michael Heseltine, declared the Hotol engine "top secret", the plan was doomed because there was no way of sharing its development costs with European partners. Since the collapse of these oversized government projects, the stage is set for private enterprise to pick up the torch. All it will take is a flash of engineering insight, some financial backing and the right kind of economic incentives - which is where the X-Prize comes in. The X-Prize, set up by US aerospace engineer Peter Diamandis, is worth $10 million, and all you have to do to win it is build a craft that will take three people 100km through the planet's atmosphere into sub-orbital flight and bring them back down to earth again. And then repeat the performance within a fortnight. The award is offered by a consortium of private investors and there are 19 teams from five countries in the race. One of the contenders is a former British Aerospace rocket scientist called David Ashford, who retired 10 years to set up a company called Bristol Spaceplanes, and to design a rocket-driven craft to pierce the atmosphere. He has come up with a sleek-looking plane called the Ascender. The Ascender would use its rockets to thrust itself almost vertically upwards at three times the speed of sound, until it reached the requisite 100km altitude before gliding back to an airfield landing. In all, it would be a 30-minute flight, including two minutes of precious weightlessness for the two crew and two passengers, who would clearly see the blue curvature of the earth below and the blackness of space beyond. And the Ascender would be robust enough to repeat the exercise several times a day. With a slightly bigger cockpit, it would have won the X-Prize decades ago, but Ashford argues that rocket-plane technology was shelved in the Cold War race to get into orbit first. "What we've had since then are manned spacecraft powered by ballistic missiles. fields.headline: Sex in space: Missionary control
fields.trailText: David Theison, campus astronomy professor at Maryland College, recently gave a lecture, Sex In Space, in which he passed around an undergarment resembling a pair of pants with not two but four leg holes. This, he said, might be a solution to the problem of couples floating apart during weightless intercourse.
fields.body:
David Theison, campus astronomy professor at Maryland College, recently gave a lecture, Sex In Space, in which he passed around an undergarment resembling a pair of pants with not two but four leg holes. This, he said, might be a solution to the problem of couples floating apart during weightless intercourse.

'If you start thrusting,' he said, 'you're likely to send your partner across the space capsule.' Without gravity, he said, objects and bodily fluids float around unless fixed to a surface. 'If you vomit in zero gravity, it just kind of hangs there' - he was probably using 'vomit' as a metaphor.

The main thing to remember about sex in space is that no one has ever done it. You heard that they had? It's a myth, says Nasa. You read it on the internet? The text was 'fraudulent'. This fraudulent myth has it that, in 1996, US astronauts carried out sex experiments on the space shuttle: a husband and wife team apparently tested 10 positions, and found that six, including the missionary position, were impossible in zero gravity without assistance from an elastic belt, an inflatable tunnel or a third party.

Had such an experiment really taken place (more detailed versions of the myth suggest that they were simply verifying earlier Russian findings), the participants would no doubt have benefited from a device invented and patented by Elaine Lerner, a New England Sunday school teacher. Her system of straps and loops enables one partner to control the movements of the other's hips during intercourse, thereby rendering 'docking' a possibility, if not a probability. But her attempts to interest Nasa in the invention have come to nothing. Possibly because mission control - or should that be missionary control? - has already got wind of those four-legged underpants.

webTitle: Food in space: Mind over matter

fields.headline: Food in space: Mind over matter
fields.trailText: He's not in the Oxford Diner's Dictionary, but perhaps he should be there, between girolle (it's a kind of mushroom) and globe artichoke. For John Glenn was the first human being to lunch in space. Not that squeezing paste out of an aluminium tube could really be called lunching. No, that was to come later.
fields.body:
He's not in the Oxford Diner's Dictionary, but perhaps he should be there, between girolle (it's a kind of mushroom) and globe artichoke. For John Glenn was the first human being to lunch in space. Not that squeezing paste out of an aluminium tube could really be called lunching. No, that was to come later.

In the early days of space flight, zero-gravity meals consisted of bite-sized cubes, freeze-dried powders (simply add water to... oops!) and a semi-liquid glop that had to be extruded into the mouth like tomato purée. And even then, crumbs got into the instruments.

Later, the cubes were held together with gelatinous coatings and the dried stuff came in plastic packs to which water could be added without spilling. Out went squeezy tubes and in came the 'spoon bowl' - the sort of all-in-one sealed pack and eating utensil that might have been invented for toddlers, but sadly wasn't.

However, it was only with the advent of the space shuttle that lunch began to resemble a meal. For the first time, astronauts could sit down (or up) and eat like anyone else, with a knife, fork, spoon and scissors. Scissors? That's for snipping the top off the food bag. Okay, so it's still not perfect. But now, at least, the stuff is warm.

Dehydrated shuttlegrub, such as soup, breakfast cereal, scrambled eggs or sweet 'n' sour chicken, comes in a sealed, bendy bowl to which water is added before placing it in an oven. The bowl has a Velcro base, so it sticks to the food tray (the tray can be strapped to the lap or attached to a wall), and the water for rehydrating comes from the shuttle's fuel cells, which produce electricity by combining hydrogen and water.

Thermostabilised shuttlegrub - food that has been heat-treated to prevent decay - comes in cans, sealed plastic cups or pouches, and the contents include beef goulash, tuna, cheese spread and various stewed fruits. There are also 'intermediate moisture foods', such as dried fruit or beef, that contain enough water to make them chewy but not enough to allow microbes to grow, and steaks that have been pre-cooked and irradiated (yum yum!). Pepper, by the way, comes in liquid form, suspended in oil, while salt is dissolved in water.

These days, astronauts get to select their own food, which is then colour-coded and stored in personalised lockers - presumably to prevent bloodshed as crews fight over the last pouch of what the shuttle menu calls 'Chicken a la King'. Special requests are accepted, but only after rigorous testing by Food Systems Engineering Facility personnel aboard the Nasa zero-gravity aeroplane, known as the 'vomit comet'.

 To sample 'the foods that the real astronauts eat in space', order from www.flyingsaucers.com. Delicacies include Astronaut Chicken Dinner and Astronaut Cheese Pizza. 'Each of these authentic freeze-dried items comes in a sealed space pouch and can be enjoyed right out of the bag,' says the blurb. 'You can use them for a space meal for your favorite space cadets, as a picnic for space nuts, or for one of those nights under the stars. Or keep some for your Abduction Survival Kit.'
fields.bodyText: He's not in the Oxford Diner's Dictionary, but perhaps he should be there, between girolle (it's a kind of mushroom) and globe artichoke. For John Glenn was the first human being to lunch in space. Not that squeezing paste out of an aluminium tube could really be called lunching. No, that was to come later. In the early days of space flight, zero-gravity meals consisted of bite-sized cubes, freeze-dried powders (simply add water to... oops!) and a semi-liquid glop that had to be extruded into the mouth like tomato purée. And even then, crumbs got into the instruments. Later, the cubes were held together with gelatinous coatings and the dried stuff came in plastic packs to which water could be added without spilling. Out went squeezy tubes and in came the 'spoon bowl' - the sort of all-in-one sealed pack and eating utensil that might have been invented for toddlers, but sadly wasn't. However, it was only with the advent of the space shuttle that lunch began to resemble a meal. For the first time, astronauts could sit down (or up) and eat like anyone else, with a knife, fork, spoon and scissors. Scissors? That's for snipping the top off the food bag. Okay, so it's still not perfect. But now, at least, the stuff is warm. Dehydrated shuttlegrub, such as soup, breakfast cereal, scrambled eggs or sweet 'n' sour chicken, comes in a sealed, bendy bowl to which water is added before placing it in an oven. The bowl has a Velcro base, so it sticks to the food tray (the tray can be strapped to the lap or attached to a wall), and the water for rehydrating comes from the shuttle's fuel cells, which produce electricity by combining hydrogen and water. Pepper, by the way, comes in liquid form, suspended in oil, while salt is dissolved in water. These days, astronauts get to select their own food, which is then colour-coded and stored in personalised lockers - presumably to prevent bloodshed as crews fight over the last pouch of what the shuttle menu calls 'Chicken a la King'. fields.headline: 2001: A Space Odyssey - The reality
fields.trailText: It is 1965, and at a cinema near you, The Sound Of Music is showing for the first time. And there's another new film with some catchy tunes - Doctor something... ah, yes, Zhivago.
fields.body:
It is 1965, and at a cinema near you, The Sound Of Music is showing for the first time. And there's another new film with some catchy tunes - Doctor something... ah, yes, Zhivago.

But never mind historical fiction.

In the real world - the high-rise, hi-fidelity present - the future beckons. The Americans have just mastered the art of 'docking' two spacecraft, and even as we hum Lara's Theme, Early Bird, a satellite that will revolutionise telecommunications is being slung into orbit. By the end of the decade, they say, we'll have a man on the moon. There will be no holding us. Who knows what humankind will be doing by the end of the century? Who knows what our world will be like 12 months into the next millennium?

In a Hertfordshire film studio, two men are doing their best to predict the answers to these very questions. The American director Stanley Kubrick and the English science-fiction writer Arthur C Clarke are shooting a film called 2001: A Space Odyssey, and are determined that their fantasy will be entirely plausible. 'I never considered 2001 as a strict prediction,' Clarke will say in retrospect, 'but as more of a vision, a way things could work.'

Yet their attention to detail verges on the obsessive. Will the first men on the moon see more stars than we can through our atmosphere? After much debate, they decide that they will. It is, as the Surveyor lunar probe will soon show, the right decision. They spare no effort in getting such minutiae right, consulting experts on everything from spacewalks to exploding bolts.

But what of the broader vision? How clearly do they see what, for us, is now the present? At about the time he was debating stellar visibility, Clarke did make one prediction: by 2001, a colony 1,000-strong would be established on the moon. But even as he spoke, the US was sending its first combat troops into Vietnam. Years later, Clarke said that the sheer expense of Vietnam pushed serious space travel on to the slow-burner in the last decades of the 20th century.

It goes without saying, then, that, in terms of its plot line, Space Odyssey is light years off beam. Patently, there is no colony on the moon. And although there has been an upturn in planetary exploration recently, the mapping and prospecting of the solar system is conducted exclusively by remote-controlled machines. Humans remain earthbound, or venture into orbit in small groups; the nearest we have come to the vast artificial moon that wheels silently through the early part of the film is the relatively unimpressive assemblage of labs and locker rooms of the International Space Station currently under construction.

To say that the only lasting benefit from the space programme of the 60s is the non-stick frying pan is, of course, an exaggeration. But only a slight one. Sure, we've grown some enormous crystals, and our flying telescopes tell us awesome things about the universe. But it's hardly the bright future that flashed on to our screens in 1968. When the film was released, MGM issued journalists with a booklet setting it in context. Space travel, naturally, would be far advanced. The wheeling space station is served by a fleet of plush PanAm shuttles, and provides a springboard into deeper space while offering luxury hotel facilities for visiting VIPs. In the real world, MGM believed that commercial spacecraft would be making scheduled trips to the moon by 2001.

Meanwhile, life on earth would have moved on apace. Terrestrial transportation would frequently include travel by ballistic rocket, reducing the maximum journey time anywhere on the planet to less than an hour. A dozen nuclear power stations would supply the US with all its electricity, and 'cancer, senility, mentally retarded children will no longer exist'.

In his quest for veracity, Kubrick asked several firms to supply him with designs for possible future products, some of which appeared in the film or its publicity material. The result was that Space Odyssey always looked cool, whereas The Man From Uncle looked downright naff. One company, Hamilton, came up with a gadgetal wristwatch that would not look out of place in a modern high-street jeweller's. Parker produced an 'atomic pen' that would be perfectly convincing if only the word 'atomic' were replaced with 'turbo'.

The 'smart ring' that American Express said would identify account holders is not a million miles away from today's smart card; the Whirlpool food dispensing galley would be at home in any burger bar; and as for the Bell Telephone videophone used by one character, well videophones are now a fact of life.

Maybe Kubrick didn't predict that BBC reporters would no longer speak in BBC English, but from the Velcro footwear worn by the weightless flight attendants to the computer displays with their astounding graphics and modern typefaces, the film looked - and still looks - totally convincing.

And the leading character? According to the MGM booklet, 'ultra-intelligent computers will be constructed within about the next 30 years', and these will be 'capable of performing every intellectual activity'. MGM was talking, of course, about HAL, the Discovery's all-singing, all-talking onboard super-computer that steals the show. But while artificial intelligence of the order displayed by HAL seemed an achievable goal to scientists in the mid-60s, the reality has fallen short of expectations. In terms of hardware, of course, all those knobs and flashing lights are already a thing of the past. Honeywell, Burroughs and IBM supplied Kubrick with projections for computer design in 2001, yet none foresaw the miniaturisation of computers or the invention of the Macintosh interface that would make it possible to take command of the Discovery using a mouse and a screen.

But as for what HAL could do - as for what HAL was, even who HAL was - with the exception of his chess-playing skills, today's computers don't come close. Sure, they can speak, but they haven't a clue what they're on about. And while some can just about recognise human speech, their grasp of meaning is only about canine in terms of ability. They might peer through digital cameras instead of the whirring shutter that we hear on the Discovery at one point (oops!), but when it comes to scene analysis they still can't see for looking.

The fact is that, in the 35 years since HAL was conceived, scientists have come to see just how distant is this goal called artificial intelligence. We might have cracked the hardware problems, but the software is another matter. As one researcher put it, even if we could build a machine of sufficient complexity, we couldn't begin to program the thing.

Ask them to perform specific tasks, of course, and our finest, tiniest processors cut quite a dash. In a way, that's where Kubrick and Clarke got it really wrong. For in the real 2001, computers are tiny specialists embedded in our car dashboards or sitting in our hands. Do Dave or Frank carry a PalmPilot in the film, or is that a clipboard we see before us?

As Clarke says, Space Odyssey was never intended as a set of predictions - just as a plausible vision of a possible future reality. It was entirely plausible in 1968 that, by the end of the century, we'd be sending astronauts to the outer reaches of the solar system in spaceships run by devious, lip-reading super-computers. But then, it was also plausible that PanAm would still be in business.

fields.headline: Ask a fellow traveller
fields.trailText: Readers share their expertise on Russia's complicated bureaucracy.
fields.body:
Denise Burton wants to visit her daughter at Moscow university. She would prefer to organise the trip herself but is concerned about Russia's complicated bureaucracy.

To stay with friends, you each need an official letter of invitation from a Moscow resident. This is the so-called militia clearance certificate, valid for up to three months. The resident will need details of your passport, full name, date of birth, etc. Alternatively book accommodation through a reputable company such as Hotel Select, supplying all the above details at the time of booking. Eventually, you will receive a tourist voucher and confirmation of accommodation from the hotel. You then apply for your visas with either the private invitations or tourist vouchers. The Russian embassy is in London, but we prefer to use the Edinburgh consulate. They take about seven days to process the applications and telephone to sort out problems. Their customer service and attitude is excellent. You must send your passports, recent passport-sized photos, £30 fee and insurance details.

Sheila Robinson

A visa agency such as DJB Passports and Visas (020-7689 5905), which specialises in the former Soviet bloc can be invaluable. I have also used a specialist tour service located at St Petersburg university named Rusistika Travel (contact Sergei Volkov, e-mail: rusistik@rusakad.spb.ru). They can organise letters of invitation, accommodation, internal travels and guided tours, too.
David Williams

www.hotelsrussia.com takes hotel bookings by credit card and for a fee of $30 will give "visa support" - it will fax the confirmation you need to organise your visa, and register your passport once you're there. Alternatively, try the Moscow youth hostel (tel: +7 (095) 378 0001, e-mail: hostelasia@mtu-net.ru) - I've found them very efficient. You pay for one night's accommodation plus visa support and they fax you a letter stating you're staying for the full duration of your visit. (I've never actually stayed at the youth hostel, but that's the way things work in Russia.)
Margaret Matthew

This week's question

I am planning to go travelling for a year in a van. Is a VW Camper the best choice, and where can I buy a good one cheap?
James Hood

 If you have questions or advice, please write to: Ask a fellow traveller, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Or e-mail: ask.a.fellow.traveller@theguardian.com.

fields.headline: Tickets to ride
fields.standfirst: Your guide to the cheapest flights around
fields.trailText: Sydney | Amsterdam | New York
fields.body:
Six top destinations:

Sydney: £474
Austrian Airlines from Heathrow or Manchester via Vienna. Must be booked by January 16. Full payment required when booking. Valid for departures until April 8, then April 23 - June 30. Minimum stay one Saturday night, maximum one month. All travel must be completed by June 30. Airline Network (0800 747000).

Amsterdam: £79
British Airways from Heathrow. Must be booked by January 29. Valid for departures until April 5. Minimum stay one Saturday night, maximum one month. Trailfinders (020-7937 1234).

New York: £177
Virgin Atlantic from Heathrow. Must be booked by Jan 29. Valid for departures until Feb 28. Minimum stay one Saturday night, maximum one month. Going Places Direct (0161-908 7967).

Hong Kong: £373
KLM from Heathrow, London City, Stansted, Aberdeen, Birmingham, Manchester, Bristol, Cardiff, Edinburgh, Glasgow, Humberside, Leeds/Bradford, Teesside, Newcastle or Norwich via Amsterdam. Must be booked by Jan 31. Valid for departures until April 5, then April 23 - June 15. Minimum stay seven days, maximum one month. Quest Travel (0870 4430746).

Los Angeles: £231
British Airways from Heathrow. Must be booked by January 29. Valid for departures until February 28. Minimum stay one Saturday night, maximum one month. Thomas Cook Flights Direct (0870 7520066).

Paris: £106
British Airways from Birmingham. Must be bought at least three days before departure. Valid for departures until Dec 31. Minimum stay one Saturday night, maximum one month. Trailfinders (0121-236 1234).

The pick of the rest:

Royal Brunei from Heathrow via Brunei. Must be booked by February 27. Valid for departures from January 16 to March 31. No minimum stay. All travel must be completed by May 30. Thomas Cook Flights Direct (0870 7520066).

Antigua: £359
Virgin Atlantic from Gatwick. Valid for departures until April 5. Minimum stay one Saturday night, maximum three months. Trailfinders (020-7937 5400).

And the rail alternative:

Same-day return. Must be bought at least one day before travel. Valid for departures on Saturdays and Sundays until Feb 11. Eurostar (08705 186186).

NB Fares can change rapidly. These were available in reasonable quantities at the time of writing, but they can sell out in a sudden rush.

fields.headline: Hiring a campervan in Canada
fields.standfirst:
Can anyone give us advice (especially do's and don'ts) about hiring a campervan in Canada, travelling in the Canadian Rockies with a campervan, using campsites in the Canadian Rockies, travelling by train between Calgary and Vancouver, walking in the Canadian Rockies and flights to Canada (Rockies). Is it cheaper to fly to the US and hire a camper there for travel in Canada?
Heather Skaife
fields.trailText: Can anyone give us advice (especially do's and don'ts) about hiring a campervan in Canada, travelling in the Canadian Rockies with a campervan, using campsites in the Canadian Rockies, travelling by train between Calgary and Vancouver, walking in the Canadian Rockies and flights to Canada (Rockies). Is it cheaper to fly to the US and hire a camper there for travel in Canada?
fields.body:
 We've travelled in Western Canada/Alaska over the past 20 years.

1 Rent your vehicle in Alberta rather than British Columbia, because you don't pay any provincial sales tax there. Renting in the US can be cheaper, but there are then extra gas and mileage charges.

2 The bigger the vehicle you rent, the less places you can take it.

3 Almost all rental companies forbid you to drive off paved highways, but the best places to visit are often up small gravel roads/forest roads. The only company we know that actually encourages getting off the highway is AllDrive - depots in Calgary and Vancouver. You can pick up in Calgary and leave it in Vancouver.

4 Some rental companies are prepared to do nice deals at the end of the season - late September onwards - such as three weeks for the price of two.

5 Avoid commercially-owned/ private campgrounds - provincial park or national park campgrounds are uniformly great, always in the best places, each site is "treed off" from the next, provides a barbecue pit and bench, and they cost about C$12 a night.
Eileen Martin

 Get on to the internet and do a search for keywords: canada, rental, motorhomes, or, canada rv rental, etc. When you have found something you think might be suitable, start e-mailing. When you think you want to clinch a deal, start phoning. Do not hire through an agent over here because they take a big cut.
Martin Ragg
