fields.headline: Yours for $14k a day
fields.standfirst: They don't come much smaller or more exclusive than this.  Ben Mallalieu pays a visit to Richard Branson's Balinese playground in the Caribbean
fields.trailText: They don't come much smaller or more exclusive than this. Ben Mallalieu pays a visit to Richard Branson's Balinese playground in the Caribbean.
fields.body:
The hammock, I am reliably informed, was invented by the Arawak indians who once inhabited the Virgin islands, and in 1783... actually it doesn't matter a fig what happened in 1783 because, when you own a private island, history, geography and just about everything else are whatever you choose to make them.

If you like Bali but have got fed up with the journey, the climate or possibly the government, you can, like Richard Branson, create your own Balinese island in the West Indies. And if you want to call one of the buildings Bali Hi and another Bali Lo, no one is going to stop you.

Branson first saw Necker in 1979 when, posing as a multi-millionaire, he was given a red carpet tour of available islands by some very upmarket estate agents who installed him at an expensive hotel and flew him around by helicopter. The asking price for Necker was £2m. He offered £175,000. The red carpet was pulled from under his feet and he had to pay his own fare home. Later, when he really was a multi-millionaire, the island was still hanging on the market, and he was able to buy it in 1981 for the comparatively knock-down price of £200,000.

Not that Necker was anything special as West Indian islands go. About three-quarters of a mile long and half a mile wide with a hill some 100ft high running down the middle, it had two good beaches but no buildings, no fresh water and very few trees. The only previous known residents had been the journalist Andrew Alexander and the photographer Don McCullin who were landed there in 1968 to write an article for the Weekend Telegraph on what it was really like to be marooned on a desert island. And a miserable time they had of it.

It is now more comfortable. The houses have been built in traditional Balinese style with no obvious expense spared. The timber and the dark stone for the walls were brought from Brazil, the honey-coloured floor stone from Yorkshire. The statues, furniture and fabrics came from Indonesia. The goats who roamed the island were "persuaded to leave".

Branson spends three months of the year on Necker, keeping open house for his friends, and he considers it his home. When he isn't there, the island is available to rent to the likes of Steven Spielberg, Harrison Ford, Robert DeNiro, Bryan Ferry, Mike Oldfield, John Hurt, Peter Gabriel, Rosanna Arquette, Oprah Winfrey, Michael J Fox, Mel Gibson, Annie Lennox and George Michael - and you if you have the odd $14,000 a day to spare on a holiday.

You arrive at Necker from Tortola at 50 miles an hour in an enormous white speedboat, the kind that the talented Mr Ripley would certainly have envied. A dozen or so staff live on the island, all young, fair-haired and bronzed. The women look like Greta Scacchi circa 1985, and - even stranger - the men are like younger, better-looking versions of Branson himself. The resident staff tend to the guests, teach tennis and sailing and drive the speedboat on sunset cruises. They seem disconcertingly like the Midwitch Cuckoos come of age, but they are more than happy to treat you, me and "Richard" as their equals. The cleaning and general maintenance is performed by a further staff of 20 who are brought in for the day from Tortola, but not in the speedboat.

The buildings are, by any standards, spectacular. The house on the hill has views of the sea on all sides, and a breeze blows through every room and corridor. Plants grow in the hall, almost a jungle in the main lounge. Most of the bathrooms are open-sided, and you can watch the ocean while standing in the shower or sitting on the lavatory. (The last time I was in a bathroom with a wall missing was in a squat in Clapham, but it wasn't the same - the view only went as far as the tumble-down house next door.) Some of the lavatories are covered in Balinese mosaic, the shower walls built from coral and driftwood.

The rest of the island is proving more intractable to Balinisation. Hundreds of trees have been planted as well as cactus and frangipani, but the strong winds, fierce sun and poor soil cause problems, and the shade is insufficient to sustain the ornamental gingers, ferns and orchids that define a Balinese landscape. Most of the colour comes from tecomas, oleander, hibiscus and too much purple bougainvillea.

The island is not yet full of sounds and sweet airs - unless you count David Gray and early Bob Dylan - and half way between the quay and the main house a strong smell wafts from what I was told is the "organic wildlife pond". When you own a private island, a malfunctioning sewage plant can become an organic wildlife pond any time you want.

When they were here, Alexander and McCullin lived on a dismal diet of what few fish they could catch, stale coconut, sea grapes and prickly pears, spending hours trying to remove the fine prickles from their mouths. Sitting at the long dining table on the veranda, I could look down to the beach where they lived, and I often thought of them as I ate quails eggs stuffed with caviar and drank Chateau Lynch-Bages (perhaps a little too young) or the Necker-branded champagne.

The food on the island is an elaborate concoction of sculpted vegetables artistically arranged, open ravioli of lobster and fennel, duck and foie gras, chargrilled snapper and tempura prawns, and strange stick-like objects tied up with seaweed which you don't know whether to eat or use as cutlery. Differently-coloured sauces are dripped elegantly around the plate like a painting by Jackson Pollock. It is all rather in the style of Raymond Blanc of whom Private Eye once said: "Surely this man would eat his own toes if the right recipe occurred to him."

In the long term, this diet is unlikely to do you any more good than Alexander and McCullin's, although if you wanted something simpler, you would certainly get it. You could even have beans on toast, but it would probably come in a perfect pyramid topped with a sprig of dill.

Alexander and McCullin slept on the beach, soaked by the rain and eaten by mosquitoes. McCullin counted 51 bites on the back of one hand, and on the first night, his last words were: "I do not much like what I see." As I lay in my large comfortable bed under the mosquito net, listening to the roar of the surf and watching the intense blue of the Caribbean night sky, the thin white curtains blowing in the breeze, I rather liked what I saw. My last thought on the first night was that a couple of Howard Hodgkins might possibly have brightened up the walls a bit.

Alexander and McCullin were desperate with thirst for most of their stay, never able to collect enough rainwater. Had they been here now, they would only have had to stroll a few yards through the bushes to find an open-sided pagoda where there would have been an ample supply of clean towels, sun-tan oil (factors nought to infinity), snorkelling gear and a fridge full of cold water, cans of beer and bottles of champagne.

They had probably intended to stay for months, but after a fortnight they gave up, each having lost about two stone. Were they staying here now, a fortnight's stay would set them back $196,000 - an awful lot of money for a holiday, but the island is booked up far in advance and many guests come back regularly. Necker can house 26 visitors, which cuts down the cost per head, although hardly to a bargain price. Often, couples rent the island just for themselves, moving from room to room as the fancy takes them.

Unlike a hotel, none of the rooms have keys, nor do they need them. You can eat and drink what you want, whenever you want, and do pretty much as you please, without any fear of running into strangers or paparazzi, not that I've ever found paparazzi to be a problem.

If you can't face the 200-yard walk from the beach to the house, a phone is always near at hand for you to call a car. If you find the sea just a little bit too warm, the temperature in one of the nearby pools is kept a few degrees colder. When bored with tennis, snooker, backgammon, chess, sailing, snorkelling, windsurfing and the inflatable banana, you can visit the nearby love temple for a quiet bonk (or even a noisy one). It consists of a very large bed on stilts.

But there are limits to the luxury. The staff talked proudly of how, at the last minute, they had been able to "source" a bottle of Chateau Haut-Brion 1978 for an earlier guest, but sadly my request for Iranian Sultanie vodka went unanswered.

It is an absurd life, one far removed from the problems of commuting on a Virgin train, but one you get used to absurdly easily, and you find yourself frowning when you notice that one of yesterday's champagne corks has not yet been removed from the beach.

And here are some that won't cost - or deliver - as much...

Private islands are not for everyone. An English couple who bought an island off the west coast of Scotland spent their evenings gazing wistfully at the lights on the mainland. Most mornings the husband would say: "I'm just going out in the boat," and he would head off to spend his lunchtimes in one of the dreariest pubs in the Highlands.

They, like most people, suffered from the delusion that there is a great party going on somewhere nearby and they haven't been invited. Successful owners of private islands are very different. They believe that any party they haven't been invited to isn't worth going to. That, too, is a delusion.

They are also, for the most part, barking mad. Typical owners include:

Dr Moreau who sought total privacy in the South Seas to conduct his beastly genetic experiments.
Hospitality rating: 0/10.

Dr No who sought total privacy in the West Indies to plot world domination.
Hospitality rating: 0/10.

Calypso and Circe in the Odyssey, who welcomed strangers to their alder-fringed islands in the Mediterranean, so long as they didn't make any plans to leave.
Hospitality rating: 5/10.

Lord Summerisle in The Wicker Man. Rather too warm a welcome.
Hospitality rating: 0/10.

Count Zaroff in the classic 1932 film The Most Dangerous Game. The perfect host until after dinner when he would amuse himself by setting his hounds on the guests.
Hospitality rating: 0/10.

The queen of Emain Ablach, the island of apples in the far west. In Celtic legend, Bran the son of Febal stayed for a year, entertained with every imaginable luxury, but when he returned home, he found that hundreds of years had elapsed. When one of his sailors jumped overboard, he turned to ashes the moment he touched the ground.
Hospitality rating: 8/10, but don't expect to make the flight connection on the way home.

Uncle Quentin on Enid Blyton's Kirrin Island. Lashings of ginger beer fail to make up for the high crime rate on the island.
Hospitality rating: 2/10.

The practicals

Necker can be booked through Limited Edition by Virgin, 5 The Lanchesters, 162-164 Fulham Palace Road, London W6 9ER (0800 716919, fax: 020 8600 0485). Renting the whole island costs $14,000 a day for 1-7 guests, rising to $29,000 for 20-26 guests. On special Celebration Weeks - September 5-12, October 7-14 and November 18-25 - rooms cost $13,000 per couple per week, master suite supplement $1,100, Bali Hi and Bali Lo supplement $1,925. Flights not included. Virgin Atlantic (01293 616161) flies London Heathrow to Tortola via Antigua for £2,218.30p premium class return, £814 economy.

They believe that any party they haven't been invited to isn't worth going to. That, too, is a delusion. They are also, for the most part, barking mad. Typical owners include: Dr Moreau who sought total privacy in the South Seas to conduct his beastly genetic experiments. Hospitality rating: 0/10. Dr No who sought total privacy in the West Indies to plot world domination. Hospitality rating: 0/10. Calypso and Circe in the Odyssey, who welcomed strangers to their alder-fringed islands in the Mediterranean, so long as they didn't make any plans to leave. Hospitality rating: 5/10. Lord Summerisle in The Wicker Man. Rather too warm a welcome. Hospitality rating: 0/10. Count Zaroff in the classic 1932 film The Most Dangerous Game. The perfect host until after dinner when he would amuse himself by setting his hounds on the guests. Hospitality rating: 0/10. The queen of Emain Ablach, the island of apples in the far west. In Celtic legend, Bran the son of Febal stayed for a year, entertained with every imaginable luxury, but when he returned home, he found that hundreds of years had elapsed. When one of his sailors jumped overboard, he turned to ashes the moment he touched the ground. Hospitality rating: 8/10, but don't expect to make the flight connection on the way home. Uncle Quentin on Enid Blyton's Kirrin Island. Lashings of ginger beer fail to make up for the high crime rate on the island. Hospitality rating: 2/10. The practicals Necker can be booked through Limited Edition by Virgin, 5 The Lanchesters, 162-164 Fulham Palace Road, London W6 9ER (0800 716919, fax: 020 8600 0485). Renting the whole island costs $14,000 a day for 1-7 guests, rising to $29,000 for 20-26 guests. On special Celebration Weeks - September 5-12, October 7-14 and November 18-25 - rooms cost $13,000 per couple per week, master suite supplement $1,100, Bali Hi and Bali Lo supplement $1,925. Flights not included. Virgin Atlantic (01293 616161) flies London Heathrow to Tortola via Antigua for £2,218.30p premium class return, £814 economy.

fields.headline: Visiting Russia
fields.standfirst:
My husband and I are planning to visit our daughter, who is studying at Moscow University, during the school Easter holidays. Package deals or city breaks do not fit the bill as we want to spend about a week with her and then a few days in St Petersburg. We would like some advice on how to organise the visit ourselves - it seems that Russia still has a very complicated bureaucracy.
Denise Burton
fields.trailText: My husband and I are planning to visit our daughter, who is studying at Moscow University, during the school Easter holidays. We want to spend about a week with her and then a few days in St Petersburg. How can we organise the visit ourselves - it seems that Russia still has a very complicated bureaucracy?
fields.body:
 You can arrange a home stay in St Petersbourg or Moscow by ringing the organisation called "Interchange" on 0208 681 36 12.

Irina Bourmistrova

 To stay with friends, you each need an official letter of invitation from a Moscow resident. This is the so-called militia clearance certificate, valid for up to three months. The resident will need details of your passport, full name, date of birth, etc. Alternatively book accommodation through a reputable company such as Hotel Select, supplying all the above details at the time of booking. Eventually, you will receive a tourist voucher and confirmation of accommodation from the hotel. You then apply for your visas with either the private invitations or tourist vouchers. The Russian embassy is in London, but we prefer to use the Edinburgh consulate. They take about seven days to process the applications and telephone to sort out problems. Their customer service and attitude is excellent. You must send your passports, recent passport-sized photos, £30 fee and insurance details.
Sheila Robinson

 A visa agency such as DJB Passports and Visas (020-7689 5905), which specialises in the former Soviet bloc can be invaluable. I have also used a specialist tour service located at St Petersburg university named Rusistika Travel (contact Sergei Volkov, e-mail: rusistik@rusakad.spb.ru). They can organise letters of invitation, accommodation, internal travels and guided tours, too.
David Williams

www.hotelsrussia.com takes hotel bookings by credit card and for a fee of $30 will give "visa support" - it will fax the confirmation you need to organise your visa, and register your passport once you're there. Alternatively, try the Moscow youth hostel (tel: +7 (095) 378 0001, e-mail: hostelasia@mtu-net.ru) - I've found them very efficient. You pay for one night's accommodation plus visa support and they fax you a letter stating you're staying for the full duration of your visit. (I've never actually stayed at the youth hostel, but that's the way things work in Russia.)
Margaret Matthew

 It is essential to obtain an "invitation" so that you can get a visa. Your daughter should be able to negotiate such an invitation from her university. Accommodation may be a problem in a city such as Moscow. Foreigners inevitably pay higher prices than Russians everywhere - hotels, trains etc. but compared with costs in the UK they are low. Your invitation should cover your wish to visit Petersburg in addition to visiting Moscow, as travel is limited to what is stated on the visa. You need to be aware that my wife, despite having an invitation obtained while I was in Russia, was refused a visa, apparently on the grounds that it was not an official visa, stamped by a government body.
Richard Ehlers

 My son spent some time this year in Samara (a city on the Volga) as a language assistant and I visited him at Easter. As he had a flat there I only wanted flights organised. I had to arrange my own visa, which was very complicated as I needed a letter from an official organisation inviting me to Samara, which only arrived two days before I was due to travel. I used a company in Croydon called Interchange (020-8681 3612) who were very efficient, helpful and cheap. They would probably be able to arrange a package for you and if they book hotel accommodation, they will also be able to sort out you visas. They deal with the Russian consulate in Edinburgh. It is almost impossible to get through to the one in London.
Norma Cook

 It is very difficult to get a Russian visa without a hotel booking. However specialist tour operators to Russia can make individual arrangements at a wide range of hotels, which secures a visa automatically. It would be a pity though to limit travel just to Moscow and St Petersburg. Take the opportunity of staying in towns along the Golden Ring such as Suzdal and Yaroslavl. For mid-range hotels in Moscow, allow about £50 a night for a twin, and in St Petersburg about £60. Prices are lower elsewhere. At Easter an airfare into Moscow and out of St Petersburg should be around £300.
Neil Taylor, Regent Holidays, Bristol

 I suggest you contact Intourist and ask for information as an independent traveller. Intourist have offices in Manchester (who have always provided me with good service and advice) and London. The company can book hotels, flights, travel within Russia and arrange visas all at a reasonable price. An opportunity to visit St Petersburg should not be missed: I have found the Moskva hotel to be good value when on special offer, and only two metro stops from the centre of Nevsky Prospekt. The Pulkovskaya is also good value, but some distance from the centre. The Astoria has particular grandeur, style and location but is more expensive. The Europa is probably the most luxurious, but with business client prices to match.
Malcolm Hill

 Russian bureaucracy is over-rated. I've had seven visas in the past three years, and each one's been a cliff-hanger. Intourist has a visa service: you pay a premium, bit it's worth it. Moscow isn't a hot destination, but you can still get cheap fares if you ask around. Aeroflot hasn't too many fans, but it's my airline of choice. The planes might be improvised, but the pilots all graduated from the Biggles School of Flying, aka the Soviet Air Force. Stay at the Mir, opposite the White House and the US Embassy; it's the former Comecon building. The foyer is deceptively imposing. But Moscow is expensive, and the Mir is well situated and relatively good value. The staff are immensely helpful and friendly, and many of them speak reasonable English. Go to Petersburg by train, more fun. Stay somewhere central and you can do most of it on foot. The heart of the city is quite compact.
David Gladwell

 Two years ago the two of us went to Moscow and St Petersburg under our own steam. Neither of us speak Russian, and we live in the North Midlands, 132 miles away from London, the Russian Embassy and visas. In the event all our travel needs and documentation were organised for us by a Russian travel service known as Academservice (email acs@acase.ru. Visas were arranged for us and sent well in time. We were met at Moscow airport by minibus and were whisked to a good hotel in the middle of the city. At the end of the first week we travelled by train to St Petersburg, again booked for us, and we were met at the station by another minibus to take us to a very comfortable hotel. Overnight travel back to Moscow - an experience not to be missed - was all set up for us, as was the journey back to our Moscow hotel. Nothing was too much trouble. Bureaucracy was at a minimum. Everyone did there best to please. For people like us, who like to devise their own itinerary, it was ideal.
John and Jenny March

fields.headline: Elf Night-vision Scope
fields.trailText: Its high-resolution image intensifiers light up the object you are looking at.
fields.body:
I'm off on the African safari trip of a lifetime and I know we will be going to some of the animals' night watering holes, but how am I going to see anything in the dark?
I've got just the thing for you, its small, light and will give you amazing night vision.

A pair of infra-red binoculars?
No, its called an Elf Night-vision Scope. It fits into your palm, it's 4.5 inches long and can be used one-handed.

What does it do and how does it work?
It looks like an old fashioned-camera and its high-resolution image intensifiers light up the object you are looking at.

What if it's pitch black outside?
Then you can switch on the infra-red light source and get a clear image of the object.

Brilliant. So I can then see the animals clearly, not just their eyes?
Absolutely. It's great for bird watching at dusk or at any time when the light is not very good.

How much does it cost?
£149 plus £3.25p p&p. Call 01932 253333. A more expensive version, the Night Owl, which gives magnification x3, costs £245. Both take two AA batteries.

fields.headline: The ice storm
fields.standfirst: Frozen food is about a whole lot more than chicken nuggets and peas, says Bob Granleese. Especially if Weekend's Kitchen Doctor Rosie Sykes has anything to do with it
fields.trailText: Frozen food is about a whole lot more than chicken nuggets and peas, says Bob Granleese. Especially if Weekend's Kitchen Doctor Rosie Sykes has anything to do with it.
fields.body:
Most of us, at one time or other, have had one of those fridges with a freezer compartment that resembles the polar ice cap. Usually, the fridge ends up in a skip and its owner buys one that works. David Thody, however, has lived with just such a clapped-out fridge for the best part of 12 years.

David - or Doc, as he is known to his friends, on account of him being the first person at his school to wear Dr Martens boots - simply got around his ice-bound freezer box by ignoring it. In fact, he is possibly the only 37-year-old in the country who has never bought anything from the freezer section of a supermarket. Not even a fish finger.

By late last year, his girlfriend, Sophie, had had enough. The fridge was going, she said. As was the oven with a door that had to be wedged shut with a brick. And the rest of the kitchen, while they were at it. It was time to have a proper, grown-up cooking space in which everything did what it was meant to.

"It was beyond embarrassing," Doc tells Rosie Sykes, Kitchen Doctor, in his Brixton flat while Imogen, her assistant for the day, unpacks the ingredients for the KD's latest mercy mission. "Not least because I design shops, restaurants and exhibition spaces for a living."

So, new kitchen equalled problem solved - or so Doc thought, until he went to Tesco. "I suddenly realised I was a freezer-aisle virgin. I spent ages in the frozen-food section, but didn't have a clue what to buy. My first reaction was, 'Hey, there's lots of food here that's really quick to cook.' Then I realised that I didn't know what to do with any of it. So I bought loads of ice cream and came home."

"That's why I'm here," says Rosie. "Next time, you'll have no problem."

"I wouldn't bank on it," says Doc. "I don't cook much at the best of times, though that's because I had such a rubbish kitchen."

Rosie tuts, then explains her plan. "The idea is to show you how to rustle up good meals from stuff you can buy frozen, and also a couple of things to make in bulk and freeze. Mind you, I got over-excited at the supermarket. Like you, I'm not used to buying frozen food, and got carried away with the novelty of it all."

Doc perks up, pleased that so accomplished a cook is a kindred spirit, at least where frozen food is concerned. "So, what's first?"

"Pea soup. You'll have it for lunch while I get on with the other dishes."

"Anything you want me to do?"

"You could wash the fresh veg for this and the other dishes..."

"Oh," says Doc, miffed that this means he won't get to play with Rosie's collection of very big, very sharp knives. Instead, he finds himself by the sink, up to his elbows in water and vegetables, while Imogen chops onions, celery and bacon for the soup, and then moves on to the veg so heroically cleaned by Doc.

Rosie sets a big pot on the stove and in what seems like next to no time the soup is cooked, blended and passed through a sieve. "Only because that's what I'd do in a restaurant," she explains. "It makes it much smoother. But it tastes fine without." The end result, finished off with a drizzle of truffle oil ("Very expensive," says Rosie, "but you need only the barest whiff") and Parmesan shavings, does indeed taste fine, to judge from the way Doc smears up every last drop with a hunk of bread offered by Rosie. "By the way," he says, "this bread is wonderful. I didn't even see how you made it."

"That's because I bought it," says Rosie, who has already turned her mind to the Asian-style pancakes. "These are a cinch. All the veg is ready cut and frozen, as are the prawns, so it's just a matter of defrosting what you need and bunging it in a wok. And the broth that goes with it you can make in advance and freeze. The only real cooking is steaming the rolls once they're filled, and that's not hard, is it?"

Doc has to agree: "This cooking lark doesn't seem like such a chore, after all." And so it proves, as Rosie takes him through the construction of the pancakes and the making of the clean-flavoured fish broth.

While Doc enjoys a taste of their labours - "It's really light. Mind you, that's just as well if I'm going to have room to try everything" - Imogen gets to work on the lamb meatballs and Rosie finishes off a rabbit, chilli and chocolate affair, the very thought of which "scares me", admits Doc. "Don't worry," says Imogen confidently. "It might seem strange, but it works brilliantly. Anyway, before it's ready to taste, I really think you ought to help me out with these meatballs, so you know what's what."

Doc complies, although his first gnarled effort looks like the poor relation of Imogen's immaculate little creations. "Oh dear," says Doc. "It's a bit of a runt, isn't it?"

"Er, yes, it is," says Imogen, brandishing the offending object for Rosie's perusal. "If any break up while you're poaching them, don't blame me," she tells the KD.

Doc looks suitably chastened, and then frightened, for Rosie approaches him with a bowl of the rabbit. He gingerly takes a spoonful. "That is really weird," he says. "You can smell the chocolate a mile off, and the first taste is unmistakably chocolate, but then the other flavours come through and you don't notice any more. In fact, I'd eat that again."

"Just as well," says Rosie, looking at the full pot on the stove.

"Oh, that's all right," says Doc. "We'll have the rest for dinner tonight, when Sophie gets home from work. So long as I can fit anything else in, that is."

Rosie grins, well-pleased with his response to her efforts, and starts on a chickpea and tomato sauce for the meatballs. "I'll tell you another good thing to do with chickpeas," she says absent-mindedly. "Toss them in cornflour and spices - cumin, paprika, stuff like that - then fry them. They go all tempura-y. Really simple, and they taste fabulous."

No sooner has she finished speaking than the sauce is ready, the meatballs are laid on top, and Doc is required, once again, to don his chief taster's hat. "Oh God, that's a big plateful," he says. "I've still got pudding to try, you know." Then he tastes it, the complaints stop and he stays silent until the plate is empty.

Meanwhile, Rosie constructs an apple and raspberry filo pie and pops it in the oven. Twenty minutes later, it emerges, but Doc has had enough by now: "I can only manage a spoonful," he sighs, surveying his kitchen and all the finished dishes laid out in containers. "There's still so much left. We'll never eat it all before it goes off."

Rosie smiles knowingly, then says, "Well, you could always try freezing some of it."

All recipes serve four.

Pea soup

Frozen peas are just the best - this soup is fast and delicious, the perfect winter warmer. And if you wanted to serve it in summer, just add some mint and have it cold with a dollop of crème frache, in which case you should pass the soup through a sieve, so that it is smooth. Once cooked, it should keep for a day or two in the fridge.

2 medium onions, roughly chopped
2 sticks celery, roughly chopped
1 leek, white part only, roughly chopped
4 cloves garlic
175g smoked bacon, chopped
400g frozen peas
40g butter
tbsp oil
55g fresh Parmesan, grated
Truffle oil (optional)
Salt and pepper

In a heavy-based pan, heat the oil and then fry the bacon for a couple of minutes until it begins to render its fat. Add the onion, garlic, celery and leek, cover, and sweat down for about 15 minutes, until softened. Add the butter and, once it has melted, the peas. Stir for a minute until all the peas are coated, then pour in enough water to come about 3cm above the contents of the pan.

Simmer gently until the peas are completely soft. Put into a liquidiser (you may need to do this in batches), and whizz until quite smooth. Add water if it seems too thick. If the resulting soup is not quite smooth enough for your taste, push it through a sieve. To serve, reheat the soup, pour into a bowl and scatter Parmesan shavings on top and, if you are feeling saucy, a drizzle of truffle oil.

Prawn rolls and fish broth

The idea here is to minimise the time you have to spend chopping by taking advantage of all that ready-sliced veg in the freezer aisle. Also, spring roll wrappers usually come vacuum-packed, so will keep for an age in the cupboard. Make lots of the broth and freeze it until next time. In short, the perfect quick weekday meal.

55g frozen sliced mixed peppers
55g frozen sliced mushrooms, cut in half
55g frozen baby sweetcorn
1 small tin water chestnuts
200g frozen peeled tiger prawns, slit in half lengthways
200g frozen white fish fillet (preferably not cod)
20g fresh ginger, peeled and cut into thin matchsticks, skin and any trimmings reserved
2 stalks lemongrass, roughly chopped
55ml Amontillado sherry
1 tsp fish sauce
1 big bunch fresh coriander, with roots, if possible
2 tbsp fresh mint
1 medium onion, roughly chopped
5 cloves garlic
6 spring onions, trimmed, sliced into matchsticks, trimmings and most of green part reserved
1 tbsp dark soy sauce
Any leek, carrot or celery you may have lying around, roughly chopped
1 tbsp sesame oil
1 tbsp sunflower oil
8 spring roll wrappers, or rice pancakes

Place the fish fillets and all the vegetable and herb trimmings, peelings, roots and stalks in a pan. Pour in the sherry and fish sauce, then cover with water. Bring to a boil, skim off any scum that rises to the surface, and simmer very gently while you prepare everything else.

Heat the oil in a wok and, when it is smoking, throw in the peppers, mushrooms, sweetcorn and onion. Toss these around until they begin to soften, then add the ginger, spring onions, water chestnuts, prawns and garlic. Move around for a couple more minutes, allowing any liquid in the wok to evaporate, then season to taste and turn out on to a plate. Leave to cool.

Soak a clean teatowel under the cold water tap, then squeeze it out and lay it flat on the work surface. Place a couple of the spring roll wrappers or rice pancakes on one half of the teatowel, then fold over the other to cover. Press down gently, and leave for about a minute, until the wrappers are pliable. Place a small mound of the prawn/vegetable filling in the middle of each roll, add a mint leaf and a sprig of coriander, then fold in the two sides and roll up lengthways to form a small see-through package. Place the prepared rolls seam-side down on a plate, and when they are all done, refrigerate until you are ready to dish up.

To serve, strain the stock into a clean pan, bring back to the boil and stir in a large handful of coriander leaves. Steam the rolls in a lidded colander over the broth until cooked through, about five minutes. Add soy sauce to the broth, and taste. Season according to taste, then pour a little into a shallow bowl. Serve the rolls in the broth or on the side.

Rabbit with chilli and chocolate, and herbed potatoes

This Mexican inspired dish makes a good, quick supper, if a little unusual.

250g frozen boneless rabbit pieces
30g bacon, finely diced
1 large red onion, finely sliced
3 sticks of celery, finely sliced
3 small red chillies, finely chopped
400g tin chopped tomatoes
1 tbsp cornflour
1 tbsp sunflower oil
1 tbsp white-wine vinegar
40g very dark chocolate
A pinch each of paprika and cinnamon
Salt and pepper

For the potatoes

6 medium potatoes, scrubbed and chopped into quarters
2 spring onions, finely chopped
1 large tbsp coriander, finely chopped
1 large tbsp mint, finely chopped
2 tbsp olive oil

Heat the oil in a heavy-based pan. Mix the spices into the cornflour and season. Toss the rabbit in this mixture, then brown it all over in the hot oil. Lift out with a slotted spoon. Bring up to a simmer and return the meat to the pot. Season as necessary, then add up to 100ml of water if it is looking as though it may dry out. Cover, then cook at a gentle bubble while you make the potatoes.

Boil the potatoes in salted water until tender, then drain and return to the pan. Add the oil, herbs and spring onions, season generously and gently stir until they are well coated. A salad would be a nice accompaniment.

This is the other side of freezer food - that is, making something in a big batch, freezing it and then pulling out as much or as little as you need to whip up a little food storm.

8 spring onions, trimmed and finely chopped
1 tbsp finely chopped dill
1 tbsp finely chopped mint
1 tbsp finely chopped parsley
450g minced lamb
Salt and pepper
100g uncooked rice
400g chickpeas
3 beef tomatoes, peeled and roughly chopped
red pepper, chopped
1 red onion, chopped
2 cloves garlic, chopped
3 tbsp olive oil

Shape the mixture into walnut-sized balls, and leave to rest in the fridge while you bring a large pan of salted water to the boil. Carefully add the meatballs, and poach them very gently for 25 minutes. Lift them out of the water with a slotted spoon, and set to one side. Reserve 100ml of the cooking liquor. To reheat them, put 1 tablespoons of oil in a pan, add the chickpeas and sauté until they are slightly crispy. Add the onion, red pepper and garlic, then tip in the tomatoes and stir. If the mixture is very dry, add some of the reserved cooking liquor. Gently place the meatballs on top, put a lid on the pan and let the meatballs steam for about five minutes. Lift them out with a slotted spoon, then stir the reserved herbs into the chickpea mixture. Serve the meatballs on top of the chickpeas.

Filo is so versatile and easy to use. This pie uses frozen raspberries, but you could try any fruit, really.

5 dessert apples (Cox's, say) peeled, cored and finely sliced
250g raspberries
100g granulated sugar
100g butter
1 tbsp Cointreau
270g packet filo pastry (usually around six sheets per pack)

Mix the apple and raspberries with the Cointreau. Butter a 24cm tin, lie a sheet of pastry so that half of it is resting on the base of the tin, sprinkle with butter and sugar, and fold over the other half of the pastry sheet. Repeat with another sheet of filo, then top with the apple and raspberry mixture. Top off with another two sheets of filo, finishing with a sprinkle of butter and sugar. fields.bodyText: Most of us, at one time or other, have had one of those fridges with a freezer compartment that resembles the polar ice cap. Usually, the fridge ends up in a skip and its owner buys one that works. David Thody, however, has lived with just such a clapped-out fridge for the best part of 12 years. David - or Doc, as he is known to his friends, on account of him being the first person at his school to wear Dr Martens boots - simply got around his ice-bound freezer box by ignoring it. In fact, he is possibly the only 37-year-old in the country who has never bought anything from the freezer section of a supermarket. Not even a fish finger. By late last year, his girlfriend, Sophie, had had enough. The fridge was going, she said. As was the oven with a door that had to be wedged shut with a brick. And the rest of the kitchen, while they were at it. It was time to have a proper, grown-up cooking space in which everything did what it was meant to. "It was beyond embarrassing," Doc tells Rosie Sykes, Kitchen Doctor, in his Brixton flat while Imogen, her assistant for the day, unpacks the ingredients for the KD's latest mercy mission. "Not least because I design shops, restaurants and exhibition spaces for a living." So, new kitchen equalled problem solved - or so Doc thought, until he went to Tesco. "I suddenly realised I was a freezer-aisle virgin. I spent ages in the frozen-food section, but didn't have a clue what to buy. My first reaction was, 'Hey, there's lots of food here that's really quick to cook.' Then I realised that I didn't know what to do with any of it. So I bought loads of ice cream and came home." "That's why I'm here," says Rosie. "Next time, you'll have no problem." "I wouldn't bank on it," says Doc. "I don't cook much at the best of times, though that's because I had such a rubbish kitchen." Rosie tuts, then explains her plan. "The idea is to show you how to rustle up good meals from stuff you can buy frozen, and also a couple of things to make in bulk and freeze. Mind you, I got over-excited at the supermarket. Like you, I'm not used to buying frozen food, and got carried away with the novelty of it all." Doc perks up, pleased that so accomplished a cook is a kindred spirit, at least where frozen food is concerned. "So, what's first?" "Pea soup. You'll have it for lunch while I get on with the other dishes." "Anything you want me to do?" "You could wash the fresh veg for this and the other dishes..." "Oh," says Doc, miffed that this means he won't get to play with Rosie's collection of very big, very sharp knives. Instead, he finds himself by the sink, up to his elbows in water and vegetables, while Imogen chops onions, celery and bacon for the soup, and then moves on to the veg so heroically cleaned by Doc. Rosie sets a big pot on the stove and in what seems like next to no time the soup is cooked, blended and passed through a sieve. "Only because that's what I'd do in a restaurant," she explains. "It makes it much smoother. But it tastes fine without." The end result, finished off with a drizzle of truffle oil ("Very expensive," says Rosie, "but you need only the barest whiff") and Parmesan shavings, does indeed taste fine, to judge from the way Doc smears up every last drop with a hunk of bread offered by Rosie. "By the way," he says, "this bread is wonderful. I didn't even see how you made it." "That's because I bought it," says Rosie, who has already turned her mind to the Asian-style pancakes. "These are a cinch. All the veg is ready cut and frozen, as are the prawns, so it's just a matter of defrosting what you need and bunging it in a wok. And the broth that goes with it you can make in advance and freeze. The only real cooking is steaming the rolls once they're filled, and that's not hard, is it?" Doc has to agree: "This cooking lark doesn't seem like such a chore, after all." And so it proves, as Rosie takes him through the construction of the pancakes and the making of the clean-flavoured fish broth. While Doc enjoys a taste of their labours - "It's really light. Mind you, that's just as well if I'm going to have room to try everything" - Imogen gets to work on the lamb meatballs and Rosie finishes off a rabbit, chilli and chocolate affair, the very thought of which "scares me", admits Doc. "Don't worry," says Imogen confidently. "It might seem strange, but it works brilliantly. Anyway, before it's ready to taste, I really think you ought to help me out with these meatballs, so you know what's what." Doc complies, although his first gnarled effort looks like the poor relation of Imogen's immaculate little creations. "Oh dear," says Doc. "It's a bit of a runt, isn't it?" "Er, yes, it is," says Imogen, brandishing the offending object for Rosie's perusal. "If any break up while you're poaching them, don't blame me," she tells the KD. Doc looks suitably chastened, and then frightened, for Rosie approaches him with a bowl of the rabbit. He gingerly takes a spoonful. "That is really weird," he says. "You can smell the chocolate a mile off, and the first taste is unmistakably chocolate, but then the other flavours come through and you don't notice any more. In fact, I'd eat that again." "Just as well," says Rosie, looking at the full pot on the stove. "Oh, that's all right," says Doc. "We'll have the rest for dinner tonight, when Sophie gets home from work. So long as I can fit anything else in, that is." Rosie grins, well-pleased with his response to her efforts, and starts on a chickpea and tomato sauce for the meatballs. "I'll tell you another good thing to do with chickpeas," she says absent-mindedly. "Toss them in cornflour and spices - cumin, paprika, stuff like that - then fry them. They go all tempura-y. Really simple, and they taste fabulous." No sooner has she finished speaking than the sauce is ready, the meatballs are laid on top, and Doc is required, once again, to don his chief taster's hat. "Oh God, that's a big plateful," he says. "I've still got pudding to try, you know." Then he tastes it, the complaints stop and he stays silent until the plate is empty. Meanwhile, Rosie constructs an apple and raspberry filo pie and pops it in the oven. Twenty minutes later, it emerges, but Doc has had enough by now: "I can only manage a spoonful," he sighs, surveying his kitchen and all the finished dishes laid out in containers. "There's still so much left. We'll never eat it all before it goes off." Rosie smiles knowingly, then says, "Well, you could always try freezing some of it." All recipes serve four. webTitle: A Great Weekend in Venice, Hachette, £4.99

fields.headline: A Great Weekend in Venice, Hachette, £4.99
fields.trailText: Hachette's Great Weekend series' latest publication breaks down Venice into four manageable sections: what to see, where to stay and eat, what to shop for and where, and nightlife
fields.body:
How many times have you gone to a foreign city for a weekend and bought yourself a guidebook that gives you far more than ever wanted or needed?

Hachette's Great Weekend series has attempted to sort this out with guides, the latest being for Venice, broken down into four serviceable parts - what to see, where to stay and eat, what to shop for and where, and a section on nightlife.

The section on what to see divides the city into the obvious districts, such as Piazza San Marco, Around the Rialto and the Campo di Santa Margherita district (village Venice). The descriptions are, by necessity, short, as the whole guide is only 130-odd pages, and if you want detail you will have to look elsewhere. But it is very practical. For each area it includes at least one place to eat, which saves you having to scrabble around in the eating section.

The shopping section is serious. It suggests routes and subjects with addresses and phone numbers of lots of speciality shops - those selling stationery, fabrics, carnival masks and costumes, linen, leather, jewellery and toys. The guide suggests that stationery, from one of the many "legatorie", makes the typical Venetian souvenir and is both chic and inexpensive. At the other end of the price scale is the names and addresses of the craftsmen who will make either a smart all-wooden speedboat or a gondola. Gian Franca Vianello makes five or six gondolas a year. But they are difficult to transport, being 36ft long and weighing half a ton.

With 350 colour photos and maps, lists of words and phrases, this is perfect for a weekend away - but not, probably, for any longer.

fields.headline: Somewhere for later
fields.trailText: Sweden | Nepal | St Lucia
fields.body:
Europe

UK: Until February 17, you can rent a four-bedroomed house near St Kew on the north Cornwall coast for £323 a week. The Granary is a farmhouse set in three-and-a-half acres of garden. Classic Cottages (01326 555555).

Sweden: Drive your own dog team through the forests of the Arctic Circle to the Ice Hotel in Jukkasjärvi. Arctic Experience (01737 214214) is offering a four-day trip to Swedish Lapland from £835pp (two sharing), including all flights, selected meals, three nights' accommodation, dog sledging and Lapland guides. Various departure dates in January, February and March.

Belgium: Relax on a weekend tour of Bruges, Brussels, Ostend and Antwerp, with optional guided walks. Departs January 26. Three-nights' accommodation at a four-star hotel in Ghent costs £125 per person, including return coach travel and breakfasts. Leger Holidays (01709 839839).

Germany: Throughout January and February, Moswin (0116 2719922) is cutting the price of its two-night Berlin breaks by £66, to £219pp. The price, based on two sharing, includes return scheduled flights from Heathrow and B&B at the three-star Wittelsbach Hotel.

Italy: Eurobreak (020-8780 7700) is offering a three-night stay in Verona for £262pp until the end of March, including British Airways flights from London Garwick and B&B at the Hotel Verona. Flights are available from regional airports at a supplement.

Thailand: Quest Travel (0870 4430746) is offering 10 nights at the three-star Dusit Resort, Pattaya, between May 1 and June 30, for £529pp (based on two sharing) including British Airways or Qantas flights and transfers.

St Lucia: Luther Vandross and Ronnie Laws top the bill at this year's St Lucia Jazz Festival running May 3-14. First Choice (0870 7500001) is offering 14 nights' room-only accommodation at the Harmony Suites for £849pp including return flights and transfers.

fields.headline: Post-Christmas trimmings
fields.standfirst: Need to shed a few festive pounds?  Max Riddington finds some places to burn off the calories
fields.trailText: Need to shed a few festive pounds? Max Riddington finds where to burn off the calories in the UK
fields.body:
1 Alpine adventures in Berkshire

Skiing and Berkshire aren't usually associated, but this is an exception. Next door to the Coppid Beach Hotel is a full range of alpine activities. Try dry skiing, snowboarding and tobogganing on Berkshire's very own Cresta Run.

The hotel has a sauna, spa bath, steam room, solarium, and beauty treatments. If you are fit enough, you can enjoy a spot of après-ski exercise in the gym, and 24-hour room service is available for those too sore to move. You can eat brasserie-style in the Bier Keller, and modern British or French food at the Rowans restaurant. Residents also have access to the Après nightclub.

Price: from £79 per person. Address: Coppid Beech Hotel, John Nike Way, Bracknell, Berks RG12 8TF. Tel: 01344 303333.

2 Saunter and sway the Yorkshire way

It doesn't come any fresher than this. Walk amid stunning Yorkshire scenery along coastal paths to Scarborough and Whitby. Two walks daily at a gentle pace get you firmed up for the evening's dance-led activities - a mix of country, folk and fun on a large sprung dance floor with expert tuition.

Price: from £169 full-board and tuition for a four-night break. Proprietors: Peter and Steve Mann. Address: 9 Stone Hill, Eldwick, Bingley, West Yorkshire BD16 3DS. Tel: 01274 567558.

3 Take the plunge in Devon

Learn to swim, or brush up on your strokes at this specialist residential centre providing professional tuition in modern, purpose-built indoor pools. Groups are small, and accommodation is comfortable and cosy. The nautical-themed bar has a separate games room with pool table. There's a gym, sauna and solarium, and a range of beauty treatments.

Price: from £403 for a week's course, including half board. Address: The International Swimming School, Straightway Head, Whimple, nr Exeter EX5 2QT. Tel: 01404 822553.

4 Float, bike and hike at Rutland Water

One of the largest man-made reservoirs in Europe set in 3,100 acres of gorgeous countryside, the lake is a focal point for walking, cycling, sailing and windsurfing. Canoes and boats are available for hire in the sheltered creek and harbour, and the 25-mile signposted circuit around the water's edge is suitable for all ages.

The Lake Isle Hotel and restaurant in Uppingham, about five miles from Rutland Water, provides ensuite rooms, including one with a large double whirlpool bath to soothe aching limbs.

Lake Isle Hotel prices: from £52. Address: The Lake Isle Hotel and Restaurant, 16 High Street East, Uppingham, Rutland. Tel: 01572 822951. Cycle hire: 01780 460705, www.rutlandcycling.co.uk. Water sports: 01733 234418.

5 Llama trekking in Cumbria

This may sound a little bumpy, but it sure beats walking when you have a large pack to carry. You can guide these friendly creatures on short, medium or long walks along beautiful bridleways and rugged routes.

B&B accommodation is in a recently converted 17th-century farmhouse in the pretty village of Garrigill on Alston Moor.

If you prefer to leave the llamas behind, there's a choice of spectacular footpath walks. Hadrian's Wall and the Lake District are less than an hour's drive away.

Prices: from £28 per person, including B&B and a one-hour trek. Longer treks are available. Address: Pennine Llama Treks, Ivy House, Garrigill, Alston, Cumbria CA9 3DU. Tel: 01434 382501.

6 Surf, sand... and very cold sea

It may be winter, but that doesn't mean the sea is off limits. At Watergate Bay, Cornwall, there are surf clinics all year round, and experts will provide anything from a half-day to a full week's worth of specialist tuition. If you are more of a speed freak, try kite surfing - where you get out on a board, hold on to a kite rope and get pulled along at a terrific pace.

Accommodation at the surf school's hotel annexe has ensuite rooms, family suites and a baby-listening service, all at reduced rates.

Accommodation from £30 per person per night. Address: Watergate Bay, Cornwall TR8 4AA. Tel: 01637 860543. Surf tuition: £20 for a half day, £30 for a full day.

7 Horsing around

Liscombe Farm in Somerset provides escorted rides for novices or the experienced on a half-hourly, hourly or half-daily basis, all year round. With the emphasis on fun and friendliness, its approach should suit all the family. The farm is within walking distance of an ancient clapper bridge, Tarr Steps, and has panoramic moorland views. The self-catering accommodation includes a former stone barn converted to sleep four and the old farmhouse sleeping up to nine.

Prices for riding: from £15 for an hour to £55 for a day. Cottages: from £180 a week. Address: Liscombe Farm, Tarr Steps, Dulverton, Somerset TA22 9QA. Tel: 01643 851551.

8 Clear up in Cliveden

National Trust properties often need loving attention and hard labour. Help restore the grounds of a beautiful graded building, burn off a few calories and earn your keep on a working weekend. One building is the former home of Nancy Astor, situated in 150 acres of glorious gardens and woodland on a spectacular escarpment overlooking the Thames. Help is needed replanting storm-damaged woodland, clearing scrub and doing a little footpath maintenance. Accommodation includes bunk beds, showers, a drying room, communal kitchen and payphone. Food is a shared affair. Please quote code KX1 when making an enquiry.

Price: £23. Age range: 18-70. Dates: February 16-18. Address: The National Trust Working Holidays, PO Box 84, Cirencester, Gloucester GL7 1ZP. Tel: 01285 644727.

9 Rock and ropes in Ross-shire

Learn basic rock-climbing skills and techniques while staying in a converted lighthouse-keeper's cottage with spectacular views over to Skye and the Western Isles. There are beginner, improver and advanced courses with instruction from experts.

Price of rock climbing: from £40 per person for a one-day introductory course. Room price: from £22 per person per night. Address: Melvaig, Gairloch, Ross-shire IV21 2EA. Tel: 01445 771263. Website: www.scotland-info.co.uk

fields.headline: Ski tips
fields.trailText: Dijon | Val d'Isère | Avoriaz
fields.body:
Dijon is hoping to lure skiers off the autoroute this winter with a range of packages including return Channel crossings with Hoverspeed and a night in a hotel with dinner and breakfast. Prices start at £54 per person, based on four in a car sharing two rooms. The town's tourist office has set up a dedicated reservations number: 0870 442 9848.

If thoughts of breaking the journey with a blow out in Burgundy prompt you to leap into the car, Finlays (01835 830562) has space available this month at its chalets in Val d'Isère and Courchevel. The firm allows customers to hop between the resorts, charging £28 a night for B&B or £38 for the full chalet package. "DIY skiing is on the increase," says a spokesman. "We've been finding that people just drive into the resorts and look for somewhere to stay."

Meanwhile Eurotunnel Motoring Holidays (0870 3332001) has cut the price of some one-week, self-drive packages to the French Alps arriving February 3. A group of five staying at the self-catering Residence Falaise in Avoriaz would get a discount of £182, bringing the total price down to £772 including Channel Tunnel crossings. Four people travelling together would pay £582 in Méribel or £530 in Alpe d'Huez - reductions of £152 and £130 respectively.

Skiers no longer need to catch a shuttle bus to reach the slopes at California's Heavenly resort. A new 2.4-mile-long gondola has opened, only five minutes' walk from most of the hotels in the South Lake Tahoe. Built at a cost of $20m, it reaches the foot of the Tamarack Express lift in just under 12 minutes.

For last-minute independent skiers, STA Travel (0870 1606070) is offering return flights from Stansted to Munich with British Midland for £71. The deal is available for departures until the end of January, but you must stay at least one Saturday night and no more than a month.

Ski Safari (020-7740 1221) is offering a one-week package to Vermont's Killington for £565. The deal is available until the end of April, excluding February 12-25, which includes the school half term. The price, based on two sharing a room, includes scheduled flights from Heathrow to Boston, a hire car and seven nights' B&B accommodation at the Killington-Pico Motor Inn.

Free postcards are on offer at Aspen in Colorado. Visitors can get them at any lift ticket window or at guest service centres on the mountain - and the Aspen Ski Company will pay for postage anywhere in the world.

fields.headline: Fastsellers 2000: the hot paperbacks
fields.standfirst: Alex Hamilton  analyses last year's figures and asks the industry what's in a bestseller
fields.trailText: Alex Hamilton analyses last year's figures and asks the industry what's in a bestseller
fields.body:
How do publishers see bestsellers? As tanks behind which the poor infantry can dash in, or as queen bees to which the whole hive is dedicated? Simon Master, MD of Random House, takes the bees option. "A much smaller publisher with only the odd chance of something big might want a tank for access. But we don't need a bag opener." Ursula Mackenzie, publisher at Little, Brown, accepts both. "Certain books, like Rebecca's Tale by Sally Beauman, with strong title, promotable author, great concept, will drive all the trade promotions. Others, like Anita Shreve, are more queen bees - nurtured and pushed along." Helen Fraser, MD of the general division at Penguin, compares a bestseller to "a balloon, into which everybody has to be constantly pumping hot air to get lift-off".

But none of these metaphors would quite do for the Harry Potter phenomenon, which has been more like an avalanche carrying everything in its path. It is said now (in Time's Christmas issue) to have sold 74m worldwide. In Britain the hardcover of HP4 seems to have outdone the paperback of HP3, with sales of 978,993. Apparently feeling the strain, Bloomsbury said: "We can't give you all the details until March when we tell the City. It's very share-sensitive." So that's something else a bestseller can be: a dart aimed at the FTSE. And how did I get the figures shown in italics? Magic, of course. Actually the export total is my estimate, based on the 15% performance of HP2 in 1999.

Whatever image you choose, everyone in the balloon business declares that a large publishing firm can't live without a bestseller, and the ideal is to have several. Adrian Bourne, MD of the general division of HarperCollins, recalls that when they had the management consultants in, "We were told to publish only bestsellers. 'Oh, thanks very much,' we said." Consultants would doubtless focus on items that "drive the market". Last year, many of the hardcover drivers were celebrities, famous for singing, dancing, cooking and passing footballs relentlessly into the goalmouth. Barbara Windsor, an Asda natural, reached 125,000; Martine McCutcheon and Ronan Keating passed 150,000; David Beckham reached 275,000.

In the home market the nation's culinary heartthrob Jamie Oliver whacked out 1,346,972 hardcover copies of Return of the Naked Chef , plus 171,000 export. Michael Joseph also has the pond-weeder's pin-up, Charlie Dimmock, on 126,983 for Enjoy Your Garden. But it's not all cooking and digging. A late surge for The History of Britain Vol I by the dynamic Simon Schama (BBC Worldwide) took it to 137,000, while Philip Pullman reached 112,204 with the final volume of his resonant trilogy for children, His Dark Materials (Scholastic).

Brand-name fiction also displays impressive hardcover results. Jeffrey Archer's stories sold enough to make the angels weep: 187,930. With what may be his last book, Dick Francis, who's been in these fastseller lists with racing thrillers every year since they began in 1980, shows 268,642 for Shattered. Techno-thriller veteran Tom Clancy has 368,855 for The Bear and the Dragon, Patricia Cornwell's latest Scarlatta thriller nears 350,000, and John Grisham has a UK sale of 308,303 for The Brethren and remains ahead of international Potter, with 100m plus. Many people class travel as para-fiction, so I include here Bill Bryson's Down Under, with 407,000. The Guardian 's "must-read of the year", Zadie Smith's first novel White Teeth, was read by more than 30,000 buyers.

With substantial discounting, the numbers sold of lead titles, both hard- and soft-cover, have much increased. "Discounting exists to fund the squabbles of retailers fighting for market share," says Malcolm Edwards, MD of hardcovers at Orion. "It must stop!" Master exclaims. "They're cutting nobody's throats but their own." Few publishers would dissent. Amanda Ridout, Headline MD, explains the deadly spiral. "On mass-market paperbacks the pressure comes from Asda, who want to be the lowest. That in turn gets the other supermarkets going, which gets Smith's going, which gets Waterstone's going. When that gets back to Asda ... nightmare scenario!" David Young, CEO of Little, Brown, says: "The margins for all our businesses are very fine. A lot of salespeople think that when they give away 1% they give away 1%, but in fact what they're giving away is 25% of the profit margin."

Fraser regretted the "enormous amount" of three-for-two offers. Apart from the third book being marked "sold at 0.001p", it delays the reader's next visit. "A lot of us worry about that. And club introductory offers block up people's reading for months." "What puzzles us," said Patrick Janson-Smith of Transworld, "is why booksellers have no mechanism to drive people right into the store, instead of stopping them just inside the door with all the bargains."

Hodder MD Martin Neild feels that certain kinds of book are disdained by "inexperienced but confident gatekeepers" - youths who buy for the chains. "Selling in trad storytelling to the trade, and historical fiction, for example, is a pain." Ridout has long supported historical fiction, which may now be coming out of the doldrums. Hodder emerged from a ferocious auction clutching Kydd, Julian Stockwin's start on a series of tales of a lower-deck figure in the Napoleonic war. The outstanding model is the late Patrick O'Brian's Napoleonic saga, now totalling 2.1m copies with HarperCollins.

Elsewhere, in the chick-lit and city-girl zone, where Penguin have a 100% success rate, publishers complain of manuscript overdose. "We need fewer 'city girls' and more Trollopes," says Edwards. Even Penguin agrees. "The older woman has been under-catered to," Fraser says. "We're actively searching." But the city-girl sorority is also maturing: time to move on, as Jane Green signals with her next book, Babyville.

Sporting books spread like a pitch invasion. And Ben Elton led what could be an unremarked genre: novels by comedians, such as Stephen Fry, David Baddiel and Jenny Eclair. Yesteryear's Bridget Jones's Diary climbed to 1.8m, and the film of The Beach added 385,485 to the 858,235 already sold. Mind/body/spirit, a portmanteau concept, continued to burgeon, raising Conversations with God to 150,000. Some oldies recovered from slumps, notably Wilbur Smith, through turning the clock back on his price to 1987. £3.99 was a challenge to discounters but Asda managed, while Waterstone's complained: "People won't know it's his new one!" Another perennial, Stephen King, offered a novel serially on the internet, but gave up when the response was more clicks than dollars. Will others try their luck? "Yes," says Ridout, "these people follow all routes to market."

In the accompanying fastseller list, which is exclusive to books published in paperback for the first time in 2000, the cut-off point is the highest ever, and the 154 titles that passed 100,000 is the largest. Typically, only two debutants figure in the top 25, Tony Parsons and Joanne Harris, with 10 other newcomers to the list. The 1999 Booker winner, JM Coetzee, duly found a place, and although Anita Desai, the "runner-up", did not, a figure of 112,540 was 10 times her average sale. The diminishing percentage of American authors is down to 27. There is a 50/50 split between the sexes, women thus achieving parity for the first time, having increased steadily from 75/25 in 1990.

See the full table of sales here .

Last year, many of the hardcover drivers were celebrities, famous for singing, dancing, cooking and passing footballs relentlessly into the goalmouth. Barbara Windsor, an Asda natural, reached 125,000; Martine McCutcheon and Ronan Keating passed 150,000; David Beckham reached 275,000. In the home market the nation's culinary heartthrob Jamie Oliver whacked out 1,346,972 hardcover copies of Return of the Naked Chef , plus 171,000 export. Michael Joseph also has the pond-weeder's pin-up, Charlie Dimmock, on 126,983 for Enjoy Your Garden. But it's not all cooking and digging. A late surge for The History of Britain Vol I by the dynamic Simon Schama (BBC Worldwide) took it to 137,000, while Philip Pullman reached 112,204 with the final volume of his resonant trilogy for children, His Dark Materials (Scholastic). Brand-name fiction also displays impressive hardcover results. Jeffrey Archer's stories sold enough to make the angels weep: 187,930. With what may be his last book, Dick Francis, who's been in these fastseller lists with racing thrillers every year since they began in 1980, shows 268,642 for Shattered. Techno-thriller veteran Tom Clancy has 368,855 for The Bear and the Dragon, Patricia Cornwell's latest Scarlatta thriller nears 350,000, and John Grisham has a UK sale of 308,303 for The Brethren and remains ahead of international Potter, with 100m plus. Many people class travel as para-fiction, so I include here Bill Bryson's Down Under, with 407,000. The Guardian 's "must-read of the year", Zadie Smith's first novel White Teeth, was read by more than 30,000 buyers. With substantial discounting, the numbers sold of lead titles, both hard- and soft-cover, have much increased. "Discounting exists to fund the squabbles of retailers fighting for market share," says Malcolm Edwards, MD of hardcovers at Orion. "It must stop!" Master exclaims. "They're cutting nobody's throats but their own." Few publishers would dissent. Amanda Ridout, Headline MD, explains the deadly spiral. "On mass-market paperbacks the pressure comes from Asda, who want to be the lowest. That in turn gets the other supermarkets going, which gets Smith's going, which gets Waterstone's going. When that gets back to Asda ... nightmare scenario!" David Young, CEO of Little, Brown, says: "The margins for all our businesses are very fine. A lot of salespeople think that when they give away 1% they give away 1%, but in fact what they're giving away is 25% of the profit margin." Fraser regretted the "enormous amount" of three-for-two offers. Apart from the third book being marked "sold at 0.001p", it delays the reader's next visit. "A lot of us worry about that. And club introductory offers block up people's reading for months." "What puzzles us," said Patrick Janson-Smith of Transworld, "is why booksellers have no mechanism to drive people right into the store, instead of stopping them just inside the door with all the bargains." Hodder MD Martin Neild feels that certain kinds of book are disdained by "inexperienced but confident gatekeepers" - youths who buy for the chains. "Selling in trad storytelling to the trade, and historical fiction, for example, is a pain." Ridout has long supported historical fiction, which may now be coming out of the doldrums. Hodder emerged from a ferocious auction clutching Kydd, Julian Stockwin's start on a series of tales of a lower-deck figure in the Napoleonic war. The outstanding model is the late Patrick O'Brian's Napoleonic saga, now totalling 2.1m copies with HarperCollins. Elsewhere, in the chick-lit and city-girl zone, where Penguin have a 100% success rate, publishers complain of manuscript overdose. "We need fewer 'city girls' and more Trollopes," says Edwards. Even Penguin agrees. "The older woman has been under-catered to," Fraser says. "We're actively searching." But the city-girl sorority is also maturing: time to move on, as Jane Green signals with her next book, Babyville. Sporting books spread like a pitch invasion. And Ben Elton led what could be an unremarked genre: novels by comedians, such as Stephen Fry, David Baddiel and Jenny Eclair. Yesteryear's Bridget Jones's Diary climbed to 1.8m, and the film of The Beach added 385,485 to the 858,235 already sold. Mind/body/spirit, a portmanteau concept, continued to burgeon, raising Conversations with God to 150,000. Some oldies recovered from slumps, notably Wilbur Smith, through turning the clock back on his price to 1987. £3.99 was a challenge to discounters but Asda managed, while Waterstone's complained: "People won't know it's his new one!" Another perennial, Stephen King, offered a novel serially on the internet, but gave up when the response was more clicks than dollars. Will others try their luck? "Yes," says Ridout, "these people follow all routes to market." In the accompanying fastseller list, which is exclusive to books published in paperback for the first time in 2000, the cut-off point is the highest ever, and the 154 titles that passed 100,000 is the largest. Typically, only two debutants figure in the top 25, Tony Parsons and Joanne Harris, with 10 other newcomers to the list. The 1999 Booker winner, JM Coetzee, duly found a place, and although Anita Desai, the "runner-up", did not, a figure of 112,540 was 10 times her average sale. The diminishing percentage of American authors is down to 27. There is a 50/50 split between the sexes, women thus achieving parity for the first time, having increased steadily from 75/25 in 1990. See the full table of sales here .

webTitle: Who lost their heart in Machu Pichhu?

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... Machu Picchu
fields.standfirst: Douglas Schatz, managing director of Stanfords, the chain of map and travel book shops
fields.trailText: Douglas Schatz, managing director of Stanfords, the chain of map and travel book shops.
fields.body:
Why: There is something about ruins that really attracts me, and Machu Picchu is one of the most mysterious ruins of all. You come upon it from the stone trail which the Incas built. Along the way you pass ruined Inca outposts, and walk through some pretty dramatic scenery before going over the rise and seeing these strange ruins.

Unlike tourists who visit on a day trip from Cuzco, you arrive on foot, not off a bus, and you don't have to get back on the bus in the afternoon. You can be there at eight in the morning and stay till five o'clock at night. You feel very special being there when the tourist buses have gone home. You get some sense of a personal connection to the place.

I went as part of a long trip through Peru and Bolivia and was lucky to be able to spend a few days getting acclimatised and then to have the time to walk the trail. The Inca Trail starts at "Kilometre 88". The train from Cuzco stops there - there isn't a station, just a man selling Coke or whatever by the side of the track. About a dozen of us got off, and at first I felt disappointed that we were not entirely alone, but everyone soon splits up and walks at their own pace.

Over the next two and half days we barely saw anyone else. You gradually work your way through the valleys and up the mountains, sleeping in old Inca ruins. One day, we arrived in darkness and cloud, then we woke up to see these amazing snow-capped mountains. It is quite hard work, but we had already done some walking and were used to the altitude.

The Inca civilisation was only destroyed in the 1500s, which is not that long ago, but very little is known about the place. It was overgrown and completely unknown until 1911. There are terraces for growing food and what looks like a sacrificial temple but no one knows exactly what the Incas did there, so your imagination can run riot.

The setting is wonderful - lush hills, mountains and then this place clinging to the mountain. It is on its own, not near a city or a big concentration of people. It was rumoured that there was another Inca city somewhere in the jungle so end up you looking at the hills and wondering what else is out there.

The best thing: It is a truly magnificent, romantic place. I was lucky to go when you could still walk the Inca Trail independently - that is changing and now you have to go as part of a group.

My advice: Do the trail, but don't underestimate how fit you have to be. It is not like a walk in the Lake District. Spend some time in Cuzco to get used to the altitude. Make sure you have the equipment you need. It gets very cold at the top of these mountains, and bring a good map.

How do I get there: Destination South America (01285 885333) organises 14-day tours to Machu Picchu for £2,795 all inclusive, seven days for £1,600. Dragoman (01728 861133) has 14-night treks from £790, plus $370 kitty; flights from London to Lima from £580 extra.

fields.headline: Untitled Film Still 53, Cindy Sherman (1980)
fields.trailText: · View the work online
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: Cindy Sherman. Born in New Jersey in 1954, Sherman put herself into American myth in a series of photographs called Untitled Film Stills. These pictures, which she began making in the mid-1970s, all feature the artist in different landscapes, made over into characters from films we've never seen, but feel we have: women alone, but part of a story written in advance.

Subject: Cindy Sherman, who has continued making masquerade photographic self-portraits, the disguises becoming ever more elaborate, including prosthetic horror makeup.

Distinguishing features: She's alone - a silent, out-of-place person in another time, another place. Something about the brick wall with the old- fashioned electric lamp suggests a ranch-house, perhaps in 1950s New Mexico. Her dress is old-fashioned, neat; her expression harder to read. She is right there in front of us, but at a tangent to our reality.

We know, even if we haven't heard of Sherman or her self-fictionalising project, that this is not a photograph snatched from life. The elements are manifestly fictional, the lamp artfully poised to light the scene. At the emotional centre of the picture is Sherman's round, wide face, made up with exaggerated conventionality under that permed hair. In other pictures in Untitled Film Stills, we see a woman alone in America's open spaces - hitchhiking in an empty mountain landscape, or at the railroad station for Flagstaff, Arizona, or in a Manhattan street late at night. Here, she's in close-up, looking sidelong, maybe at someone else in the room, or maybe out of a window, or at nothing but her own thoughts. She might be looking at her husband, planning his murder, or at her children, planning to leave them.

None of these possibilities is resolved. All you have to go on is her face. It is in shadow, and the lamp illuminating the wall behind her emphasises the lightless foreground. Surrounded by a halo of light cast on the brick wall, her face is a shadowed mask. It's a melodramatic lighting effect that immediately suggests despairing or violent thoughts. How do you read a face? Just by the light on it? By a turning away of the eyes?

What Sherman touches on in this picture is a problem portrait painters dealt with for centuries: what does someone's face tell us about their inner life? Sherman's face is a blank. It does not really have an expression, or communicate anything, except what is implied by the lighting, the setting and our desire to translate everything into stories.

You can look at hundreds of Sherman's pictures, each one featuring this face, and, though costumes and settings impose different emotional tones, you realise her face never says or does much. It just exists. Sherman is an anonymous everywoman taking on different roles. She photographs her face like Andy Warhol painted soup cans or Carl Andre placed bricks. She displays it in series, in a way that downplays individuality. Our faces are lumpen masks, her art suggests, and where we exist is elsewhere, in fictions and dreams.

Inspirations and influences: Sherman's art of masquerade was anticipated by the surrealist artist and writer Claude Cahun, born Lucy Schwob (1894-1954), who took photographs of herself in personae of her own imagining - a pilot, a femme fatale - and whose compelling self-portraits, long forgotten, have recently been rediscovered, partly because of their similarity to Sherman's.

Where is it? Nude, Action, Body galleries, Tate Modern, Holland Street, Bankside, London SE1 (020-7887 8000).
