fields.headline: The big con
fields.standfirst:
As the US cuts interest rates in a bid to stave off recession, Thomas Frank explains how the "New Economy" was always based on a dangerous myth
More net news
fields.trailText: As the US cuts interest rates in a bid to stave off recession, Thomas Frank explains how the "New Economy" was always based on a dangerous myth
fields.body:
As the 20th century came to an end, Newsweek magazine chose to mark its passing with a strong dose of the hokey cultural populism Americans have loved ever since the 1930s. Leading the celebration, Newsweek staffer Kenneth Auchincloss cast a long look back on the events of the "people's century" and opined that for once in human experience "ordinary folks changed history".

In support of this bold assertion of popular empowerment, Auchincloss singled out a succession of heroes who had changed things over the course of the century: suffragettes, feminists, the anti-war and civil rights movements, and, finally, "the entrepreneurs", this last group illustrated with a drawing of Bill Gates. Although his story brimmed with 30s populist stylings, Auchincloss took pains to point out that the landmark economic reforms of that decade weren't nearly as wonderful as everyone thought. And while the story hailed the richest man in the world as a champion of the common people, the labour movement was not mentioned at all.

Indeed, wherever one looked in the 90s, entrepreneurs were occupying the ideological space once filled by the noble sons of toil. From the pages of Newsweek to the smiling bubble-talk of CNBC, the cable channel devoted to covering the stock market, it was businessmen who were sounding off against the arrogance of elites, railing against the privilege of old money, protesting about false expertise and waging relentless, idealistic war on the principle of hierarchy wherever it could be found.

From Deadheads to Nobel-laureate economists, from palaeo-conservatives to New Democrats, American leaders in the 90s came to believe that markets were a popular system, a far more democratic form of organisation than (democratically elected) governments. This is the central premise of what I call "market populism": that in addition to being mediums of exchange, markets are mediums of consent. With their mechanisms of supply and demand, poll and focus group, superstore and internet, markets managed to express the popular will more articulately and meaningfully than did mere elections. By their very nature markets conferred democratic legitimacy, markets brought down the pompous and the snooty, markets looked out for the interests of the little guy, markets gave us what we wanted. As journalist Robert Samuelson announced in 1998, "the Market 'R' Us".

One of the reasons market populism prospered so fantastically in the 90s was that it was an extremely useful doctrine. As business leaders melded themselves with the common people, they discovered powerful new weapons to use against their traditional enemies in government and organised labour. Since it was markets that expressed the will of the people, virtually any criticism of business could be described as an act of "elitism" arising out of despicable contempt for the common man.

According to market populism, elitists were not those who, say, watch sporting events from a private box, or spend their weekends pottering on a computer-driven yacht, or fire half their workforce and ship the factory south. No, elitists were the people on the other side of the equation: the trade unionists and Keynesians who believed that society could be organised in any way other than the market way. Since what the market does - no matter how whimsical, irrational or harmful - was the Will of the People, any scheme to operate outside its auspices or control its ravages was by definition a dangerous artifice, the hubris of false expertise.

This fantasy of the market as an anti-elitist machine made the most sense when it was couched in the language of social class. Businessmen and pro-business politicians have always protested about the use of "class war" by their critics on the left; during the 90s, though, they happily used the tactic themselves, depicting the workings of the market as a kind of permanent social revolution in which daring entrepreneurs endlessly toppled fat cats and picked off the millions of lazy rich kids.

The scions of ancient banking families were said to be finding their smug selves wiped out by the streetwise know-how of some kid with a goatee; the arrogant stockbrokers of old were being humiliated by the e-trade masses; the Wasps with their regimental ties were getting their asses kicked by the women, the Asians, the Africans, the Hispanics; the buttoned-down whip-cracking bosses were being fired by the corporate "change agents"; the self-assured network figures were being reduced to tears by the vox populi of the web. A thousand populist revolts shook the office blocks of the nation, and the great forums of corporate ideology overflowed with praise for in-your-face traders from gritty urban backgrounds, for the CEO who still retained the crude manners of the longshoreman.

It was a strange faith but, by the middle of the 90s, it was a populism in the ascendancy. Everyone seemed to find what they wanted in the magic of markets. Markets were serving all tastes, markets were humiliating the pretentious, markets were permitting good art to triumph over bad, markets were overthrowing the man, markets were extinguishing discrimination, markets were making everyone rich.

In the right hands, market populism could explain nearly any social phenomenon. The "tiger economies" of Asia had collapsed, market populists told us, because they had relied on the expertise of elites rather than the infinite wisdom of the people. Similarly, the economies of western Europe were stagnant because the arrogant aristocrats every red-blooded American knows run those lands were clinging to old welfare-state theories. The House of Morgan was swallowed up by Chase Manhattan because it was a snooty outfit that had foolishly tried to resist the democracy of markets.

More important, market populism proved astonishingly versatile as a defence of any business beset by meddling critics in government, union or environmental movement. On the Wall Street Journal editorial page, one saw market populism wheeled out to defend the advertising industry, to defend the auto industry, to bolster demands that the software industry be permitted to import more workers, to hail stock options as the people's true currency and, most remarkably, to defend Microsoft from its antitrust pursuers. Since a company's size (like the value of a billionaire's pile) was simply a reflection of the people's love, antitrust itself was fundamentally illegitimate, a device used by elitist politicians, the Journal once proclaimed, "to promote the interests of the few at the expense of the many".

Even after the Microsoft verdict had been announced, the paper continued to assert that the company "should have argued that we have a monopoly because our customers want us to have one". And when Al Gore began annoying the men of privilege last autumn with his (admittedly feeble) attacks on big business, the paper responded in the most direct manner imaginable. "Mr Bush should tell Americans [that] when my opponent attacks 'big corporations', he's attacking you and me."

Market populism proved particularly useful in the workplace. Whether you toiled for one of the great American corporations, for some zesty startup, or on an assembly line, workers in the 90s couldn't help but realise that class power was lopsided as never before. Management held all the cards in the 90s, and CEOs were able to work their will without encountering much organised resistance. The corporation "delayered", throwing off entire levels of white-collar workers; it "disaggregated", ridding itself of its extraneous operations; it embraced "flexibility", replacing career employees with zero-benefits temps; it "outsourced" every possible piece of work to the lowest bidder; it "re-engineered" its various processes in a less labour-intensive way; it "disintermediated", used new technology to cut out middlemen and move "back office" jobs to the lowest-paid climes on earth. Unions shrank before professionally directed assaults and, in the US, organised workers finally slipped below 10% of the private sector workforce. Meanwhile, the remuneration awarded to American CEOs rose to astronomical levels. In 1999, corporate chiefs were paid, on average, some 475 times what their blue-collar employees took home.

Yet to read the management literature of the decade, what was really going on in the world of the corporation was democratisation. Whatever recommendations individual gurus might make regarding the structure of the workplace, the management literature of the 90s almost universally insisted that its larger project was liberation, giving a voice to the voiceless, "empowering" the individual, subverting the pretensions of the mighty, and striking blows against hierarchy of all kinds.

Management theory performed this reversal by redefining the workplace power struggle. The problems of the corporation weren't its upward redistribution of wealth or its refusal to bargain with its workers collectively or the massive disparities between bosses and bossed; the real problems were moral ones - "elitism", "arrogance", "certainty." And these were to be solved by embracing the Jacobin forces of the market ever more closely, by throwing out such distasteful relics of the past asloyalty and lifetime employment.

Understood this way, the true warriors for workplace democracy weren't trade unionists; they were the new breed of executives - the ones who abjured stuffy suits for casual wear, the zany "change agents", the makers of wow. Readers of new business magazines like Fast Company and Business 2.0 thrilled to tales of caring CEOs, of bosses who sat in cubicles like everyone else, of white-collar workers who demanded the right to drink beer and wear jeans in the office.

The entrepreneur, by virtue of his or her close relationship to the market, was the true bearer of populist humility - and also the true hero of the common man. Über-guru Tom Peters claimed that, in terms of the populist lexicon, the dotcom millionaires and the working class had switched moral positions - even stretching this absurd argument so far as to apply the populist keyword "parasite" to describe the very folks who once made up the labour movement.

"When I began working as a management consultant at McKinsey & Co in 1974," he wrote in 1997, "'we' (the professional service people - accountants, lawyers, consultants, ad agency denizens) were considered the parasites... living off the sweat of real people's brows. Times have changed. And how! The nerds have won! Bill Gates is the richest man in the world! It is the Age of Brainware. Now the people who lift 'things' (the rapidly declining fraction) are the new parasites living off the carpal-tunnel syndrome of the computer programmers' perpetually strained keyboard hands."

Again Bill Gates's money is thought, unproblematically and transparently, to endow him with the approval of the people, to establish him as vicar of the general will. This may seem silly at first, but it was a logic that yielded results. By insisting that bosses were the real commoners, that outsourcing was an act of humility, that downsizing was just an opportunity to pursue your personal authenticity, that corporations were, by virtue of their attunement to market forces, bearers of a kind of soulfulness that government and union could never touch, management theory brought an unprecedented degree of workplace quiescence.

It was thanks, at least in part, to the hyperbolic prose of Tom Peters and his colleagues that so many of the downsized agreed that what had happened to them was right, was necessary, was justified; it was thanks to the revolutionary crowing of magazines like Fast Company that so many left the parking lots of their former employers in such an orderly fashion, talking confidently about their impending careers as "free agents". Even more tellingly, in a decade when unemployment got as low as 4% - making management extremely vulnerable to demands for increased wages - union organising and strike activity remained at their lowest points since the 1920s. That the US was able to endure the wrenching upward redistribution of wealth that it did in the 90s with only small, localised outbreaks of social unrest must be chalked up, in part, to the literature that explicitly sought to persuade the world of the goodness and the justice of that redistribution.

Market populism did equally valuable service in the passionately, stridently optimistic rhetoric of the rising stock market. As everyone knows by now, the 90s was supposed to have been the age of Wall Street's "democratisation". The myth went like this. Once upon a time the world of finance had been a place of elites, of unbridled snobbery, of wealthy Wasps in suits, sneering at the common people and keeping this glorious thing, the stock market, all to themselves. But the great bull market of the 1990s, the myth continues, was something different: a bull market of the people, a powerful tool for economic democracy. This bull market was thought to be the Götterdämmerung of the ruling class, the final victory of the common people over their former masters.

Sometimes this "democratisation" was spoken of as a sort of social uprising, a final routing of the snobbish old-guard culture of Wall Street. Sometimes it was said to be the market itself that had worked these great changes, that had humiliated the suits and enriched all sorts of colourful proletarians. Sometimes it was described as a demographic phenomenon, a reflection of the vast percentage of the nation's population that was now entrusting their savings to the market. But however you looked at it, one thing was sure. The common people, we were told, understood this market, warmed to it instinctively the way they would a beloved relative.

At the same time, we were told, the old-money elites just didn't get it, and they flailed and failed as the little people paid them back for centuries of snooty hauteur. The decade was filled with corny tales of down-home investors whipping the pros. In the early 90s we thrilled to stories of Warren Buffett, the down-home billionaire; of Peter Lynch, the man who told us to forget about the complex stuff and invest in the companies that made our favourite everyday products; and of the Beardstown Ladies, a group of small-town Illinois grandmas whose local investment club was said to have racked up some gigantic figure or other by investing in humble, populist companies like Wal-Mart. The point of the episode wasn't the ladies' investing advice, which was fairly rudimentary (like how to read the stock listings in the newspaper), but instead a moral lesson, a demonstration that even society's feeblest, lowliest and worst-informed - kindly grannies from the ever innocent small-town midwest - could beat, as they put it, the "self-important MBAs" of "New York, or Zurich, or Tokyo".

In the late 90s we were deluged with tales of average people prospering hugely by investing in hi-tech stocks: the secretaries who had been transformed into mil lionaires by the grace of Microsoft; the college dropouts whose stock options had showered on them the kind of money most of us can't even imagine. The fantastic appreciation in internet shares in 1998 and 1999 was said to be a special sort of boom, one that was only comprehensible to the unpretentious. While the hated "experts", those cosmopolitan sophisticates who are the enemy in all populist narratives, carped and doubted, the common people trusted their new corporate heroes without reservation or cynicism. Looking out at what has been the most lopsided prosperity in our lifetimes, market populism told us that all was well, that with the demise of the welfare state and the crushing of union power a newer, more extreme form of economic democracy was being born. Because our billionaires were so cool, because our websites were so very interactive, this was the most democratic of all possible worlds.

fields.bodyText: As the 20th century came to an end, Newsweek magazine chose to mark its passing with a strong dose of the hokey cultural populism Americans have loved ever since the 1930s. Leading the celebration, Newsweek staffer Kenneth Auchincloss cast a long look back on the events of the "people's century" and opined that for once in human experience "ordinary folks changed history". In support of this bold assertion of popular empowerment, Auchincloss singled out a succession of heroes who had changed things over the course of the century: suffragettes, feminists, the anti-war and civil rights movements, and, finally, "the entrepreneurs", this last group illustrated with a drawing of Bill Gates. Although his story brimmed with 30s populist stylings, Auchincloss took pains to point out that the landmark economic reforms of that decade weren't nearly as wonderful as everyone thought. And while the story hailed the richest man in the world as a champion of the common people, the labour movement was not mentioned at all. Indeed, wherever one looked in the 90s, entrepreneurs were occupying the ideological space once filled by the noble sons of toil. From the pages of Newsweek to the smiling bubble-talk of CNBC, the cable channel devoted to covering the stock market, it was businessmen who were sounding off against the arrogance of elites, railing against the privilege of old money, protesting about false expertise and waging relentless, idealistic war on the principle of hierarchy wherever it could be found. From Deadheads to Nobel-laureate economists, from palaeo-conservatives to New Democrats, American leaders in the 90s came to believe that markets were a popular system, a far more democratic form of organisation than (democratically elected) governments. This is the central premise of what I call "market populism": that in addition to being mediums of exchange, markets are mediums of consent. With their mechanisms of supply and demand, poll and focus group, superstore and internet, markets managed to express the popular will more articulately and meaningfully than did mere elections. By their very nature markets conferred democratic legitimacy, markets brought down the pompous and the snooty, markets looked out for the interests of the little guy, markets gave us what we wanted. As journalist Robert Samuelson announced in 1998, "the Market 'R' Us". One of the reasons market populism prospered so fantastically in the 90s was that it was an extremely useful doctrine. As business leaders melded themselves with the common people, they discovered powerful new weapons to use against their traditional enemies in government and organised labour. Since it was markets that expressed the will of the people, virtually any criticism of business could be described as an act of "elitism" arising out of despicable contempt for the common man. According to market populism, elitists were not those who, say, watch sporting events from a private box, or spend their weekends pottering on a computer-driven yacht, or fire half their workforce and ship the factory south. No, elitists were the people on the other side of the equation: the trade unionists and Keynesians who believed that society could be organised in any way other than the market way. Since what the market does - no matter how whimsical, irrational or harmful - was the Will of the People, any scheme to operate outside its auspices or control its ravages was by definition a dangerous artifice, the hubris of false expertise. This fantasy of the market as an anti-elitist machine made the most sense when it was couched in the language of social class. Businessmen and pro-business politicians have always protested about the use of "class war" by their critics on the left; during the 90s, though, they happily used the tactic themselves, depicting the workings of the market as a kind of permanent social revolution in which daring entrepreneurs endlessly toppled fat cats and picked off the millions of lazy rich kids. The scions of ancient banking families were said to be finding their smug selves wiped out by the streetwise know-how of some kid with a goatee; the arrogant stockbrokers of old were being humiliated by the e-trade masses; the Wasps with their regimental ties were getting their asses kicked by the women, the Asians, the Africans, the Hispanics; the buttoned-down whip-cracking bosses were being fired by the corporate "change agents"; the self-assured network figures were being reduced to tears by the vox populi of the web. A thousand populist revolts shook the office blocks of the nation, and the great forums of corporate ideology overflowed with praise for in-your-face traders from gritty urban backgrounds, for the CEO who still retained the crude manners of the longshoreman. It was a strange faith but, by the middle of the 90s, it was a populism in the ascendancy. Everyone seemed to find what they wanted in the magic of markets. Markets were serving all tastes, markets were humiliating the pretentious, markets were permitting good art to triumph over bad, markets were overthrowing the man, markets were extinguishing discrimination, markets were making everyone rich. In the right hands, market populism could explain nearly any social phenomenon. The "tiger economies" of Asia had collapsed, market populists told us, because they had relied on the expertise of elites rather than the infinite wisdom of the people. Similarly, the economies of western Europe were stagnant because the arrogant aristocrats every red-blooded American knows run those lands were clinging to old welfare-state theories. The House of Morgan was swallowed up by Chase Manhattan because it was a snooty outfit that had foolishly tried to resist the democracy of markets. More important, market populism proved astonishingly versatile as a defence of any business beset by meddling critics in government, union or environmental movement. On the Wall Street Journal editorial page, one saw market populism wheeled out to defend the advertising industry, to defend the auto industry, to bolster demands that the software industry be permitted to import more workers, to hail stock options as the people's true currency and, most remarkably, to defend Microsoft from its antitrust pursuers. Since a company's size (like the value of a billionaire's pile) was simply a reflection of the people's love, antitrust itself was fundamentally illegitimate, a device used by elitist politicians, the Journal once proclaimed, "to promote the interests of the few at the expense of the many". Even after the Microsoft verdict had been announced, the paper continued to assert that the company "should have argued that we have a monopoly because our customers want us to have one". And when Al Gore began annoying the men of privilege last autumn with his (admittedly feeble) attacks on big business, the paper responded in the most direct manner imaginable. "Mr Bush should tell Americans [that] when my opponent attacks 'big corporations', he's attacking you and me." Market populism proved particularly useful in the workplace. Whether you toiled for one of the great American corporations, for some zesty startup, or on an assembly line, workers in the 90s couldn't help but realise that class power was lopsided as never before. Management held all the cards in the 90s, and CEOs were able to work their will without encountering much organised resistance. The corporation "delayered", throwing off entire levels of white-collar workers; it "disaggregated", ridding itself of its extraneous operations; it embraced "flexibility", replacing career employees with zero-benefits temps; it "outsourced" every possible piece of work to the lowest bidder; it "re-engineered" its various processes in a less labour-intensive way; it "disintermediated", used new technology to cut out middlemen and move "back office" jobs to the lowest-paid climes on earth. Unions shrank before professionally directed assaults and, in the US, organised workers finally slipped below 10% of the private sector workforce. Meanwhile, the remuneration awarded to American CEOs rose to astronomical levels. In 1999, corporate chiefs were paid, on average, some 475 times what their blue-collar employees took home. Yet to read the management literature of the decade, what was really going on in the world of the corporation was democratisation. Whatever recommendations individual gurus might make regarding the structure of the workplace, the management literature of the 90s almost universally insisted that its larger project was liberation, giving a voice to the voiceless, "empowering" the individual, subverting the pretensions of the mighty, and striking blows against hierarchy of all kinds. Management theory performed this reversal by redefining the workplace power struggle. The problems of the corporation weren't its upward redistribution of wealth or its refusal to bargain with its workers collectively or the massive disparities between bosses and bossed; the real problems were moral ones - "elitism", "arrogance", "certainty." And these were to be solved by embracing the Jacobin forces of the market ever more closely, by throwing out such distasteful relics of the past asloyalty and lifetime employment. Understood this way, the true warriors for workplace democracy weren't trade unionists; they were the new breed of executives - the ones who abjured stuffy suits for casual wear, the zany "change agents", the makers of wow. Readers of new business magazines like Fast Company and Business 2.0 thrilled to tales of caring CEOs, of bosses who sat in cubicles like everyone else, of white-collar workers who demanded the right to drink beer and wear jeans in the office. The entrepreneur, by virtue of his or her close relationship to the market, was the true bearer of populist humility - and also the true hero of the common man. Über-guru Tom Peters claimed that, in terms of the populist lexicon, the dotcom millionaires and the working class had switched moral positions - even stretching this absurd argument so far as to apply the populist keyword "parasite" to describe the very folks who once made up the labour movement. "When I began working as a management consultant at McKinsey & Co in 1974," he wrote in 1997, "'we' (the professional service people - accountants, lawyers, consultants, ad agency denizens) were considered the parasites... living off the sweat of real people's brows. Times have changed. And how! The nerds have won! Bill Gates is the richest man in the world! It is the Age of Brainware. Now the people who lift 'things' (the rapidly declining fraction) are the new parasites living off the carpal-tunnel syndrome of the computer programmers' perpetually strained keyboard hands." Again Bill Gates's money is thought, unproblematically and transparently, to endow him with the approval of the people, to establish him as vicar of the general will. This may seem silly at first, but it was a logic that yielded results. By insisting that bosses were the real commoners, that outsourcing was an act of humility, that downsizing was just an opportunity to pursue your personal authenticity, that corporations were, by virtue of their attunement to market forces, bearers of a kind of soulfulness that government and union could never touch, management theory brought an unprecedented degree of workplace quiescence. It was thanks, at least in part, to the hyperbolic prose of Tom Peters and his colleagues that so many of the downsized agreed that what had happened to them was right, was necessary, was justified; it was thanks to the revolutionary crowing of magazines like Fast Company that so many left the parking lots of their former employers in such an orderly fashion, talking confidently about their impending careers as "free agents". Even more tellingly, in a decade when unemployment got as low as 4% - making management extremely vulnerable to demands for increased wages - union organising and strike activity remained at their lowest points since the 1920s. That the US was able to endure the wrenching upward redistribution of wealth that it did in the 90s with only small, localised outbreaks of social unrest must be chalked up, in part, to the literature that explicitly sought to persuade the world of the goodness and the justice of that redistribution. Market populism did equally valuable service in the passionately, stridently optimistic rhetoric of the rising stock market. As everyone knows by now, the 90s was supposed to have been the age of Wall Street's "democratisation". The myth went like this. Once upon a time the world of finance had been a place of elites, of unbridled snobbery, of wealthy Wasps in suits, sneering at the common people and keeping this glorious thing, the stock market, all to themselves. But the great bull market of the 1990s, the myth continues, was something different: a bull market of the people, a powerful tool for economic democracy. This bull market was thought to be the Götterdämmerung of the ruling class, the final victory of the common people over their former masters. Sometimes this "democratisation" was spoken of as a sort of social uprising, a final routing of the snobbish old-guard culture of Wall Street. Sometimes it was said to be the market itself that had worked these great changes, that had humiliated the suits and enriched all sorts of colourful proletarians. Sometimes it was described as a demographic phenomenon, a reflection of the vast percentage of the nation's population that was now entrusting their savings to the market. But however you looked at it, one thing was sure. The common people, we were told, understood this market, warmed to it instinctively the way they would a beloved relative. At the same time, we were told, the old-money elites just didn't get it, and they flailed and failed as the little people paid them back for centuries of snooty hauteur. The decade was filled with corny tales of down-home investors whipping the pros. In the early 90s we thrilled to stories of Warren Buffett, the down-home billionaire; of Peter Lynch, the man who told us to forget about the complex stuff and invest in the companies that made our favourite everyday products; and of the Beardstown Ladies, a group of small-town Illinois grandmas whose local investment club was said to have racked up some gigantic figure or other by investing in humble, populist companies like Wal-Mart. fields.headline: Down under
fields.standfirst: Paul Murphy learns how to scuba dive in the Caribbean
fields.trailText: Paul Murphy learns how to scuba dive in the Caribbean.
fields.body:
Flapping around, 40ft below the water's surface, close to a sandy seabed 4,000 miles from home, the first instinct is to panic. This just feels unnatural - sucking desperately on a piece of neoprene. There is space all around and yet the claustrophobia is crushing.

Rim Brim, a 28-year-old Grenadan diving instructor, glides over. He juts a finger towards my face. Staring intently, demanding absolute attention, he moves two fingers to his own eyes and then stabs one to his chest: YOU... WATCH... ME.

He lays a hand over the respirator at his own mouth and breathes deeply, exhaling slowly. I follow his lead. The flapping stops. I sink slowly to the seabed alongside half-a-dozen other novice divers. Rim Brim creates a circle with his thumb and index finger. I return the gesture. Yes, I am "okay".

The next 30 minutes are sublime; a graceful, weightless meander over coral and rocks, stopping to admire lobsters, a moray eel and a stingray which curves round the group of divers and then heads off into the watery haze.And everywhere there are fish, every possible size, shape. It is an exhilarating, habit-forming experience.

This is day three, and I am hooked. Day one had been spent on a sun lounger by the pool of La Source, a pristine beach resort five miles from St George, the capital of Grenada, the most southerly of the Windward Isles.

While scuba is a big draw, only a small portion of La Source's regular clientele take to the dive boat. It is the only "official" all-inclusive resort on the island, with a good standard of cuisine and excellent service. But its commercial success, under its British general manager Richard Fenn, has led to increasing imitation among Grenada's rival top-flight hotels.

I had signed up for one of the open-water diving courses run by Padi - the Professional Association of Diving Instructors. This basic course, which usually takes around five days, grants a graduate the right to hire or buy full scuba-diving kit and take to the water anywhere.

Stage one, the sun lounger section, consists of ploughing through Padi's textbook, complete with tests, "safety alerts" and the like. After watching a video that supports the reading material, learners are able to strap on the tanks and slip into a swimming pool to practise all the underwater acts they have been reading about.

Yet two days do not quite prepare you for the extraordinary experience of sitting on the edge of a boat, donning flippers and then tumbling backwards into the warm sea.

Out of the boat, the training continues during the stipulated four open-water dives. While the coursework is rigid, and to some extent repetitive, the rules governing safe scuba, which restrict how often and to what depth someone can dive, mean that a diving course is not a full-time holiday occupation. There is room to collect a tan or to explore a holiday destination.

Many famous diving resorts are known for having precious little to do above sea level. Grenada is different. A soft, safe island, it remains poor by all the usual benchmarks - roads, medical care, per capita income. But everywhere there is a richness of colour. There is also a sense that the island has not yet mortgaged its own economic and cultural strengths. Tourism is one of its big hopes, and standards are already exceptionally high.

Our final dive is to two rusting wrecks, a mile offshore and 60ft below the surface. As we glide weightlessly through the water, there are even more eels, rays and coral. And the early anxiety has melted away.

Then, to the left of the diving group, down towards the seabed, the unmistakable shape of a shark comes into view. It is the first we have seen in five days. But it is the real thing and is at least three-and-a-half feet long...

The practicals

Seven nights at LaSource, flying with JMC from Gatwick, including transfers, all meals, drinks, land and sea sports and one treatment per day at the Oasis, costs from £1,256pp and can be booked through Caribtours (020-7751 0660). For a free brochure on LaSource, call: 020-8392 2344.

The hotel is set in 40 acres and has 100 rooms. Treatments include aromatherapy, Swedish massage, foot massage, tai chi, yoga and facials. PADI-accredited diving courses start at $120 for the one-day Discover Diving experience to $300 for the open water course.

fields.headline: Fiction's great outlaw
fields.standfirst: Without question the pre-eminent literary voice of post-colonial Australia, he loves to take risks. In his latest novel, he has provoked the establishment by suggesting that the notorious Ned Kelly was his home country's Thomas Jefferson.  Nicholas Wroe  reports
fields.trailText: Without question the pre-eminent literary voice of post-colonial Australia, he loves to take risks. In his latest novel, he has provoked the establishment by suggesting that the notorious Ned Kelly was his home country's Thomas Jefferson. Nicholas Wroe reports
fields.body:
Halfway through the opening ceremony of last year's Sydney Olympic Games, hundreds of huge, black-clad men with box-shaped heads entered Stadium Australia and began to dance around fountains of sparks and collapsible wooden huts. The crowd in the stadium went wild at the representation of legendary 19th-century outlaw Ned Kelly, but watching it all on television, the Australian author Peter Carey groaned.

Carey's novel, True History of the Kelly Gang, was due for publication in Australia a month later. It is an ambitious book that not only probes a key episode of Australian history, but also makes large claims for Kelly's importance to Australia's present. Carey has one of the witnesses to Kelly's final battle - the famous one where he wears the homemade armour - rhetorically ask at one point: "What is it about us Australians, eh? What is wrong with us? Do we not have a Jefferson? A Disraeli? Might not we find someone better to admire than a horse thief and a murderer?"

Carey's initial dismay at the representation of Kelly was based on a belief that the country was selling its Jefferson short. "Yes, when I first saw the Olympic thing I was a bit appalled," he says. "I thought the bucketheads and sparklers were unbelievably stupid and thoughtless and cheap. But I then saw the real point. So many Australians were pleased to see him there as part of the story."

Just as contentious as the suggestion that Kelly's legacy still shapes Australia was the fact that Carey was tackling the subject at all. He has lived in New York with his wife, theatre director Alison Summers, and their two sons, since the late 80s. To come back and tackle the nation's most potent myth was risky, and indeed, coverage of the book duly broke out of the arts ghetto and on to the news pages. "There was some bullshit controversy about me glorifying a murderer," he explains. "But it is bullshit. Most people don't feel that. Kelly was a popular hero at the time of his death and his reputation has been stable ever since. Only official Australia has always hated him."

Friend and fellow novelist Patrick McGrath was in Australia when the book was published. "It was clear he had breathed life into this iconic national figure and had aroused powerful antagonisms," says McGrath. "There were letters to the papers condemning his suggestion that Kelly was the Thomas Jefferson of Australia. That reaction indicated the statement was true, but also very troubling for Australians. That, in fact, a strand of their character could be traced back to a murderer and a thief who wound up on the gallows."

McGrath watched Carey reading to a packed hall at the Brisbane Writers' Festival. "His role was almost bardic in that he had articulated one of the great myths of this people. Here was an Australian author speaking directly to a large section of the Australian people about who they were. It is such a rare thing for a literary novelist to plug in like that."

"This was in Melbourne, and he was teaching someone else to drive at the time."

Even to his untrained ear, he was convinced that some people were speaking with home counties accents, and everyone was known by their surnames. "In the seven years I was there, no one ever called me Peter," he once recalled.

He says the class differences manifested themselves in several ways. "I had good friends at school whom I never saw in the holidays. The friends I did see were all the sons of solicitors or doctors in small towns. More my class." One of these boys was Peter Smalley, now a writer living in London. "Neither of us were part of that squatocracy - the equivalent to the English landed classes who founded the school - so we both felt to some extent excluded," says Smalley. "Peter was obviously a bright kid in the class, but in a school like that you get ahead by being sporty or part of the establishment, and he was never into all that." You have to shut off the more vulnerable side of yourself and if, for instance, you preferred books to sport, you had to repress an awful lot of your personality in order to survive."

He agrees with Smalley that being sent to the school was hugely traumatic, although for years he didn't admit it even to himself. "And what's worse is that very quickly, having survived in the posh place, you can't bear to go back to the place where you now think the people are impossibly vulgar. You get dislocated."

He says he was over 50 before he realised that his fiction was full of orphans, metaphorical and actual. The obvious larger historical and political point is Australia being the orphan of England. The same year he married his first wife, Leigh Weetman. Although his fiction closely draws on his experiences in terms of society and landscape, it rarely reads as being confessional or directly autobiographical. But he has published several pieces of personal reminiscence, one of which is about his delayed coming to terms with an abortion (then illegal) which Weetman had when she was 20 and he was 18. In the same piece he goes on to explain his regrets at not naming the three still-born children they had when they were later married. "I wish only that we had honoured those children with a plaque, a name," he wrote. "I will always wish that, for ever."

Most writers have hard-luck stories about early rejections, but Carey's are collectors' items. His second novel was first accepted and then rejected by a publisher in Australia, who sent it on to Victor Gollancz in London. Shortly afterwards Carey was travelling in Europe - he lived in London for a year in 1969 - and went to the Gollancz office. "I explained to the receptionist that Mr Gollancz had a manuscript of mine which he was going to publish. She asked me to wait a moment and when she came back a few minutes later she had the manuscript with her which she gave back to me. And that was that."

While living in London, he wrote a novel called Wog. "The title was contentious but that was the least of its problems," he says. The novel included blurry, photocopied pictures and notes written on cornflake boxes. "I vowed that these things were so essential to the book that I would never publish it without them. Then a respectable London publishers said they liked the book and wanted to know whether I would publish without all this stuff. I agonised for a long time and eventually said they could. Then, of course, they said no."

After these disappointments Carey returned to Australia in 1970 and decided to write short stories. It was an inspired tactical retreat. "After Wog, these stories began to work in a way that nothing had worked before. They felt like the first authentic things I had done."

Bruce Woodcock has written a critical study of Carey's work and says the early stories do read like an avant-garde writer coming into the mainstream. "He did read a lot of strange stuff in the 60s and 70s," says Woodcock. "He is still a novelist of ideas, but he learned to write wonderful narrative. With one or two exceptions the characters in the stories are less interesting than in the novels, but they have a real fizz and pizzazz to them." They also exhibit a political prescience. Woodcock says his story War Crimes predicted the move to global capitalism. "These hippie capitalists are sent to sort out a frozen-food depot in the desert. They take their job literally, and get their guns out and blow people away for not performing. He foresaw Thatcherism and Reaganism."

Carey was active on the left throughout the 70s and, although too old for the draft, was a leading member of the Vietnam Moratorium Committee, which he remembers as a family business run by an old Stalinist. "All my friends were communists, Maoists, Trotskyists. I talked for hours and really badly wanted to be converted, but never was, and I never joined a political party. But I was one of those idiots who thought the Cultural Revolution was a fantastic thing. It's embarrassing, particularly now I have met people who went through it all and endured it."

But he is always writing about the dispossessed or people who have been done over by forces of authority. He often gives voice to the voiceless, people who have no literary space. In Ned Kelly, every so often he lifts his eyes from the main story and gives you a picture of this whole people of Irish immigrants who have been brutalised and are struggling for some space and some reasonable way of life."

In 1973 Carey separated from Weetman. The following year his debut collection of short stories, The Fat Man in History, was published, and he began to live with the painter Margot Hutcheson. He got a job running the Grey advertising agency office in Sydney and moved with Margot to an alternative community at Yandina in Queensland. "For 18 months I worked flat out and then I moved to Queensland and worked one week in four. I really milked it." He says he kept his job secret from the rest of the community for quite a long time, but when they found out they were quite pleased that someone like him was working in advertising. "They were very pragmatic hippies."

Carey went on to own his own agency - for which he again worked part-time - and didn't really leave advertising until he moved to the US in 1989. For many years he played down his advertising career, but now acknowledges that it was important to him. "I think I felt socially embarrassed about advertising and would become defensive with my literary, leftwing friends. But for years I wrote every day and didn't worry if it sold or not. And I never really thought there was anything wrong with selling. My dad was a car salesman, after all." His best-known campaign was for Lindeman's wine, with the catchline: "You make us smile, Dr Lindeman."

In 1979 he published a second collection of stories in Australia, War Crimes, and a year later Faber & Faber published stories from both collections in the UK, in a volume confusingly also called The Fat Man in History. His first novel, Bliss, was published in 1981 and his reputation began to grow. In 1984 he and Margot were living in Bellingen, a bohemian neighbourhood near Sydney, when he was asked to work on an eco-political rock musical with performance artist Mike Mullins. Because of Carey's name, it attracted significant funding, but "they didn't want a writer because they didn't believe in writers," he recalls. "They asked me to construct a literary scaffolding for a play. That's where I met Alison. I fell in love and never went back to Bellingen." Things were further complicated, as Carey explains, when "Mike went off to comfort Margot."

He describes the eventual production as "like Springtime for Hitler, but working the way it was meant to work. For the first 30 seconds on the opening night you thought it might be all right." By the time the play had eventually been produced, Carey had published his second novel, Illywhacker. The rollicking journey through Australian history, as told by a 139-year-old conman, was shortlisted for the Booker prize, and Carey made the journey to London. "I'd never even read aloud so the thought of standing up in the Guildhall and speaking was terrifying," he remembers. "The only thing I could do to calm myself down was to imagine someone else winning. I wanted either Doris Lessing, because of her lifetime of work, or Keri Hulme [whose book The Bone People was the eventual and controversial winner] because the money would make a difference to her life."

Despite being shortlisted for the Booker, Carey still had no plans to give up the day job - or week-a-month job as it was by then. "Illywhacker is the type of book you only write once. It's a big, reckless sort of thing. When I saw how long it was I was surprised that anyone would publish it. I have a dilemma that I'm only interested in doing things that are risky, and then I'm always terrified of the risks. Illywhacker felt like a very big risk."

His follow-up was equally ambitious. Oscar and Lucinda came in at over 500 pages and this time won the Booker in 1988. It was an extremely strong year, with Salman Rushdie's Satanic Verses and Bruce Chatwin's last novel, Utz, also shortlisted. Blake Morrison was one of the judges. "Michael Foot was chairman and was a great fan of the Satanic Verses - this was pre-fatwa - but four of us had this special feeling for Oscar and Lucinda. It was about as unanimous as it gets with the Booker. Foot took it on the chin, and so did Salman Rushdie. People had accused him of behaving badly a few years previously when Coetzee had won, but he liked Carey, and liked the book, and was grace itself."

The prize elevated Carey to the front rank of writers and soon after he moved to New York. The typical story of clever Australians leaving to succeed? "Not really," says Carey. It was the generation before him that had to leave to have a career - Clive James, Germaine Greer. "You can date it quite precisely by the fact that they left by ship. There was nothing for them in that Australia, but for me it wasn't so bad. The early 70s had been a heady time for those on the left. The Labour government quickly recognised China and withdrew from Vietnam. People started coming home, as opposed to emigrating. In the arts, there were opportunities."

Which begs the question: why did he move? "Partly because it was possible," he says. "But I admit I never imagined it would go on this long. I used to say that coming here was a moral holiday. Then my son said to me one day that 'we bombed Iraq'. And I said, hang on a minute 'they' bombed Iraq, not us. But it made me think. I have two American kids. But I'm still having a good time and my wife works in the theatre here. Sooner or later, we will go, but I've stopped worrying about it."

Hermione Lee notes that Alison Summers plays an important part in his work. Carey thanks her for her "flawless dramatic instinct" in the acknowledgments for the latest book. "The fact she is a theatre director is crucial. His work is very dramatic and theatrical. He has a strong sense for a scene. In Ned Kelly there is a lot of dressing up, for instance, and Jack Maggs was a very theatrical novel. It's an important thing that comes out of that relationship."

When his next novel, The Tax Inspector, was published in 1991, Carey says it was "cutting-down-tall-poppy time". It is a bleak tale featuring violence and incest. "Everyone in Australia thought it was so dark because I lived in New York," he says, "but it grew out of Sydney. And this time they didn't choose, as they had with Illywhacker, to ignore what it criticised about Australia and take on what it celebrated."

Caryl Phillips, who lives part of the year in New York, says that the city has "freed him [Carey] from the critical scrutiny of Australia. That has been difficult for him sometimes. And there is a community of writers here; it's a cross-roads of writers from all over the world." Carey's 1994 novel, The Unusual Life of Tristan Smith, was widely seen as his most direct response to life in America. It was his biggest failure, albeit an ambitious and interesting one.

Bruce Woodcock admits that although he discussed Tristan Smith in his study of Carey, "I really didn't know what to make of it. I suspect it's a better novel than people gave it credit for, but I still haven't found a way of really talking about it, which I think is most people's problem. All the issues are there - it is a critique of Americanisation - but I'm not as happy with total fantasy as a form. He doesn't handle it as well as the historical novels with fantasy, like Jack Maggs or Oscar and Lucinda."

Since Tristan Smith, Carey has written a children's book, The Big Bazoohley, Jack Maggs, and now the Kelly book. "Jack Maggs isn't set in Australia but it is totally about Australia," he says, "so I suppose Ned Kelly does represent a relaxing about the fact that I can write an Australian book." Patrick McGrath says that Carey knew he was doing something important when he started the Kelly project. "He knew it was a big risk because he was moving in on this central iconic figure in the Australian consciousness. But he was also quietly excited because he suspected he had pulled off something great."

Carey came to the novel after seeing the series of Ned Kelly paintings - on which the Olympic opening ceremony characters were based - by the Australian artist Sidney Nolan at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York. "I tried to explain them to my friends, and in the process of telling the story to foreigners, I recognised what a wonderful story it was."

Julian Barnes praises Carey's "narrative power and exact ventriloquism" in the book. "At the very basic level it does what the best literature does. It convinces you that it was exactly like that. That this is how they lived and these were their mental and physical parameters. I didn't hear a single false beat."

The Kelly story has been featured in several novels in recent years, not to mention the Mick Jagger film - "a homage to the fast-forward button if ever there was one," laughs Carey. "I wanted to do something historians aren't allowed to do. How can you understand an important story without knowing the emotional state of the characters?"

He says that initially in Australia, people had little idea how hugely made-up his version was. "They saw it as much as history as literature. But there have been some more sophisticated readings of it, and a good reaction in Australia matters a lot. I have to write for a place, and Australia is my place. Australians read the book in a different way. They are passionately engaged and in the end it is theirs to love or to hate."

Life at a glance: Peter Philip Carey

Born: 7 May 1943.

Education: Bacchus Marsh State School 1948-53; Geelong Grammar School 1953-60; Monash University, Melbourne 1960-61. Family: married Leigh Weetman 1964 (separated 1973); married Alison Summers 1985, two sons - Sam, born 1986, Charley, born 1990. Career: Worked for ad agencies Walker Robertson Maquire, Grey, McSpedden Carey 1962-89.

Short stories: The Fat Man in History 1974; War Crimes 1979; Collected Stories 1995.

Film script: Until the End of the World 1992.

Children's: The Big Bazhooley 1995.

Novels: Bliss 1981; Illywhacker 1985; Oscar and Lucinda 1988; The Tax Inspector 1991; The Unusual Life of Tristan Smith 1994; Jack Maggs 1997; True History of the Kelly Gang 2001.

Prizes: New South Wales Premier's Award 1980; Miles Franklin Award and National Book Council Award 1982; Booker Prize 1988; Commonwealth Writers' Prize 1998.

Awards: Fellow of the Royal Society of Literature; Doctor of Letters, University of Queensland.

 True History of the Kelly Gang is published on 15 January by Faber & Faber at £16.99

But he is always writing about the dispossessed or people who have been done over by forces of authority. He often gives voice to the voiceless, people who have no literary space. In Ned Kelly, every so often he lifts his eyes from the main story and gives you a picture of this whole people of Irish immigrants who have been brutalised and are struggling for some space and some reasonable way of life." In 1973 Carey separated from Weetman. The following year his debut collection of short stories, The Fat Man in History, was published, and he began to live with the painter Margot Hutcheson. He got a job running the Grey advertising agency office in Sydney and moved with Margot to an alternative community at Yandina in Queensland. "For 18 months I worked flat out and then I moved to Queensland and worked one week in four. I really milked it." He says he kept his job secret from the rest of the community for quite a long time, but when they found out they were quite pleased that someone like him was working in advertising. "They were very pragmatic hippies." Carey went on to own his own agency - for which he again worked part-time - and didn't really leave advertising until he moved to the US in 1989. For many years he played down his advertising career, but now acknowledges that it was important to him. "I think I felt socially embarrassed about advertising and would become defensive with my literary, leftwing friends. But for years I wrote every day and didn't worry if it sold or not. And I never really thought there was anything wrong with selling. My dad was a car salesman, after all." His best-known campaign was for Lindeman's wine, with the catchline: "You make us smile, Dr Lindeman." In 1979 he published a second collection of stories in Australia, War Crimes, and a year later Faber & Faber published stories from both collections in the UK, in a volume confusingly also called The Fat Man in History. His first novel, Bliss, was published in 1981 and his reputation began to grow. In 1984 he and Margot were living in Bellingen, a bohemian neighbourhood near Sydney, when he was asked to work on an eco-political rock musical with performance artist Mike Mullins. Because of Carey's name, it attracted significant funding, but "they didn't want a writer because they didn't believe in writers," he recalls. "They asked me to construct a literary scaffolding for a play. That's where I met Alison. I fell in love and never went back to Bellingen." Things were further complicated, as Carey explains, when "Mike went off to comfort Margot." He describes the eventual production as "like Springtime for Hitler, but working the way it was meant to work. For the first 30 seconds on the opening night you thought it might be all right." By the time the play had eventually been produced, Carey had published his second novel, Illywhacker. The rollicking journey through Australian history, as told by a 139-year-old conman, was shortlisted for the Booker prize, and Carey made the journey to London. "I'd never even read aloud so the thought of standing up in the Guildhall and speaking was terrifying," he remembers. "The only thing I could do to calm myself down was to imagine someone else winning. I wanted either Doris Lessing, because of her lifetime of work, or Keri Hulme [whose book The Bone People was the eventual and controversial winner] because the money would make a difference to her life." Despite being shortlisted for the Booker, Carey still had no plans to give up the day job - or week-a-month job as it was by then. "Illywhacker is the type of book you only write once. It's a big, reckless sort of thing. When I saw how long it was I was surprised that anyone would publish it. I have a dilemma that I'm only interested in doing things that are risky, and then I'm always terrified of the risks. Illywhacker felt like a very big risk." His follow-up was equally ambitious. Oscar and Lucinda came in at over 500 pages and this time won the Booker in 1988. It was an extremely strong year, with Salman Rushdie's Satanic Verses and Bruce Chatwin's last novel, Utz, also shortlisted. Blake Morrison was one of the judges. "Michael Foot was chairman and was a great fan of the Satanic Verses - this was pre-fatwa - but four of us had this special feeling for Oscar and Lucinda. It was about as unanimous as it gets with the Booker. Foot took it on the chin, and so did Salman Rushdie. People had accused him of behaving badly a few years previously when Coetzee had won, but he liked Carey, and liked the book, and was grace itself." The prize elevated Carey to the front rank of writers and soon after he moved to New York. The typical story of clever Australians leaving to succeed? "Not really," says Carey. It was the generation before him that had to leave to have a career - Clive James, Germaine Greer. "You can date it quite precisely by the fact that they left by ship. There was nothing for them in that Australia, but for me it wasn't so bad. The early 70s had been a heady time for those on the left. The Labour government quickly recognised China and withdrew from Vietnam. People started coming home, as opposed to emigrating. In the arts, there were opportunities." Which begs the question: why did he move? "Partly because it was possible," he says. "But I admit I never imagined it would go on this long. I used to say that coming here was a moral holiday. Then my son said to me one day that 'we bombed Iraq'. And I said, hang on a minute 'they' bombed Iraq, not us. But it made me think. I have two American kids. But I'm still having a good time and my wife works in the theatre here. Sooner or later, we will go, but I've stopped worrying about it." Hermione Lee notes that Alison Summers plays an important part in his work. Carey thanks her for her "flawless dramatic instinct" in the acknowledgments for the latest book. "The fact she is a theatre director is crucial. His work is very dramatic and theatrical. He has a strong sense for a scene. In Ned Kelly there is a lot of dressing up, for instance, and Jack Maggs was a very theatrical novel. It's an important thing that comes out of that relationship." When his next novel, The Tax Inspector, was published in 1991, Carey says it was "cutting-down-tall-poppy time". It is a bleak tale featuring violence and incest. "Everyone in Australia thought it was so dark because I lived in New York," he says, "but it grew out of Sydney. And this time they didn't choose, as they had with Illywhacker, to ignore what it criticised about Australia and take on what it celebrated." Caryl Phillips, who lives part of the year in New York, says that the city has "freed him [Carey] from the critical scrutiny of Australia. That has been difficult for him sometimes. And there is a community of writers here; it's a cross-roads of writers from all over the world." Carey's 1994 novel, The Unusual Life of Tristan Smith, was widely seen as his most direct response to life in America. It was his biggest failure, albeit an ambitious and interesting one. Bruce Woodcock admits that although he discussed Tristan Smith in his study of Carey, "I really didn't know what to make of it. I suspect it's a better novel than people gave it credit for, but I still haven't found a way of really talking about it, which I think is most people's problem. All the issues are there - it is a critique of Americanisation - but I'm not as happy with total fantasy as a form. He doesn't handle it as well as the historical novels with fantasy, like Jack Maggs or Oscar and Lucinda." Since Tristan Smith, Carey has written a children's book, The Big Bazoohley, Jack Maggs, and now the Kelly book. "Jack Maggs isn't set in Australia but it is totally about Australia," he says, "so I suppose Ned Kelly does represent a relaxing about the fact that I can write an Australian book." Patrick McGrath says that Carey knew he was doing something important when he started the Kelly project. "He knew it was a big risk because he was moving in on this central iconic figure in the Australian consciousness. But he was also quietly excited because he suspected he had pulled off something great." Carey came to the novel after seeing the series of Ned Kelly paintings - on which the Olympic opening ceremony characters were based - by the Australian artist Sidney Nolan at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York. "I tried to explain them to my friends, and in the process of telling the story to foreigners, I recognised what a wonderful story it was." Julian Barnes praises Carey's "narrative power and exact ventriloquism" in the book. "At the very basic level it does what the best literature does. It convinces you that it was exactly like that. That this is how they lived and these were their mental and physical parameters. I didn't hear a single false beat." The Kelly story has been featured in several novels in recent years, not to mention the Mick Jagger film - "a homage to the fast-forward button if ever there was one," laughs Carey. "I wanted to do something historians aren't allowed to do. How can you understand an important story without knowing the emotional state of the characters?" He says that initially in Australia, people had little idea how hugely made-up his version was. "They saw it as much as history as literature. But there have been some more sophisticated readings of it, and a good reaction in Australia matters a lot. I have to write for a place, and Australia is my place. Australians read the book in a different way. They are passionately engaged and in the end it is theirs to love or to hate." Life at a glance: Peter Philip Carey Born: 7 May 1943. Education: Bacchus Marsh State School 1948-53; Geelong Grammar School 1953-60; Monash University, Melbourne 1960-61. Family: married Leigh Weetman 1964 (separated 1973); married Alison Summers 1985, two sons - Sam, born 1986, Charley, born 1990. Career: Worked for ad agencies Walker Robertson Maquire, Grey, McSpedden Carey 1962-89. Short stories: The Fat Man in History 1974; War Crimes 1979; Collected Stories 1995. Film script: Until the End of the World 1992. Children's: The Big Bazhooley 1995. Novels: Bliss 1981; Illywhacker 1985; Oscar and Lucinda 1988; The Tax Inspector 1991; The Unusual Life of Tristan Smith 1994; Jack Maggs 1997; True History of the Kelly Gang 2001. Prizes: New South Wales Premier's Award 1980; Miles Franklin Award and National Book Council Award 1982; Booker Prize 1988; Commonwealth Writers' Prize 1998. Awards: Fellow of the Royal Society of Literature; Doctor of Letters, University of Queensland.  True History of the Kelly Gang is published on 15 January by Faber & Faber at £16.99

webTitle: We're no net stock, Lynch insists

fields.headline: We're no net stock, Lynch insists
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Autonomy, the FTSE 100-listed Cambridge software developer, yesterday moved to distinguish itself from a swath of ill-starred internet businesses in an effort to stem the decline in its share price.
fields.body:
Autonomy, the FTSE 100-listed Cambridge software developer, yesterday moved to distinguish itself from a swath of ill-starred internet businesses in an effort to stem the decline in its share price.

In a short statement to the market, it said: "We have not experienced a slow-down in our overall revenue growth... Demand remains strong for Autonomy's products amongst a current and potential customer base."

The chief executive, Mike Lynch, said that 95% of the company's business was in providing database software to established and profitable bluechip clients including British Aerospace, Lucent, News Corporation, GlaxoSmithKline and Barclays. He said investment in internet-related business made up the remaining 5%.

Autonomy was expected to continue to record a growth rate of 20% to 25%, and had $130m in cash in its accounts, he said.

"There has been a lot of guilt by association, a lot of rumours in the market about Autonomy slowing down, which is completely untrue, so rather exceptionally we have taken the step of putting out a statement clarifying this," Dr Lynch said.

Shares in Autonomy surged 225p on the back of the announcement - making it the highest climber in the FTSE 100 index - despite no facts or figures from the company.

On Thursday, Autonomy's share price fell 7% after an analyst at ABN Amro drew a comparison with Inktomi, a US technology firm which had issued a profit warning. This prompted Dr Lynch to issue yesterday's statement.

Autonomy's share price had fallen from about £41 in November.

Darren Lauber, a technologies analyst at WestLB Panmure, said:

"The slow-down in the US, and particularly in companies' IT budgets, has panicked the market.

"But Mike Lynch is right to draw a distinction. There are some software investments which firms like to make in order to increase revenues, but others, like Autonomy products, are essential efficiency measures."

Deutsche Bank, Autonomy's house broker, said: "In the short term we strongly believe that the stock has been oversold."

webTitle: Filmgoing is back in the frame

fields.headline: Filmgoing is back in the frame
fields.standfirst: British cinemas notch up highest attendance since 1974
fields.trailText: British cinemas notch up highest attendance since 1974.
fields.body:
Films about the antics of toys, plasticine chickens, mice, mutants and an orphaned dinosaur helped pull the biggest crowds for more than a quarter of a century into British cinemas in 2000.

A largely "feelgood" diet of bland family entertainment angled towards the young attracted more than 143m people, according to provisional figures yesterday. Ticket sales between January and November were 2.2% up on last year and the trend is thought to have continued last month.

While only one British-made film, Billy Elliot, reached the top 10 in its own country, three others - Peter Lord and Nick Park's Chicken Run, Sam Mendes' American Beauty and Danny Boyle's The Beach - had British directors. The film-going public was higher than in any year since 1974 - shortly after the UK's long postwar cinema-going boom began to collapse under the assault of television. At its lowest, in 1984, admissions sank to 54m.

The figure comes from the Cinema Advertising Association, which monitors all UK cinema admissions. It confirms a recovery dating from the late 1980s and continued through the 1990s.

The force behind the recovery is that cinemas are recapturing their "lost" audiences of thirtysomethings.

People who began seeing films as youngsters in the 1980s have kept the habit according to Samantha Newsom, an association research executive

"That would probably not have happened 10 years ago," she said. "Also, 15- to 24-year-olds are still going in large numbers, despite all the other interests they have these days.

"You go with your mates, it's something you plan to do and, at an average ticket price of £4 a head, it's something you can still afford to do on a night when you can't afford to go clubbing."

The year's top five films were: 1. Toy Story 2 (US, with British gross takings of £43.5m): 2. Gladiator (US, £31m): 3. Chicken Run (UK-US, £29.3m): 4. American Beauty (US, £21.3m): 5. Stuart Little (US, £17.8).

For the British magazine Screen International yesterday, the big surprise was the success of Stuart Little, about "the adventures of a heroic and debonair mouse with human qualities".

It narrowly beat the hugely hyped, special effect-based Mission: Impossible 2 to fifth place. Among the other top five, Chicken Run - with an almost entirely British cast apart from Mel Gibson - is "a comedy escape drama with a touch of passion set on a sinister Yorkshire chicken farm in 1950s England".

Toy Story is about a toy called Woody who is stolen by a collector and rescued by his comrades Mr Potato Head and Slinky Dog. X-Men, in eighth place, is about the "high kinks" of mutant children. Dinosaur, in 10th, is the story of "an orphaned donosaur raised by lemurs after a meteorite shower".

In 1974 - the last time cinema attendance figures reached 143m - the top five was dominated by adult films. The films were 1. The Sting: 2. The Exorcist: 3. Bruce Lee's Kung Fu film Enter the Dragon 4. The Three Musketeers 5. Papillon.

In 1973 attendances were 142m - one of the first horrendous postwar drops on the 1972 figure of 163m.

Ms Newsom said that, while this year's top 10 films were mainly aimed at younger audiences, the rest of the list contained "a good solid core: of films aimed at older people".

The British trend runs counter to the US, where box office takings are reportedly 17% down on last year and critics have complained of "a relentless assault of lousy movies". Blockbusters such as The Perfect Storm were box office disappointments.

webTitle: Success puts Glastonbury party on hold

fields.headline: Success puts Glastonbury party on hold
fields.standfirst:
Safety concerns force organiser to take a year out from mammoth summer festival

Special report: Glastonbury 2000
fields.trailText: Safety concerns force organiser to take a year out from mammoth summer festival.
fields.body:
It has become an essential fixture of the British summer, as important as Wimbledon and more popular than Henley, Glyndebourne or Ascot.

But this year hundreds of thousands of music lovers must forgo their traditional summer celebration, for the Glastonbury festival has been scrapped due to safety concerns.

Just over 30 years after the first festival was held at his farm in Pilton, Somerset, Michael Eavis this week announced he was cancelling the mammoth weekend concert. He is facing prosecution by the local council after more than 15,000 fans sneaked into last year's event, which was already full with up to 100,000 ticket holders.

But what might have weighed more heavily on his mind is the spectre of Roskilde, the Danish festival where nine music fans died in a crush last year. He hopes that taking a year out will allow him to make the site fully secure and force gatecrashers to think about the consequences of their actions, discouraging them from freeloading in future.

Glastonbury is a victim of its own success, cancelled because it was simply too popular. Eavis has taken years off before, and Glastonbury's absence might not seem to matter when promoters are arranging more events than ever. Last year the public could choose from the Reading festival (twinned with one in Leeds), V2000 in Staffordshire and Chelmsford, T in the Park near Kinross in Scotland ,and dance events Creamfields and Homelands - not to mention old favourites such as the Fleadh in London and Womad.

But like many music lovers, Mark Beaumont of the music magazine NME predicts the cancellation will leave a "gaping chasm" in the festival calendar.

"Glastonbury's a lifestyle. Reading's just a big gig," he said.

"It has a kind of freedom. It's brilliant - you don't even have to see any bands; you can leave your office and call yourself Moonbeam and paint your face like a tiger and no one cares, and there has to be a place for that in society."

Strangely, the more festivals that appear, the more unusual Glastonbury seems: an event not driven wholly by corporate sponsorship, but by an individual's passion for music and a sense of community. It is many years since it was free, but even now profits go to charities such as Greenpeace instead of into the organiser's pocket.

Even rival Vince Power - head of the Mean Fiddler organisation and promoter of the Reading and Fleadh festivals - described the cancellation as "very disappointing".

"People go for more than just the music; it's an institution," he said. "Michael feels very passionately about the music; it is his baby, and I'm sure he will come back stronger next year."

Eavis has managed to avoid the increasingly heavy sponsorship which revellers complain kills the atmosphere of festivals. Carling backs Reading/Leeds, Virgin sponsors the V festivals, and Tennants is behind T in the Park.

Eavis has not totally spurned the corporate shilling - the Guardian is one sponsor and Orange paid for a relaxation area at Glastonbury last year, but the commercial activity is less relentless than elsewhere.

Tom Rowlands of the Chemical Brothers, who headlined the festival last year, summed up many people's feelings. "There's something different about it; it's not sanitised. It's not like the bands are wheeled on and wheeled off again. A good festival is not just about buying in a load of acts that you think will go together."

Mark Beaumont agreed. "It's unique in the range of its line-up. Reading usually sticks to two days of indie music and one day of metal. V goes for whoever's selling most records - it's fairly closed-minded and it's a shame, because a lot of the best records don't sell very much."

The rush to get big names also results in an astounding homogeneity at other events. Last year, three out of the four major festivals signed up Macy Gray, Ocean Colour Scene and Travis. The idea of festivals used to be that you had to be there: Monterey Pop and Woodstock in the late 1960s went down in history because so many people saw their idols for the first time. Now fans who miss their heroes one week can catch them in a different field the next.

Vince Power concedes: "The festival roster is overcrowded, there have been too many and there's huge competition. There are not enough artists for all the festivals."

But Glastonbury still man ages to book the likes of David Bowie and Burt Bacharach, despite its relatively low fees. The event's status and Eavis's personal commitment have ensured top names will waive their usual fees for the prestige of heading the bill.

"Bowie probably wouldn't play any other festival," Beaumont said. "It's probably the most famous festival in the world and people see it as a huge achievement to play there.

"The Mean Fiddler [in London] pay a lot more but people do Glastonbury because of its name and because they love it so much. They have a huge amount of respect for Michael Eavis because he built it up from scratch."

Glastonbury may be the only major festival to inspire such affection, but smaller counterparts are emerging, with disaffected indie kids spurning the mammoth weekenders for events such as All Tomorrow's Parties. Showcasing cult bands and staged in the relative comfort of a holiday camp at Camber Sands, East Sussex, it has proved so successful there are rumours the New York band Sonic Youth will stage an American version.

Up to 3,000 fans shell out £100 a throw and while the thought of exchanging muddy fields and canvas for a beach and chalets may help, the unique line-ups are a better draw.

"Camber Sands has a very alternative feel; it's as indie as indie can get," said Mark Beaumont.

"It's great they have that and I think it's a reaction against the big bucks feel of the major festivals."

But those who insist on waiting for their favourite festival need not fear; no one doubts Glastonbury will return next year, bigger and better than ever. Music industry insiders are already whispering that Madonna will headline in 2002.
