fields.headline: Attracted to a uniform career?
fields.standfirst: Millennial kids are more likely to join the forces
fields.trailText: Millennial kids are more likely to join the forces.
fields.body:
If you were sitting on two job offers - one from, say, Accenture (formerly Andersen Consulting) and another from the army - which would you choose? The vast majority of graduate job seekers would probably go for Accenture. In fact, 85% of general management graduates and a whopping 90% of IT graduates would prefer to risk their souls in a consultancy than their lives in the army.

The research that provided this statistic was commissioned by the army, but it highlights a problem faced by all the armed forces. The army, navy and the RAF, as well as the police (which to many people is now the fourth armed service) all need to hire people of the Accenture calibre. Getting hold of them however is proving increasingly difficult.

"The demographics are against us," concedes Chris Allender, head of corporate recruitment at the Metropolitan Police. "Jobs are becoming more demanding and society more complex, which means that organisations are competing for the diminishing pool of high quality graduates capable of doing them. In the case of the services there are other cultural factors at work. There has, for example, been a movement throughout the western world away from uniformed organisations."

"Graduate officer recruitment has been a challenge in the past few years," agrees a spokesperson for the Royal Navy, "as it has been for many other organisations. The core functionality of the armed forces, the structure and discipline required, is at odds with young people's lives. We are unable to change this because a more relaxed, unstructured approach will not produce the people who can function in the most stressful situations. But it should not be forgotten that there are groups of people who thrive in a more structured environment."

The shift away from the armed forces is a result of cultural change. Society is more egalitarian and in most sectors discrimination on the grounds of race, sexual orientation or gender is on the run.

However, accusations of institutional racism, an in-built gender imbalance which derives in part from differences in strength and endurance, and the difficulty the forces have in dealing with homosexuality have created a perception that the services do not share the new, more egalitarian world order.

Secondly, concepts such as self-sacrifice and service are themselves difficult to sustain in an intellectual environment dominated by post-modernism. Being prepared to die for your beliefs now looks like the result of either indoctrinated insanity or a quaint old-fashioned naivety.

"Queen and country is now very low on the list of reasons for people joining," accepts the Royal Navy. "The old elite retains these beliefs, but people joining today are much more likely to be motivated by less selfless considerations."

You may not be asking what you can do for their country. But consider what your country's armed forces could do for you The army identifies four key factors. Well for starters, there is the active outdoors lifestyle. Apart from professional sportsmen and women, no other profession offers you so much money for breathing fresh air and playing games. It's only when the bullets start flying that things get serious.

Then there is the opportunity to test yourself in the most challenging environments humanity has to offer. Once you've served in Belfast or the Balkans, few other places can cause you much trepidation. There is genuine variety in employment and location, and finally there is the training and opportunity for advancement.

The forces used to be perceived as a career dead-end, but with leadership now one of the key attributes in successful management, the forces are acknowledged to be a stepping stone to many other opportunities.

While the alternative lifestyle the services offer will only ever appeal to a tiny minority of graduates, there are signs that the demographics are about to change.

"We have just completed some research into this," says Lieutenant Colonel Jonathan Howard of the Army Training and Recruitment Agency, "and the generation born after 1982 are going to be different. We are calling them the 'millennial kids', and we expect them to be less bolshy and cynical than 'generation X'. They're likely to be more patriotic in a general cultural sense, and this gives us cause for optimism."

So, if you feel yourself strangely attracted to a career in uniform, don't worry. You may be a precursor of a generational shift in fashion rather than an oddity. The loose-fit culture that has dominated the past decade-and-a-half may be about to change.

fields.headline: Moving on up
fields.standfirst: An ABC guide to  keeping New Year resolutions
fields.trailText: An ABC guide to keeping New Year resolutions.
fields.body:
A. Wait loss
That's it, we've turned the corner, the days are getting longer and there's a whole new year to go at. Regardless of whether that exhilarates or depresses you, now is a good time to review your career plans - or think about making some. Take a fresh look at how you want your working life to shape up this year. Resolve first of all not to be passive. Nothing comes to those who simply wait. It's up to you to generate the energy and enthusiasm to create opportunities.

B. Train times
Measure the gap between what you'd really like to be doing and what you're actually involved in. The larger that is, the more urgent the need to investigate ways of bridging it. Additional training is a good starting point; it works well for both minor adjustments and complete overhauls. Don't allow yourself to make excuses about time or cost - if it's important enough there's always a way. Succeeding at learning something new will give you the confidence to believe you can make major alterations.

C. Dream ticket
If you're feeling restricted by realities, think laterally. The constraints that keep you in a job that's going nowhere or taking over your life are made by you. A cut in salary will not mean starvation and a year's travelling or voluntary work will enhance rather than damage your employment prospects. A sideways move or complete change of career could be the best investment you can make in your future.

webTitle: Help: I don't want to go back to work!

fields.headline: Help: I don't want to go back to work!
fields.trailText: Facing up to the post-Christmas blues.
fields.body:
I was really thrown in at the deep end when I started my new job six weeks ago. Only the prospect of the Christmas break kept me going, but having time off has left me feeling I don't want to go back.
TR, public relations consultant, Brighton

The period before Christmas is often frantic. Everyone behaves as if the world is about to end rather than just have a few days holiday. Chances are you'll be returning to a much calmer set up, so at least go back and see.

You've survived so far and that should give you confidence. New jobs get easier with time - the first run through any cycle of activities is full of the unexpected and perplexing.

One of the good things about working on something spectacularly difficult is that when you revert to more normal

activities they feel really easy. The ideal is a balance between the excitement of being almost out of your depth and periods of calm. Without the odd respite you can end up going under, but when life is quiet and predictable, that's dull. You need to experience both to fully appreciate either. If things are no better, ask for help. An easy mistake to make is working so hard at creating the impression of coping that no-one realises you're in difficulty.

Be clear about the assistance you need. Is it a reduced workload, more support, a clearer definition of your role or additional training? It's in their interest to ensure you don't sink and disappear.

Make sure the distress signals you send are not misinterpreted as a friendly wave. If your bid for help is ignored, that's the time to quit.

But try it first.

 Contact Irene Krechowiecka at ijk@excite.com

fields.headline: Cool companies
fields.standfirst: No 47 Codemasters
fields.trailText: No 47 Codemasters.
fields.body:
No, this firm has nothing to do with number crunching for state security services or deciphering encrypted communications from spooks in far flung places. Codemasters develops and publishes video games for Sony, Nintendo and Sega consoles as well as PCs. Established in 1986 by Richard and David Darling, Codemasters has accumulated a wealth of experience and impressive portfolio of best-selling games including Colin McRae Rally, Brian Lara Cricket, Micro Machines, and TOCA 2.

As a measure of the firm's consistent record of success, Codemasters games have spent 878 weeks at the number one spot in the UK charts and scored more than 60 No.1 hits across Europe. Now the challenge is for Codemasters to grow its reach and reputation into the global marketplace. The company claims to have the corporate flexibility to adapt in what is a notriously fickle and evolving marketplace. Its new media department, for example is developing the business and gaming opportunities from emerging internet technology. However, the firm's popularity among games players is founded on an understanding of what players actually want - and the ability to create that experience.

Last month Codemasters picked up a Queen's Award for Enterprise in the innovation category. Specific innovations highlighted by the award, which honours managers and workers alike, included the creation of "dynamic node skeletons" which enabled designers to generate characters with lifelike movement as seen in recent titles like Prince Naseem Boxing (PlayStation). The company was also praised for using car telemetry data to accurately recreate the engine and performance characteristics of real racing cars in games like Touring Car and Colin McRae Rally series (PlayStation and PC).

Codemasters employs more than 380 staff in its 140-acre headquarters in Leamington Spa and offices in the USA, France, Germany, Spain and Holland. Its purpose-built HQ will eventually accommodate more than 600 employees.

Not surprisingly, competition for positions within the firm is fierce - last year it received more than 8,000 applications of which 1,000 were invited for interviews and just 70 were hired.

Artists need at least a 2.1 in a relevant degree, an "outstanding portfolio" and experience of 2D and 3D software packages. In return the firm offers starting salaries of between £16,000 and £18,000 according to experience, and an individually tailored training scheme with mentor to guide you along your chosen career path.

To apply, send a CV and covering letter with showreel, disk or other work examples to: Stephen Harrison-Mirfield, Recruitment Manager, Codemasters, PO Box 6, Leamington Spa, Warwickshire, CV47 2DL.

webTitle: How to... listen to music at work

fields.headline: How to... listen to music at work
fields.standfirst: Organise a play list that suits everyone's mood and taste
fields.trailText: Organise a play list that suits everyone's mood and taste.
fields.body:
As the great Bard once said: "Music makes the people come together. Music makes the bourgeoisie and the rebel..." And I think it was the newly-wed queen of pop, Mrs Ritchie, who wrote: "If music be the food of love, play on." Or was it the other way round?

Music has been society's gel since time immemorial. Now, new research reveals that it's also taking over the workplace. The study, conducted by the Future Foundation for Startle, a specialist in the digital delivery of music, found that more than half (54%) the UK working population listens to music while they do their jobs. Men are more tuneful in their work than women - 61% won't work in silence, compared with 41% of women.

And by far the biggest music lovers are 16 to 24-year olds: eight in 10 of them admit to listening to music during their working day.

Why are employees whistling while they work? One in four of those questioned in the survey claimed it made them more productive and two-fifths said music made it easier to concentrate on their work.

There may be some truth in this. Psychologists have suggested that music can have a beneficial effect on workplace performance - though evidence remains scarce. The so-called 'Mozart effect' has becoming a booming industry in the US after it was found that playing Mozart to children raised their IQs and stimulated their mental development. State-funded schools in Florida are now legally required to play classical music.

Adrian North, lecturer in psychology at Leicester University, says the latest research shows that music does indeed have an effect on workers, affecting both morale and productivity: "If employees like the music that's being played, it improves morale," he explains. "But if they don't like the music, it's no better - or even worse - than silence."

The effect of music on productivity is more complex, says Adrian: "If you're doing dull and repetitive tasks, music makes you more alert and improves your productivity. However, if you're doing tasks which require thought and analysis, music has a detrimental effect. That's because the brain, like a computer, can only deal with so much at the same time. If you overload it, it crashes."

Whether or not your boss allows music in your office usually comes down to individual company policy and the nature of your profession. "Background music changes the atmosphere in workplaces, making them more informal, light-hearted places," says chartered psychologist Martin Lloyd-Elliott.

The latest dance track may get creative juices flowing in an advertising design studio, but probably won't be seen as appropriate in a corporate environment.

What if you can't stand the choice of music in your workplace? Last month, Slade and Wizzard's Christmas anthems were banned from Dixon's in-store playlist, after staff and shoppers said the songs were "too annoying". The Startle survey reveals that squabbles over music selections can dent camaraderie. One in 10 offices - a significant minority - are brought to a daily halt when colleagues quarrel about which tunes to play. After all, one man's Robbie Williams is another man's Poison.

The solution: democratic compromise. "The office should organise a rota system, where each day, everyone gets to play their choice of music - or have periods of silence," suggests Adrian. "I have seen this work well in workplaces."

Andrew Ross, a designer in a music company, says his office used to receive regular complaints from the marketing department next door about the cacophony of noise generated by the CD players on everybody's desk (a dozen of them).

"We resolved it by allowing one person to choose the communal music each day," he recalls. "Everyone else had to listen to their own selection on a personal stereo. It made the working environment far calmer and the suits in marketing left us alone."

But some of us - myself included - find it impossible to work with any background noise. Stick in a CD and my working day becomes no more productive (though I'd like to think a little more tuneful) than a karaoke night at the local pub. According to Adrian, introverts can't tolerate musical stimulation because their resting brains already work at a fast rate. Extroverts need outside stimulation to rev up their brains.

"I would encourage people to be assertive about their right to work in a peaceful environment," says Martin. "I have worked with people who persuaded their team not to listen to music at all. Although they resisted at first, when the decision was enforced everybody welcomed it and admitted it helped them work."

If you don't remember anything else...

Like it or not, music looks set to become a permanent fixture. The research predicts that by 2010, two in five people will be listening to music while they work.

fields.headline: News
fields.trailText: Responsibility points | Graduates of the week | If you've got it, flaunt it
fields.body:
Responsibility points
Job-hunters are placing increasing importance on the ethical and environmental stances of employers, according to new research from the Industrial Society. Its survey found 82% of people would not work for an organisation whose values they did not believe in and 99% said they cared about whether an employer acted responsibly or not.

Graduates of the week
A pizza firm is claiming to employ the "upper crust" of workers after discovering that one of its stores is manned by three staff with PhDs. The trio work full-time preparing food at a Domino's Pizza in Cardiff. "We must surely have the highest ratio of doctorates to total employees of any company in the country," boasts a spokesman.

If you've got it, flaunt it
Men show off their mobile phones to impress women - and it works. Researchers at Liverpool University had previously found men like to flaunt their phones in public. But their latest research suggests women are more likely to seek relationships with such show-offs.

Flex your muscle: It's official: flexible working works! A survey of almost 200 flexible workers in senior jobs found that 70% had a higher level of output than traditional full timers. The study, presented at the British Psychological Society's conference in Winchester, showed that more than two thirds of executives who shared their job had a 30% higher output.

Stress mess: Chain-smoking workers who blame their habit on stress may be deluding themselves. Dr Rob Briner of Birkbeck College in London says employees are being given inaccurate information about stress. "Everybody gets a bit depressed about their work sometimes but that doesn't mean that they're suffering from stress," he says.

Flagging optimism: The Welsh are the biggest worriers about earnings while East Anglians are more concerned with self-improvement, according to a survey by recruitment website reed.co.uk. The study of workers reveals that careers are the top priority for change in 2001 with three in five Britons say they intend moving their careers forward this year.

Tip of the week

Try the business card CV: Fortune magazine suggests that for movers and shakers who do their career-advancement networking at conferences, a business card CV might be just the ticket. During the self- introduction and handshake, the ubiquitous business card is exchanged - but the flip side features a brief but impressive history of past company affiliations, job titles, and achievements. The business card CV puts your contact information and tantalising background info into the hands of potential employers. Futher details can then be sent on a traditional CV and covering letter.

webTitle: Get your career up and running

fields.headline: Get your career up and running
fields.standfirst: Leave the rut behind in 2001
fields.trailText: Try Rise's "Get out of a Rut" quiz to see if, in the New Year, it's time to find a new career.
fields.body:
The first week of January can be, in office terms at least, one of the most drearily depressing of the year. The whole indulgence-fest that is Christmas is over and suddenly you're suited and booted, back behind a desk and all the problems and insecurities that you left behind in 2000 come popping out of the filing cabinet.

But will the disaffection disappear after a few days - or is it something deeper? Try Rise's "Get out of a Rut" quiz to see if, in the New Year, it's time to find a new career.

1. On a weekday morning do you:

a) Spring out of bed, slip into a clean, ironed suit, down a glass of freshly squeezed juice and arrive at the office bright and early. (10 pts)

b) Stagger out of bed, pull on yesterday's suit, buy a chocolate croissant to cheer yourself up and arrive five minutes late. (5 pts)

c) Sleep through the alarm, hit the snooze button four times, pull on any old clothes and turn up at the office half an hour late. (0 pts)

2. You're given responsibility for a new project. Do you:

a) Groan. Why couldn't they have given it to someone who wanted it? (0 pts)

b) Feel really pleased. It's a compliment and makes you feel more confident about your abilities. (5 pts)

c) Look unsurprised. You've put in the extra hours, worked really hard and deserve it. (10 pts)

3. You meet someone at a party. When they ask you about your job do you:

a) Shift from foot to foot, mutter something about work being the curse of the drinking classes and head to the bar. (0 pts)

b) Launch enthusiastically into a monologue about your brilliant career and not stop until you realise the room has emptied. (10pts)

c) Explain briefly what you do, trying to make it sound as interesting as possible, before asking the same question of them. (5 pts)

4. If you could, what aspect of your job would you change?

a) Get rid of all the admin. And a four day week would be nice. (5 pts)

b) Get my own office rather than be in the open plan area - enabling me to concentrate more, have less interruptions and increase my productivity. (10 pts)

c) There are so many things about my job that I would like to change, I couldn't define just one. (0 pts)

5. There's an internal promotion going. Do you:

a) Not bother going for it. You've tried twice before and failed both times, so what's the point? (0 pts)

b) Get the application form and leave it on the coffee table. You're definitely going to apply, of course. It's just getting round to it. (5 pts)

c) Apply straight away, using an extra sheet of A4 to explain all the reasons why you are suitable for the job. (10 pts)

6. How do you spend your evenings in the week?

a) Either in the pub, trying to blot out the horror of having to go to work again tomorrow or asleep in front of the TV. (0 pts)

b) I work late, get home exhausted, shove a ready meal in the microwave and fall into bed. I mean to see friends in the week but somehow never have time. (10 pts)

c) I go to the gym, see some friends, or watch a video. I try and relax and forget about work. (5 pts)

7. Does the idea of doing your boss's job make you feel?

a) Excited. It's something I am striving for - more power, responsibility and money. (10 pts)

b) Anxious. Although I think it's what I want, I'm unsure about dealing with that level of responsibility. (5 pts)

c) Suicidal. More paperwork, more time in the office, more meetings. Frankly the whole idea makes me feel sick. (0 pts)

8. How do you think your colleagues perceive you?

a) Hardworking, conscientious and reliable. (10 pts)

b) Fairly competent, cheerful and hopefully easy-going. (5 pts)

c) Good for a laugh and always up for a lunchtime drink. (0 pts)

9. Do you think your current job has changed you?

a) I take work a bit more seriously these days, am perhaps less likely to get drunk on a school night, but hope I haven't changed as a person. (5 pts)

b) I used to think I'd really achieve something special. I don't believe that any more - now it feels like an achievement just to make it into the office. (0 pts)

c) I never seem to have any time any more - and I am quite stressed. But I enjoy my work and have friends in the office. (10 pts)

10. Ideally, where do you see yourself in five years time?

a) Probably in the same field that I'm in now, perhaps freelance or working more flexible hours - hopefully in a higher position. (5 pts)

b) Doing something completely different - I just wish I knew what. (0 pts)

c) Definitely in the same industry, either running my own company or at an extremely high level. (10 pts)

How healthy is your career?

0-35 pts

It's pretty clear that your job is not making you happy. Everyone has off-days, but you seem to be having an off-career. Take a good look at your working life - if it makes you depressed, demotivated or disappointed then it's time to make a change. Start talking - and thinking - about it. Check out job ads, websites, talk to friends about the jobs they do. Once you've realised that you're in a rut, you're half-way to getting out of it.

35-70 pts

Like most people, you are relatively satisfied with your job - but things could be better. Although you may be happy in your chosen field, you may be stuck in a rut with your present job. Examine what parts of your job you don't enjoy, what frustrates you, what you resent - and talk to your boss or someone in HR about how to improve those areas. And then consider what you could do better, what areas you could improve in, start working on them and take control in 2001!

70-100 pts

You're obviously fortunate enough to love your job and be happy in nearly all aspects of your working life. However, it is worth remembering that life isn't just about work - in order to be most productive in the workplace you need to have interests outside of it as well. You may be in a routine of over-working, so loosen up a little and remember that the office has a social side too.

fields.headline: Top rung/Bottom rung
fields.trailText: Two employees of Fish Design share their experience from either end of the career ladder.
fields.body:
Top rung

Julian Jordan
Aged 31
Director
Fish Design

A year as a band photographer "nearly starved" Julian Jordan who, after doing shoots of groups like The Lemontrees, Sham 69 and Soul Asylum, went on to be a rostrum cameraman for a presentation agency in London.

CV to date: He developed the agency's multimedia studio working on accounts as diverse as Nestlé, Gallagher, Barclays, Mirror Group, P& O Shipping and the British Navy. He became an assistant photographer and then a Unix presentation operator in 1990. He was instrumental in the design of CD-roms for London Underground. Then came his own business, Fish Design, founded in 1991 with Stephen Peaple.

"Fish is a multi-faceted agency and is in the unusual position of having grown from a dual base of technology and design but now encompassing branding, identity, advertising, publishing and print."

Best moment: "The high point was winning a three-way pitch for the Blockbuster Video interactive account in the first year."

The buzz? "The continuing development of technology and the myriad applications for our developments - along with working with some very talented people."

Bottom rung

Wayne McManus
Aged 24
Senior web developer
Fish Design

Wayne McManus has proved that swimming against the tide is a great way to find yourself a good career. He cut his own deal with Fish Design and backs the idea of working for a smaller company.

With a degree in business studies and human resource management from Middlesex University he became interested in the internet and went on to take a masters in interactive computer systems.

He worked for Blockbusters Video to fund his course and travel. When he had to look for a work placement he checked out the Blockbusters website and got in touch with Fish.

"I got their details, sent a CV and then negotiated the package via email. I met the two partners just before my placement began and we all seemed happy.

"The partners took me on initially to help out with various websites but as my understanding of the internet grew, my competence increased. After my three month placement, Fish offered me a job."

Ambition? "To keep on learning and eventually to run my own commercial site and/or company."

Tip to others: Consider working for some of the less obvious players in the market.

fields.headline: In the line of hire
fields.trailText: Robin O'Donovan, team leader for sales recruitment specialist Evolution.
fields.body:
Name: Robin O'Donovan

Status: Team leader for sales recruitment specialist Evolution.

Past: European business and Spanish degree from University of Buckingham. Took a job in Montpellier in France as marketing executive for a medical company selling ultra-sound equipment. Returned to England to work as recruitment consultant for TSA Human Resources. Appointed team leader when TSA created Evolution.

Present: Manages eight recruitment consultants who develop new client business and source quality graduates to match those clients' needs. Interviews and assesses graduates on clients' behalf.

Future: "Increase team to 20 by end of the year and become associate director of Evolution within 18 months. Ultimately I want to run my own recruitment firm."

Strengths: "Determined, focused, able to think very well on my feet and inspire and motivate other people."

Weaknesses: "Not quite as organised as I could be."

Wisdom: "Make sure you achieve something from each hour and each day that you work."

References: www.evolution-tsa.co.uk.

webTitle: No strings attached to my gifts, peer insists

fields.headline: No strings attached to my gifts, peer insists
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: When Lord Haskins, the amiable chair of Northern Foods and the government's red tape tsar, decided to donate to Labour, he did so with no hope of becoming a working peer.
fields.body:
When Lord Haskins, the amiable chair of Northern Foods and the government's red tape tsar, decided to donate to Labour, he did so with no hope of becoming a working peer.

A life-long supporter of the party, the 63-year-old has contributed for 25 years, bestowing £5,000 in each of the past five years with the exception of 1997, when he gave £13,000 to fight the election.

"A lot of people give to Labour. I just see myself as a slightly richer lifelong Labour supporter," he said.

"The Labour party is one of about 10 or 15 things I support - I give a similar amount to Oxfam, for instance - and I don't expect any back payments.

"Certainly no one suggested that I would do so, and the peerage thing I've always found slightly embarrassing."

Lord Haskins, who was made a peer in 1998, has given the exact amount which ensures that his identity is revealed, and did son, in part, to avoid later allegations of cronyism. "I think it's better if you don't make a secret of things: people have said I should have given £4,500 and then I wouldn't be listed, but that cloak-and-dagger stuff is not really me."

He backs the new rules. "Genuine transparency is a good thing, and will avoid accusations of cronyism."

And he refuses to be critical of Labour accepting £2m or £1m sums from the likes of Lords Sainsbury and Hamlyn, describing them as "highly principled people - idealists, philanthropists".

Talk about it
Should political donors be named?

webTitle: Pressure on Blair to cap cash gifts to parties

fields.headline: Pressure on Blair to cap cash gifts to parties
fields.standfirst:
Labour unease at increasing links with big business

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Labour unease at increasing links with big business.
fields.body:
Pressure was growing on Tony Blair last night to accept the need for a cap on donations to political parties - possibly at £100,000 - in response to concern that his ministers are too close to business donors such as the property developer Robert Bourne.

It was confirmed yesterday that Mr Bourne, head of the £125m Legacy consortium bid to buy the Millennium Dome, paid the third instalment of his £100,000 contribution to Labour funds about the time last November when Legacy succeeded Nomura as the government's "preferred bidder" for the Greenwich site.

Aides to Mr Bourne, who is the frontman for an investment largely provided by the Dublin-based Treasury Holdings group, point out that the donation was made public and that the three-stage payment was arranged well in advance of Legacy's dome connection.

But the suspicious view taken of all major donations to Labour and Conservative coffers means that voters and party activists are quick to accuse their rivals of trading influence for large cheques.

Not even the ultra-clean reputations of all three of Labour's newly disclosed £2m donors - Lords Sainsbury and Hamlyn, and publisher, Christopher Ondaatje - is likely to stem ill-ease within Labour ranks.

MPs and activists believe that the shift from grassroots funding to big money philanthropists, however disinterested, is an unhealthy one. "No one should be said to have excessive influence in this way," an MP said last night. Another MP, ex-minister Peter Kilfoyle, said: "It will raise questions as to how much weight will be added to their voice in the highest councils of the party when they are able to contribute such huge amounts to election funds."

Media attention on Mr Bourne and his wife, Sally Greene, has been accentuated this week by the revelation that weeks after Peter Mandelson returned to the cabinet in October 1999 they staged an impromptu party for his 46th birthday at their Chelsea home.

Innuendo in some newspapers suggested that Mr Mandelson, no longer "dome secretary", must have influenced Legacy's progress to preferred bidder status - though, in reality, it was the result of Nomura's cold feet. Even the Daily Telegraph admitted yesterday that the Northern Ireland secretary was guilty of nothing more serious than social climbing.

But senior Labour MPs, including Clive Soley, newly reelected chairman of the Parliamentary Labour Party, are concerned that the party leadership go further in being open about the sources of the £25m a year it now needs to run a campaigning central team.

MPs differ as to how best to proceed. Mr Soley believes that ministers should allow small donors - below £5,000 - to "check off" their donation for tax purposes in the American style. It is a reform which the Conservatives also want to see and Labour rejected because it suspected the Tories would benefit most.

Other senior Labour backbenchers, including Tony Wright, chairman of the public administration select committee, David Winnick and Andrew Mackinlay, want to accept the one key recommendation of the Nolan/Neill reforms of conduct in public life which they initially rejected: the cap on individual donations, possibly around £100,000 some MPs argue.

Labour rightly claims to have pioneered acceptance of most Nolan reforms, including the naming of major donors by law from February 16. The Liberal Democrats want to go further in accepting state funding of parties, something which divides Labour and angers the Tories.

Both parties are braced for a formal cap on overall election spending this year at £15m to £20m - "an end to the arms race" which cost each side £25m in 1997.

But that will require a "gentleman's agreement" not to overspend before the starter's gun is fired, probably in late March.

Mr Mandelson's attendance at the Bourne birthday party roused the Daily Mail to fury yesterday. Tory MPs said they would be asking him to explain if he reported the event to his permanent secretary or the MPs' register of interests.

Those attending confirm it was a Mandelson birthday party for 20 or 30 people, mostly friends outside the political world. But even the minister's enemies were hard-pressed to say what exactly he had done wrong. Talk of the guests being "very establishment" may be more aspirational than actual, some said.

Talk about it
Should political donors be named?

Labour party
Committee on standards in public life

webTitle: New Labour revives old tradition of courting rich

fields.headline: New Labour revives old tradition of courting rich
fields.standfirst:
Political donations

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Political donations
fields.body:
In the run-up to the 1997 general election, Tony Blair was obsessed with raising money, fearful that the Tories would outspend Labour and convinced that lack of cash had been one reason Neil Kinnock had gone down to defeat five years earlier.

Indeed, persuading New Labour's rich friends to part with substantial cheques for the party or its leaders' network of trusts effectively became his chief of staff, Jonathan Powell's, main job.

The Labour leader was determined to reposition the party as "pro-business" and distance it from the trade unions, which had long provided most of Labour's income. Union funding remained a focus of political controversy and the rising Blairite star Stephen Byers famously floated the prospect of a complete rupture of Labour's links with the unions at a fish supper in Blackpool.

Four years on, the prime minister's efforts have paid off handsomely. With three £2m donations from former Tory and Social Democratic Party backers signed off in the past few months, Labour is fast overtaking the Tories - who had six donations of between £2m and £3m in the run-up to 1997 - as the favoured vehicle of wealthy political influence-brokers. The issue of union funding is to all intents and purposes off the political agenda.

The big Labour-affiliated unions were yesterday content to have their own financial backing for the party - likely to be close to £10m for the coming general election campaign - out of the spotlight for a change. "All the embarrassment has come from New Labour's ham-fisted efforts to obtain money from the private sector", said a senior official.

Rows over New Labour sleaze and influence-peddling involving rich businessmen can have positive spin offs for the unions, showing their transparent and democratic funding role in a more positive light. "So long as everything is open and above board and people are genuinely committed to the aims and ideals of the party, we don't see any reason why these people shouldn't be allowed to contribute money to support the party," a GMB spokesman said yesterday of the Labour's newly-revealed donors.

Others in the party are less relaxed about the ever-growing political leverage they believe is enjoyed by Labour's rich new friends - and the latest disclosures about the donations from Robert Bourne, whose consortium is poised to buy the Millennium Dome, will only intensify that anxiety.

From the days of Ramsay MacDonald's dalliances with duchesses to Harold Wilson's coteries of businessmen, there is a long-established tradition of Labour leaders courting the wealthy. But under Tony Blair, the process has gone far further and is widely seen as reflecting an accelerated Americanisation of Britain's political culture.

With corporate donations to the Tories falling away, both parties are, according to a recent report from the union-backed Labour Research Department, "increasingly reliant on wealthy individuals for cash as politics turns into a rich person's game". Clive Soley, chairman of the parliamentary Labour Party, said last night that both MPs and ordinary members were "unhappy and uncomfortable" with the growing reliance on large business donations.

"I'm not saying that rich people can't have a social conscience and they're only doing it for their own sleazy reasons and I haven't heard anyone saying we should hand it back. But there is certainly concern about it."

Mr Soley, along with some other Labour figures, says he is now attracted to state funding for political parties or tax breaks for small donors as a way of saving the party from sinking into an increasingly sleazy political culture.

Although new rules will next month set a new spending limit for general election spending and require all donations over £5,000 to be declared, there is little expectation that these changes will by themselves solve the problem.

Labour is also concerned that tax breaks for small donors would favour the Tories' generally better-off supporters. But many Labour and trade union figures remain strongly opposed to state funding as an alternative to the party's current success with its new billionaire chums, citing public hostility and the German experience of state funding combined with private sleaze.

webTitle: New strain on peace process as Maginnis quits

fields.headline: New strain on peace process as Maginnis quits
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The Northern Ireland peace process braced itself for further strain yesterday when the Ulster Unionist MP Ken Maginnis announced he intended to step down.
fields.body:
The Northern Ireland peace process braced itself for further strain yesterday when the Ulster Unionist MP Ken Maginnis announced he intended to step down, sparking fears of a succession battle between the pro and anti-Good Friday agreement factions of his party.

Mr Maginnis, 62, MP for Fermanagh/South Tyrone and one of the staunchest allies of the UUP leader, David Trimble, is to leave Westminster after 18 years at the next election. He said he would remain active in politics, however.

The two most likely contestants for his seat are on opposite wings. The solicitor and UUP vice-chairman, James Cooper, who was Mr Maginnis's election agent, is a Trimbleite. Arlene Foster, a lawyer who works for Mr Cooper in Enniskillen, is against the Belfast peace accord and supports the dissident Lagan Valley MP, Jeffrey Donaldson.

Both said they were actively considering running for selection. The constituency association will vote to agree a candidate on January 29.

Mr Trimble is under pressure from rebels such as Mr Donaldson, who may call a meeting of the party's ruling council to try to force him to pull out of power-sharing with Sinn Fein over the issue of decommissioning.

The yes/no split on the 860 ruling council members is very close, but six of the party's nine MPs are anti-agreement, and the possibility of another agreement opponent taking Mr Maginnis's place would be a blow to the UUP leader and the entire political process.

Mr Maginnis, a former teacher and Ulster Defence Regiment major, whom the IRA has tried to kill at least five times, was one of 15 Unionists who resigned in protest but was re-elected.

But Mr Maginnis, who lost the leadership contest in 1995, became a linchpin in the new hierarchy and claimed the party had made progress for peace in the past few years. "Our party's strength is that it works with reality rather than a wish list," he said.

Mr Cooper's backers said they were confident he would be selected and could easily retain the seat Mr Maginnis held by a majority of almost 13,700.

But anti-agreement sources suggested that choosing him over Mrs Foster could create an opportunity for Ian Paisley's hardline Democratic Unionists, who have not fielded a candidate in the constituency for some years but could put up the Stormont social development minister, Maurice Morrow, if they thought he could steal a march on a pro-agreement candidate.

"There are a lot of disaffected yes voters in the area," said one source. "There is a fear the Ulster Unionist party will be slaughtered in the next general election if they are still in power with Sinn Fein with no handover of IRA guns."

Mr Cooper said yesterday he saw the differences between himself and Mrs Foster as contrasts of approach and emphasis rather than policy and he hoped the contest would not be divisive.

fields.headline: In a field far from the Beaufort
fields.standfirst:
Working class hunt - Welshfoot soldiers find themselves in a life or death battle

Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: Working class hunt - Welshfoot soldiers find themselves in a life or death battle.
fields.body:
As the first snows of winter slowly melted on the peaks of North Wales, Dylan Davies gingerly led the hounds up the steep valley towards the rocky outcrops of Snowdon. They sped for almost four hours across rough pasture, sodden heather and hillsides, dotted with thousands of sheep, until the pack closed in for the kill.

In fading light they cornered an old, yet agile fox hiding behind a pile of rocks. A Lakeland terrier was sent in to prise him out. When that failed, the men of the Eryri Hunt began digging. They shot the fox with a .22 pistol.

There was little triumphalism, and even a hint of remorse, as the humble huntsmen, cash strapped with the collapse of sheep prices, headed home to their farms in the wild and beautiful national park. In Snowdonia, and in Britain's other upland farming areas, hunting is regarded as a necessity, rather than a sport.

The Eryri was founded by anxious farmers, on the back of an old harrier pack, more than 50 years ago, to deal with the appetite of foxes for new-born lambs. But the 80 or so foxes they cull annually pales into relative insignificance when set against the scores of lambs killed by an animal which, surprisingly, still commands respect from Dylan Davies, the young huntsman who looks after 50 hounds in the Eryri kennels.

Like a good number of the 313 packs in Britain, the Eryri is run by working men, struggling farmers, sometimes former miners and often Labour voters, rather than by the old rich, and the new money, in their red jackets, cream breeches, fresh from Range Rovers and country piles, who have come to symbolise hunting.

There is little glamour about the Eryri. It is a foot pack, a world away from wealthy hunts in the south, such as Gloucestershire's Beaufort, patronised by the Prince of Wales and Camilla Parker-Bowles, and labelled the country's most fashionable pack.

But the Eryri has no horses and little cash. Its huntsman, 24-year-old Dylan (who started in the trade as a whipper-in for his father Tom) can easily cover over 30 miles a day, ascending up to 2,000 feet, following the pack over bracken and bog. Dylan is a hunting professional, serving small farmers who are poised to become the vanguard of a mounting campaign to oppose a bill banning hunting in England and Wales (Scotland will have separate legislation).

Although MPs voted heavily in favour of a ban in a second reading just before Christmas, strong resistance is certain from the Lords in the run-up to a general election. The well-funded Countryside Alliance, planning a big demonstration in London in March, as well as a series of regional protests, is preparing a national advertising drive to highlight what it sees as the absurdity of a ban.

For huntsman like Dylan Davies, it will be simply unenforceable. "No matter what happens, foxes will have to be controlled. The way we do it is by far the most humane method of hunting," he says. "Farmers will not tolerate foxes. If they are not allowed to hunt, they will simply adopt other methods - baiting, and laying poison - which could prove very dangerous to other wildlife. They will resort to desperate measures, there is no doubt about it."

This is no idle threat. With their incomes plunging, upland farmers like Ken Jones are in a militant mood. On his 1,000 rolling acres in mid-Wales, he expects that foxes will follow their usual pattern and kill 70 or 80 of his lambs this spring. As master of the Irfon and Towy hunt, founded by his grandfather in 1910, Mr Jones says the mood on the hills is reaching boiling point. A former Labour voter who now supports Plaid Cymru, he believes that "if hunting is banned, land owners will take the law into their own hands".

Although the Irfon and Towy kills about 250 foxes annually, Mr Jones is lyrical about the animal. "Everyone in the country loves a fox," he smiles. "They are the most beautiful creatures on earth, but if they are not controlled I'm telling you they'll be roaming the countryside like packs of wolves - take that from me."

He makes a simple calculation. "Say a hundred of the foxes we kill go on to breed - they might have four to six to a litter, and that's up to 600 more foxes. Repeat that across the country and you see the problem. A total ban on hunting would present us with a real crisis, so this could get very nasty."

This month MPs will vote on three options: a ban on hunting with hounds; statutory regulation, based on the premise that hunting with dogs should be allowed on a licensed basis; and self-regulation, as advocated by the Countryside Alliance. The home secretary, Jack Straw, has come out against an outright ban in favour of licensing hunts.

Privately, he is supported by some Labour MPs representing rural constituencies. They fear that the intensifying debate over hunting will prove a damaging distraction to the party's campaign as the election approaches. And they believe that many working people support hunting. William Hancock, senior master of the Banwen Miners' Hunt, formed near Swansea 40 years ago, believes Labour voters are becoming disillusioned over the government's anti-hunting stand. "It's very sad to see, because this is a big Labour area, but many people are fed up."

The hunt, like many working class packs, is run on a shoestring. The annual £95 subscription paid by its 150 members is not enough to meet costs of up to £28,000 for a huntsman who looks after 64 hounds. So the hunt committee has to organise dances and social events.

It is far cry from the top-notch Gloucestershire hunt, but there is a historical link. The Duke of Beaufort encouraged the formation of the Banwen on his South Wales property in the early1960s. "But we are working class," insists Mr Hancock. "There are no upper-class people here."

webTitle: Rural young losing out as rich move in

fields.headline: Rural young losing out as rich move in
fields.standfirst: Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: The trend of rich people buying up all the available housing in the countryside and forcing poorer young families to move to cities is increasing dramatically, according to research.
fields.body:
The trend of rich people buying up all the available housing in the countryside and forcing poorer young families to move to cities is increasing dramatically, according to research.

The sale of rural council houses and a lack of housing association homes mean there is no accommodation for people setting up home for the first time - unless they buy at increasingly inflated prices. Four out of 10 new households in rural areas are unable to buy a home.

Mark Shucksmith, of Aberdeen University, told the geographers' conference in Plymouth: "Rural areas are now ruled by market forces, so the rich will live in the countryside and the poor in the urban areas. The social glue that holds rural communities together is falling apart.

"The original inhabitants which formed our idealised rural communities had an age balance of all generations - now these social networks of mutual support are increasingly being fractured. The old will have no one to look after them and the young will be without the support of their parents."

The situation has been made worse by the rich incomers taking over local communities by forming the majority on parish councils, being able to lobby against any new developments, especially preventing "village homes for village people".

The trend was becoming increasingly acute, with the incoming rich "protecting their version of a rural idyll by preventing new building and in doing so inadvertently threatening the social, cultural and economic sustainability of what they are keen to preserve."

The effect on young people was particularly severe, with those wanting to stay in the countryside having to live with their parents.

A survey of 60 18-year-olds in North Yorkshire found that by the age of 22 only one had managed to achieve a level of independence while staying in a rural location. The rest had either moved to a city or were continuing to live with their parents.

The trend had accelerated because of a failure to provide social housing. It was estimated that 80,000 affordable homes were needed in rural England between 1990 and 1995, but only 17,700 new social housing units were provided between 1990 and 1997.

Plans for affordable homes built by housing associations had to be approved by parish councils to receive government funding. These were often dropped because rich newcomers wanted to prevent all new building.

Professor Shucksmith said it was the Conservative housing policies that had meant that "only the wealthy can realise their dream of a house in the country, while others are having to settle for the suburbs or cities".

The government's recent rural white paper had set a target of 9,000 affordable homes a year being built in rural areas, but this was not enough to prevent a continuation of the trend.

webTitle: How the UN king hand-picks his courtiers

fields.headline: How the UN king hand-picks his courtiers
fields.standfirst: Kofi Annan is under pressure to reform the way senior staff are appointed
fields.trailText: Kofi Annan is under pressure to reform the way senior staff are appointed.
fields.body:
It was over lunch in a top-class Paris restaurant that Kofi Annan, the UN secretary general, unexpectedly popped the question to his guest Ruud Lubbers, a professor of globalisation at Tilburg university in the Netherlands, and that country's prime minister for 12 years until 1994.

Would Mr Lubbers like to head the world's major agency for helping refugees, the UNHCR?

"I was surprised," Mr Lubbers told a small group of top staff at the UNHCR's headquarters in Geneva recently."I knew very little about the issue. I had not applied for the job." But surprises had been part of his career, he added.

If he was amazed by the job offer, the Netherlands' Labour government was furious. It had nominated Jan Pronk, the minister for international development, for the UNHCR post. Wim Kok, the prime minister put out a terse statement "regretting" the decision to bypass Mr Pronk but added, patriotically, that he was glad "an able, experienced and former prime minister, and another Dutchman was chosen".

The episode perfectly summed up the two problems with top UN appointments. Rich western governments feel they own the top jobs in the big money-spending programmes, rotating them among themselves. The secretary general, who makes the appointments, is not required to have a short-list, let alone advertise the job or give the initial screening to a selection panel.

Many former senior staff at the UN criticise the system, but nothing has been done to change it, despite lip service to reforming the UN.

"I'm not sure the secretary general should start from the position that Ruritania should get a particular post," says Sir Marrack Goulding, who served as under-secretary general for political affairs until 1997. "We need to have a much more transparent set of procedures for doing this."

"What is unacceptable, and it happens all the time, is that governments put pressure on the secretary general to appoint the person they want. This is unfair on the secretary general," he adds.

Colonel Terry Taylor, the assistant director of the International Institute for Strategic Studies, an independent think-tank that focuses on the study of conflict, served as a political affairs officer at UN headquarters in New York in the mid-1990s. He believes changes in the selection procedure are needed.

"We should make people compete for the top jobs and force governments to say why they wouldn't find a particular person acceptable," he argues.

In the UNHCR case, according to a former diplomat who represented his country on the UN security council, the Dutch probably felt they had a right to a top job "because they are a loyal and energetic member of the UN which pays a lot into the budget and haven't had a Dutchman at a senior level for a number of years".

The UNHCR, led for the past decade by Japan's Sadako Ogata, is close to bankruptcy after a shortfall in funding by the 14 governments which usually provide about 98% of its money; the body took $40m of its $50m (£33m) in capital reserves last autumn to cover running costs.

Donors for broke UNHCR

Staff are hoping that, as a former prime minister from western Europe, Mr Lubbers will have the clout to get donors to be more generous for this year's huge projected budget of $953m (£635m).

Another controversial recent appointment, that of Kenzo Oshima to head the Office for the Co-ordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), was done on Mr Annan's own initiative.

According to a senior UN insider, the secretary general is dissatisfied with the work of a particular Japanese senior official in another post in the UN and wishes to remove him. To keep Tokyo happy, (it is, after all, another major UN donor), he asked the Japanese government to nominate someone to head OCHA. When Tokyo picked Mr Oshima, who runs the department of international peace co-operation in the Japanese prime minister's office, Mr Annan appointed him.

Under the UN charter, jobs are required to reflect an equitable geographical distribution that would befit a world body.

For the roughly 1,800 jobs in the secretariat in New York, a country's economic weight, as reflected in its budget dues to the UN, plays a role. Britain had 56 of these 1,800 jobs in New York, or 3%, according to figures from the mid-1990s.

When the figures are broken down for the senior jobs - those at department-head level and above - Britain had 10 out of 210, or 5%, corresponding exactly to its contribution to the overall budget.

The picture changes radically when it comes to the under-secretary general level and the heads of the main funds and programmes, such as the UNHCR, the UN Children's Fund, the World Food Programme, the UN Development Programme and the UN Population Fund.

These are mainly staffed by people from the wealthiest countries, with the United States disproportionately represented.

Given that Washington has for years refused to pay its dues in full, this discrepancy has caused major resentment. These appointments are all made by the secretary general.

The "agencies" of the United Nations - the International Labour Organisation, the World Health Organisation, the World Bank and the IMF - have separate systems of staffing and paying the top jobs, over which Mr Annan has no control.

The UN secretariat's salaries are said by the UN to be around half those of the European Union, Nato and the World Bank.

Would Mr Lubbers like to head the world's major agency for helping refugees, the UNHCR? "I was surprised," Mr Lubbers told a small group of top staff at the UNHCR's headquarters in Geneva recently."I knew very little about the issue. I had not applied for the job." But surprises had been part of his career, he added. If he was amazed by the job offer, the Netherlands' Labour government was furious. It had nominated Jan Pronk, the minister for international development, for the UNHCR post. Wim Kok, the prime minister put out a terse statement "regretting" the decision to bypass Mr Pronk but added, patriotically, that he was glad "an able, experienced and former prime minister, and another Dutchman was chosen". The secretary general, who makes the appointments, is not required to have a short-list, let alone advertise the job or give the initial screening to a selection panel. Many former senior staff at the UN criticise the system, but nothing has been done to change it, despite lip service to reforming the UN. "I'm not sure the secretary general should start from the position that Ruritania should get a particular post," says Sir Marrack Goulding, who served as under-secretary general for political affairs until 1997. He believes changes in the selection procedure are needed. "We should make people compete for the top jobs and force governments to say why they wouldn't find a particular person acceptable," he argues. webTitle: Deadly rise of girl power with guns

fields.headline: Deadly rise of girl power with guns
fields.standfirst: With their husbands and brothers in prison, mafia women are taking control of clans across Italy
fields.trailText: With their husbands and brothers in prison, mafia women are taking control of clans across Italy.
fields.body:
The police had searched the whole of Italy, so when the tip-off came they could not help smiling. The crime boss was in the family home, issuing orders from a secret room concealed behind a kitchen cupboard and a sliding wall panel.

Waiting until midnight, armed officers stormed the Forcella quarter of Naples, heartland of the Giuliano clan.

Doors splintered apart as they charged into a flat in which drugs, counterfeiting, extortion and gambling had been built into an empire.

After 10 months on the run, Erminia Giuliano, queen of the Naples mafia, had been snared.

When the police were planning to raid another clan two weeks earlier, in the Graziella quarter of Syracuse, eastern Sicily, they decided to strike at dawn, hoping the pitbull terriers guarding the entrances would asleep.

They seized guns and ammunition - the Corsi family needed hardware for their heroin-running operation - but their priority was to capture the leaders. But the 11 men they arrested were mostly footsoldiers: the generals were among the 12 women also caught.

It is a pattern repeated across Italy, reversing all the stereotypes. Women are taking command of organised crime: negotiating syndicate structures, mapping strategy, clinching deals, ordering executions. Not a softer or gentler mafia, but more feminised.

Last February two sisters, Maria and Teresa Zappia, were arrested on suspicion of heading one of the Calabrian crime syndicates known collectively as the 'Ndrangheta.

Across the Strait of Messina, Concetta Scalisi reigned over a so-called triangle of death, bringing drugs, extortion and usury to three towns on the slopes of Mount Etna, until she was caught in April 1999.

Until that midnight raid just before Christmas Erminia Giuliano, 45, was the undisputed head of one of the leading families in the Camorra, as the Naples mafia is known.

"She was a true leader, with all the qualities usually associated with crime godfathers," the Naples police chief, Carlo Gualdi, said.

Ranked as one of Italy's 30 most dangerous criminals, Ms Giuliano is due to appear in court on Wednesday to be charged with criminal association. Meanwhile her rival Maria Licciardi, 49, who rules the Secondigliano quarter, continues to evade a police search after a gang war last year in which more than 50 people died.

On it goes, a list of women who appear to have revolutionised a sub-culture in which chauvinists value submissive females principally for bridging families by marriage and childbirth

As if to confirm the revolution, the Italian media has gleefully bestowed nicknames. Ms Giuliano's blue eyes earned her Celeste - meaning heavenly - though she also goes by Lady Camorra. Ms Licciardi is the Princess. Others are Ice Eyes, Queen, Lady Clan.

It is an intoxicating cocktail: girl power with guns, gangsta mammas, gorgeous but merciless femmes fatales. Media brio is understandable, for the story has everything.

Except it is not quite what it seems. Mafia mythology is substituting omnipotent matriarchs for wives who silently served pasta to husbands plotting murder. Neither image is accurate.

Some women are taking control, but they would never dare do so by elbowing aside male competition. Only when their men have been killed or jailed and there is no obvious successor do they step in.

There have been many vacancies in recent years. Jails are full of bosses and lieutenants betrayed by thousands of supergrasses.

Ms Giuliano became boss only after the last of her five brothers was imprisoned. Ms Licciardi would not be in charge had not the next male relative in line been murdered. Ditto the Zappia sisters and Scalisi.

"These are resourceful, strong women but they are mostly stop-gaps, waiting for men to come out or sons to grow up," a Naples prosecutor said.

More significant is the way women are engaging in the nuts and bolts of crime, moving on from preparing and running drugs to accountancy and extortion.

"Economic and financial operations, including money laundering, are increasingly dominated by women. They have entered the 'enterprise syndicate' but not the 'power syndicate'," Alison Jamieson wrote in the recently published The Antimafia.

It is helped along by the march of Italian women into the labour force and universities. Fewer are willing to stay at home. In 1990 one woman was indicted for mafia association. By 1995 there were 89 such indictments.

Prosecutors hoped women would influence men to become supergrasses, but more often they denounced collaboration as betrayal, not wanting to swap the world they knew for a witness protection programme.

"Instead of leading the tide of righteous citizens against crime, women turned out to be even more entrenched in mafia values than men," Clare Longrigg wrote in Mafia Women.

Even if it is not quite a revolution, women are playing a decisive role in rebuilding the mafia after a sustained assault by the state.

Erminia Giuliano's behaviour as officers invaded her kitchen suggests that the change is irreversible.

After insisting on a shower and visit from her hairdresser, she donned high heels, a fake leopard-skin coat and handcuffs, and told her daughters: "I'm counting on you now. I am relaxed. I have taught you all the true values in life."

webTitle: Wildlife park aims to turn around wasteland

fields.headline: Wildlife park aims to turn around wasteland
fields.trailText: Spain is creating a 45-mile-long wildlife park to try to ensure the survival of the Iberian lynx. In 1998 the area near Seville had been so devastated by a dam collapse that it looked "like the Somme."
fields.body:
Spain is creating a 45-mile-long wildlife park to try to ensure the survival of the Iberian lynx. In 1998 the area near Seville had been so devastated by a dam collapse, however, it looked "like the Somme", and all farming was banned because any crops would be too dangerous to eat.

Naturalists were shocked when the Donana national and natural parks, the largest wetland in Europe and the last great wild area of Spain, were threatened as 6m cubic metres of very acid water containing arsenic, lead, mercury, zinc cadmium and other heavy metals burst from a mining dam. All life in the Agrio and Guadiamar rivers below the spill was wiped out.

Birds that feasted on the hundreds of thousands of dead fish also died in their thousands, and there were fears for the Iberian Lynx, the last of Europe's big cats. There are thought to be only 650 left in the wild.

Spoonbills, flamingoes and the magnificent black vulture were hit. Ornithologists also feared that many birds that migrated to Africa from Britain and used the area as a stopover point would be poisoned and never return.

British scientists monitoring the area said it might take 50 years before the effects of the spill completely disappeared. In an attempt to clear up, the Spanish authorities removed 10m cubic metres of the river bed and the flooded areas, to pick up 2m cubic metres of heavy metals in mine debris.

"When I first arrived the area looked like pictures of the Somme," said Jonathon Turner, of the University of Wales, who presented a paper on the clean-up.

The authorities barred farmers from their land, and bought up the area to create a wildlife corridor. They planted thousands of trees to replace those lost, but 90% of the first planting died.

"This year things are looking a lot better. There are reeds growing in the river, hardier plants like buttercups are colonising, and some areas look green, even lush.

"The birds are coming back, I saw a marsh harrier and bee eaters, frogs, hares and rabbits, but not yet any fish, but eventually they will come back too. It will take maybe 50 years before it will be fully restored."

webTitle: Leader: Dr Shipman's mighty army of victims

fields.headline: Beyond imagination
fields.standfirst:
Dr Shipman's mighty army of victims

Special report: the Shipman trial
fields.trailText: Dr Shipman's mighty army of victims.
fields.body:
We do not know, and are unlikely ever to know, how many of his patients were killed in his 26 years practising medicine by the Greater Manchester doctor Harold Shipman, who was convicted last January of what then seemed the frightening total of 15 murders. Now the painstaking research of Professor Richard Baker of Leicester University has suggested that the number who died at this doctor's hands could be as many as 300, stretching back to his earliest days in a Yorkshire hospital and in general practice at Todmorden.

There can be absolutely no certainty about the figures in Professor Baker's report. This is an actuarial type of calculation, based on comparisons between the fate of Shipman's patients and the survival rates of comparable doctors in comparable practices, with allowance made for age and social and economic conditions. But precision hardly matters. Whatever the toll, this is the most appalling case of serial murder.

What drove him to it remains as mysterious as ever. The doctor himself remains silent. No legislation will ever be framed which can prevent a person with Shipman's freedom to elevate death over life from using that power as he did. But the chilling feature in all that has now emerged is that, almost until the end, nobody seemed to notice. In his last years in Hyde he practised alone, and one of the lessons at the time of his conviction seemed to be that group practices, where others might begin to suspect what a rogue colleague was up to, might be safer than singlehanded ones. Yet now it is clear that Shipman was killing patients even while working with colleagues.

A public inquiry under the high court judge, Dame Janet Smith, has already been ordered. Maybe it will make sense of all this, maybe not. But one conclusion is clear. The evidence that Shipman's patients were dying where other doctors' patients survived was there from the start. It was simply not observed, assessed or explored. As at the Bristol children's hospital, it was only when a whistleblower appeared that serious suspicions surfaced.

Yet now, in the age of computers, such evidence can be far more readily assessed and understood than ever before, both by doctors and those who supervise them and by coroners' courts. That may be no defence against a new Shipman. But it should make it far more likely that someone would smell something wrong, long before the killing reached such dimensions.

fields.headline: Mitterrand accounts frozen
fields.trailText: Switzerland has ordered its banks to freeze accounts held by Jean-Christophe Mitterrand, the son of the late French president.
fields.body:
Switzerland has ordered its banks to freeze accounts held by Jean-Christophe Mitterrand, the son of the late French president. Yesterday's move comes as investigators continue to delve into his alleged involvement in illicit arms dealing, influence peddling and embezzlement.

An investigating magistrate in Geneva, Daniel Devaud, said he had acted on a request from his French counterpart, Philippe Courroye, head of the investigation into Mr Mitterrand's alleged role in weapons trafficking to Angola in the early 90s.

The elder son of François Mitterrand, who was one of his father's chief strategy advisers, has been in jail since December 21.

He has reportedly admitted taking £3.1m from a firm run by the accused arms dealer, Pierre Falcone, but insists it was a legitimate payment.

A Paris appeal court earlier this week granted his release from pre-trial detention, but set bail at an unusually high £500,000. Mr Mitterrand, 54, is said to want to fight the claims rather than have the case dropped.

fields.trailText: I must spring to Romania's defence ('Romania with burgers' jibe makes Walsall turn ugly, January 5)." Mr Dalrymple appears incredibly ill-informed on the breathtaking beauty of Romania.
fields.body:
I must spring to Romania's defence ('Romania with burgers' jibe makes Walsall turn ugly, January 5)." Mr Dalrymple appears incredibly ill-informed on the breathtaking beauty of Romania. Furthermore, Bucharest alone boasts over 14 McDonald's outlets.
Tom Wilson
Barnoldswick, Lancs

 Never mind all this about when the Millennium begins (Letters, January 5) here's a real quandary: how to write the date. Should I write 6/1/01, 6/1/1, 06/01/01, or some other combination?
Hazel Sydeserff
Glasgow

 Surely 0BC and AD0 are one and the same? They represent no time before and no time after a fictional event.
Huw Davies (aged 13)
Cardiff

 I mentioned the interest in our unique dialect to an old friend of mine. His response: "Thee casn't speak as well as thee cust, cast? And if thee cust thee uhsunt, uhst?" Jayne Hathway
Bristol

GQ Williams
Bristol

fields.headline: Home team
fields.trailText: Your comments on the appointment of Dr Ian Hudson as director of licensing at the medicines control agency (Leader, December 30) are unjust.
fields.body:
Your comments on the appointment of Dr Ian Hudson as director of licensing at the medicines control agency (Leader, December 30) are unjust.

You suggest ministers insist the MCA grows its own executives. It does. Dr June Raine was appointed director of post-licensing in 1999 and Doreen Hepburn was appointed director for information management last year. Both were internal appointments.

These, and all appointments to senior civil service posts, are on the basis of open competition, and selection on merit. The civil service commission oversees the process. We would rightly be accused of failing in our duty to protect health if we did not appoint the most qualified person for such demanding high-profile positions. Dr Hudson's career spans medical practice, research and pharmaceutical medicine, including regulatory registrations.
Dr Keith Jones
Chief executive Medicines Control Agency

webTitle: Letters: Who is paying the piper?

fields.headline: Who is paying the piper?
fields.trailText: Clive Soley thinks that state money for political parties would "resolve a lot of problems" (Call for state cash for political parties , January 4). It would certainly complete the Blair revolution.
fields.body:
Clive Soley thinks that state money for political parties would "resolve a lot of problems" (Call for state cash for political parties , January 4). It would certainly complete the Blair revolution. Once the Labour party relied on the enthusiasm and financial commitment of its members. The leaders had to take some notice of their opinions.

Increasingly they only have to take notice of millionaire business funders. With state funding they could dispense with an active membership, courtesy of the tax payer. A Blairite nirvana.
Stuart King
London
scking@gn.apc.org

 What a choice at the next election (Election war chest piles up, January 5). Either a party funded by Lord Ashcroft and Lord Harris or a party funded by Lord Hamlyn and Lord Sainsbury. What about the workers?
David Osler
London

 It was gracious of Lord Sainsbury to reveal his donation of £2m. No doubt this will help the government defend its decision to keep the lower minimum wage for those under 22. Will the science minister now divulge how much the Sainsbury's supermarket chain saves by giving its youthful staff such pitiful pay?
Helen Rogers
Guildford, Surrey

 I would be more impressed by Hamlyn and Ondaatje had they donated to the genuinely needy instead of already wealthy elites like the Royal Opera House and the National Portrait Gallery.
Jeff Ambler
Kingston upon Hull

 Andrew Lansley complains about Labour's income from a small number of large donors. Isn't he more worried by Tory dependence on a small number of small donors?
Ann Black
Oxford
ablack@brookes.ac.uk

fields.headline: Jackson Pollock's fractals
fields.trailText: I read John Dunford's article on the negative image of maths teachers (Could do better, January 4) with great interest. Working on an outreach programme set up by the University of Cambridge to promote interest in and appreciation of maths, we're all too aware that attracting maths graduates into teaching is difficult.
fields.body:
I read John Dunford's article on the negative image of maths teachers (Could do better, January 4) with great interest. Working on an outreach programme set up by the University of Cambridge to promote interest in and appreciation of maths, we're all too aware that attracting maths graduates into teaching is difficult.

Unfortunately, it's not just the teachers who are seen to be uncool - there is a common belief that maths is boring and difficult.

While we might not be able to help poor beleaguered maths teachers to follow Mr Dunford's orders to lose weight, shave and wear contact lenses, we could suggest some topics of conversation other than quadratic equations. Our online mathematics magazine,Plus, features articles ranging from the maths of limericks and the appearance of fractals in Jackson Pollock's paintings to whether the universe has any edges. The current issue also explains how to mathematically morph faces from Cleopatra to JFK - or maybe even from a "fat, bald nerd with glasses" to Liz Hurley.
Julia Hawkins
University of Cambridge

 Maths teachers may not be nerds, but I have never met a maths teacher without an eccentricity. I once had a cool, young hip teacher. Unfortunately, he soon buckled under the weight of teaching and being a human at the same time, so he got his nipple pierced, threw a bag out of a closed first-floor window and had a nervous breakdown. Nice try Mr Dunford.
Laurie Page
Brighton, E Sussex

fields.headline: Fire storm
fields.trailText: Your report on the thermobaric weapon (January 5) took me back to a visit to Baghdad just after the Gulf war bombings by the US.
fields.body:
Your report on the thermobaric weapon (January 5) took me back to a visit to Baghdad just after the Gulf war bombings by the US.

One building, a modern structure of several floors, had the appearance of having imploded and collapsed within itself, as did the incinerated Ameriya shelter, where hundreds of civilians were killed and injured. The extraordinary damage at both these sites was beyond my comprehension as a civil engineer and as one who had experienced the bombing of London during the second world war. Now I learn that these horrendous "thermobarbaric" weapons were developed and used by the US in the Gulf war and later by the Russians in Grozny. Is there no end to the evil these military freaks will resort to?
Jim Howard
Abingdon, Oxon
