webTitle: Letters: Our debt to Dr Lukwiya

fields.headline: Our debt to Dr Lukwiya
fields.trailText: As a young Ugandan whose parents grew up in Gulu, it was a great pleasure reading about Dr Matthew Lukwiya, who so genuinely loved his people and work (A good man in Africa, G2, January 2).
fields.body:
As a young Ugandan whose parents grew up in Gulu, it was a great pleasure reading about Dr Matthew Lukwiya, who so genuinely loved his people and work (A good man in Africa, G2, January 2).

He could have gone anywhere in the world and made a great deal of money from his profession and lived a life that his people only see in their wildest dreams. What made Dr Lukwiya conspicuous was that in an age of corruption, greed and violence he had no ulterior motive except to help those in need.

Not many people know where Uganda is, let alone Gulu. But Dr Lukwiya's great work, thousands of miles away in this tiny town, has been brought to the attention of millions. Your tribute was a great statement for me as a young Acholi and as a student. It has taught me a great deal about humility and hard work. It is a challenge to us to learn from him and not let his death be in vain.
Juliet Akello
London
Dabest2080@aol.com

 Thank you for your tribute to Dr Lukwiya. The doctor needed more publicity and support back in November to relieve the pressures that led to his death. As you point out, it may be premature to claim that the ebola outbreak is "nearly over". The risk of a new epidemic is greatest in the overcrowded "protected villages", like Pabbo, at some distance from Gulu, where people still fear to surrender their sick or dead relatives knowing they will never see them again. In these circumstances the removal of the ebola testing laboratory from Gulu to the south of Uganda seems inexplicable.

Our committee raises money to support the care of victims, to rebuild the capacity of Gulu and Lacor hospitals when it has subsided, and to develop the local level of disaster preparedness and knowledge of haemorrhagic diseases so as to prevent or control any future outbreak. These hospitals must cope next time without the exceptional skills of Dr Lukwiya.
George Heron
Crisis Committee on Ebola in Northern Uganda
george@parksway.demon.co.uk

 I wish the family of Charlotte Wilson well in their effort to prevent further vehicle hijacks in Burundi (Letters, January 2), where their daughter was so tragically killed. Unfortunately, such incidents are not infrequent - they only reach our news when a Briton is involved.

Our church here in Mulbarton has maintained links with church leaders in Democratic Republic of Congo. Recently we heard that an Anglican archdeacon was involved in a similar incident in late November on the road south from Bukavu to Uvira (parallel to the road used by Ms Wilson). Ven Kalondji's vehicle was ambushed and all the passengers ordered off and shot. He was saved because his assassin recognised him and said: "He was my teacher, I can't shoot him." It went unreported because all those killed were locals and the incident was regarded as unexceptional.
Jill Wright
Norwich

 It will be of little comfort to Charlotte Wilson's family and friends that the deliberate killing of foreign aid workers is rare. But the deaths of Charlotte and of another dedicated development worker, Dr Matthew Lukwiya, underline the risks aid workers face on and off duty.

Through our work, we know that too many other injuries and deaths in the sector remain unrecorded, let alone investigated. The challenge for agencies is to sustain a systematic awareness of the hazards, hence our members subscribe to a voluntary code of practice. The duty of governments, including ours, is to promote a culture of safety throughout the international aid sector and call to account those who threaten innocent civilians and the people who are there to help.
Sara Davidson
People Aid

webTitle: Leader: Labour donations come with suspicions attached

fields.headline: How the money pours in
fields.standfirst:
Labour donations come with suspicions attached

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Labour donations come with suspicions attached.
fields.body:
By revealing the names of two more £2m donors before the the Economist did, the Labour party should have precluded a further season of turmoil over party donations. Yet many Labour people are still far from happy about what is emerging. The fact that Christopher Ondaatje used to give generous sums to the Conservative party can perhaps be exploited to demonstrate the trust which Labour now enjoys among the business community.

That Lord Sainsbury, one of Tony Blair's ministers, should have given £2m now, making a total of some £6m since Mr Blair became leader, is more troublesome, since when ministers put up money, it could be read as a form of insurance against dismissal. There is also the unfortunate matter of the donation from Robert Bourne, chairman of Legacy, coming just about the time when his company was doing its deal on the dome. The money had been promised long before, but it makes yet one more ingredient for critics to put in the pot.

These new acts of generosity have fuelled the complaint that Labour is becoming unhealthily dependent on a few large gifts from a few rich men. That this objection should have come from the Conservative party suggests a degree of hypocrisy unusual even among politicians in the run-up to an election. Perhaps they think the world has already forgotten their own dependence on the moneybags of their treasurer, Lord Ashcroft, who has given more than £1m a year to the party, backed up by interest-free loans. But when such objections come from Labour's own ranks, they deserve to be listened to.

Yet what other options are there? Labour is anxious not to be seen as in thrall to the unions. But when it looks for alternatives, these too are attacked. So now the cry arises: please keep us clean from temptation by introducing state funding of political parties.

In this sense, the present disturbances may even be welcome to party managers, bringing on to the agenda proposals which the Labour leadership had feared to put there before. Taxpayers would be investing, proponents argue, in a form of political education, helping the parties meet the substantial expense of putting their message across without leaving them dependent on private largesse.

But that is too simple. Experience of poster campaigns in particular suggests they have less to do with education than with image-building, smearing the opposition and publishing half-truths or worse. Why should taxpayers have to fund that?

The new legislation puts a ceiling of £20m on what a party can spend in the year before an election. Would honest election debate really be shackled if that sum were sharply reduced? Hailing this legislation, the home secretary, Jack Straw, wrote in the Guardian: "The political parties need a system in which they too can have confidence, knowing that all parties are on a level playing field, abiding by the same rules." But there can be no level playing field while the spending ceiling is set at a level which Labour and the Conservatives are able to reach, but is way beyond the means of other parties.

Alternatively, Labour could try to disperse the suspicion that donations to party funds are a path to a place on the honours list or to other fat government favours. One Labour backbencher has suggested that those who make large donations should be barred for five years thereafter from membership of the Lords. If Labour wants to pocket this precious money without incurring suspicions of sleaze, some such self-denying ordinance is well worth considering.

Talk about it
Should political donors be named?

webTitle: Leader: Mr Fischer's unruly past is forgiven. Good

fields.headline: Thirty years on
fields.standfirst: Mr Fischer's unruly past is forgiven. Good
fields.trailText: Mr Fischer's unruly past is forgiven. Good.
fields.body:
Joschka Fischer is Germany's most colourful politician as well as its most popular. A former student radical who became foreign minister, a former pacifist who approved of Nato's intervention in Yugoslavia, still officially a Green though now more gradualist than most of his party, much married and much divorced, Mr Fischer is widely admired.

This week's revelation that he fought with police during the turbulent squatter-evictions of the 1970s has done nothing to dent his image in Germany. Even the rightwing tabloids seem unmoved. What a relief. It confirms how far Germany has moved from the smug conformity, blind materialism and eagerness to demonise the entire left which used to be the country's mainstream stance at the time the radicals were active.

Mr Fischer long ago changed his mind over the tactics of violence and has repeatedly confirmed that he never supported the strategy of assassination and bombing which the Red Army Faction and other ultra-radicals adopted. But he was a leader of his generation. His social conscience was in high gear. He saw politics as a matter of passion. He was furious over America's war on Vietnam and European governments' failure to denounce it. He protested at poverty in the midst of affluence.

Welcome to the club. In every western country in that decade from the mid-60s to the mid-70s, hundreds of thousands were like him, including respected members of the present British and French cabinets. The freakish thing was not to have been enragé in those days. In Germany, the protests had a specific context. A generation felt that their parents had covered up their place in the Nazi past, and the nation as a whole had not properly faced up to what fascism meant. Why was there no truth commission? Mr Fischer's views were normal and typical for those years. Had they not been, his present role in his country's politics would count for less.

fields.headline: Dome and donations
fields.trailText: You have devoted considerable coverage to the sell-off of the dome. What happens to this exceptional structure and the regenerated land on which it stands is of major interest - so it is essential that you get the facts right.
fields.body:
You have devoted considerable coverage to the sell-off of the dome. What happens to this exceptional structure and the regenerated land on which it stands is of major interest - so it is essential that you get the facts right.

First the idea that we are negotiating the sale with Legacy plc because Robert Bourne has given money to the Labour party is just wrong. Last summer two bidders Nomura and Legacy, were, on the basis of professional advice, shortlisted after taking part in a thorough competition beginning in March 1999. The government subsequently decided Nomura was the better of the two and it was made preferred bidder. The Nomura bid was headed by Guy Hands - who has a well-publicised friendship with William Hague. That is why I find the Bourne allegation so bizarre.

When Nomura pulled out last September, it was entirely sensible and proper that we should have discussions with the runners-up - Legacy. It took up that offer enthusiastically and has now been granted preferred bidder status. That has meant that Legacy has been able to put together a high-powered team which includes the likes of McAlpines and Ove Arup. Negotiations will continue over the next few weeks and if all goes well we will exchange contracts next month.

Second we have a carefully timetabled programme of decommissioning which means that if the Legacy deal does not proceed options are still open - including running the dome as a new visitor attraction. No significant asset owned by the NMEC will be removed which could prevent future leisure or commercial use. The zones will not be dismantled before the auction is due to take place on February 27. Assets not owned by the NMEC, such as leased items like lighting and sound equipment and the Journey and Talk zones (owned by their sponsors) are being decommissioned first. If they stayed put, they would incur additional hire charges.

As I have made perfectly clear if there was to be a housing development there would be clawback arrangements on any excess profits. The government will ensure that appropriate conditions will be attached to any sale to protect the interests of the public sector.

webTitle: Hell, mud and rock and roll

fields.headline: Hell, mud and rock and roll
fields.trailText: "What I love about Glastonbury is wandering around and seeing all the strange people. It's a wonderful place, a great feeling."
fields.body:
"What I love about Glastonbury is wandering around and seeing all the strange people. It's a wonderful place, a great feeling."

Tom Rowlands, the Chemical Brothers

"The festival's links with CND and with groups such as Greenpeace are evidence of an effort to present or explore different ideas...by re-examining alternative traditions from real and mythic pasts alike. This merging of past and politics is one of the festival's lasting achievements."

George McKay, author of Glastonbury: A Very English Fair

"The only trouble with it is, it's hard to be rock'n'roll when you're wearing wellies."

Sarah Blackwood, Dubstar

"It's unique and it has a loyalty from bands and fans which has been built over 30 years. You can't compete with that."

Vince Power, Reading festival promoter

"Glastonbury represents exactly the right amount of anarchy: the brief delusion that things can be as you know they will never be."

Bel Mooney

"When it rains and there's all the mud and you wake up soaked - it's hell really."

Ian Broudie, the Lightning Seeds

"It could send you into a megalomaniac tailspin if you actually started thinking about it too much because so many people will see you."

James Dean Bradfield, the Manic Street Preachers, on headlining the festival

"The great beauty of Glastonbury for me lies in the understanding that you can have a ripping weekend without deliberately setting out to hear any music at all. The musical highlights have been there, of course, but it's the aimless, some would say mindless, pottering I like."

John Peel, Radio One DJ

"Playing here is like a dream come true."

Bob Dylan

"It's exciting. It's the thrill of giving a great party for about 100,000 people - the hugest party in the world. You can pick up on the excitement as you walk around, even now that it has got very big."

Michael Eavis

Related story
Success puts Glastonbury party on hold

fields.headline: Weather chaos costs farmers £500m
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Parts of Britain are back on flood alert after fresh downpours across the country yesterday, while farmers estimated the bad weather had already cost them millions of pounds this winter.
fields.body:
Parts of Britain are back on flood alert after fresh downpours across the country yesterday, while farmers estimated the bad weather had already cost them millions of pounds this winter.

The environment agency warned the rainfall could lead to rivers flooding and said Hampshire, West Sussex and Kent were "saturated" after 20mm (0.8in) of rain fell earlier. Motorists in the south-east were warned of widespread surface flooding.

Weather forecasters said a deep Atlantic depression was responsible for the prolonged rain which spread across southern England and Wales.

An environment agency spokesman said: "In places driving conditions are difficult and dangerous. Ankle-high water can sweep a pedestrian off their feet. A car will float at knee height. Many roads are under water at levels which are potentially dangerous."

The number of flood warnings in England and Wales rose by three overnight to 32, the agency added. Nationally, the situation was stable.

New warnings are in place on the river Colne between Uxbridge and Staines, south-west London, and on two more stretches of the Great Ouse in Buckinghamshire.

In Kent, flood warnings of imminent threat to life and property were later issued on the rivers Teise and Lesser Teise between Lamberhurst and Yalding, and the Beult from Pluckley to Yalding.

In East Sussex, the river Cuckmere and the Rother between Mayfield and Newenden were also on flood warning, as were the Upper and Lower Test Valley, and the Upper and Lower Itchen Valley in Hampshire.

A flood warning was also issued for the river Uck in East Sussex, which flooded in October, devastating the market town of Uckfield, and the river Ouse, from Isfield to Barcombe.

The severe weather has cost farmers an estimated £500m in uninsured losses of crops and property, according to the National Farmers' Union.

Farmers and rural businesses have made 4,000 claims to their biggest insurer, NFU Mutual, during the bad weather.

The NFU said around 13% of the national potato crop - some 822,200 tonnes on 19,500 hectares - had been destroyed or remained in the ground almost two months after the first deluge, at a possible cost of £97m. The cereal and sugar beet crops had suffered similar fates.

In addition, the grain harvest this year could be several million tonnes lower than in 2000 because of poor growing conditions and waterlogged land, at an estimated loss to growers of £300m.

The NFU said the total loss to the industry, including damage to buildings, was likely to top £500m.

Union president Ben Gill said: "These figures confirm our worst fears. Some farmers have had almost their entire business wiped out."

fields.headline: Talking heads
fields.standfirst: Lesley MacDonagh, managing partner of international law firm Lovells
fields.trailText: Lesley MacDonagh, managing partner of international law firm Lovells.
fields.body:
What was your first career aspiration?

To teach art.

What has been your best moment in management?

The overwhelming vote for our first European merger.

And your greatest mistake?

Agreeing to choose the firm's Christmas card.

How would you describe your management style?

Mostly collaborative.

Which case would you most like to have been involved with?

Spycatcher, which one of my colleagues handled. In 1985 the Attorney General tried in New South Wales to stop Peter Wright publishing his book Spycatcher.

What do you find most annoying in your staff?

Irrational mood swings.

Does your organisation have a "glass ceiling"?

Categorically not.

What management wisdom is most over-rated?

That cascading information delivers a consistent message.

What is the biggest challenge facing your profession?

Adapting our services to keep in tune with the most innovative clients.

What single lesson would you pass on to young lawyers?

It's the extra 10% you give in everything that you do which always makes the real difference.

Which management guru do you believe in?

Professor John Adair, author of Not Bosses But Leaders and The Art of Creative Thinking.

Who is your management hero?

Barbara Kux, an executive director with Ford Europe.

Favourite politician?

Of all time: F D Roosevelt. Today, I admire David Blunkett.

I f you could change one aspect of the British legal system, what would it be?

Some aspects of the right to trial by jury.

What phrase or saying do you most over-use?

Could I have the "heads up" on X or Y.

Apart from quality time with your family, what else makes you happiest in life?

Producing or creating something - other than an edible meal, which is beyond me.

What annoys you most?

No signal on a mobile phone network and anything that desensitises people - especially violent films.

How do you relax?

G&Ts and/or being bossed around at home by the children.

What was your last cultural experience?

The Smallest Angel at the Chiltern Street Nursery School.

What is your favourite city?

Florence, for personal reasons.

Do you have a favourite website ?

Yes, Reef.

What is your greatest regret?

Only having four children.

What is your biggest fear?

Losing the passion for life.

What would you really like to have been?

Chief executive of LVMH (Louis Vuitton Moet Hennessy) - what a great train set to have!

webTitle: Jobs and Money: From the top

fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: The year 2001 looks like being a tough one. The US economy seems set to slow down. A pre-election spending spree by Gordon Brown could cause problems as expectations soar while capacity struggles to adjust.
fields.body:
The year 2001 looks like being a tough one. The US economy seems set to slow down. A pre-election spending spree by Gordon Brown could cause problems as expectations soar while capacity struggles to adjust.

A wave of new regulations from Europe, increased local competition, increasingly demanding consumers and technological change will pose more challenges.

The failure of the railways is the first example of the accumulated costs of decades of neglect of UK infrastructure. Watch out for breakdowns in the Underground, air traffic control, posts, telecoms, water and sewage, where Labour's decision to stick to Conservative spending policies will haunt it.

Some old and some new survival skills are needed. Cash is king when businesses are under pressure. Years of easy credit and increasing share and asset prices make managers undervalue cash during good times. Tough conditions mean that cash-rich companies do well. Effective cash management means tight controls on costs. Credit control is crucial as the old adage that: "you have not sold anything until you have been paid, before that it's a gift" bites. Stock levels that looked good in easy times become liabilities when markets tighten. Stock turn rates become a key business indicator.

Customers become more demanding. The age of the never-satisfied-consumer has arrived. Clothing, furniture and white goods producers find no one wants to buy at full manufacturers' recommended retail prices.

Discount malls boom while high street stores struggle as consumers want bargains without sacrificing the latest features and styles. Price pressure on manufacturers and retailers will grow. Innovation and creativity provide the only sustainable defence against this onslaught on prices. Technological and idea search are moving from the periphery of business operations to their core.

New information technologies are changing our lives. Comparable revolutions are occuring in materials technologies and life sciences. Juan Enriguez and Ray Golding said recently in the Harvard Business Review that "boundaries between many once-distinct businesses, from agribusiness and chemicals to pharmaceuticals and healthcare to energy and computing, will blur".

This year looks like being the end of the beginning in the knowledge wars, but with two new twists. Knowledge management strategies are increasingly common in large corporations. Those slow to adjust lose out as real returns to intellectual assets strengthen balance sheets.

The first twist is that the public sector, especially in North America, is recognising the value of its knowledge assets. Leading institutions are matching the strategies and structures of their corporate rivals while establishing powerful locks on their accumulated assets.

The second is the sophisticated use of knowledge management by consumers, users and interest groups. The era of the smart consumer means that buyers use tech nologies to assert their power not only over goods and services but the reputation of their suppliers.

International search by consumers is commonplace in books, music, clothing, and computing. The only barriers are worries about security and product delivery. Solving these will see further expansion.

These changes will extend beyond the private sector. Key public sectors are now part of the same global marketplace. Services like NHS Direct compete with alternatives like CBS's mediscape.com. This stage in the new economy looks like being tougher for everyone.

 Professor Tom Cannon is chief executive of RespectLondon.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: 'Life enhancement' for employees

fields.headline: The future's bright, the future's people
fields.standfirst: Tom Gosling of PricewaterhouseCoopers says there is a greater emphasis on 'life enhancement' as employers vie for workers with scarce skills
fields.trailText: Tom Gosling of PricewaterhouseCoopers says there is a greater emphasis on 'life enhancement' as employers vie for workers with scarce skills
fields.body:
In the workplace of 2005, will businesses or individuals reap the benefits of the challenges posed by the searing heat of technological change, increasing globalisation and fundamental changes to the traditional working week?

While today's global business leaders may disagree about the effectiveness of rival business models and the implications of e-business, the growing importance of "people" issues now stands firmly at the top of their collective agenda.

In a world shaped by the importance of recruiting and retaining the best talent, skills shortages in key areas and the need to meet the expectations of a new generation demanding a shift in balance between working and private lives, only those business leaders who actively promote these new values will succeed in turning their strategies into reality.

To assist both employers and employees to prepare for the challenges ahead PricewaterhouseCoopers has been researching good practice in human resource management and the workplace for some years. This year we went one step further and asked some outside thinkers to work alongside some of the best minds in our Global Human Resources Solutions practice to outline some of the key HR challenges set to face business by 2005.

What emerged is a vision with a number of surprisingly common themes. They include: greater diversity in working patterns, with more home-working and portfolio careers, where employees work for several employers simultaneously and seek new opportunities via internet labour exchanges.

A greater emphasis on work-life balance and "life enhancement" emerges as employers compete for workers with scarce skills. Virtual assessment centres replace traditional interviews, with candidates assessed on their ability to deal with differing tasks. We see the development of a "global diverse workforce". More people are paid for what they achieve rather than for time worked.

Businesses will have to transform the way they perceive the value of people issues to take advantage of the changes afoot. Our thinkers came up with the following advice:

Embrace fluidity; changing working patterns are here to stay. Rather than resisting them, employers will need to be creative about harnessing all aspects of reward, not just money. This will include more home-working, and of portfolio careers where individuals sell their services to several employers simultaneously.

Recognise social responsi bility. The flood of news and information to hand-held computers will make the IT-savvy "MTV" generation more aware of the world's problems than any previous one. People in 2005 will demand different ethical standards from their employers and be more socially responsible. This will not just be a question of avoiding damage to products and brands, as suffered by many in recent years. Corporations will have to see their brand as an employer, because good people will only work for employers they respect.

Unlearn in order to learn. In a world of sophisticated global capital markets and high-speed information flows, businesses will learn the strategic logic of unlearning. They will know that there is no point in recruiting new people only to push them into the old ways of do ing things. Successful businesses will value the importance of the management of knowledge and, crucially, decide what they need to succeed and what to give up.

In the workplace of the future, traditional models of command and control management will fail. Leaders will have to earn the right to "followership" from employees and business partners. Leadership will increasingly be about creating the environment for the knowledge networks that produce value to flourish. This will require significant personal development for tomorrow's leaders, who will need the ability to recognise the importance of the feelings and values that drive their employees.

Predictions about future change are always contentious and never perfect. But what has become clear from our analysis is that the corporate environment is changing faster than we expect. Central to this seismic change are people - how they work, how they are managed and rewarded and how they learn. To meet these challenges the human resources function within organisations must shift its focus from the delivery of core administrative services to become a strategic, creative and even visionary force.

What is required is root-and-branch reform of the way business looks at people issues in the process reassessing the traditional role of the HR director.

 Human resource business briefing Workplace 2005 is available from nicola.mcgregor@uk.pwcglobal.com or may be viewed at PWC Global.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: My big break

fields.headline: Amazing his grace
fields.standfirst: Adrian Fisher has developed a global business constructing mazes and labyrinths after building his first for the Archbishop of Canterbury 20 years ago. Martyn Seal investigates
fields.trailText: Adrian Fisher has developed a global business constructing mazes and labyrinths after building his first for the Archbishop of Canterbury 20 years ago. Martyn Seal investigates.
fields.body:
Here's a puzzle. What connects the ancient and the modern, is both distinctly British yet also entirely international and can still arouse excitement and fear as much today as when first invented thousands of years ago?

Answer: Our enduring fascination with mazes. And it's mazes that have been Adrian Fisher's expertise for the last 20 years. He's become an authority in the field of maze design and is one of Britain's great experts in this area.

His love of mazes and labyrinths developed from an understanding of landscape, a talent for mathematics and a keen appreciation of art, which led to him first to constructing a hedge maze in his father's garden as a young man.

But his big break came in 1980 when Robert Runcie was made Archbishop of Canterbury and, during the ceremony, used the metaphor of the maze in his sermon, likening it to the path of life. It inspired Mr Fisher to write to a newspaper pointing out that maze metaphors had been used by the Christian church for centuries.

After the letter he landed his first commission, the Archbishop's maze in Grey's Court, Henley. "I met a retired diplomat called Randoll Coate and he and I eventually built 15 mazes together," he recalls. "We did up to three in a year, not as a serious venture at first, but enough to make me realise, in 1983, that I should go for it. So I gave up management consultancy and went full-time."

His first commissions were few due to the specialised nature of the business but he had faith in the potential of his venture. "I knew mazes were inherently fascinating; they're an intriguing subject which catches people's imagination."

So how did he get his new business going? "It took me two years to earn as much as my previous salary but that's typical in a small business. fields.headline: Why it can be a career bar none for some
fields.standfirst: In a week that saw the death of George Carman, Britain's most celebrated and highly paid advocate, Liz Stuart and Natasha Ram discover that the barrister's lot is not as lucrative as it once was
fields.trailText: In a week that saw the death of George Carman, Britain's most celebrated and highly paid advocate, Liz Stuart and Natasha Ram discover that the barrister's lot is not as lucrative as it once was.
fields.body:
Few professions are as steeped in mythology and mystique as the bar. It's Rumpole of the Bailey, it's North Square, the TV series depicting a set of fictional legal chambers in Leeds, and it's individuals like Clive Anderson, so brilliant and versatile as a barrister that he has made a second career as a top television personality.

But while City solicitors are being headhunted and offered graduate starting salaries in excess of £40,000, a career at the legal bar is beginning to look as unhealthy as propping up a public one.

Last year the number of claims heard at the Queen's Bench was down by nearly 40% and, increasingly, solicitors are snapping up the advocacy business traditionally enjoyed by junior barristers, turning a difficult career path into an arduous assault course.

The profession already has high barriers to entry and the bar continues to be accused of operating as a self-perpetuating elite. While Lord Bingham of Cornhill, the former Lord Chief Justice, claims in the newly published book Discriminating Lawyers that the stereotype of the profession as predominantly a "white, middle-class, middle-aged, Oxbridge-educated elite" is misleading, he does admit that there is some foundation for the cliche. He says it is harder for women from ethnic minorities or for graduates of "unfashionable universities" to enter.

Professor Phil Thomas of Cardiff University, the book's author, says that 66% of male Oxbridge graduates se cured pupillage (a one-year apprenticeship during which trainee barristers are attached to one or two chambers) against 10% from new universities. Further acknowledgment that there is a problem came when Cherie Booth QC was told, very publicly by her fellow barristers, that government policy was to blame for the industry's skewed profile. "An overdraft of £20,000 is common. That is a lot of money by any standards, but to poorer families it is a huge amount... Let's be clear, and Cherie Booth please note, it is the result of deliberate government policy to cut out grants and force students to borrow instead," says Jonathan Hurst QC at a bar conference. He also urges the bar to make it compulsory for pupils to be paid through their year of training.

The Lord Chancellor himself, Lord Irvine of Lairg, is currently being challenged by the Equal Opportunities Commission over the employment of a male special adviser, who was also a friend, without the post first being advertised.

The Bar Council denies the charge of elitism. Look to the figures, it says. Last year 973 people were called to the Bar, 447 of whom were female and 526 male, and last year more women than men were called: 769 against 624. According to the records office of the Bar Council, in the first round of applicants for places in the 2000-2001 academic year of the 1,000 who are trying for a place on the Bar Vocational Course exams, just 80 are from Oxbridge, while around 450 are from former polytechnics.

But still, just one-third of practising barristers are female and a tiny percentage are non-white: 0.7% of the males are Afro-Caribbean and there are only 18 Pakistani women at the bar.

There are moves afoot to make it easier to get pupillage. From April it will be compulsory for all places to be advertised on the Bar Council website, although not all chambers will have to participate in the bar's application scheme and in February it will be debating measures to introduce funding for pupillages across the board.

Matt Swallow of The Lawyer magazine says that the Bar Council figures are misleading in that they represent only the people who are taken on to professional training courses. "Of those there is a ridiculously small proportion of people getting pupillage and getting tenancy is even harder," he says.

Money is still a major issue in the profession. The big salaries are earned only by the few: according to a salary survey carried out by accountants BDO Stoy Hayward the estimated net receipts for a barrister in years one to five are between £15,000-35,000, rising to £33,000-69,000 after five years.

The best-paid QC earned £268,000, although these figures mainly represent earnings in the smaller, general criminal and legal chambers. The big commercial sets can pay £25,000 just for pupillage and after five years as a common-law barrister you could be netting up to £100,000. Specialists earn more than generalists.

But still these figures are not excessive when you consider the training (the Bar Council exams cost around £7,000, plus living expenses) and expertise of these individuals. Mr Swallow warns that because of the in creased rights of solicitors to represent clients in court, many people looking at a career at the bar may be better off training with a large commercial law firm and later moving to chambers when they want to be self-employed. "The big firms will pay your way through law school and the training programme guarantees employment for two years. Many of them also guarantee that you will gain advocacy experience," he says.

Mark Humphries, head of advocacy at City law firm Linklaters, agrees, but says that in Australia, where this kind of training system for self-employed advocates exists, the norm is for people to stay with the law firm for around 15 years before making the switch.

But Bar Council spokesman Jon McLeod argues this is too simplistic: "There is no evidence that this is yet happening in the UK... The solicitors' training does not have the pure emphasis on advocacy work which a barrister would have had, and in any case the bar attracts individuals who do not want to work in practice with others."

He also argues that charges of elitism are unfair as the bar was the first profession to introduce comprehensive equality rules, and ones drawn up by legal minds with the highest levels of expertise in the area of equal opportunities at that.

But this does not solve the problem that new entrants to the bar often find it difficult to find enough work. "Some people are now saying that the bar will not exist in 10 years, but I think this is over-egging it," says Mr Swallow. "There will definitely always be a specialist advocacy profession in this country, but I think it will shrink to half the size of the present one. This is a problem for new entrants. It is now very hard for people to come in and find enough work to build a reputation."

In this atmosphere specialising is more about survival than earning big bucks. Whether on the criminal or commercial side, barristers need to be as good at marketing themselves as advocating for their clients.

The sticker: 'Bar is a matter of pure academic ability'

Jolyon Maugham, 29, is a barrister specialising in tax and working in London. "I love my job. The principal fact about the work I do is that it is a great intellectual challenge; it's not really something you can get bored of because you never feel that you have mastered it.

"You constantly feel as if you are on the brink of being awful at it. I also do some teaching work, which increases the diversity of my working week."

His specialism means that he does little advocacy work (representing clients in court) and instead is mostly called upon to give opinion, either in written form or "at conference", that is, verbally in meetings.

He studied law at Durham University and went on to take a Masters in European law in Brussels. He was then offered tenancy in the chambers of Lord Irvine. "They were prestigious chambers. There were a few things on my CV which they liked, such as the fact that I had a reference from the Belgian Advocate General and had done a lot of European law at the Court of Justice. The BBC has also broadcast a play of mine: I think these were evidence of an ability to look at things in a different way.

"The bar is a referral business - you need to get on with solicitors so they will use your services again - so you have to be able to get along with people.

"But it is also quite definitely a matter of pure academic ability. This is the way in which I would agree that it is still an elite profession - it is an elite of intellectual capabilities - but I would not agree that you cannot get on unless you come from a certain background or a particular school, although I do agree that certain chambers recruit images of themselves, and if you are not like that, you are unlikely to be taken on." He attended a state school in New Zealand and does not come from a legal family - his father is a writer.

He himself has been victim of sexism in the legal profession: as a student he was sent by a temping agency to carry out secretarial work for a law firm, which promptly sent him back upon discovering that he was a man.

Mr Maugham sued and was awarded damages, but he says that he has sees no evidence of sexism at the bar. "I also love working for myself. If I want to go home at 2pm and watch High Society on television, I can," he says.

The quitter: 'You deal with a lot of thankless clients'

Diana Galpin, 31, had wanted to be a barrister all her life, had a law degree from Kingston university, had, like most people, paid her own way through bar school, attained tenancy in chambers and worked for five years before she decided to quit the profession for a dot.com company.

"I think I had a more realistic expectation than many people about what the profession would be like, because I had worked for a couple of years before coming in. I knew that I would be self-employed, and so that there would be a degree of insecurity - although I did think that there would be more security once I had qualified.

"It is not a glamorous profession. Most of it is man management, having to deal with solicitors who don't always know what they are doing, or others who are as qualified as you or more so. You have to have a professional approach without being condescending or overbearing: with the good ones you have to show you can hold your own even though they have been doing their job for 20 years and you have been doing yours for two.

"But you must deal with a lot of thankless clients. There is now a culture of 'I've cut my finger, let's sue.' There are a lot of genuine cases, but there are also a lot of whingers and television advertising is making the situation worse."

She says the work was intellectually stimulating, but repetitive. "When you got a new case and had to forge new areas of the law it was brilliant, but it was easy to reach a plateau in your work.

"I quite enjoyed the traditions. The best training is discussing cases with other, more experienced barristers, so in principle the idea of dining is a good one: it can provide you with a network of people you see regularly. The problem was that you tended to mix only with other students, so you didn't really get to learn your trade this way.

"In the last couple of years I became very demoralised. I was in the wrong chambers for the work I wanted to do, and although I did think of changing, it is very hard. I tried a couple of times, but it is better to sit tight for five years if you want to be taken seriously.

"Most of the cases which reached me should not have gone to litigation; I think that often people argue unnecessarily and solicitors fuel the fire. Now I feel I am in a far more constructive position."

She is now business development manager for an internet company and has no regrets about her decision to quit: "I am not earning as much as I could have done at the bar but I don't have to do my own VAT or tax, I get paid for holidays and I don't have to wait for my money."

webTitle: Letter bombs linked to animal rights terror

fields.headline: Letter bombs linked to animal rights terror
fields.trailText: Police forces across the north were put on the alert for a new wave of animal rights terrorism yesterday after two letter bombs exploded at a farm and an agricultural auctioneers.
fields.body:
Police forces across the north were put on the alert for a new wave of animal rights terrorism yesterday after two letter bombs exploded at a farm and an agricultural auctioneers.

The blasts in Yorkshire, which injured a farmer and may have damaged the eyesight of a secretary, followed a similar mail bomb sent to a pest control firm last week in Cheshire, which injured the owner's six-year-old daughter.

A fourth device was also made safe on December 15 at an agricultural business in Masham, north Yorkshire.

The county's deputy chief constable, Peter Walker, last night warned anyone connected to the animal trade to be on their guard and said they should not open unexpected packages.

Meanwhile in Kent, 46 hounds worth almost £100,000 were stolen by the Animal Liberation Front from a Beagle kennel near Wye College, in the early hours of yesterday.

The group claimed responsibility for the theft in an email to a local radio station in which activist James George claimed the dogs had been kept in inhumane conditions. However, hunt secretary Will Denne dismissed the accusation insisting the beagles, which are bred to hunt hares, were well cared for.

As the search for the hounds continued last night, detectives in Yorkshire continued to piece together evidence from the three attacks.

Padded envelopes containing batteries, small nails and ball bearings were used in all three attacks, for which no-one has claimed responsibility. Detectives are not yet ruling out other motives but animal issues are common to each of the targets.

"We are liaising with other forces including the Metropolitan police anti-terrorist branch to see if the cases are definitely linked," said Mr Walker. "It is only by good fortune that no one has been seriously injured or killed.

The first of yesterday's incidents saw the centre of the east Yorkshire village of Patrington sealed off after an explosion, triggered when 43-year-old Janet Blythe opened a Jiffybag at local estate agents Frank Hill and Sons.

The explosion rocked the two-storey building, and Mrs Blythe, who had only recently recovered from heart problems, was taken to Hull Royal Infirmary, suffering from facial injuries.

Frank Hill's is well known on the Holderness peninsular of east Yorkshire for livestock and farm auctions and a friend of its 80-year-old founder, Charles Hill, who keeps sheep on an estate near Patrington, said that animal rights extremists were inevitably in the frame.

The second blast saw a 58-year-old farmer near Ripon, North Yorkshire, have what police called a miraculous escape, when he opened a nail bomb which splintered furniture. The farmer, who is not being identified for his own protection, escaped with minor facial injuries and severe shock.

Police appealed to anyone in the agricultural industry to clearly identify packages when sending routine mail.

Army bomb disposal experts from Catterick military base in north Yorkshire are examining debris from both of yesterday's devices.

Mrs Blythe was in a comfortable condition last night, with injuries to her face and eyes. The child victim of the Cheshire bomb is recovering from superficial injuries to her legs.

Detectives are not yet ruling out other motives but animal issues are common to each of the targets. "We are liaising with other forces including the Metropolitan police anti-terrorist branch to see if the cases are definitely linked," said Mr Walker. "It is only by good fortune that no one has been seriously injured or killed. The first of yesterday's incidents saw the centre of the east Yorkshire village of Patrington sealed off after an explosion, triggered when 43-year-old Janet Blythe opened a Jiffybag at local estate agents Frank Hill and Sons. The explosion rocked the two-storey building, and Mrs Blythe, who had only recently recovered from heart problems, was taken to Hull Royal Infirmary, suffering from facial injuries. Frank Hill's is well known on the Holderness peninsular of east Yorkshire for livestock and farm auctions and a friend of its 80-year-old founder, Charles Hill, who keeps sheep on an estate near Patrington, said that animal rights extremists were inevitably in the frame. The second blast saw a 58-year-old farmer near Ripon, North Yorkshire, have what police called a miraculous escape, when he opened a nail bomb which splintered furniture. The farmer, who is not being identified for his own protection, escaped with minor facial injuries and severe shock. Police appealed to anyone in the agricultural industry to clearly identify packages when sending routine mail. Army bomb disposal experts from Catterick military base in north Yorkshire are examining debris from both of yesterday's devices. Mrs Blythe was in a comfortable condition last night, with injuries to her face and eyes. The child victim of the Cheshire bomb is recovering from superficial injuries to her legs.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Briton to return for murder trial
fields.body:
Briton to return for murder trial

A Dutch court yesterday rejected an attempt to block the extradition of William Beggs, 37, of Kilmarnock, Ayrshire, to stand trial for murder.

Parts of the dismembered body of Barry Wallace, 18, also from Kilmarnock, were found 60 miles apart after he disappeared in 1999. Beggs denies the killing, and claimed "negative" media coverage might prejudice a fair trial.

Damages for early retirement

An industrial tribunal in Leeds yesterday awarded undisclosed damages against West Yorkshire police to former constable Jeanette Lundy, 27.

It had earlier found the force had discriminated when, following injuries she received in a car crash on duty, it advanced her early retirement on hearing she was pregnant.

Nudist appears naked in court

Vincent Bethell, 28, appeared naked at Southwark crown court in south London yesterday to deny causing a public nuisance last summer "by being naked in a public place and refusing to clothe himself". Senior judge George Bathurst-Norman told the nudist campaigner to remain seated in the waist-high dock throughout the proceedings - including when the judge entered or left, when it is a requirement for all to stand. The case continues.

Kray associate 'stitched up'

Dave Courtney, 41, from south London and a former associate of the Krays, yesterday issued a writ against the Metropolitan police and the crown prosecution service, claiming that the force had attempted to have him murdered.

It follows his acquittal in a recent Old Bailey trial in which he was branded a police informer. "The police have tried to stitch me up," he said. "People want me dead."

webTitle: Four-pint driver jailed for crash that killed his son

fields.headline: Four-pint driver jailed for crash that killed his son
fields.trailText: A man was jailed for 2 years yesterday after killing his only son in a car crash on the night before his sixth birthday.
fields.body:
A man was jailed for 2 years yesterday after killing his only son in a car crash on the night before his sixth birthday.

William Robson, 34, sobbed in the dock at Maidstone crown court, Kent, as he was sentenced for killing his son, Joshua, after drinking four pints of strong lager. At an earlier hearing in December, he had pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving while having an excess of alcohol in his blood, and to driving without insurance.

After the case, his former girlfriend and the mother of Joshua, Tracy Mahoney, 29, said: "The sentence was not long enough. Would you think it was if it was your child? Joshua had everything to look forward to. In any other country [Robson] would have got 10 years for that."

Sentencing Robson, Judge Andrew Patience said: "It was an act of madness to drive having drunk in that way."

The court heard Robson drank four pints of Stella Artois before he crashed a friend's Vauxhall Vectra into a steel bollard at Ashford, Kent, in March last year. Joshua died in hospital. The boy and his sister, Collette, eight, were in the back of the car when it crashed.

Robin Johnson, prosecuting, said the children were wearing seat-belts but Joshua seemed to have slipped his arm out of the shoulder strap. Collette, who suffered internal injuries, was transferred to Guy's Hospital, London.

Miss Mahoney left a note on the front door of her home in Shadoxhurst, near Ashford, telling other parents and their children that Joshua's party had been cancelled.

Michael O'Sullivan, defending, said Robson, a machine operator, was grief-stricken by "a one-off momentary error of judgment."

Mr O'Sullivan said Robson was driving at 30mph when he was distracted by the children playing in the back. As he looked round to tell them off, the car hit the unlit bollard.

fields.headline: Parent's woe hits First Tuesday
fields.standfirst:
New meaning to B2B at net club

More net news
fields.trailText: First Tuesday, the European networking organisation for internet entrepreneurs, could be forced to dramatically scale down its business because pressure is being applied to its parent company to cut back or even close.
fields.body:
First Tuesday, the European networking organisation for internet entrepreneurs, could be forced to dramatically scale down its business because pressure is being applied to its parent company to cut back or even close.

Yazam, the Israeli investment group which bought the networking "club" for an estimated $50m last July, has been approached about a radical restructuring by investors anxious to recoup their stakes.

At the forefront of investors' minds has been the departure of Yazam's chief executive and the downturn in the dot.com sector.

First Tuesday was in the vanguard of internet start-ups, helping to launch businesses such as Confetti, Lastorders and the ill-fated Clickmango, which went into voluntary liquidation.

First Tuesday's prevailing culture has been turned on its head by recent events, with people leaving the sector and returning to jobs in old technology businesses referring to B2B - "back to banking" - moves and the B2C - "back to consulting" - exodus.

Investors in Yazam have asked the company, whose core business is funding hi-tech start-ups, to consider a number of options including liquidation, a source said.

This would allow them to recoup some of the $40m left in the company.

Yazam's high profile investors include Texas Pacific Group, the Carlyle Group, Merrill Lynch, JP Morgan and Apax Partners. The company was able raise $60m in investment last summer.

However, the source said, the most likely move now for Yazam is a dramatic reduction in size, with the company writing off weaker investments and focusing on the management of its core portfolio.

Yesterday Shlomo Kalish, the chairman of Yazam, said: "Like all responsible companies in our area, given the turn of events in the financial markets, many options are being considered to reduce our burn rate.

"This includes taking a hard look at all our business units, but winding down First Tuesday is not an option."

Scaling back the network was a possibility, he admitted.

First Tuesday was founded by four friends two years ago in a bar in Soho, London.

The organisation started life as little more than a series of drinks parties for like-minded entrepreneurs to meet venture capitalists, but quickly grew into a network of meetings held in other British cities and later around the world on the first Tuesday of each month.

The sale to Yazam last summer is thought to have been welcomed by at least two of First Tuesday's founders - who were glad to cash in on the wave of enthusiasm for internet start-ups.

A third co-founder, Julie Meyer, a former venture capitalist and the driving force behind many of First Tuesday's activities, lobbied hard against the sale, only $1m of which was paid for in cash.

First Tuesday declined to comment yesterday.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Guide to railfares

fields.headline: Off-peak travel? It's just the ticket
fields.standfirst: Rail fares are going up again although services remain abysmal. But Kate Harvey finds there are still many ways to ride cheaply
fields.trailText: Rail fares are going up again although services remain abysmal. But Kate Harvey finds there are still many ways to ride cheaply.
fields.body:
Train travel should be something we look forward to - a window seat looking out on our green and pleasant land, silver service at mealtimes, the chance to relax with a novel and porters to carry our Louis Vuitton cases to a waiting cab.

Dream on, especially at the moment, when the prime consideration is whether the train will ever reach its destination the same day, let alone on time. And to add insult to injury, some train operators have signalled fare increases from tomorrow. So, in the meantime, the only concern - other than arriving - should be to pay as little as legally possible.

Once railways charged by the mile. Now, thanks to a variety of ticket offers, the near-400 miles between London and Edinburgh can even be marginally cheaper than travelling half the distance to Leeds. A £225 first-class return to the Scottish capital includes two meals plus car parking while the £184 first-class return to Leeds only produces tea or coffee.

But most of the best deals are for second-class travellers prepared to avoid peak time.

Four can sometimes travel as cheaply as one - Silverlink offers up to four adults travelling off-peak on its Birmingham to London route a ticket for the price of two, and GNER to Leeds has a deal that two, three or four people can travel from only £54 return.

And if you know what to ask for, travel from A to B can cost you very little - although sometimes from B to A can be even less. As a general rule, return journeys originating in London are more expensive than similar trips starting elsewhere. Marketing executives have decreed that Londoners have more money - on the other hand, those living outside are more prone to jump into their cars and so need more encouragement to take to the rails.

London-Bath

Costs range from £19 to £109 and booking in advance helps. For those travelling to Bath from Paddington by First Great Western, trains leave every 30 minutes with a 1 hour 20 minutes journey time costing £25.50 if booked the day before travel and £72 if you buy on the day of travel. First-class after 9.25am is £80.65, but £109 before.

If you're prepared to choose a slower and less frequent service from Waterloo on the Wales & West trains to Bath you will save about £45. If you buy your ticket on the day you travel it will cost only £24.90 and booked a day in advance just £19. The journey will take four hours, though.

London-Birmingham

Fares range from £15 to £137 and there is a choice of three routes from London to Birmingham; the fast Virgin service and two slower ones, Silverlink or Chiltern. Euston to Birmingham by Virgin can cost as much as £80, if the ticket is bought on the day of travel, and takes just under two hours - trains should leave every 30 minutes. Being prepared to spend an extra half hour or so on a train can produce significant savings. It can take up to three hours travelling by Silverlink, but will cost you only £16.90 return if you leave Euston after 9.30 compared to £34.90 return if you travel earlier.

A slightly quicker option with Chiltern will take two hours and 30 minutes. It departs from Marylebone, and arrives at Snow Hill, (10 minutes from the centre of Birmingham), and will cost only £21.50 return if travelling after 8.30 am.

But you can have speed and low fares by booking seven days in advance with Virgin. You could pay £15 to travel to Birmingham New Street while booking three days in advance will cost £22. Mind you, its first-class open return will set you back £137.

London-Swansea

Great Western Trains has the only practical London- to-Swansea route, and fares cost from £34 to £165. Departing from Paddington, it will cost you £34 if booked the day before travel. If bought on the day of travel it can cost as much as £112 return and only £50 more to travel first-class, £165 return.

London-Edinburgh

When travelling to Scotland, advance booking pays big dividends as fares range from £49 to £242. Kings Cross to Edinburgh by GNER is £77 return if the ticket is bought on the day of purchase, but booked a day in advance it is £63 and £49 if purchased seven days in advance. Buy an open first-class return and the charge is £242.

The Caledonian sleeper service between London and Scotland (Glasgow, Edinburgh) is only £89 return for a sleeper apex or a sleeper standard for £119 return.

You share the compartment, either with a friend or a same-sex stranger. A Scotrail sleeper apex ticket to Inverness and Aberdeen is £109 return, £185 sleeper standard to Inverness, and £2 more to Aberdeen. Travelling by day to Inverness and Aberdeen with a ticket booked seven days in advance only costs £55 return, while turning up on the day will cost £92.50 and £90.50 respectively.

Brighton-London

Taking a train from Brighton to London for the day, you can save money if you travel to a London terminus rather than add a tube journey. For example, if you travel to Farringdon via Thameslink after 9am it will cost you £14.60, but Brighton to Blackfriars - a 10-minute walk away - is £12 return.

It also pays to save money using network cards.

For £20 a year the Network railcard gives you a third off travel when catching virtually any weekday train after 10am in the south-east of England area or at any time at weekends.

Milton Keynes-Farringdon

A daily return from Milton Keynes to Farringdon costs £10.55 with a network card but an extra £1.35 each day without. There are further discount railcards for other groups.

Whenever you travel with children, a family railcard gives you one-third off the adult fares and applies to most national tickets.

The card costs £20 for the year and then all children under 16 years can enjoy 60% off the normal child fare.

For 16-25 year olds an £18-a-year young persons railcard will save one-third on most rail fares, a similar deal to the senior Railcard for people aged 60-plus.

Compensation you can expect for the delays

By the end of January thousands of people will have claimed compensation, as operators like GNER are giving its season ticket customers 22 days' free travel.

Connex, South Central and Scotrail, Central East are giving 15 days' and Silverlink's Northampton line and Southwest trains will both get 16 days' free travel, Virgin CrossCountry 21 days free.

Many other rail operators are offering similar compensation.

But one-off journeys can attract compensation as well. The train has to be delayed by one hour or more over the official timetable in force. And you must complain - don't expect the train operators to offer you a form voluntarily.

Will you be hit by the New Year increases?

Not all operators will be increasing fares tomorrow. Some will hold off until Easter when services should be back to normal and others will try to rebuild customer numbers with cut-price deals.

GNER will hold prices. Connex will give reductions on some season ticket prices. Virgin is freezing all prices and Thameslink is not increasing season tickets, although daily fares will increase by an average of 2.3%, and off-peak fares will rise by up to 4%.

All fares on Scotrail will rise by 2.3% and Southwest trains are putting prices up by an average of 2.4%.

fields.headline: 'Gold-digger' jailed for tricking widower
fields.standfirst: Five years for phoney scriptwriter who fleeced businessman out of £260,000 and then sought to damage his reputation
fields.trailText: Five years for phoney scriptwriter who fleeced businessman out of £260,000 and then sought to damage his reputation.
fields.body:
A ruthless gold-digger who swindled a lonely businessman out of £260,000 and then tried to blacken his name in court was jailed yesterday for five years.

Christina Wilson, who claimed she had been paid thousands of pounds to dress as a schoolgirl for kinky sex, cried out "It's so unfair" from the dock at Lincoln crown court as sentence was passed.

She was told by Judge Jonathan Teare that she had "mercilessly milked money" from former shipping agent John Weissberger, 63, by spinning a web of lies to persuade him to make her huge loans.

The retired widower, who met Wilson after advertising in a lonely hearts column, was made to believe that his new friend was a Hollywood screenwriter, a suddenly bereaved mother, and the victim of breast implants which had gone wrong.

As well as lying repeatedly about being a BBC playwright and having to bring an orphaned grandson back from Canada, the alleged former beauty queen and opera singer also laid siege to Mr Weissberger's reputation in court.

Her counsel, David Farrell QC, showed photographs of her wearing fake pigtails and bending over to be smacked, allegedly taken by Mr Weissberger in exchange for cash.

The smears were denied by Mr Weissberger and dismissed by Judge Teare yesterday. But Wilson's case also involved bringing up other, unproven allegations that Mr Weissberger had approached a woman at a supermarket and offered to pay for sex.

The judge ridiculed home-made security bonds offered to Mr Weissberger as security for loans of up to £94,000 and described Wilson's whole approach to her victim as a sham.

As well as concocting lies about a £9m Hollywood deal and a daughter's death on holiday, she invented a story about expecting compensation for a failed breast implant operation to extract more cash.

The lies had tricked Mr Weissberger into making at least 12 payments which left him almost destitute and having to put up his house at Woodhall Spa, Lincolnshire, for sale. Wilson, meanwhile, splashed out on cars and cosmetic surgery and built up a fortune in her bank account.

"You have been convicted on the clearest possible evidence," the judge told her. "You mercilessly milked Mr Weissberger of his life's savings.

"I have no doubt the total you obtained from him was well over a quarter of a million pounds. And when you were asking him for £5,500 and he was protesting he had nothing left, you had stored in your bank account £134,000."

Wilson, who chose not to give evidence and called no defence witnesses, interrupted, saying: "Your honour, I have not been allowed to put my point of view". But the judge went on: "You are a heartless gold-digger. You worked your way into his affections and then milked him for every penny you could.

"Not only that but you have blackened his name in a way he finds most distressing by alleging he had paid you for kinky sex." The businessman told the hearing that the sex allegations were a put-up job which would never be believed by anyone who knew him. He denied ever having sex with Wilson, taking photographs or seeing her undressed.

Before Wilson was jailed, the court was told that a psychiatric report on her said she was suffering from a hysterical personality disorder, which was characterised by self-dramatisation.

Mr Farrell, in mitigation, said that she had threatened suicide if found guilty. Wilson, of Grimsby, Lincolnshire, had denied 12 charges of procuring a valuable security by deception between February 1995 and September 1998. She is subject to court orders freezing her assets, which include an £80,000 house.

As well as lying repeatedly about being a BBC playwright and having to bring an orphaned grandson back from Canada, the alleged former beauty queen and opera singer also laid siege to Mr Weissberger's reputation in court. Her counsel, David Farrell QC, showed photographs of her wearing fake pigtails and bending over to be smacked, allegedly taken by Mr Weissberger in exchange for cash. The smears were denied by Mr Weissberger and dismissed by Judge Teare yesterday. But Wilson's case also involved bringing up other, unproven allegations that Mr Weissberger had approached a woman at a supermarket and offered to pay for sex. The judge ridiculed home-made security bonds offered to Mr Weissberger as security for loans of up to £94,000 and described Wilson's whole approach to her victim as a sham. As well as concocting lies about a £9m Hollywood deal and a daughter's death on holiday, she invented a story about expecting compensation for a failed breast implant operation to extract more cash. The lies had tricked Mr Weissberger into making at least 12 payments which left him almost destitute and having to put up his house at Woodhall Spa, Lincolnshire, for sale. Wilson, meanwhile, splashed out on cars and cosmetic surgery and built up a fortune in her bank account. "You have been convicted on the clearest possible evidence," the judge told her. "You mercilessly milked Mr Weissberger of his life's savings. "I have no doubt the total you obtained from him was well over a quarter of a million pounds. And when you were asking him for £5,500 and he was protesting he had nothing left, you had stored in your bank account £134,000." Wilson, who chose not to give evidence and called no defence witnesses, interrupted, saying: "Your honour, I have not been allowed to put my point of view". But the judge went on: "You are a heartless gold-digger. You worked your way into his affections and then milked him for every penny you could. "Not only that but you have blackened his name in a way he finds most distressing by alleging he had paid you for kinky sex." The businessman told the hearing that the sex allegations were a put-up job which would never be believed by anyone who knew him. He denied ever having sex with Wilson, taking photographs or seeing her undressed. Before Wilson was jailed, the court was told that a psychiatric report on her said she was suffering from a hysterical personality disorder, which was characterised by self-dramatisation. Mr Farrell, in mitigation, said that she had threatened suicide if found guilty. Wilson, of Grimsby, Lincolnshire, had denied 12 charges of procuring a valuable security by deception between February 1995 and September 1998. She is subject to court orders freezing her assets, which include an £80,000 house.

fields.headline: Muscle in on getting fit at the right price
fields.standfirst: Every January the fitness industry rubs its muscly thighs in glee as Christmas-fattened bellies hit the treadmills. Will their fat fees make you thin? Or just slim your wallet? This week Jobs & Money writers gave the major gym chains a financial workout
fields.trailText: Every January the fitness industry rubs its muscly thighs in glee as Christmas-fattened bellies hit the treadmills. Will their fat fees make you thin? Or just slim your wallet? This week Jobs & Money writers gave the major gym chains a financial workout.
fields.body:
Holmes Place

Location
42 centres, many in London but also in Bristol, Poole, Milton Keynes, Nottingham and opening shortly in Birmingham and Manchester.

The image
Upmarket but more quality four-star than luxury five-star. One of the fastest growing chains in the UK with centres offering deals with local employers.

The muscle
The London Barbican Holmes Place has a huge range of machines, running track, banks of televisions, workout rooms, 25m pool, sauna, jacuzzis and steam rooms, plus free towels.

The financial pain
Refuses to disclose precise charges "because it depends on an individual's circumstances and which company they work for". The London Barbican centre charges a joining fee of £40-£250 and monthly fees of £40 (off-peak) to £76 (peak). Total for one year: £858-£1,162.

The reality
Impressive, high-quality, facilities, upbeat, lively and efficient atmosphere - at a price. Very office-worker oriented - quiet during daytime but approaches overcrowding in evenings. Good value, popular restaurant, though somewhat worn-out looking.
Patrick Collinson

David Lloyd Leisure

Location
46 clubs in England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland.

The image
The UK's largest chain of health and fitness clubs with 200,000 members. Recently added 12 Curzon clubs in London and 50 Marriott Hotel Country Clubs to its portfolio. Emphasises racquet sports and family membership.

The muscle
The club at Castle Farm in Newcastle upon Tyne is one of the group's largest with five indoor and six outdoor tennis courts, 25m indoor pool with sauna, steam room, and children's pool, fully equipped gym, separate free weights room, aerobic dance studio and creche.

The financial pain
One-off joining fees range from £200-£400, with some clubs running special offers during January. Monthly membership costs range from £48-£127 with discounts for senior citizens, students and children. Total cost to join the Newcastle club for one year (excluding racquet sports): £687.

The reality
Impressive facilities and enough capacity to satisfy demand at even the busiest periods. The Newcastle centre has worked hard at creating a "clubby" atmosphere with its classes and active social programme of evening events. The club is also trying to become more family-friendly with weekend lessons for children, which makes the shameful rule that only able-bodied adults can eat in the carpeted area of the restaurant all the more absurd.
Ian Wylie

Cannon's

Location
38 centres, many in London but including Liverpool, Portsmouth, Swindon and other clubs across England and Wales. The same group also runs the exclusive Harbour club in London and 'Courtney' gyms attached to public recreation centres across the UK.

The image
Strong reputation as one of the first 'luxury' gym clubs opened in the 1980s, it remains at the top-end of the gym world, although other chains now largely match Cannon's facilities.

The muscle
Most centres have wide range of machines, rooms and pools. Coombe Grove Manor, an exclusive country club and hotel outside Bath has a Cannon's gym, aimed at families rather than corporate membership, with gym, in and outdoor swimming pool, sauna, jacuzzi, aerobic studio, four tennis courts and a golf course. Beauty facilities come as extras.

The financial pain
Coombe has a joining fee of £150 but this is being waived at the moment, plus a one off payment of £750 for the year. The Cannon's Connection card gives access to all 38 gyms at £100 joining fee and £78 a month, making a total for the year of £1,036. The Harbour club is £775 plus £100 per month, total £1,995.

The reality
"This gym is very hard to fault" says Bianca Bridges a member of Coombe. The staff are very friendly and when you join you are given a fitness assessment and programme. "The setting and environment is perfect for a fitness/health club," says Ms Bridges. Perfection comes at a high price.
Juliet Shedden

Fitness First

Location
13 centres, London and Manchester.

The image
Fitness First, owned by ex-squash star Mike Corby, operates 13 gyms, all but one of which is in London (Manchester opened this year). Just three are open at weekends and have a pool. The group is one of the only independently-owned gym chains in the country and its brand image is middle market and friendly.

The muscle
The Tottenham Court Road branch in London has a 14m pool, small sauna and steam cubicles, two aerobic studios holding an average of 56 classes a week and a large gym area with cardio-vascular, cross-training and weight training sections.

The financial pain
The joining fee is £150 plus a monthly fee of £70.50 for peak membership and £46.50 off-peak and this includes all classes bar a couple of esoteric martial arts sessions. Total for one year (peak time): £996.

The reality
The gym has a friendly feel and the staff seem both knowledgeable and genuinely caring. The pool is a reasonable size and one side of it is laned off. On the downside, the gym feels more utilitarian than luxurious, the changing rooms are carpeted which feel and look unpleasant and the studios are not soundproofed, so if you take a Pilates class you will hear the step teacher next door barking instructions.
Liz Stuart

YMCA

Location
29 gyms around the UK, including Bolton, Doncaster, Manchester, Plymouth, Sheffield and West Bromwich.

The image
The 'value' end of the market, focusing on core facilities rather than free towels and jacuzzis. Each centre is autonomous and equipment and facilities vary markedly.

The muscle
The Central YMCA in London (Great Russell St), the organisation's biggest gym, boasts a full-size 25m swimming pool, machine and free weights rooms, a sports hall for badminton and basketball, several step/workout rooms offering a vast array of classes - and a chapel.

The financial pain
The joining fee is £85 plus an annual fee of £420 for peak membership, £300 off-peak. Total for one year: £505. Considerable discounts for under-26s and senior citizens.

The reality
Rapidly improving worn-out facilities after competition from the new gym chains, although running/rowing/cycling machines still less numerous than other (admittedly much pricier) gyms. Plus points include a general inclusivity - a broader mix of young, old, ethnic and disabled than other gyms - and the quality of its fitness instructors, as it is the centre which trains most trainers.
Patrick Collinson
