webTitle: Mark Lawson: Even the toady press is royal-bashing

fields.headline: Relegated royals
fields.standfirst:
Suddenly even toadyish parts of the British press are beginning to bash the Windsors

Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Suddenly even toadyish parts of the British press are beginning to bash the Windsors.
fields.body:
Last week, the Times printed its traditional New Year letter from the reader who tots up the ribbons cut and hands shaken by each member of the royal family during the previous year. He carefully divides visitations from the Windsor clan into five categories lettered A-E, with a footnote warning that numerical supremacy should not necessarily impress. Lunch at an orphanage in Belize may be worth three brisk walkabouts in Norfolk villages. Allowance should also be made for artificial hips and privy council duties in camera.

For some time, the letter has seemed an oddity in a newspaper run by a prominent Australo-American republican, but, this year, the incongruity truly shocked. Coming across it in the columns was like finding yourself as a character in one of those period TV serials in which a crisp facsimile copy of the Times from 1950 lies on the breakfast table.

Because, by now, a majority of Times readers surely find the handshake-table as quaint and strange as the paper's proprietor would. And, even for those who still read the feature with interest, its meaning has subtly changed. A letter which was initiated as a bulwark against criticism of The Family - value for money, days to remember for a lifetime, national ambassadors, priceless tourism asset, blah blah blah - now seems more likely to fuel rebukes. Is that all she did? How many months at Balmoral this year then?

The reason is that the plaque-and-bouquets league table for 2000 was published in a week when the royal family was suffering an extraordinary relegation in cultural and media esteem. We should be very wary of the word "unprecedented", because of the abdication crisis, so triumphantly survived. But that problem involved the crushing of one royal bad apple into a cider in which the public might again drink toasts. This week's newspapers contained a whole tainted barrel-load.

Anne was under continued attack for her bizarre sarcasm to Mrs Iris Halfpenny, who trekked through the night from the Midlands to Sandringham to deliver a flower-basket at Christmas church. Edward and Sophie were nastily reported first to be occupying separate bedrooms, and then to have interviewed a society nanny ahead of any announcement or assumption of conception.

Andrew was photographed in trunks on the deck of a yacht off the Thailand coast, surrounded by topless totty, in scenes captioned with abdication-era sneers about the Playboy Prince. Most astonishingly, Margaret, the unfortunate victim of what appears to be a second stroke - to add to debilitating burns on her legs - received not the expected sympathy but moralistic commentary about how her brain had suffered the consequences of too much smoking and drinking during extended holidays in the West Indies. The implication seemed to be that she had been crocked by monarchy and privilege.

The coverage of Margaret's sickness was remarkable in breaking simultaneously two traditions of mainstream British journalism: sycophancy towards the older royals and sentimentality towards public figures revealed to be seriously ill. Even in the case of Reggie Kray, a sick-note let him off some of the columnists' games, but the general view seemed to be that the Queen's sister had got what was coming to her.

In the past, the Daily Mail has been, among the British prints, the most solicitous toady-in-waiting to the Windsors. It's true that there have been spasmodic attacks on Philip's crankiness, Fergie's weight and vulgarity, Charles's vegetarian mysticism and adultery, and the daffiness of Diana, at least before death made her a saint in tabloid heaven. Even so, the general monarchism of the publication and its readership was taken for granted.

In the past few days, however, there has been a suspicion that the paper is running the royal pennant down the flag-pole, deliberately to see if the hot air of readers on the correspondence page flutters it back to the top. The Mail's queen pundit, Lynda Lee-Potter, suggested that Anne's barking at the flower woman finally told us what the royals are really like, in opinions lavishly promoted on the paper's front page. Merely from this week's pieces about Anne, Margaret, Andrew and Edward, the visiting Martian traditionally invoked on these occasions would have got the impression that the royal family harboured arrogance, alcoholism, lechery and a sham marriage.

Where have all the bouquets gone? Last week, I wrote here about the collapsing popularity of the Queen's Christmas address on television in terms which, even five years ago and even in the editorially sceptical Guardian, would have prompted angry defences of the monarch. And yet, this time, the only dissent came not from monarchists but Christians who had misunderstood my point about the Queen's public piety. (To clarify, her deep Christianity is sincere and commendable; my objection is that the expression of it is unlikely to popularise the monarchy in a Britain which is secular or multi-faith.)

What's happened, I think, is that, as predicted, the low ratings for the TV speech have been taken by newspapers as a thermometer of monarchism. British journalism has been given courage, or at least curiosity, to explore the opposition.

Is it, though, a blip or a bloodless revolution? In the past, when royal popularity has dipped, historians and commentators usually assumed that simpering equilibrium would be restored around the focal point of a royal wedding or funeral. But there have been so many divorces in the family now that Windsor nuptials are conducted with a book fairly openly running, among press and public, on the date when his and hers removal vans will draw up outside the grace-and-favour residence. And, against any expectation, even the first major royal funeral of the late 20th century encouraged republican rather than monarchist sentiment.

Unless the actuarial tables are entirely flouted, at least one other cortege will head for Westminster Abbey within the next 10 years, but you wonder now if, even among reliable purveyors of bowing and curtsying journalism in the past, those events will be covered in a tone not consolidatory but valedictory. You increasingly feel that the chap in middle England diligently listing the garden parties and plaque unveilings may think that he is counting up but is, in fact, counting down the royals.

comment@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Star gazer who skinned the City big guns
fields.standfirst: 'The summer solstice could have a major impact on markets, by Jupiter. And stub out your tobacco stock'. Tony Levene looks ahead
fields.trailText: 'The summer solstice could have a major impact on markets, by Jupiter. And stub out your tobacco stock'. Tony Levene looks ahead.
fields.body:
Last year we asked financial astrologer Christeen Skinner for her top share tips - and she outperformed most City pundits.

Her predictions here a year ago of a downturn at Express Newspapers, Clinton Cards and Tomkins and a good 12 months for Manchester United all proved correct.

What about this year? A solar eclipse on the summer solstice on June 21 could have a major impact on markets. "It could eclipse some top company bosses and point to a hard landing for the world economy," says Christeen. "Unilever is the big one based on birth date, time and place. It may have a big direction change and take a stock market buffeting," she says.

Cadbury-Schweppes and Pilkington are also to be avoided but the eclipse could mark a turning point for Tate & Lyle where Ms Skinner foresees an acidic start but a sweeter second half. But stub out your shares in tobacco group BAT Industries.

"I would stay well clear of this one especially as it is vulnerable to huge legal action from anti-smoking groups.

"The planets on May 6 when Jupiter passes opposite Pluto indicate a global giant in trouble - it could be a tobacco firm or a computer company such as Microsoft but I can't be more specific," she says.

US financial astrologer Henry Weingarten also sees huge significance in May 6. "It's halfway between December 1994 when whales first started eating whales - the era of mega-mergers - and December 2007 when baby boomers are forecast to exit the market," he says.

Weingarten is also wary of tobacco - expecting more smoking bans although corporate action could bring rewards to Philip Morris stockholders.

But there is some optimism. Ms Skinner expects good aspects from the opposition of Saturn and Neptune in the autumn. "This will be good for dotcoms, hi-techs and for bio-technology," she says.

Both Weingarten and fellow US astrologer Eugenia Last failed to forecast this week's US interest rate cut. But Ms Last is now looking for market volatility in early February while March could be a good month thanks to the position of Jupiter, the planet of abundance, in the birth chart of the New York stock exchange.

Mr Weingarten is gloomy about US prospects in 2001. Last May's Jupiter-Saturn conjunction was instrumental in the tech stock downfall, he claims, and this will continue to influence markets, leading to more realistic stock valuations.

This year, the interaction between Jupiter and Pluto and between Saturn and Pluto signals more failed mergers and further anti-globalisation prospects.

And he sees the dollar slipping. The financial world has been warned!

webTitle: Polls put Sharon way ahead in Israeli election

fields.headline: Polls put Sharon way ahead in Israeli election
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Ariel Sharon, the former Israeli defence minister vilified by Arabs and the left for his involvement in the Lebanon massacres almost 20 years ago, is cruising to victory in the Israeli prime ministerial election, according to polls published yesterday.
fields.body:
Ariel Sharon, the former Israeli defence minister vilified by Arabs and the left for his involvement in the Lebanon massacres almost 20 years ago, is cruising to victory in the Israeli prime ministerial election, according to polls published yesterday.

The widespread assumption on the left in the country is that victory on February 6 for Mr Sharon, a hawk, will mean the end of the already faltering peace process.

Polls published in two Israeli daily newspapers, the Maariv and the Yediot Ahronot, gave Mr Sharon 50% of the vote. The Yediot Ahronot poll put the prime minister, Ehud Barak, on 32% and the Maariv gave him only 22%, reflecting the disillusionment with his handling of the peace negotiations and with the resumption of violence.

The increase in support for the right in the polls coincided with a series of protests by Jewish settlers on the West Bank. The settlers are set to join other hardliners in a huge protest outside the walls of Jerusalem's Old City on Monday.

A statement issued by the organisers yesterday predicted that "hundreds of thousands" will attend in a show of solidarity against concessions to the Palestinians offered by Mr Barak.

Flights have been chartered to bring in supporters from the United States, Britain, France and Russia, according to the statement.

Mr Barak has become such a hate figure for the right that one of his colleagues this week had to make a public appeal to stop the death threats being made against him by fellow Jews.

Meanwhile, Hagai Ben-Artzi, a rightwing activist and brother-in-law of the former prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu, accused Mr Barak of betraying Israel, during a settlers' demonstration outside the prime minister's residence.

Settlers on the West Bank, unnerved by the fatal shooting of Binyamin Kahane, the leader of a rightwing extremist group, on New Year's Eve, have set up their own illegal observation posts and closed off access to Palestinian villages. The armed settlers claim these actions are necessary for their own protection.

At Ofra, a Jewish settlement near the spot where Mr Kahane and his wife were ambushed by Palestinian gunmen, the settlers have taken over a hilltop looking down on the main road and out over the Palestinian village of Ein Yabrud.

If the proposals put forward by the US president, Bill Clinton, were to be adopted, many of the Jewish settlements on the West Bank, such as Ofra, will have to be abandoned, and control passed to the Palestinian Authority.

A large Israeli flag has been defiantly hoisted above the Ofra post, which has attracted a steady stream of visitors from Israel to show support. The settlers also used a digger to put mounds of earth across the access roads to Ein Yabrud, blocking in the Palestinians.

Mr Sharon, less at home in front of television cameras than Mr Barak, has had a low-key campaign, giving few interviews.

He published his plan for a peace settlement this week in the Jerusalem Post, promising to accede to the demands of the settlers and right-wingers: Jerusalem will not be divided and the settlers will not be forced to uproot from the West Bank.

Mr Sharon, while defence minister in 1982, initiated the Israeli invasion of Lebanon. He was forced to resign after a commission of inquiry found him to be indirectly responsible for the massacres by Christian militia of Palestinian refugees in the Sabra and Shatilla camps, near Beirut.

Mr Barak's campaign team was forced to apologise to Mr Sharon yesterday for placing an advertisement in the Arab press showing scenes from the massacres and asking: "Who knows [Mr Sharon's history] more than you?"

webTitle: Liberty Surf in talks with Italian rival

fields.headline: Liberty Surf in talks with Italian rival
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Internet service provider Liberty Surf was the focus of speculative attention yesterday after Italian rival Tiscali announced that it was in talks with the French group.
fields.body:
Internet service provider Liberty Surf was the focus of speculative attention yesterday after Italian rival Tiscali announced that it was in talks with the French group.

There were also reports that Liberty Surf - part owned by Kingfisher - is considering the closure of its non-French operations, including its British business, which employs just over 100 people.

Earlier this week Liberty Surf was linked with Belgium's state controlled telcoms group Belgacom - although the French firm would only say that it was in talks with a number of companies.

Yesterday French newspaper Les Echos said that Liberty Surf was planning to close its activities in Britain, Spain and Sweden in an attempt to cut costs. Some company sources appeared to confirm it was considering the option of concentrating on the French business, which accounts for the bulk of its 700,000 subscribers. Others sought to play down the suggestion.

"If they are considering scaling back their ambitions that's good news as far as I am concerned, as I am not convinced they can support their existing operations with the cash they have " said one analyst.

Liberty Surf is considered a second tier player in the European ISP sector, trailing some way behind leading players such as T-Online, Wanadoo, Tiscali and Terra Lycos - and is seen as being in need of a strategic partner.

fields.headline: The big give away
fields.standfirst:
Critics of multimillion donations would like Labour to be a party of amateurish losers

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Critics of multimillion donations would like Labour to be a party of amateurish losers.
fields.body:
Oh no, what a disaster! First the Labour party was given £2m, and then to make matters worse they've just been given another £4m. Millbank must be still reeling from these successive pieces of terrible news. The treasurer must be hanging his head in shame. "If only we were heavily in debt - then the Daily Mail wouldn't criticise us".

The truth is that these donations represent acts of humanitarian aid. Do the critics have any idea of the suffering that has been averted? Do they not realise how many Labour party karaoke nites it would have taken to raise £6m? Anyone who believes that all fundraising should be done by the membership has not had to endure the misery of spending an evening in a freezing cold tenants' hall, being forced to get up onto the stage and sing Hi Ho Silver Lining, while onlookers sip warm Liebfraumilch and finish off the vegetarian paté. They have never spent a day emptying binliners full of old jumble on to trestle tables, trying to persuade a pensioner to part with 10p for a faded El Salvador solidarity T-shirt.

They have never sat through a two hour debate over whether it is sexist to have a Father Christmas at the Christmas bazaar.

"All right, we'll have Mother Christmas then!"

"Point of order, comrades. Is not the whole Christmas-centric focus of this event a racist insult to other religious minorities?"

And then you spend the following Saturday failing to persuade any five-year-olds that they'd really like to go and visit "Mother Winter Solstice".

It takes a lot of money to run a modern political party but we have never had an election fought on a level playing field; the Tories have always spent more. A few years back Labour was consistently under attack for taking money from the unions and now it is being criticised for taking large donations from individual donors. What these critics are really implying is that the Labour party does not have the right to have as much money as the Tories. That Labour should be a party of amateurish losers. As a prospective Labour candidate I am undoubtedly biased, but I want the Labour party to be effective and for its workers to be decently paid. When I see Tory posters that have the gall to blame this government for the current rail crisis, I want Labour to have the funds to be able to counter this propaganda.

But they can't raise it all by selling little mugs that say "Tough on Crime", especially when everyone kept nicking them. So what is Labour expected to do, enter Tony Blair on Who Wants to be a Millionaire every week?

"OK Tony," says Chris Tarrant, "you've chosen to phone a friend; who do you want to call?"

"Er - Lord Hamlyn, he won't know the answer but he might give me a million or two anyway."

When I hear that Labour is going to have more money to fight the Tories at the election my overwhelming reaction is "Good!" The prime minister has cashed in his Sainsbury's Reward Card and found he had £2m in there. It's amazing how it builds up. At least now we know what happens to all those pound coins that get stuck inside the trolleys.

Of course there is an issue of what the donors expect to get in return and it might be a little tricky if the time ever comes to sack Lord Sainsbury from the government. Hopefully the Sainsbury's cash-back service will not apply.

Clive Soley did a fine job on Newsnight insisting that Labour would never consider repaying these donations with political honours, which was only slightly spoiled when he called Chris Ondaatje Lord Ondaatje by mistake.

But the only real mistake in this whole affair has been Labour's failure to observe one of the oldest rules of politics: always be completely open and above board with any information that the press could easily find out for themselves. This has meant that Labour has failed to get the credit for actually taking steps to clean up party funding, while the continuing secrecy of Tory party finances does not even seem to be an issue.

But now that Asil Nadir has fled the country and Jeffrey Archer is awaiting trial, the Tory party is currently being funded by its own treasurer, Michael Ashcroft. Nothing wrong with this except that he spends much of the year and has most of his business interests not in this country but in Central America. He's a one-nation Tory - it's just a shame that the nation is Belize. His name does appear on the electoral roll in the country, however, in the rock solid Tory seat of Maidenhead. This happens to be the seat in which I am Labour's prospective candidate. So the Labour party is going to need every penny it can get at the next general election. If only so that I can fly out to Belize to see if there's any chance of him voting for me.

webTitle: Should auld utopian visions be forgot?

fields.headline: Should auld utopian visions be forgot?
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: I will try to be less judgmental. Perhaps Jeffrey Archer is innocent. Perhaps the Dome was worth a billion pounds
fields.body:
Monday, January 1, 2001, 1.30am

I saw the new year in alone. Glenn has gone to a fancy-dress party at his mother's house. Rather disturbingly, he went as Hannibal Lecter. William is spending the weekend with his mother and her new husband, who are on honeymoon in London.

I hope my ex-wife and her new spouse can forget their sexual passion for long enough to pay proper attention to William. The lad has had two major disappointments in his life lately:

a) Santa's broken promise to bring him a Sony PlayStation 2;
b) Santa's broken promise to bring him a Barbie Plane.

As midnight struck, I reopened the bottle of sparkling chardonnay I failed to finish on Christmas Day, but the sparkle had gone out of it. So I poured it down the sink.

As I wrote the numbers 2001, I was transported back to a classroom at the Neil Armstrong comprehensive, and a lesson on "the future" given by Miss Elf, the humanities teacher. By 2001, according to Miss Elf, the world would be one, big, happy, cappuccino-coloured family. I remember her drawing this frontier-less world. How the chalk dust flew!

Miss Elf was a passionate and committed teacher. In fact, not long after I left school she was committed to the High Towers mental hospital, following a doomed staff-room romance with Podgy Perkins, the games master. He was married with seven children, all boys. (Interestingly, all the boys' names began with G.) Strange what the memory throws up.

Anyway, Miss Elf envisaged that, by 2001, there would be no hunger in the world and that everybody would have access to clean water and a flushing toilet. She drew a typical 2001 world family on the board, using a fresh box of coloured chalks. They all had brown skin and wore white, shiny, body-suits with pointy shoulders. Attached to their ankles were tiny jet engines. These devices enabled the 2001 family to fly like the birds. Though, as she pointed out, intercontinental travel would necessitate many refuelling stops.

Perhaps it is a good thing that Miss Elf is gibbering behind the high walls of an institution. She would be heartbroken to know that her utopian vision is as far away as ever, and that Israel and Palestine are still arguing the toss.

New Year Resolutions

1. I will try and secure the services of Dame Helena Kennedy in a bid to get my mother out of prison.
2. I will persist in trying to get my serial killer comedy, The White Van, made by the BBC.
3. I will try to be less judgmental. Perhaps Jeffrey Archer is innocent. Perhaps the Dome was worth a billion pounds.
4. I will look into the Buddhist religion with a view to becoming a cohort. I have always had a horror of treading on insects. Ants in particular.
5. I will attempt to fall in love with a suitable woman this year. One that doesn't cry a lot or use too much blue eye shadow.
6. I'll teach my son's the proper use of the apostrophe.

Tuesday, January 2

Pandora is back from Israel where she claimed to be on a fact-finding mission about Jerusalem. I remarked on her tan. She said, "Yeah, I managed to get a few days off in Eilat, swimming with the dolphins." How I envy Pandora's physical prowess! I would find it difficult to swim with goldfish.

I asked her if she was any nearer to achieving her medium-term goal, that of becoming foreign secretary. She tossed her treacle-coloured hair back and said, "It's acknowledged by those that count - Ian Hislop, Auberon Waugh and Andrew Rawnsley - that Robin's got to go. The man is now totally incomprehensible. How poor bloody foreigners understand his mad gabble, God only knows."

webTitle: Police move to curb sick leave

fields.headline: Police move to curb sick leave
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Police chiefs in England's second largest force have employed specialist medical staff in an attempt to curb a rapid rise in long-term sick leave over the past year.
fields.body:
Police chiefs in England's second largest force have employed specialist medical staff in an attempt to curb a rapid rise in long-term sick leave over the past year.

Hit by a recruitment crisis and rising crime, Greater Manchester police revealed yesterday that 1,183 of its 7,000 officers were off work for 28 days or more last year - one of the highest levels in Britain.

A report to the area's police authority concluded that long-term absences had reached unacceptable levels.

In-house psychiatric advice is now available at force headquarters to counsel staff in an attempt to bring down sickness levels, while trials are to begin with a company specialising in the rehabilitation of back-pain suffers.

"It is considered that early intervention, where appropriate, should lead to a reduction in long-term absence patterns but this will take some time to demonstrate its effectiveness," the report said.

Andrew Marston, chief executive of personnel for the authority, said: "We have to be prepared to try something different. We are less productive because officers are not here doing the work and it is a depressingly downward cycle if this is not addressed."

Mr Marston said there was concern among force chiefs at the 34% rise in the number of officers off work due to stress-related illnesses. Psychological disorders now account for more than a quarter of all long-term sickness in the force. "Doctors are more willing to put stress as a diagnosis and people are much more likely to self-diagnose," he said.

Vin Sweeny, deputy chief constable of Greater Manchester police, confirmed yesterday that he would be seeing the Home Office to request a tightening of the guidelines laid down for the calculation of absence statistics.

Greater Manchester police says its figures for absence are artificially inflated when compared with other forces. An independent auditor's report commissioned by the area's authority concluded that comparisons with other forces should be treated with "circumspection" because of differences in the methods of calculation.

fields.headline: Britain scraps islands' anti-gay laws
fields.trailText: Britain has scrapped anti-gay laws in its five Caribbean territories, acting after legislatures of the socially conservative and deeply religious islands refused to do so themselves.
fields.body:
Britain has scrapped anti-gay laws in its five Caribbean territories, acting after legislatures of the socially conservative and deeply religious islands refused to do so themselves.

London's move angered religious leaders, who say homosexuality is immoral and goes against the grain of their culture and religions.

"This is totally unacceptable to the minds of the Christian community here," Nicholas Sykes, chief pastor of the Church of England in the Cayman Islands, said Friday.

The order from the British Privy Council, which acts as the highest court for the territories, decriminalises homosexual acts between consenting adults in private.

The order went into effect this week and applies to Anguilla, the Cayman Islands, the British Virgin Islands, Montserrat and the Turks and Caicos.

Hundred-year-old laws inherited from Britain in the five territories had made homosexual intercourse illegal, with the punishment varying from island to island. Though the laws were rarely enforced, the Cayman Islands turned away a cruise liner chartered by 1,000 gay men in 1999.

The government said the anti-gay laws violate international human rights agreements it has signed. Britain has the power to unilaterally revoke the statutes, but had attempted for years to persuade local politicians to repeal the laws in island legislatures.

Religious leaders and local politicians said the disagreement over homosexuality reveals a widening cultural rift between what they condemned as an increasingly atheist Britain and its faraway Caribbean possessions.

The territories could opt for independence. But they do not appear to consider a break from the United Kingdom a serious option and appeared resigned to following the order.

"There is nothing we can do about it," said Orlando Smith, a legislator in the British Virgin Islands.

fields.bodyText: Britain has scrapped anti-gay laws in its five Caribbean territories, acting after legislatures of the socially conservative and deeply religious islands refused to do so themselves. London's move angered religious leaders, who say homosexuality is immoral and goes against the grain of their culture and religions. "This is totally unacceptable to the minds of the Christian community here," Nicholas Sykes, chief pastor of the Church of England in the Cayman Islands, said Friday. The order from the British Privy Council, which acts as the highest court for the territories, decriminalises homosexual acts between consenting adults in private. The order went into effect this week and applies to Anguilla, the Cayman Islands, the British Virgin Islands, Montserrat and the Turks and Caicos. Hundred-year-old laws inherited from Britain in the five territories had made homosexual intercourse illegal, with the punishment varying from island to island. Though the laws were rarely enforced, the Cayman Islands turned away a cruise liner chartered by 1,000 gay men in 1999. The government said the anti-gay laws violate international human rights agreements it has signed. Britain has the power to unilaterally revoke the statutes, but had attempted for years to persuade local politicians to repeal the laws in island legislatures. Religious leaders and local politicians said the disagreement over homosexuality reveals a widening cultural rift between what they condemned as an increasingly atheist Britain and its faraway Caribbean possessions. The territories could opt for independence. But they do not appear to consider a break from the United Kingdom a serious option and appeared resigned to following the order. "There is nothing we can do about it," said Orlando Smith, a legislator in the British Virgin Islands. Associaterd Press

fields.headline: Brown pledges jobs for all
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown will tonight set out a Labour manifesto pledge for the coming election that will commit Tony Blair's government to creating full employment in all the regions of Britain over the next five years.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown will tonight set out a Labour manifesto pledge for the coming election that will commit Tony Blair's government to creating full employment in all the regions of Britain over the next five years.

The chancellor will use a speech to the 150th anniversary dinner of the AEEU engineering union to restate Labour's radical credentials in terms of jobs for the long-term unemployed that are skilled and well-paid, rather than for the minimum wage.

Stopping only slightly short of confirming a spring general election, Mr Brown will say that it is time to set in place the programme for the New Deal in 2001-04 which will also include a tougher imposition of skills testing on benefits claimants.

The new tests, designed to get the hardcore jobless into the workforce, will amount to a skills audit that finds out what people lack in terms of basic literary and numeracy - "not punitive, but an assessment of their individual training needs", Brown aides stress.

"We will propose in our election manifesto measures to end long-term unemployment in our country and to make progress in doing so in each region," Mr Brown will say at the Grosvenor House hotel in London.

At the centre of the chancellor's ambitious plan, which reflects his conviction that Britain will escape the expected economic downturn in the US, are negotiations already under way with the IT industry to create training opportunities that will ease skill shortages in a cutting-edge industry - and create high-wage jobs.

In the pre-election budget likely to be presented on March 6 or 13, Mr Brown will offer what he calls "balanced" tax cuts - aimed at pensioners, families and the poor - rather than across-the-board cuts. He will also make great play of avoiding short-termism of the kind that ruined the later Thatcher-Major years.

"Historically Britain has failed to learn what pre-election budgets should be," Mr Brown said in an interview this week. "The budget we will set out in the spring will be one that will set out an economic manifesto, not for a month or two, but which will set out our economic proposals for the next five years."

In his speech, the chancellor will stress that "it is by combining opportunities with obligations - opportunity for those who accept responsibility - that we will make the greatest progress".

fields.headline: UN rebuffs British reforms
fields.trailText: British attempts to reform the way top jobs are handed out within the UN have been rebuffed by the secretary general, Kofi Annan, who faces mounting criticism for the secretive way in which he has awarded a number of recent posts responsible for multimillion pound budgets.
fields.body:
British attempts to reform the way top jobs are handed out within the UN have been rebuffed by the secretary general, Kofi Annan, who faces mounting criticism for the secretive way in which he has awarded a number of recent posts responsible for multimillion pound budgets.

Clare Short, the international development secretary, has said Britain would be willing to fund an open system of recruitment for the UN's top jobs, it emerged yesterday.

UN insiders and several governments have expressed their shock at Mr Annan's decision to invite Ruud Lubbers, a former prime minister of the Netherlands, to head the UN's refugee agency, controlling a budget of $953m, this week.

The appointment flabbergasted the Dutch government, which had put forward Jan Pronk, the current development minister.

But Mr Annan felt his style was abrasive and decided the best way to avoid him was to go higher. "We must trump him by finding a former prime minister or head of state," Mr Annan said, according to one top UN official. "If we get someone from the Netherlands, they cannot object".

The secretary general's power to hire people without shortlists or a selection committee is part of UN tradition. Yet Mr Annan started his tenure exactly four years ago as a self-proclaimed reformer.

Sir Brian Urquhart, who served as personal assistant to the first secretary general, said the "present system would be a disgrace to even the smallest university in the United States. But transparency is anathema to most governments".

Britain is taking up the issue. Clare Short's recent white paper on globalisation called for a system in which "competence would be put above considerations of nationality".

fields.headline: Mass killers
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Shipman trial
fields.trailText: If even the lowest estimate of 236 murders is correct, Harold Shipman would become one of the worst serial killers of all time.
fields.body:
If even the lowest estimate of 236 murders is correct, Harold Shipman would become one of the worst serial killers of all time.

In the past 100 years, only the murderous exploits of the Colombian serial killer Pedro Lopez come close to matching Shipman's toll. Lopez, branded "the monster of the Andes", raped and killed 300 young girls through Colombia, Ecuador and Peru during the 1970s. In 1999 Luis Alfredo Gavarito, also a Colombian, confessed to the rape, torture and murder of 140 children.

Until Shipman the most prolific British serial killer since 1900 was Dennis Nilsen, who confessed to murdering up to 16 young men, and was convicted for the murder of six.

The Yorkshire Ripper, Peter Sutcliffe, murdered 13 women, beginning in October 1975.

Fred West is thought to have killed 12 people at 25 Cromwell Street, Gloucester.

The most prolific of British murderers, until Shipman, was Mary Ann Cotton, who was hanged in Durham prison in 1873. She married three times and over 20 years used arsenic to poison as many as 21 people.

webTitle: Death in the afternoon - the chilling routine of a serial killer

fields.headline: Death in the afternoon - the chilling routine of a serial killer
fields.standfirst:
Ministers pressed to act after Shipman report raises toll to 236

Special report: the Shipman trial
fields.trailText: The government was under pressure last night to impose tighter controls on family doctors after an official audit of the career of the serial killer Harold Shipman calculated that he murdered at least 236 patients during 24 years as a GP.
fields.body:
The government was under pressure last night to impose tighter controls on family doctors after an official audit of the career of the serial killer Harold Shipman calculated that he murdered at least 236 patients during 24 years as a GP.

The report, establishing Shipman as the most prolific murderer in European history, revealed how warning signals were ignored. They included Shipman's frequent presence at the time of his patients' death, the absence of relatives, speed of death and the implausibility of information on death certificates.

The inquiry said there could have been no legitimate explanation for the timing of his patients' deaths, peaking abnormally between lunchtime and teatime in contrast to the normal pattern.

Richard Baker, professor of quality in healthcare at Leicester University, who conducted the inquiry, spoke of his "rage" at the betrayal by Shipman of his patients' trust.

A copy of the report was sent to Greater Manchester police, but the director of public prosecutions said it was unlikely the rogue doctor would face a further trial. Its seven recommendations included routine monitoring of GPs' patient death rates, fuller recording of patients' medical records on death certificates and tighter inspection of GPs' use of controlled drugs.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, avoided commenting on the proposals pending a judicial inquiry into the murders under Dame Janet Smith that is due to be set up over the next few weeks. But government sources said the damning report of persistent failure to act against Shipman as his patients died in excessive numbers between 1974 and 1998 would add to ministers' frustration about the slow pace of reform at the General Medical Council, the doctors' self-regulatory body.

Shipman was convicted last year of murdering 15 female patients with lethal doses of diamorphine. He is serving 15 life terms in Frankland prison, Durham. The audit of his medical career compared the death rate of his patients and those of other doctors with similar patient lists. It found Shipman was responsible for 297 "excess deaths" from 1975 - averaging one a month throughout his career as a GP.

Prof Baker said he was particularly concerned about 236 excess deaths of patients in their own homes or Shipman's surgery. That figure was the most likely estimate of the doctor's murder total.

Detailed analysis of Shipman's caseload since 1985, when fuller records became available, found 166 highly suspicious and 43 moderately suspicious deaths - more than half the total number of deaths of patients on Shipman's list. Although most of the victims were older women, they included 21 men.

Prof Baker said: "It is very hard to contemplate these findings without being concerned for the hurt and distress caused to people in Todmorden and Hyde [the areas where Shipman practised]. I feel rage, as a fellow professional, that someone betrayed the trust of people completely dependent on him."

Liam Donaldson, the chief medical officer, said: "It is horrific and inexplicable that this scale of activity was not detected earlier and this is what we are now looking at."

John Chisholm, chairman of the British Medical Association GPs committee, said: "I am determined that the medical profession will cooperate with and contribute to the public inquiry in order to prevent any possible recurrence of these appalling events."

Lawyers acting for relatives of suspected Shipman victims will now press for inquests into all his possible victims. Inquests into a further 24 possible victims are about to begin.

But Emma Smith, a spokeswoman for the law firm Alexander Harris which is representing 150 relatives, said many were upset that there might not be an inquest into the death of their loved ones. "The only proper thing now is for in quests to be held on every single suspected victim where the family requests it."

The South Manchester coroner John Pollard called for Shipman to come clean about his crimes. Even if a trial were not possible, confessions from Shipman would go a long way towards establishing the truth about his patients' deaths and helping families deal with their loss,he said.

Greater Manchester police said they would investigate any concerns from relatives of former patients of Shipman.

But the director of public prosecutions made it clear that there was almost no possibility of Shipman ever being brought back before a court.

David Calvert-Smith said: "He is now serving life, which means the rest of his natural life. The possibility of any jury being empanelled now which did not have a firm prejudice against Shipman, having read and heard all they would have heard over the last year or so, means that it is impossible really to say that he could have a fair trial."

The recommendations

The report made seven recommendations for tightening up the monitoring and accountability of doctors:

 Routine monitoring of GPs' patient death rates, medical records and prescribing of controlled drugs

 Collection of data on numbers of death certificates issued by each GP

 Death certificates to include information on circumstances of death and clinical history

 Periodic revalidation of GPs' fitness to practice should include assessment of standard of record-keeping

 Disposal of medical records of deceased patients should be more tightly controlled

 An effective system for inspecting GPs' drug registers should be introduced

 GPs should record batch numbers in clinical records when they administer controlled drugs

webTitle: Experts speculate over motive as Shipman refuses to talk

fields.headline: Does mother's early death offer pointer to GP's state of mind?
fields.standfirst:
Motive: Experts speculate as Shipman still refuses to talk

Special report: the Shipman trial
fields.trailText: Motive: Experts speculate as Shipman still refuses to talk.
fields.body:
Yesterday, as usual, Harold Shipman was woken shortly before 8am. If he followed his normal routine he would have washed and breakfasted before leaving his spartan home in the healthcare centre of Frankland prison, near Durham, for one of the prison workshops.

There he is learning to translate written text into Braille, which he has found suits his fastidious ways and his wish to do good - or at least be perceived to be doing good. One of the Harry Potter books is his first project.

He is said to have fitted in reasonably well in prison. He has always relished routine and his intelligence sets him apart from the normal prisoner.

In all likelihood he did not discuss yesterday's staggering revelations that he was probably responsible for the deaths of at least 236 patients. Nor is it probable he expressed sympathy for the distraught relatives of his victims.

For since his conviction almost a year ago he has steadfastly refused to discuss his murder spree.

In general serial killers are driven by one of two motives - money or sex. There is little support for the idea that Shipman killed for financial gain. He forged the will of one patient, Kathleen Grundy, but his deception was so clumsy that many who have studied the case believe it was a subconscious signal to the authorities that he wanted to be caught. There is also little to support the idea that Shipman derived sexual gratification from the deaths of his patients.

An examination of Shipman's life throws up another possible trigger for his crimes. As a 17-year-old he watched his mother die a slow and painful death of cancer. On the night of her death he ran miles through the streets of Nottingham in the pouring rain, tears streaming down his face.

It is tempting to link his mother's death with his series of murders. Was he angry his patients lived longer than his mother, who died at 43? Is it possible to link the injections he gave to his victims with those administered to his mother to ease her pain?

At the trial the prosecution suggested Shipman killed because he enjoyed the sense of power it gave him. Psychiatrists who have examined Shipman while awaiting trial have come to the conclusion that his killings were an example of "classic necrophilia". The condition takes many more forms than the desire to have sex with a corpse. Some sufferers simply take pleasure from being in the presence of death. A number of Shipman's traits - such as his love of order and of lists - fit in with this theory. Necrophiliacs often immerse themselves in the inanimate world, replacing love of people with love of things.

When the Shipman review was published yesterday its author Richard Baker said he could not say for certain the Shipman case was unique. David Canter, director of the Centre for Investigative Psychology in Liverpool, raised the chilling possibility that it could be a forerunner of cases to come.

The theory is that as the human race in the 21st century thinks of itself increasingly as nothing more than a collection of physical bodies in an evermore materialistic society, then there will be individuals on the extremes who come to believe they are dealing not with people but with objects. He said: "This is one of the arguments for the increase of serial killers."

Is it possible Shipman came to see his patients as nothing but objects, no more valuable than his lists? Professor Canter believes he may talk. He said: "Who knows, in 10 or 15 years when there's nothing else in his life he may think it interesting to talk about what he has done."

webTitle: Shipman trial:  coroner's pledge to concerned families

fields.headline: New inquests and public inquiry on the way
fields.standfirst:
Coroner's pledge to concerned families

Special report: the Shipman trial
fields.trailText: Coroner's pledge to concerned families
fields.body:
The next stage for many of the families of the victims of the serial killer Harold Shipman will be the inquests on 24 of his patients who died in suspicious circumstances, following on from the 15 he was convicted of murdering a year ago.

The inquests will be held at Tameside magistrates court by the South Manchester coroner John Pollard. The first hearing will take place on Tuesday.

Since Shipman's conviction Mr Pollard has already held inquests on a further three elderly patients of the former GP The coroner ruled that three patients - Alice Kitchen, Elizabeth Mellor and Sarah Ashworth - had been unlawfully killed by Shipman. Inquests into the deaths of a further 24 patients include the first suspected male victim of the serial killer, Charles Killan, who died aged 90.

Yesterday, the coroner said if additional cases were presented to him by concerned families, he would look at all the evidence placed before him before deciding whether to hold an inquest.

"I will make a decision about whether there is sufficient evidence to hold an inquest," said Mr Pollard. "If there is a body, then I would consider whether or not to hold an exhumation. If, as is more likely, there has been a cremation, then I would consider submitting evidence before the home secretary asking him to make an order so that an inquest can take place."

Emma Smith, a spokeswoman for the solicitors Alexander Harris, who are representing 150 relatives of Shipman's victims, said: "The only proper thing now is for inquests to be held on every single suspected victim - where the family requests it.

"The situation cannot be left as it is. Relatives of suspected victims have been left in the dark and they are very upset and very unhappy. These families are heartbroken and need answers."

A public inquiry into the activities of Shipman, headed by Dame Janet Smith, a high court judge, will be held next month. It is expected to take at least 18 months and will probably be held at Manchester town hall. Dame Janet, who has wide experience in medical negligence cases, will be asked to find out how the doctor remained undetected for so long.

The decision to hold the inquiry in public represented a victory for the relatives of Shipman's victims, who won a judicial review to halt an earlier closed inquiry.

fields.headline: Click here for Royal Doulton
fields.standfirst: Forget about online bidding for heavy furniture via the big auction houses, although small ceramics would provide an ideal punt. Stewart Dalby reports
fields.trailText: Forget about online bidding for heavy furniture via the big auction houses, although small ceramics would provide an ideal punt. Stewart Dalby reports.
fields.body:
I have always had doubts about certain aspects of e-commerce, especially e-retailing. Unlike America, which is vast with a lot of people living in the middle of nowhere, and therefore a good market for internet shopping, Britain is a small, overcrowded island with a supermarket on almost every corner, and agencies for booking holidays and trips out in most high streets.

People like to go to the supermarket to feel the quality of the plums, and it will be a long while before internet shopping really catches on over here, I believe. If my theory is correct then the arguments should also apply to auctions. People, especially if they are serious and specialised collectors like to feel and see what they are buying.

The big four auction houses Sotheby's, Christie's, Phillips and Bonhams & Brooks all have online sales in one form and another, and do not feel they form part of the dot.com boom and bust. Firstly, they are very much an add-on to existing business. Bonhams & Brooks and Sotheby's say online sales could amount to around one-third of overall turnover in the medium term.

Second, collecting is truly an international business, although this can also be said of QXL and E-Bay clienteles. But the fine art, antique and collectibles fraternities consist of groups of people with specific interests and usually a fine appreciation of value. Thirdly, online auctions allow offerings from a much wider supply chain than an in-house sale. Sotheby's draws on 2,300 associates, namely dealers and smaller auctions houses.

Not everything lends itself to sales online. As Georgina Petrie at Sotheby's says: "Heavy furniture, because of the shipping costs which go by weight, does not go well with online sales." Small ceramic pieces, however, would seem ideal. I was interested therefore to track the online sale at Sotheby's of Royal Doulton and Beswick which ran from December 5 to December 29. It was surprisingly easy to follow. You have to register if you want to bid. Click on to www.sothebys.com click special auctions, and get up Doulton and Beswick. There are illustrations. It tells you who is offering the piece. Then there is a column, which has current bid, estimate, and time remaining to bid. The auction started out with 141 pieces in 79 lots (38 Sotheby's and 41 dealer).

Ceramics, including Clarice Cliffe, the industrial potter, Lucie Rie the studio potter and factory ceramics like Royal Doulton and Beswick all had a good year in 2000. The thing about Royal Doulton is that it has been going a long time and is still thriving today. Clarice Cliffe and Lucie Rie are both dead so their pieces are dwindling resources. Royal Doulton has acquired Beswick, and figurines from this house especially the Beatrix Potter range are still being made, often in limited editions and are increasingly popular.

John Doulton started out in 1815 in Vauxhall in London. By 1853 the firm had moved to Lambeth and began to produce stoneware vases, sculptures and plaques decorated by artists.The company moved to the Potteries in 1877 and expanded further. At that time they began faience, a type of coloured earthenware, and in 1885 they increased production to include bone china. In the 1920s and 1930s they produced art deco figures.

The on-line auction therefore had a lot to choose from. The estimates seemed reasonable across the range, mostly in the low to mid-hundreds rather thousands, although a couple of Doulton figures did bust through the estimates. The Carpet Vendor, a Royal Doulton figure was estimated at $400. The sale included 96 Beatrix Potter figures in 55 lots dating from 1974 to1984.

When I looked on December 27 before the close there were still 43 on offer. The thing that struck me was that the bids made were just below or about the estimates. Pig Wig for example a black Berkshire pig from the tale of Pigling Bland was estimated at $240-$400 (£150 - £200) and the best bid was $200. A model of Simpkin a cat from the Tailor of Gloucester was expected to fetch $320 to $480 (£200 to £300) and the bid was under $300.

What this suggested to me was that the sale was dominated by dealers rather collectors who held on for a good price and that an online sale sees prices close to the estimates on average. Sotheby's says that 50% of the lots were sold. This is less than the average in-house auction, and those that were not sold will be offered again. This means that online auctions are probably less gladiatorial than in-house ones, or more "democratic" in Sotheby's words.

webTitle: Spectre of Shipman returns to haunt Hyde

fields.headline: A ghost returns to haunt a tragic town
fields.standfirst:
Latest revelations leave relatives and neighbours of victims shocked and angry

Special report: the Shipman trial
fields.trailText: Latest revelations leave relatives and neighbours of Shipman's victims shocked and angry.
fields.body:
The spectre of Harold Shipman returned to haunt a small town near Manchester yesterday as the news spread that he could have been responsible for at least 236 deaths. Pensioners shopping on a bitterly cold morning at the thrice-weekly open air market in Market Square, Hyde, shook their head in disgust as his name was mentioned.

Beneath the yellow, red and green corrugated iron roof of the market, small groups of shoppers huddled together to talk about the world's most prolific serial killer in hushed voices.

Ella Butt, 72, asked simply: "Why did he do it? He is the world's biggest serial killer isn't he? It is something that keeps cropping up in conversation and every time I go past his surgery I can't help but look at it and think what happened there."

Shipman's former surgery in Market Street, just around the corner from the market, was packed with patients waiting to see their family doctor. They ranged in age from babies and small children to frail pensioners. It is hoped that the practice will eventually move from its present site, where Shipman is believed to have killed at least five patients.

Many people said they felt numb by the latest revelations about Shipman.

Ian Vellender, a market trader, said the atmosphere among his customers had been very subdued yesterday. "Many people living here have got friends or relations who have been a patient of Shipman's," he said. "He has caused so much hurt and upset in this community. So many lives have been wrecked."

In Bossun's fish restaurant and takeaway nearby, Barbara Harnett said: "It is shocking that he got away with it for so many years and that so many people have died. I feel so sorry for the people who lost relatives who still had many years to live.

"He has taken away so much from so many people and I just don't know how he can live with himself. A lot of people around here feel devastated by what he has done and very let down."

Jane Ashton Hibbert, whose grandmother Hilda Hibbert died in January 1996, said it was like living under a dark cloud. An inquest into her grandmother's death will be held by the South Manchester coroner John Pollard at Tameside magistrates court next Tuesday.

Horrendous

"This has been with me since September 1998 when we were first interviewed by the police," she said. "The last two years have been absolutely horrendous for us. What sickens me is that this one individual has caused so much chaos and unhappiness for so many people in such a small place.

"It has been very hard at times. We have had to fight for a public inquiry and we have had to fight for everything. My grandmother was a very independent woman who used to go on CND marches. Murder is murder and I have got to continue fighting for her."

She said if Shipman had admitted his guilt it would have been a lot better for the families, many of whom still felt very raw with emotion.

Peter Wagstaff, whose mother Kathleen, 81, was one of the 15 women whom Shipman was convicted of murdering in December 1997, said he was disturbed by the way the figures were released.

"We knew about the clinical audit, but we didn't realise these numbers would be coming out in the audit," he said. "We thought it would be restricted to looking at Shipman's access to drugs and medical records. This was yet another revelation which was a bolt out of the blue for us."

He said many of the families felt they had been excluded from the judicial process, as Shipman had not been charged with the murder of their loved ones or inquests were not being held into their deaths. "I feel sorry for the families whose relatives died suddenly and were patients of Shipman who don't know what happened to them. This news will cause them a lot of trauma."

Jayne Gaskell, whose mother Bertha Moss is a suspected victim of the serial killer, shook her head in disgust as she watched the lunchtime television news and heard the director of public prosecutions say Shipman would be unable to receive a fair trial.

An inquest into her mother's death will be held at on February 8 at Tameside magistrates court. "She was supposed to be one of the people Shipman was charged with murdering," said Mrs Gaskell. "We were devastated when we learnt that she was not the 16th person on the charge sheet. Our family felt cheated by this decision. When she died, we were a bit suspicious at the time, but we thought that was part of the natural grieving process."

Her mother, who was 68, died of an apparent massive heart attack while lying on a treatment bed in Shipman's surgery in June 1995. "Mum was bubbly, she was a caring mother and she loved dancing. She really liked Shipman because she thought he was so caring."

Tameside councillor Joe Kitchen, whose mother Alice, 70, was unlawfully killed by Shipman, sympathised with the families who were unsure whether their relatives had been murdered.

"Our family, along with two others, have already been through an inquest when the coroner clearly said my mother had been unlawfully killed. A lot of families are not in that position and it is going to be extremely difficult for them. Obviously we are not going to know until Shipman admits to committing these crimes."

Other relatives believe that the revelations of the new figures will cause panic among the community in Hyde.

Andrea Robinson, whose 54-year-old mother Eileen died suddenly in December 1993, said she was living in a state of limbo because no inquest had been planned into her mother's death.

"We don't really know what happened to my mother," she said. "I do not suppose we ever will, but she was in good health when she supposedly died of a coronary thrombosis. Christmas used to be such a happy time for me, but now it is just memories and it makes me so angry thinking what he might have done to my mother. It makes me want to scream."

fields.headline: 'Excess death' total rises to 297
fields.standfirst:
Audit reveals growing toll of patients dying suspiciously

Special report: the Shipman trial
fields.trailText: Audit reveals growing toll of patients dying suspiciously
fields.body:
Harold Shipman's career as the world's most prolific serial killer began soon after he started in general practice at Todmorden, West Yorkshire, in 1974.

An exhaustive audit of his 24 years as a GP, published yesterday by the Department of Health, shows warning signs of an excessive death rate -particularly among his older female patients - in almost every year from 1975. Numbers climbed after he began practising in Hyde, Greater Manchester, two years later.

By 1998, when a few of his murders came to light after a complaint about a forged will, the total of "excess deaths" of patients in his care had reached 297, possibly as many as 345.

The audit of his chilling career as a GP was conducted by Richard Baker, a professor in the general practice and primary care department at Leicester University.

After comparing the medical records, death certificates and cremation forms of Shipman's patients with those of comparable local GPs, he said he was particularly concerned about 236 "excess deaths" among Shipman's patients who died at home or in his practice premises. This was probably the figure that came closest to estimating the doctor's full death toll, he said.

Prof Baker paid closest attention to the period after 1985 when fuller records were available. Shipman issued 324 medical certificates of cause of death and the audit was able to track clinical records of 288 of these patients. Prof Baker concluded that 166 of the deaths were "highly suspicious" and 43 were "moderately suspicious", in that they shared characteristics similar to the 15 murders of which Shipman was convicted last year.

The figures suggest that more than half of the patients who died while under the doctor's care during this period were killed by him. Most of the established murder victims were older women who died suddenly at home - usually in the afternoon. Shipman was present at the death or attended shortly before death.

A review of death certificates he signed showed that a disproportionate number were women over 75.

"Most died at home and had either been seen within one day of death or with Shipman present at death. The clinical histories given by Shipman often did not relate convincingly to the certified cause of death and evidence to corroborate the cause of death from other doctors was frequently not available," the report said.

Shipman commonly said deaths were due to heart problems, stroke or old age. He was 25 times more likely than comparable GPs to be present at death - attending in 20% of cases compared with a norm of 0.8%. Relatives were present at 40% of his patients' deaths, compared with 80% for other doctors. And 60% of his patients took less than 30 minutes to die, compared with a norm of 23%.

Prof Baker drew attention to suspicious comments recorded by Shipman on cremation forms. In one case Shipman wrote: "Saw patient at home, diagnosis made, arranged admission ambulance, patient dead when went back, all within 10 minutes."

The professor said this record was particularly odd because it should have been standard practice to try to resuscitate a patient until the ambulance arrived.

Perhaps the most extraordinary clue to Shipman's irregularity was the timing of his patients' deaths, peaking abnormally between 2pm and 6pm in sharp contrast to the more regular pattern experienced by other doctors. "It is impossible to come up with a logical [legitimate] explanation of why so many patients die in the afternoon," Prof Baker said.

Although most of Shipman's victims were women, the report found the deaths of 21 men were highly suspicious. "On the basis of the review of surviving records there is considerable reason for concern about the cause of death of substantially more patients than those of which Shipman was convicted," it said. Prof Baker said his evidence was circumstantial and it would be up to the police and prosecution service to investigate the cases of individual victims.

The report found Shipman's record-keeping was consistently poor. "His writing was sometimes illegible, but of greater concern was the lack of detail he recorded about patients presenting complaints and his clinical management."

A review of a small sample should have disclosed the problem. In some cases his use of inadequate records could be regarded as a deliberate ploy to conceal illegal activities, but it was impossible to judge thow far he fabricated entries.

Prof Baker was unable to reach firm conclusions on how Shipman obtained all the diamorphine he used to administer lethal doses to the patients whose deaths were suspicious. The doctor did not maintain a prescribed drugs register. The report concluded: "There was a clear rise in the numbers of deaths towards the end of Shipman's career...It was not surprising therefore that his activities eventually attracted attention."

A pattern emerged showing relatively low death rates during Shipman's first year at Todmorden and in the Hyde group practice. There were also few deaths between 1990 and 1992 when he left the group practice and set up alone. There was also evidence of clusters of deaths during shorter periods. They were more likely on certain weekdays. Occasionally several would occur on the same day or within a few days of each other.

The audit was commissioned by Alan Milburn, the health secretary, at the time of the verdict on Shipman last January. He asked Liam Donaldson, the chief medical officer, to organise a review of Shipman's practice from 1974 to 1998 without trying to gather additional forensic evidence.

Prof Baker said he had not been asked to come up with recommendations, but did so out of a sense of rage as a professional that Shipman had betrayed the trust of so many people who depended on him. The seven recommendations include routine monitoring of GPs' patient death rates, checks on their standard of record-keeping and more information on death certificates.

Prof Donaldson said: "This review is unprecedented in its remit. The analysis makes chilling reading...Everything points to the fact that a doctor with the sinister and macabre motivation of Harold Shipman is a once in a lifetime occurrence... [but] there is much to be learned from this tragedy."

He said Prof Baker's recommendations would be considered by the judicial inquiry that was set up in September to look into the circumstances of Shipman's crimes.

fields.bylineHtml: John Carvel, social affairs editor

fields.headline: On stage with the supermodel sheep
fields.standfirst: Interview: Ron James, managing director, PPL Therapeutics
fields.trailText: Ron James is used to being upstaged by his company's most famous creation, Dolly the Sheep. In fact, he seems genuinely fond of the cloned animal. "For a sheep, she has quite a strong personality," James says. "It's because she's been around people so much."
fields.body:
Ron James is used to being upstaged by his company's most famous creation, Dolly the Sheep. In fact, he seems genuinely fond of the cloned animal. "For a sheep, she has quite a strong personality," James says. "It's because she's been around people so much."

He believes Dolly considers herself a supermodel among sheep: "She's a prima donna - she knows she's famous and she poses for the cameras. She starts baa-ing furiously when you turn your back to look at any of the other animals."

The birth of Dolly, the world's first cloned sheep, catapulted the tiny Scottish biotechnology firm PPL Therapeutics into the headlines in 1997 and doubled the value of the company's shares overnight.

Dolly was followed in 1998 by a cloned cow, Mr Jefferson, and by a litter of cloned piglets last year. Debates about research on stem cells, and about genetic modification, have kept the company in the spotlight ever since.

James, 60, who is managing director of PPL, has always been willing to discuss the ethics of cloning animals from a single cell. However, he emphasises that the company's aim is not the cloning itself, but to alter animals so that they produce useful drugs, and even human organs.

He says: "Our aim is to make drugs, and to make money. The fact that we use animals to do it is interesting, but it's not what it's all about."

Although a scientist by training, James's background lies firmly in the business world. Brought up in suburban Middlesex, his hopes of going to university were dashed by the death of his father. James left school for a job in the labs at Glaxo Wellcome, to help support his mother and sister, but found time to do a part-time degree in chemistry at Birkbeck College.

With support from Glaxo, he moved on to study for a doctorate in chemistry, under the tutelage of the Nobel Prize-winning scientist Derek Barton. But he was more interested in practical applications than pure research. Moving to Wilkinson Sword, he developed lubricant coatings for razors.

He also helped design different bangs for fireworks - another Wilkinson activity at the time - before getting a job looking for hi-tech business opportunities for the Prudential's venture capital arm. It was at the Prudential, during the mid-1980s, that he had the idea which led to PPL. "We were looking for cheap ways of making proteins," he recalls. "I had this mad idea we could make them in frogs' eggs."

Frogs proved impractical, so his attention shifted to chickens. James and his colleagues then pooled their resources with the Roslin Institute, an academic outfit just outside Edinburgh which was already researching transgenic sheep.

"Mad ideas take you to sensible propositions," he says. "It's called brainstorming."

Initially, the attraction of producing medicines in animals was cost. Rather than building vast hi-tech factories, drugs could, quite literally, be made on a farm. More recently, however, the company has realised that a bigger advantage lies in volume - animals can secrete proteins in much greater quantities than machines.

"If you push artificial production too hard, you run out of chemistry sets. The advantage of our method is that you've got huge quantities of proteins available."

PPL's leading project is to breed thousands of sheep with an added gene which makes them produce milk containing a protein called AAT. Once purified, this can be given to humans to treat a deficiency of protein in the lungs, or to treat cystic fibrosis.

The sheep are kept outside Edinburgh on a site which, to the untrained eye, looks like an ordinary farm. In fact, it is built on prime arable land which was previously used for crops, rather than grazing. This is to reduce the risk of scrapies, or other animal diseases, in the soil.

Bleating new-born lambs are warmed at PPL's factory by electric heaters, and enjoy higher quality food than they would on any ordinary farm. However, there are plenty of reminders that this is a profit-seeking business, rather than a sanctuary. PPL admits, for example, that all male lambs are incinerated at birth, because they produce no milk and, as genetically altered animals, cannot be used for food.

James says: "If you're prepared to eat lamb, you shouldn't be concerned about what we do. There are strict vegetarians out there who will take a higher moralistic point of view, but that's not one shared by the majority of the population."

Alongside the farm sits an operating theatre, where the "parents" of each flock of transgenic sheep are created by scientists who add genes to embryos within pregnant sheep. Critics point out that this experimental work produces a very high death rate - Dolly, for example, was the only animal successfully born from 10 pregnancies.

James admits that "genetic abnormalities" can occur. So how many animals are born abnormal? "Taking all the experiments we've done, I would guess it would probably be about half."

Most of these victims have internal disorders, such as kidney malfunctions. James says: "There's been nothing you'd regard as being a monster. We haven't produced animals with two legs, or three heads, or anything like that."

He continues: "You have to look at whether the end justifies the means.

"What's more important - a small number of sheep involved in our earlier experiments, or the large number of adolescents who are going to die from cystic fibrosis?"

These days, PPL is working on a huge number of different transgenic animals - including rabbits, chickens and cows. The company has faced the odd demonstration from environmental objectors. James recalls: "At one point, four people turned up and stood outside with four policemen."

On May Day last year, an environmental group asked its members to go and copulate on the lawn outside PPL's head office. "We could've sold some tickets and made some money," says James. "Unfortunately, it never materialised."

A bigger threat is from the City, which has at times shown impatience towards the company. Its shares, 192p yesterday, have never recaptured the 450p peak which they hit amid the hype of Dolly's birth.

James says the hype surrounding Dolly was double-edged for PPL, because it cast the company as "a bunch of clever scientists doing interesting things with animals", rather than a pharmaceuticals firm. "It took us quite a long time to reposition ourselves as a company producing therapeutic drugs," he says.

Like most biotech companies, PPL is haemorrhaging cash. It lost £14.4m last year, despite a cost-cutting drive which involved 80 redundancies.

Critics complain that for a lead product, AAT has a limited market, and that PPL has insufficient cash to last until the commercial launch of its first product, which will be in 2004 at the earliest. James admits: "We will need more money before we get to break-even."

So, given the risks of its technology, would PPL be better off as a research offshoot of a large, wealthy pharmaceuticals corporation? James is open-minded: "Should the company remain independent? Who can tell. There are certainly times when I've wished we hadn't been on the stock market but in reality, we had to be.

"At the time we floated, in the mid-1990s, there wasn't enough venture capital available privately to allow us to begin clinical trials."

A marketing deal with Bayer boosted PPL's credibility last year - the German pharmaceuticals firm will market AAT, in return for a share of profits.

Beyond AAT, James points out that the company has a long pipeline of products. Some of its sheep have been modified to produce a fibrin sealant, used to heal wounds, and research in New Zealand is focusing on producing a multiple sclerosis drug in cows' milk.

Then there is the controversial area of xenotransplantation - growing human organs in animals. PPL cloned a litter of pigs last year - named Millie, Christa, Alexis, Carrel and Dotcom (the last of these is now known as "Dottie", its original name having lost its sheen after the collapse of the craze for internet companies).

The company is working on "knocking out" a gene in these pigs, to make their hearts and livers suitable for transplant into humans.

This type of research has raised fears that animal diseases could be introduced to humans. James concedes: "There are legitimate concerns about ensuring the animals don't have viruses in them."

He maintains, however, that farmyard animals are sufficiently different from humans to make their diseases incompatible: "We share more diseases with monkeys than we do with sheep or pigs." Genetics has its limits for him, though. He says it is one thing to alter animals to produce life-saving drugs but quite another to produce such creatures as "anti-freeze salmon", which can survive colder temperatures. "The justification there is strictly commercial. In our case, we're also about curing people. That sort of thing at least has the potential to upset the balance of nature. You've got to think long and hard about the consequences."

As for cloning humans, he says the prospect is pure scaremongering: "The scientific community has had the ability for 15 years to take a human egg, chop it in half and create another. But there's no good reason to do it."

He maintains that the risks will always be too high for cloning to become a way of life: "It will go wrong more often than not. I find it offensive that people think scientists don't have the same sense of responsibility as the rest of the community. Scientists haven't done it in the past, and they won't in the future."

He complains that fears of creating "Frankenstein" are typical of the British attitude towards science: "There's a presumption of guilt in the UK. Science starts off being bad, unless it's proved to be innocent. In the US, it's the other way round.

"We have a word for people who can't read or count - they're illiterate or innumerate. We don't have a word for people who don't understand science. Perhaps we should."

webTitle: Bush is Mr Nice Guy, says Gadafy

fields.headline: Bush is Mr Nice Guy, says Gadafy
fields.standfirst: Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: George W Bush is a nice man. That's the word on the US president-elect from Libya.
fields.body:
George W Bush is a nice man. That's the word on the US president-elect from Libya.

Giving his personal approval to the new US administration, Colonel Muammar Gadafy said in Tripoli: "I believe that George W Bush will be nice...As a person he is not malicious or imperialist."

The colonel said that although imperialism and Zionism was still at work in the US, and would put pressure on Mr Bush, he hoped the situation would improve, especially if Mr Bush learned the lessons from "wars, interventions and losses".

The colonel also approved of Bush senior - "a moderate man" - and likened President Clinton to a "good man", albeit one who was too "busy with his private life".

The colonel reserved his wrath for Ronald Reagan, calling him "the worst, aggressive and most stupid president, who ended up mad".

The election of George W Bush has been favourably received in the Middle East because he is thought to be less beholden to America's Jewish lobby. Mr Bush's nominations of an Arab-American and a Muslim to his administration have also won plaudits.
