fields.headline: German TV game show scandal
fields.trailText: The television show Who Wants to Marry a Millionaire? seems destined for perpetual scandal.
fields.body:
The television show Who Wants to Marry a Millionaire? seems destined for perpetual scandal.

The head of entertainment for Germany's RTL television station, Matthias Alberti, apologised yesterday after it emerged that the wealthy groom in Wednesday's made-for-TV wedding had known the bride for a month.

Mr Alberti said the contracts would be broken and the result of the show made invalid, with the station taking possible legal action against Thomas Tepe and Gerti Friedrichs.

The US version, aired on Fox in February, also sparked controversy, with a judge anulling the marriage in April. Fox said it would never produce such a show again.

According to RTL, Mr Tepe told the station on Thursday night that he had known Ms Friedrichs since December 2 when they met and exchanged phone numbers.

RTL has ordered the couple to return from their honeymoon in Miami and hand back a diamond ring. The station paid for both.

They lived in towns near each other and had even been members of the same tennis club, reports said.

AP, Cologne

fields.headline: Pinochet refuses health tests
fields.standfirst: Special report: Pinochet on trial
fields.trailText: General Augusto Pinochet is about to defy a court order to submit to medical tests and interrogation, setting off a fresh round of legal wrangling and possibly inviting a new order for his arrest.
fields.body:
General Augusto Pinochet is about to defy a court order to submit to medical tests and interrogation, setting off a fresh round of legal wrangling and possibly inviting a new order for his arrest.

On the advice of his senior lawyer, Pablo Rodriguez, he will not take the tests tomorrow and on Monday, a statement issued by his son yesterday confirmed.

The former dictator was escorted to his seaside home, which was widely interpreted as a preparation to defy an arrest order.

The courts want Gen Pinochet medically examined to establish his fitness to stand trial, and then questioned about his role in the murder and disappearance of 75 political prisoners by a military unit known as the "Caravan of Death."

The investigating judge, Juan Guzman, said on Thursday that if the general did not obey the order to undergo medical tests he intended to "apply the penal code", - meaning he would once again order his arrest.

Judge Guzman's first arrest order, on December 1, was annulled by the supreme court because Gen Pinochet had not been properly interrogated first. The court ruled that Judge Guzman must interrogate him within 20 days, after medical tests.

Judge Guzman has ordered Gen Pinochet to submit to a battery of physical, neurological and psychological tests.

He has also made sure that they will not by conducted by the military hospital, as the Pinochet family wanted, but by neutral medical institutions, "in order to clear up any doubts that the patient is taking drugs to alter his true health condition, either psychiatric, psychological or neurological."

Although the British government decision that Gen Pinochet was unfit to be extradited for trial in Spain is repeatedly cited by his defence, Chilean law is more stringent in its definition of medical exemption from criminal proceedings. The defendant must be mentally or physically incapacitated to the point of not understanding the charges.

Even the composition of the medical team appointed to conduct the tests has produced extensive political wrangling. It will include two psychiatrists, a neurologist and a psychologist from the government medical examiner's office, and two neurologists from the University of Chile. Defence and prosecution witnesses will be present.

Yesterday the supreme court rejected a defence plea to set back the Tuesday deadline for Judge Guzman to interview the general: a sign that it is likely to reject its plea for the judge's dismissal from the case.

The team's latest stalling tactic is likely to upset military-civil relations once again.

Ricardo Lagos, the Socialist president elected in March, has repeatedly said that military influence must be reduced and the Pinochet case allowed to proceed free of political interference.

fields.headline: EU inquiry into £700m revamp
fields.trailText: EU fraud-busters have begun a formal investigation into the nine-year renovation of the European commission's asbestos-riddled headquarters in Brussels.
fields.body:
EU fraud-busters have begun a formal investigation into the nine-year renovation of the European commission's asbestos-riddled headquarters in Brussels.

Belgian media said that the cost of the renovation work on the Berlaymont had risen to £700m - nearly seven times the original budget.

"We have opened an investigation, there is an inquiry," said Alesandro Buttice, head of the Olaf anti-fraud office.

Some 3,000 Eurocrats were forced out of the 13-storey, star-shaped building in 1991 when it was found that asbestos and other hazardous materials were used during its construction in 1967.

The EU and the Belgian government, which owns the Berlaymont, agreed to share the costs. Officials were due to move back in in June.

The EU has come under rising pressure from member states to curb spending on building large modern offices, which many view as a waste of taxes. The European Parliament has also repeatedly come under fire for the building of a second chamber in Strasbourg, France, which is nicknamed Fawlty Towers.

webTitle: Where are the radicals of '68 now?

fields.headline: Where are the radicals of '68 now?
fields.trailText:
Joschka Fischer German foreign minister
Peter Hain Foreign office minister
Emma Bonino Italian MEP
Otto Schily German interior minister
Daniel Cohn-Bendit German MEP
fields.body:
Joschka Fischer German foreign minister

Joschka Fischer, 52, astonished even close friends a few years back by mutating from an obese, hard-drinking hell-raiser into an abstemious fitness fanatic. His political transformation has been no less remarkable.

Back in the early 1970s, Mr Fischer was a member of an extremist group of Frankfurt squatters and street-fighters known as the "Spontis". His proximity to some who later turned to terrorism is underlined by the fact that his car was found to have carried a weapon later used in the assassination of a prominent politician. Mr Fischer has always said it was without his knowledge.

He disowned violence and joined the Greens. After Otto Schily's departure, Mr Fischer became the party's leading moderate.
John Hooper, Berlin

Peter Hain Foreign office minister

It was revealed this week that the potential prosecution of Peter Hain over the masterminding of a successful campaign to stop South Africa's cricket tour of England in 1970 was discussed by the Labour cabinet 30 years ago.

Mr Hain, then a self-confessed "quasi-Marxist", claimed his guerrilla anti-apartheid tactics, including sabotaging locks on the Springboks' hotel room doors, rampaging across rugby fields and organising boycotts of Barclays bank, led to extensive secret service surveillance.

He was acquitted of robbing a Barclays branch in south-west London in 1975 in what was a case of mistaken identity, and in two books he has demanded to see his MI5 files, claiming he was framed.

Mr Hain, now 50, joined the Labour party two years later, becoming an MP in 1991. Under Tony Blair, he was still considered a left-winger but joined the ministerial team in 1997.

Since becoming the minister responsible for Africa and the Middle East in July 1999, he has disappointed old comrades, particularly for supporting sanctions against Iraq. The radical writer Tariq Ali suggested Mr Hain could face a war crimes tribunal for backing the western allies' continuing bombing of the country.
Patrick Barkham

Emma Bonino Italian MEP

As an Italian MEP for the Radical party, Emma Bonino, 52, continues to be the voracious headline-grabber she was for decades as a human rights campaigner.

In March 1999, she was part of Jacques Santer's EU commission team that resigned in disgrace over fraud allegations.

After being arrested for having an abortion in the 1970s, Ms Bonino successfully campaigned for abortion law reform in Italy. Elected to the European parliament in 1979, she made her name calling for nuclear disarmament.

In the 1990s she benefited from some unlikely sources of patronage, including that of Silvio Berlusconi, then Italian prime minister and media magnate, who nominated her for the commission in 1995.

When she lost her position as commissioner for humanitarian aid, she maintained that the missing £600m from the EU's aid budget stemmed from before her tenure.

fields.headline: New theory in Concorde disaster
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: French accident investigators probing July's crash of a Concorde near Paris said yesterday that they believed large chunks of rubber from a burst tyre triggered a "shock wave" in the fuel tanks, causing the fire that downed the jetliner with the loss of 113 lives.
fields.body:
French accident investigators probing July's crash of a Concorde near Paris said yesterday that they believed large chunks of rubber from a burst tyre triggered a "shock wave" in the fuel tanks, causing the fire that downed the jetliner with the loss of 113 lives.

The French accident investigation bureau, BEA, said in its latest update that its original theory - that just before take-off, the Air-France Concorde ran over a strip of metal from a DC10 that had taken off minutes earlier - was "more and more probable".

But it said that rather than puncturing the aircraft's underwing fuel tank, the chunks of burst tyre may simply have dented it. The explosion that sent the plane spiralling out of control into a hotel in the small town of Gonesse was more likely caused by fuel blowing open the tank from the inside.

The investigators said tests would now be carried out on Concorde fuel tanks to confirm their theory, adding that six similar incidents in the past had led to fuel tank ruptures in Concordes at Air France and British Airways.

BEA also officially claimed for the first time that the stray strip of metal that burst the tyre came from a Continental Airlines DC10.

webTitle: Europe's past radicals face awkward questions

fields.headline: Cloud of violence hangs over the 60s firebrands
fields.standfirst: Europe's best-known radical politicians face awkward questions about their revolutionary past
fields.trailText: Europe's best-known radical politicians face awkward questions about their revolutionary past.
fields.body:
It is 33 years since the tear gas cleared from the Place St Michel and the narrow streets of the Latin Quarter where the students of Paris built barricades against the riot police. But the events of May 1968 heralded a wave of radical activism in Europe whose legacy is still very much alive today.

Many of those who first became involved in leftwing politics in the frenetic, often violent, atmosphere of the Paris riots have since gone on to high office.

This point was strikingly underlined this week when the past caught up with Germany's foreign minister, Joschka Fischer. On Thursday, Mr Fischer publicly apologised to the German police following the publication of photographs from 1973 showing him beating a fallen policeman during a demonstration. He called the resort to street violence "a tremendous mistake and a big error".

Yesterday, he went further, telling the Berlin daily Der Tagesspiegel: "We were of the world war generation. It shocks me that we couldn't see how quickly we adopted that which we rejected in the generation of our fathers."

The foreign minister's colleagues in the Green party rallied to Mr Fischer's defence. The co-leader, Renate Künast, dismissed opposition calls for his resignation, saying his past was "also the past of an entire generation in this republic".

Even before the end of the 60s, a split opened up on the radical left. While a minority was ready - even eager - to move from violent street protests to full-blown terrorism, the majority held back.

Those arguing for an "armed struggle" saw, correctly, that the working classes were not about to take to the barricades and start a revolution. But they believed, more contentiously, that they could be roused to action by means of a campaign of terror that provoked the "bourgeois-fascist" state into indiscriminate repression.

These ideas found expression in the actions of the Baader-Meinhof Gang and Red Army Faction in Germany, the Red Brigades in Italy and GRAPO in Spain.

But according to Neil Ascherson, who watched the split begin as the Observer's correspondent in Germany from 1963-69, "overwhelmingly, the left took the attitude that a resort to terroristic methods was unacceptable and irresponsible and that it could lead to the destruction of the radical left. That proved right".

The point that throwing stones at the police did not necessarily lead to planting bombs was made by Mr Fischer himself this week. "I always thought that was wrong, even suicidal," he told Stern magazine. "The whole time, for God's sake, we were working hard against this step to armed struggle, to terrorism."

Though many who rejected terrorism slid out of politics altogether, others headed for the emerging world of single-issue politics or linked up with alternative movements like Italy's Radical party and found their way to the heights of European politics. However, for a while, the distinction between those who supported and opposed "armed struggle" was fuzzy.

Some did not approve of the men and women of violence but were ready to defend them. Many of those in one camp had friends or acquaintances in the other. It is this haziness which still hangs over Mr Fischer like a cloud.

Some of those he knew in his Frankfurt student days took a different route. One such was Hans-Joachim Klein, who took part in the lethal raid in 1975 on an Opec oil ministers' meeting in Vienna. In 1999 he was extradited to Germany from France, where he had lived for 23 years under a false name. Last year, Klein was arraigned on charges of kidnapping and involvement in the murder of two bodyguards and a delegate in the raid.

Mr Fischer, who has denied supporting Mr Klein's terrorist activities in any way, has been called to give evidence at his trial later this month.

fields.headline: Russian fraud case resumes
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: The tangled case against exiled media mogul Vladimir Gusinsky was strengthened yesterday, when a Moscow court reinstated fraud charges against him.
fields.body:
The tangled case against exiled media mogul Vladimir Gusinsky was strengthened yesterday, when a Moscow court reinstated fraud charges against him.

Prosecutors in Moscow city court overturned a lower court's ruling which temporarily halted the case.

The result means that Russia's extradition request against Mr Gusinsky, who is currently under house arrest in Spain, stays in force. A spokeswoman from Mr Gusinsky's Media Most empire said it would appeal against the ruling.

Russian prosecutors claim that Mr Gusinsky misrepresented his company's assets to procure £200m worth of loans. Media Most denies the claims.

fields.headline: European beef ban down under
fields.trailText: Australia and New Zealand are to clear supermarket shelves of European beef on Monday and are imposing a blanket ban on beef products from the continent.
fields.body:
Australia and New Zealand are to clear supermarket shelves of European beef on Monday and are imposing a blanket ban on beef products from the continent. The move is aimed at checking the spread of BSE in the south Pacific.

The Australia New Zealand Food Authority (Anzfa) said its request to suppliers to suspend the sale of beef products from 30 European countries was a precautionary measure. British beef has been banned in Australia and New Zealand since 1996.

Anzfa managing director, Ian Lindemayer said the steps being taken were aimed at keeping Australian beef among the safest in the world. Australia's federal agriculture and forestry minister, Warren Truss, claimed that the country was one of only five in the world recognised as being BSE-free.

Australia has a large domestic beef industry and imports little of the meat. Such meat from Europe makes up about 0.2% of the beef consumed there each year.

Australia's chief medical officer, Professor Richard Smallwood, admitted that the risks to Australians from European beef products was "extremely small", but people were urged by Anzfa yesterday to discard any products on their kitchen shelves containing European beef.

The beef ban could be extended to bovine-derived medical and beauty products.

webTitle: US urged to sign test ban treaty

fields.headline: US urged to sign test ban treaty
fields.trailText: A study by the retired general John Shalikashvili urging the US to ratify the nuclear test ban treaty was handed yesterday to President Bill Clinton, said a US official.
fields.body:
A study by the retired general John Shalikashvili urging the US to ratify the nuclear test ban treaty was handed yesterday to President Bill Clinton, said a US official.

Mr Clinton had requested the study by the one-time chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff after Senate Republicans rejected the plan. The report finds that "it is in the interest of the United States to sign the treaty", said the official.

President-elect Bush has opposed the pact, saying it was unenforceable, though his top advisers are split. The secretary of state-designate, Colin Powell, supported it while Mr Bush's choice for defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, is against it.

General Shalikashvili's report calls for measures to build support for the treaty, including greater efforts to keep the US nuclear arsenal and a joint review by the Senate and administration every 10 years, the New York Times and the Washington Post reported yesterday.

"The view of the chairman and the chiefs has been that while there are risks with this treaty, as with most treaties, the advantages in helping the fight against proliferation outweigh the disadvantages," Mr Shalikashvili told the New York Times.

The Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty was completed in 1996, but it cannot take effect until it has been approved by the US and 43 other nations with nuclear research or power reactors.

AP, Washington

webTitle: No answers, so try a rumour

fields.headline: No answers, so try a rumour
fields.trailText: The uncertainty goes on. Investors still have no idea why the Federal Reserve cut rates this week, and it is making for a jittery market.
fields.body:
The uncertainty goes on. Investors still have no idea why the Federal Reserve cut rates this week, and it is making for a jittery market.

It had been thought that yesterday's US employment report would provide the answer. It did not.

Although weak, the report was no worse than expected and was not enough, dealers said, to warrant a between-meeting rate cut from the US central bank.

So traders had to look elsewhere for an explanation, and the City being the City all sorts of wild rumours were doing the rounds.

The most extreme was that the rate cut was a response to a crisis in the banking system. This was hardly surprising. After all, the first response of many dealers to Wednesday's cut was "who has gone to the wall?"

Moreover, the last time the Fed cut rates in such a manner was in 1998 when the collapse of US hedge fund LTCM threatened to bring down the entire banking system.

Yesterday's speculation centred on Bank of America and suggestions that it had taken a bath in the derivatives market. For a while the tale was being taken seriously and the FTSE 100 fell into negative territory on news that trading in Bank of America shares on Wall Street had been suspended.

In the event Bank of America quashed the speculation. Nonetheless the damage had been done and the buying interest, which had been so evident in the morning part of the session, evaporated.

Matters were not helped by another smattering of profits warnings from the US, which forced Wall Street's leading indices lower.

By the time London traders were heading home for the weekend, the Nasdaq was off around 4.34% and the Dow Jones industrial average down nearly 2%.

Back in London, the final scores showed the FTSE 100 up 12.5 points at 6,198.1, a somewhat misleading figure given that the blue chip index entered the closing auction process around 10 points lower. But, as is becoming all too common, it spiked higher after a couple of big trades were put through the market right on the close.

Elsewhere, the Techmark 100 fell 11.24 points 2,448.63, unsettled by the performance of the Nasdaq.

Telecoms stocks were having another good session with Deutsche Bank - probably the biggest force in the telecoms sector - encouraging clients to pile into the likes of Vodafone, 3.25p better at 242.25p, Colt Telecom, up 95p to £16.20, Fibernet, 30p higher at 755p, and BT, 17p to stronger to 630p.

But the award for best blue chip performer of the day went to software developer Autonomy, up 225p to £15.35p, after it issued a positive trading statement.

Over in the banking sector, there was renewed interest in Abbey National, 39p higher at £12.74, following news that Lloyds TSB, up 1p to 751p, is seeking clearance from regulators for its proposed takeover. Dealers also heard a late rumour that HSBC, off 10p to £10.26, might be poised to enter the fray with an offer for Abbey.

On Thursday it was drug stocks and yesterday it was the turn of insurance stocks to be hit by profit taking. After a good run, investors decided that it was time to cash in some of last year's gains. CGNU fell by 65p to £10.26, while Royal & Sun Alliance dipped 27p to 520.5p.

Lower down the corporate ladder, telecoms switch maker BATM picked up 11p to 116.5p, with dealers attributing the rise to the clearance of a large stock overhang of some 10m shares on Thursday. Enterprise Oil ended 2.25p higher at 570p after Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein swiftly placed 8m shares at 553p.

At the speculative end of the market, Psion, the handheld computer maker, fell 13.5p to 256.5p, hit by renewed speculation that a profits warning was on the way.

webTitle: Panic wave engulfs Bank of America

fields.headline: Panic wave engulfs Bank of America
fields.standfirst: Fears of recession force leading US lender to deny it is facing huge losses
fields.trailText: America's largest commercial bank was forced to deny that it was nursing huge losses yesterday amid mounting anxiety in the world's financial market about the stability of the global economy.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson  in New York, Jill Treanor and Mark Atkinson
fields.body:
America's largest commercial bank was forced to deny that it was nursing huge losses yesterday amid mounting anxiety in the world's financial market about the stability of the global economy.

After suspension of its shares on the New York Stock Exchange, Bank of America insisted it was "conducting business as usual" despite speculation that it had incurred heavy trading losses in volatile financial markets.

Dealers said the speed with which the rumours mounted reflected the precarious sentiment in the markets after the unexpected interest rate cut in the US on Wednesday. BoA bore the brunt of rumours that the real motivation for the rate cut was a looming systemic crisis in the financial system - and not concerns about an impending recession in the US.

The financial market's doubts about the cut mounted after data released by the US labour department yesterday was not as bad as economists had feared, showing that the American economy still managed to create 105,000 new jobs in December.

The FTSE slid after BoA's shares were suspended - routine in the US before an announcement by a company - but recovered into positive territory by the close of trading. In Europe, the pan-European FTSE Eurotop 300 and the blue-chip DJ Euro Stoxx 50 were each off 0.3%, the US hi-tech Nasdaq market was down 5% and the Dow Jones indus trial average 2%. "People are very worried about nasty surprises out there and if there is something they don't know much about, then they will assume it's bad news," said Mike Young, European equity strategist at Goldman Sachs.

"There are rumours going around about one stock after another, largely financials and technology. It's a very uncertain environment and we're not out of the woods yet."

BoA, the largest commercial bank in the US but third largest overall, faced rumours about problems in a variety of markets, ranging from derivatives losses in Asia and Russia to loans to utilities in the US. One derivatives trader said the Californian roots of BoA, bought by Carolina-based Nationsbank, had increased fears that it was exposed to the region's energy crisis.

Utilities in the region are having to pay much of the cost of gas being used by consumers - after regulations forced them to maintain a freeze on retail prices despite a four-fold increase in wholesale prices - leading to fears that some of the biggest of them could face bankruptcy.

The bank's share price declined sharply in early-morning trading yesterday, prompting the New York Stock Exchange to halt trading before the day had officially begun.

webTitle: Simon Rocker: Money and the ministry

fields.headline: Money and the ministry
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: One group of workers who would not have enjoyed a Christmas bonus, but probably deserved it more than most, is the clergy.
fields.body:
One group of workers who would not have enjoyed a Christmas bonus, but probably deserved it more than most, is the clergy. Spiritual leaders are expected to await their true reward in the life hereafter; they are meant to be sustained by the ideal of vocation.

Not that they are wholly indifferent to their material situation. The Manufacturing, Science and Finance union recently lobbied for a rise in the average church of England stipend from £16,420 to more than £23,350. Indeed, it would be unreasonable to assume that the relationship between ministers of religion and their communities is immune from wider social change.

What is apparent in the modern, urban rabbinate, for example, is a growing process of professionalisation. A review of the mainstream Orthodox rabbinate in Britain a few years ago explicitly cast the rabbi as "senior professional" of his community. Earlier this year, the Reform Synagogues of Great Britain introduced new pay guidelines with a top rate for premier incumbents of more than £74,000.

The most remarkable thing about this is that it marks a complete departure from the Talmudic role model. The great classical sages were gifted amateurs, dispensing the wisdom of the Torah out of religious duty. While scholars may have been exempted certain taxes, they were expressly forbidden to make a living from the Torah.

Some were wealthy men, others may have had lowly occupations. One rabbi of renown reputedly lugged wooden beams, proclaiming, "Great is work". Centuries later, the influential medieval authority, Maimonides, himself a physician, explained the rationale; if rabbis took money for their knowledge, people would "think the Torah is a profession like other professions" and "come to lose respect for it".

I believe the traditional system had another advantage. It ensured that rabbis were not remote figures; through earning a living, they understood the ways of the world and could share more easily in the lives of the people.

History had other ideas, and pragmatism prevailed over purity, with salaried rabbis becoming the norm. The arrangements were justified on the ground that rabbis were being paid not for spreading the word of God as such, but in lieu of what their talents could have earned them in other employment.

The late Lord Jakobovits, when chief rabbi, was fond of quoting the old adage about peanuts and monkeys in his efforts to make the rabbinate a more attractive career option. If congregations were prepared to offer better conditions, it reflected their growing demands on ministers. A rabbi is on call day and night; he (and in Progressive communities, at least, she) is asked to fulfil multiple functions - teacher, preacher, counsellor, care-giver, ministering to the sick, the needy, the orphan, the widow.

But while he has always expected to be a walking exemplar, embodying the ideals of the faith, his inspirational role has taken on a new and more urgent emphasis. Amid the growing threat of secularism, he is expected to keep numbers up, acting, as it were, as God's recruiting agent. Hence the premium placed on personal charisma and communication skills.

Being media-savvy is more of an asset than being mystically profound. A proposal was even made not so long ago that a rabbi's contracts should include a clause stipulating his responsibility for increasing his congregation. No one went so far as to suggest performance-related pay, but the invocation of market forces was clear: successful rabbis attracted new members; new members created bigger congregations; bigger congregations could afford to support their rabbis.

But there is something else, too. Rabbis are religious figureheads, and if a reasonably well-to-do suburban congregation has a poorly paid rabbi, it reflects badly on the congregation's own sense of dignity. The size of the salary may be less significant than the status it is supposed to represent. Without status, the rabbi would find it more difficult to command respect; and without respect, more difficult to get his message across.

In the Bible, the patriarch Abraham, having embarked on his monotheistic mission, is described as being "very rich in cattle, silver and gold". A later rabbinic commentator, offering an explanation, said this was necessary because wealth conferred authority, and without it no one would have given him the time of day. For wealth, today read professional standing. And that, of course, comes at a price. Pastor, farewell. Welcome, heaven's senior pro.

 Simon Rocker is a journalist with the Jewish Chronicle

fields.headline: At this price?
fields.standfirst: Danka
fields.trailText: After months of disappointing announcements - including a string of profit warnings - photocopier distributor Danka Business Systems has something to cheer about.
fields.body:
After months of disappointing announcements - including a string of profit warnings - photocopier distributor Danka Business Systems has something to cheer about.

It has agreed orders worth more than $38m (£25.3m) with Kinko's, the privately owned visual communications and documents copying firm. The deal will see the placement of Canon colour laser copiers over the next four months that Danka will be contracted to service.

But investors buoyed up by the news would do well to keep their chequebooks locked away, at least for the immediate future. Danka's recent history makes far from pleasant reading, and those keen to take a closer look should resist the temptation.

In November the company announced it had appointed a financial adviser "to assist in studying its strategic options" after a very tough year. Precious little in the way of new information has followed, although there may be a little more next month, when it reports its third quarter results.

Frankly, the bottom has fallen out of Danka's world as far as the share price is concerned. Four years ago it stood at 848p, while this year's lowest point was 6.5p.

Last year Danka issued two profit warnings, in March and November, and parted company with Larry Switzer, its chief executive.

Blaming weak hardware sales in the US and pressure on its margins and currency movements, it said the switch from analogue to digital copiers had happened far more quickly than expected.

The company announced earlier this week it was still in talks with its bankers over credit facilities, and said it may receive advances for its ordinary operational needs over the next few months.

Yesterday's order news, however, helped reverse the downward trend. As the markets closed last night the stock had risen 35%, or 3.5p to 13.5p, although this is a long way off the 200p year's high.

Loyal investors are likely to have lost a substantial amount: one to avoid.

fields.headline: France revives absinthe friends
fields.trailText: The hallucinogenic green liquor which inspired Verlaine, Baudelaire, Manet and Toulouse-Lautrec to poetry and painting (and Vincent van Gogh to chopping off his ear) is back, in a recipe authenticated by a lecturer in cellular biology at a Paris university.
fields.body:
The hallucinogenic green liquor which inspired Verlaine, Baudelaire, Manet and Toulouse-Lautrec to poetry and painting (and Vincent van Gogh to chopping off his ear) is back, in a recipe authenticated by a lecturer in cellular biology at a Paris university.

Absinthe, the fin-de-siècle tipple of artists, intellectuals and the man in the pavement cafe, was banned in France, Belgium and Switzerland in 1915.

But with the help of Marie-Claude Delahaye, director of the world's only absinthe museum outside Paris, a British company has succeeded in recreating the secret blend of wormwood, anise, lemon balm, hyssop and other aromatics.

"This is 68 proof, none of your rubbish," Ms Delahaye said proudly. The elegant bottles of La Fée - honouring absinthe's original nickname la fée verte (the green fairy) - will bear her signature.

Green Bohemia, the company responsible, says it is breaking no laws because absinthe is not banned in Britain and its manufacture is permitted in France, providing it is for export only. It plans to sell the terrifying tincture by mail order and the internet.

Introduced to France in the 1790s, the aniseed-flavoured spirit exercised an all too fatal charm on the French.

Accused of inducing hallucinations, convulsions, fits, insanity and not infrequently death, it was widely blamed for the French army's more than usually dismal performance at the beginning of the Great War.

Much of the appeal probably lay in the complex ritual of drinking it, known as "strangling the parrot". Special glasses with a hollow bubble at the bottom held the liquid, and drinkers, who asked for un train direct pour Charenton - a non-stop ticket to the Paris lunatic asylum - put a sugarlump on a perforated silver spoon and doused it with water, diluting and sweetening the drink to taste.

The revised version will not, Ms Delahaye promises, induce quite the same effects. Her carefully adapted formula contains only the legal level of the active ingredient, thujone.

webTitle: Draconian tobacco laws fail to smoke out Estonian president

fields.headline: Draconian tobacco laws fail to smoke out Estonian president
fields.trailText: Lennart Meri is a Marlboro man. But the new millennium may leave the chain-smoking Estonian president gasping for a fag.
fields.body:
Lennart Meri is a Marlboro man. But the new millennium may leave the chain-smoking Estonian president gasping for a fag.

The country ushered in the new year with some of the most sweeping measures against smoking yet seen in Europe. Its "law on tobacco", which took effect on Wednesday, bans cigarettes in all public places, from offices to the stairwells of blocks of flats.

The no-smoking signs are being hung up in every indoor gathering place. Cafes, bars, and restaurants must be entirely smoke-free zones unless they offer separate rooms for smokers, which must be equipped with new air conditioners refreshing at least eight litres of air a minute.

Habitually heavy-smoking members of the Russian minority in the capital, Tallinn, pleaded for the law to be relaxed in the town hall.

"No way," said the mayor, Yuri Myiz. "The law is the law."

The smallest of the post-Soviet states, Estonia is likely to be the first to join the European Union, cementing its reputation for rapid social and economic advance.

It leads internet development in the region. Last year the cabinet last year introduced "no-paper" sessions at which ministers consult their laptops for guidance, and the country is setting up a national gene pool archive, following Iceland's example.

Not even the street is safe. Under-age smokers caught lighting up become liable to a £400 fine - a huge sum by local standards - and callers to a a radio phone-in programme in Tallinn this week were relishing the prospect of reprimanding anti-social elements taking a puff at bus stops.

Mr Meri, 72 in March, is a heavy smoker of Marlboro Lights. "He doesn't smoke in public places, and he always tells photographers not to snap him when he is smoking," his spokeswoman, Epp Alatalu, said. "But he smokes far too much."

And he is going to exploit a let-out which allows ventilated smoking rooms if there is a sufficiently strong demand. When he returns from his New Year holiday his office in the presidential palace will be fitted with the specified fans to let him puff lawfully.

fields.headline: Mining boost doubts
fields.trailText: Predicting which stocks and sectors will benefit from the Federal Reserve's unexpected rate cut has become one of the City's favourite games this week.
fields.body:
Predicting which stocks and sectors will benefit from the Federal Reserve's unexpected rate cut has become one of the City's favourite games this week.

But those tempted to focus on the boost lower interest rates should bring for the mining industry should think again.

According to Deutsche Bank, the Fed's decision means that more, not less, bad news lies in store for commodity demand.

With the likes of Anglo American, Rio Tinto and Billiton trading at the top of their medium-term trading ranges, Deutsche was yesterday advising investors to book some profits.

Historically, Deutsche says, there has been little correlation between Fed rates and the performance of the sector.

In fact, an end to interest rate easing has generally signalled the best moment to enter the sector, it says.

As recent economic data has shown, this could be a while away yet.

fields.headline: Loadsa tunny  £570/kg price record
fields.standfirst: Special report: global fishing in crisis
fields.trailText: Japanese sushi-lovers will be getting their lips around the world's most expensive tuna this weekend: an unnamed buyer astonished observers by paying £116,000 for a 202kg blue-fin in the Tokyo fish market yesterday - more than twice the previous record.
fields.body:
Japanese sushi-lovers will be getting their lips around the world's most expensive tuna this weekend: an unnamed buyer astonished observers by paying £116,000 for a 202kg blue-fin in the Tokyo fish market yesterday - more than twice the previous record.

Blue-fin is the most succulent and expensive variety of tuna, but the current deflation has driven prices below last year's average and no one was prepared for yesterday's drama.

"I was being stubborn and didn't want to give in to the other bidders," the winner told TV Tokyo. "I won't make any money from this purchase."

Gourmets already pay up to £50 for a mouthful or two of the fattest cut, and chefs are unlikely to pass on the full financial flavour of yesterday's prize.

webTitle: Peter Hain: I fought apartheid. I'll fight Saddam

fields.headline: I fought apartheid. I'll fight Saddam
fields.standfirst:
My critics are wrong: they are merely propping up a dictator

Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: There is vigorous public debate about Britain's support for UN sanctions on Iraq. I have no intention of ducking this debate, because I am convinced Britain's policy is right, writes Peter Hain.
fields.body:
There is vigorous public debate about Britain's support for UN sanctions on Iraq. I have no intention of ducking this debate, because I am convinced Britain's policy is right.

Saddam Hussein's regime is a danger to its neighbours and to its people. That danger must be contained. Britain has a duty to play its role, as a supporter of the UN, a defender of human rights and an opponent of aggression.

Hans von Sponeck (Foreign Office challenged on UN's Iraq sanctions, January 4) and other sanctions critics overlook the nature of Saddam Hussein's Iraq. He has used chemical weapons against his own people and against Iran. He has invaded Kuwait. And he has terrorised his country, ordering political killings, torture and mutilations.

Sanctions were imposed to force Iraq to eliminate its weapons of mass destruction. The threat was real then. It remains real now. Iraq is still hiding weapons of mass destruction. It has admitted concealing chemical and biological weapons and missile parts in the desert, caves and railway tunnels.

UN weapons inspectors have been unable to account for 4,000 tonnes of so-called precursor chemicals used in the production of chemical weapons, 610 tonnes of precursor chemicals used in the production of the nerve agent VX and some 31,000 chemical weapons munitions. Iraq retains a capacity to develop nuclear weapons.

The consequences of ending containment by abandoning sanctions would be horrendous. One teaspoon of the nerve agent sarin can cause up to 10,000 deaths. The international community cannot walk away from this threat.

Sanctions have contained the regime's threat to its people and neighbours. Since they were imposed, Iraq has not used chemical weapons against the Kurds or Iran or invaded its neighbours. Nor has it fired Scud missiles at Israel. Before sanctions Iraq did all of these. That is why Britain supports sanctions.

Critics of our policy point to the suffering of the Iraqi people under Saddam Hussein. But they move quickly and uncritically to the conclusion that sanctions are the cause of the suffering.

This year the UN is making up to $17bn available to Iraq for the purchase of humanitarian goods. This is more than Egypt, Syria or Jordan have to spend in equivalent areas (eg health, education, housing). Yet critics never ask why the people of those countries do not suffer the same privations as the people of Iraq. Could the answer be to do with Saddam's brutal indifference to the condition of his people?

In recent years, sanctions have been targeted more closely on items of potential use in weapons programmes. It is a myth that sanctions cover food and medicines. To export the majority of goods to Iraq - including food, medicines, agricultural, educational and water and sanitation goods - you need simply notify the UN.

The Iraqi people continue to suffer because the regime is not spending the money made available by the UN on its people's needs. Iraq has ordered no medicines under the UN oil for food programme for the last six months. Iraq had put $1.1bn worth of goods on hold at the end of October. Iraq is exporting food and medicine.

webTitle: As sound as the Bank of America

fields.headline: As sound as the Bank of America
fields.standfirst: Markets play 'guess the failure'
fields.trailText: We're OK, folks! Bank of America assured us yesterday afternoon, London time, as it sought to halt a market murmur that threatened to become a rout. No, its financial plight was not the real reason Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan hit the panic button and slashed American interest rates this week.
fields.body:
We're OK, folks! Bank of America assured us yesterday afternoon, London time, as it sought to halt a market murmur that threatened to become a rout. No, its financial plight was not the real reason Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan hit the panic button and slashed American interest rates this week.

The North Carolina-based institution may rank as the most exposed lender to the new economy dream - anywhere. It may have clumsily gotten itself all tied-up in California's energy crisis, where a number of the local utilities are in danger of going to the wall. But the great Bank of America is not going bust.

Stop and think of the significance of this. What is, by some measures, the third largest financial institution on the planet had to suspend its shares and issue a statement denying it was in trouble - a denial which was not immediately taken at face value.

Yesterday afternoon, from America's west coast to London and beyond, people were standing around in offices saying: "Have you heard the news? Apparently Bank of America's popped."

We could blame the ageing Mr Greenspan, of course. In the space of three weeks he moved from deciding that no loosening of American monetary policy was yet required to an emergency half-point rate slash.

The last time he moved between the Fed's regular open market committee meetings was in the late summer of 1998, when it subsequently emerged that the Long Term Capital Management affair was humming away in a Wall Street office suite and ready to blow. And it would be rude not to speculate now that a similarly destructive threat forced the Fed's hand.

For months now, we have been banging on about the inevitable pain associated with the speed and violence of the hi-tech sell off, which kicked off in real earnest in September.

Along the way, banks and trading houses have continued to make their glib claims that, having learned from history, the sophistication of their risk management controls ensures that any real catastrophy will be avoided - a claim that is, and always will be, nonsense. Bank of America may well manage its way out of the bind to which it has already owned up. But it, or the next victim of the markets' traditionally educated guessing game, will also have to live with the fact that the very existence of rumours can exacerbate a problem which might - in calmer circumstances - have been solved.

Too many billions of paper dollars have evaporated in the last four months to pretend that the financial system is anywhere near stable.

Reverse signals

Whatever events on the other side of the Atlantic might suggest, the Bank of England's monetary policy committee is unlikely to find enough in the domestic UK economy to opt for a cut in interest rates when it meets next week.

True, yesterday's figures from the Halifax show the British property market had its "worst" year since 1995.

But for the MPC's cautious tendency, worst might well equate with best. An average increase of just 3.1% is not the sort of number which keeps central bankers awake at night.

Rather the reverse. It signals little risk of the market overheating and no great dangers from the wealth effect - always a worry in the UK, given the prevelance of home ownership.

Just to reinforce the caution, housing economists reckon the balance of probability is that the market will pick up this year. No sense in getting things out of kilter by cutting rates and bringing down mortgages.

The latest indications from the labour market are hardly likely to persuade the hawkish members of the MPC that a touch on the economic accelerator is required, either.

Acording to research group NTC yesterday, however, although the growth in permanent and temporary job placements is slowing, the labour market remains tight. Wage growth is slowing, too, but is still running ahead of 1999. Again, hardly an encouragement to cut borrowing costs, despite the pressure from some sectors of business.

The great unknown, of course, is why the Fed cut rates when it did.

So far, analysts have found no justification for the timing of the between meetings' move. Until some satisfactory explanation is provided or is made evident by events, the markets will continue to expect a nasty shock around every corner.

Such a state of mind is bound to undermine confidence and may yet contribute to a result the rate cut was designed to avoid.

But until the fallout from the US, either in terms of the knock-on effects of an economic slowdown or market turbulence, presents a clear threat to the UK, the minority on the MPC that is already advocating lower rates will find it hard to persuade the rest.

webTitle: Airbus lines up two more deals

fields.headline: Airbus lines up two more deals
fields.trailText: Airbus is close to sealing contracts with Lufthansa, the German national carrier, and FedEx, the US cargo operator, to buy its A380 superjumbo, insiders said yesterday.
fields.body:
Airbus is close to sealing contracts with Lufthansa, the German national carrier, and FedEx, the US cargo operator, to buy its A380 superjumbo, insiders said yesterday.

Lufthansa said it would decide in the first quarter of this year whether to buy A380s or the stretched version of the rival Boeing jumbo, the 747X, but indicated a preference for the Airbus aircraft.

A deal with FedEx, reported to be for 10 aircraft worth around $2.3bn, was also said to be imminent.

webTitle: BAE Systems to restructure declining military business

fields.headline: BAE Systems to restructure declining military business
fields.trailText: BAE Systems, the aerospace and defence group, is to announce a 10-year plan that could see a further round of job losses and substantial restructuring of its military business to cope with declining budgets, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
BAE Systems, the aerospace and defence group, is to announce a 10-year plan that could see a further round of job losses and substantial restructuring of its military business to cope with declining budgets, it emerged yesterday.

The group - forged from the £7bn merger of British Aerospace and the then GEC's Marconi defence electronics operation - is engaged in drawing up "an integrated business plan" covering the next five to 10 years which is due to be published before it announces its annual results in March.

Last year BAE, which employs 65,000 in the UK, axed 3,800 industrial jobs and shed 1,500 managerial posts following the Marconi merger and, while insiders insisted no figures had been put on the scale of any further rationalisation, another round of redundancies is expected. The group is taking on 1,700 at Broughton, north Wales, and 100 at Filton, near Bristol, for work on the new Airbus A380 superjumbo.

John Weston, the chief executive, warned in September when the group reported a 48% rise in pre-tax profits for the first half to £507m, that further rationalisation would take place on top of measures to achieve the £275m savings targeted for the third year after the Marconi merger.

Yesterday officials admitted BAE faced several short term "challenges" but insisted that programmes in difficulty such as the £2bn contract to upgrade 21 Nimrod maritime patrol aircraft for the ministry of defence and the Hawk trainer aircraft were back on track.

Analysts expect the group to take a hit of up to £400m for the delays to the Nimrod contract which, the MoD has agreed, now involves the aircraft being delivered 23 months late - in 2005 rather than 2003.

"We're examining efficiencies and savings across the board. We're a global company and have to make continuous improvements to competitiveness to be successful," officials said.

Fears over the future of the Hawk plant in Brough, east Yorks, have abated following India's decision to opt for 66 of the aircraft. Uncertainty about the short-term financial impact of both programmes, however, helped drag BAE shares down 19p to close at 361p.

But BAE Systems insisted that long-term prospects were excellent, with a £37bn order book and the first Eurofighter to be delivered to the RAF next year.

fields.headline: Leigh Ashton
fields.trailText: In 1934, the newly qualified Dr Leigh Ashton, who has died aged 92, discovered that he would need to wait three years to marry his fiancée if he went to China for the China Inland Mission. So he went to Africa instead.
fields.body:
In 1934, the newly qualified Dr Leigh Ashton, who has died aged 92, discovered that he would need to wait three years to marry his fiancée if he went to China for the China Inland Mission. So he went to Africa instead.

His employer, the Africa Evangelical Fellowship, sent him to a new hospital at Kapsowar, a remote area of Kenya. The hospital was a single brick building with a dispensary, an outpatients' department and a rudimentary operating theatre. His fiancée, Marion Tryon, joined him the following year, having completed her medical training.

Ashton met her off the ship on a steamy hot morning in Mombasa, and they married within hours. A fellow passenger acted as best man, while his wife played the organ. Her repertoire comprised one hymn, How Sweet The Name Of Jesus Sounds In A Believer's Ear. It was to prove peculiarly fitting to the couple's life and work.

They added wards and a maternity wing to the hospital, and Ashton trekked over mountains and through forest tracks, setting up medical outposts and working in the smaller communities. He talked with his patients about spiritual matters alongside their medical needs.

After war service in the King's African Rifles, he returned to Kenya and set up home with his wife at Eldoret, 200 miles north of Nairobi. Their house became a meeting place, and gatherings there led to the emergence of today's Eldoret Christian Fellowship. Their son and two of their three daughters were born there.

Ashton became experienced in eye surgery, orthopaedics, obstetrics and gynaecology, trauma care and cranial - and even plastic - surgery, but it is one of the curiosities of the developed west that such men were required to retrain on re-entry to this country. So in 1964, after 30 years in Africa, Ashton became a trainee general practitioner, before becoming a partner in a medical practice at Winterbourne, near Bristol, and then taking on his own practice in Peterborough.

Born in Purley, Surrey, Ashton was the eldest of three children, and the only son of a civil servant. His family moved to Harrogate, and then to Bristol, where he entered the city's university medical school. His fun-loving spirit, breadth of ability and singlehearted Christian discipleship were reminiscent of the Olympic runner and missionary Eric Liddell, whose story was told in the film, Chariots Of Fire.

After Ashton retired, he picked up a copy of East Asia's Millions, the Overseas Missionary Fellowship magazine. Formerly, the OMF had been the China Inland Mission, with whom the Ashtons would have worked back in the 1930s. Noticing a need for doctors in central Thailand, and with Marion's backing, he offered his services for three years.

This period was spent largely in the small market town of Nongbua. With very little Thai language, Ashton was dependent on fellow missionaries to act as interpreters, and always encouraged them to talk privately with the patients about matters of faith during the consultation, even if he could not join in. The Thai nurses loved him, and called him "Daddy Leigh".

The tenacity of Leigh and Marion Ashton's lives was made possible by their sense of adventure and strong marriage. In March 1995, their diamond wedding was marked by Roger Royle on BBC Radio 2's Sunday Half Hour. At their four children's request, How Sweet The Name Of Jesus Sounds In A Believer's Ear was sung.

Marion died earlier this year; Leigh is survived by his son and three daughters.

 Leigh Ashton, doctor and missionary, born April 14 1908; died November 13 2000

fields.headline: Sir Laurence Whistler
fields.standfirst: He singlehandedly revived a great renaissance tradition of glass engraving
fields.trailText: He singlehandedly revived a great renaissance tradition of glass engraving.
fields.body:
Sir Laurence Whistler, the writer, poet and glass engraver, who has died aged 88, singlehandedly revived the tradition of point engraving on glass goblets and bowls, an intricate technique popular in the 17th and 18th centuries. His simultaneous use of line engraving and stippling methods on both sides of the glass was a great innovation, creating an illusion of perspective in his portrayal of unmistakeably English landscapes.

Laurence had many followers, and in 1975 became the first president of the newly-established Guild of Glass Engravers. Exhibitions of his glass over the years included those at Agnews in 1969, the Coming Museum, New York, in 1974, Sotheby's in 1992 - to celebrate his 80th birthday - and one with his son, Simon, also a glass engraver, in Salisbury in 1994.

His glasses were popular commemorative gifts and he received several important commissions from members of the royal family. He also engraved glass for several church windows, including his most important commission of 12 large windows at Moreton church, Dorset.

Laurence was the youngest son of a builder and decorator, and his wife, who lived in Eltham, southeast London. He revered his older brother, the artist Rex Whistler. The family moved at various times, and he was finally sent to Stowe school, where his history tutor, Martin Mac- laughlin, encouraged him to make measured drawings of the school buildings. In 1930, he went to Balliol College, Oxford, where his fees were paid by Rex, by then earning a good deal as an artist and illustrator.

Laurence changed from studying history to English, leading a quiet life mostly reading poetry. His first book of poems, Armed October, was published in 1932, with illustrations by Rex. In 1934, he published a second book of poems and took a job as assistant secretary to the press board of the Church Assembly. In 1935, he won the Royal Gold Medal for Poetry, given for the best book of the year by a writer under 35.

On the strength of this prize, Laurence left his job, and signed contracts for a further book of poems, and a life of the architect and dramatist Sir John Vanbrugh. Published in 1938, this last book was a pioneering work, which revived interest in the English baroque architecture movement.

To supplement his income, Laurence began glass engraving. In 1934, he stayed with the daughter of Sir Edwin Lutyens in Northumberland, where, with a diamond-tipped pencil, he engraved a sonnet on a window pane, decorating it with an urn of wild flowers. Rex encouraged him and Laurence's first designs were in the manner of his brother.

It was around this time that he met Jill Furse, a young actress. They married in 1939 and, when war was declared, settled at a cottage at Venton, near Bideford, where he continued glass engraving and, with Jill's encouragement, wrote poetry. Their idyllic life at this time is described in Laurence's book, The Initials In The Heart, which was published in 1964 to wide acclaim. During the war, he served as an army instructor.

In 1944, he suffered two personal tragedies. In July, Rex was killed in action in Normandy - Laurence read the news when he picked up a newspaper at Waterloo station. Then, in November, not long after the birth of a daughter, Jill died of a blood infection. Laurence was unable to be with her at the time.

After demobilisation, he went to live with his young children, and the Furse family, in London and, later, Devon. In 1950, he married Theresa, the younger sister of Jill, with whom he had a son and daughter. This marriage broke up. His third marriage, to Carol, in 1987 was dissolved in 1991.

Other books included Rex Whistler, His Life And His Drawings (1948), The Laughter And The Urn, The Life Of Rex Whistler (1985), and several works on his engraved glass. Laurence was a man of great intellect, kindness and modesty, always encouraging young artists and writers. His books and glass engravings are endowed with a rare poetic sensitivity as well as a very professional vigour.

 Laurence Whistler, glass engraver, born January 21 1912; died December 19 2000

The family moved at various times, and he was finally sent to Stowe school, where his history tutor, Martin Mac- laughlin, encouraged him to make measured drawings of the school buildings. In 1930, he went to Balliol College, Oxford, where his fees were paid by Rex, by then earning a good deal as an artist and illustrator. Laurence changed from studying history to English, leading a quiet life mostly reading poetry. His first book of poems, Armed October, was published in 1932, with illustrations by Rex. In 1934, he published a second book of poems and took a job as assistant secretary to the press board of the Church Assembly. In 1935, he won the Royal Gold Medal for Poetry, given for the best book of the year by a writer under 35. On the strength of this prize, Laurence left his job, and signed contracts for a further book of poems, and a life of the architect and dramatist Sir John Vanbrugh. Published in 1938, this last book was a pioneering work, which revived interest in the English baroque architecture movement. To supplement his income, Laurence began glass engraving. In 1934, he stayed with the daughter of Sir Edwin Lutyens in Northumberland, where, with a diamond-tipped pencil, he engraved a sonnet on a window pane, decorating it with an urn of wild flowers. Rex encouraged him and Laurence's first designs were in the manner of his brother. It was around this time that he met Jill Furse, a young actress. They married in 1939 and, when war was declared, settled at a cottage at Venton, near Bideford, where he continued glass engraving and, with Jill's encouragement, wrote poetry. Their idyllic life at this time is described in Laurence's book, The Initials In The Heart, which was published in 1964 to wide acclaim. During the war, he served as an army instructor. In 1944, he suffered two personal tragedies. In July, Rex was killed in action in Normandy - Laurence read the news when he picked up a newspaper at Waterloo station. Then, in November, not long after the birth of a daughter, Jill died of a blood infection. Laurence was unable to be with her at the time. After demobilisation, he went to live with his young children, and the Furse family, in London and, later, Devon. In 1950, he married Theresa, the younger sister of Jill, with whom he had a son and daughter. This marriage broke up. His third marriage, to Carol, in 1987 was dissolved in 1991. Other books included Rex Whistler, His Life And His Drawings (1948), The Laughter And The Urn, The Life Of Rex Whistler (1985), and several works on his engraved glass. Laurence was a man of great intellect, kindness and modesty, always encouraging young artists and writers. His books and glass engravings are endowed with a rare poetic sensitivity as well as a very professional vigour.  Laurence Whistler, glass engraver, born January 21 1912; died December 19 2000

webTitle: Iranians lose faith in pivotal murder trial

fields.headline: Iranians lose faith in pivotal murder trial
fields.standfirst: 18 'rogue' agents accused of killing dissidents
fields.trailText: The decision by the Iranian judiciary to hold hearings in secret into the murder of four dissidents by "rogue" intelligence agents has prompted claims that the proceedings are designed to protect senior officials and clerics rather than uncover the truth.
fields.body:
The decision by the Iranian judiciary to hold hearings in secret into the murder of four dissidents by "rogue" intelligence agents has prompted claims that the proceedings are designed to protect senior officials and clerics rather than uncover the truth.

Since the court sessions began on December 23, claims that the wrong defendants are on trial have sparked renewed national tensions.

"The court hearings on the serial murders case are not satisfying public opinion," said the reformist MP Naser Qavami, head of the parliamentary committee on judicial affairs. "It seems there is no hope that this court will administer justice properly."

Eighteen "rogue" agents from the intelligence ministry are accused of murdering four liberal dissidents in late 1998: nationalist politicians Darioush and Parvaneh Forouhar, and writers Mohammad Mokhtari and Mohammad Jafar Pouyandeh.

Reformists allege that the killings were part of a campaign by state-sponsored death squads to silence dissent.

But conservatives blame what they say are links between the reformist camp and the killers, with the murders designed to discredit the clerical establishment and force an overhaul of the security services.

Two pro-reform journalists and a former interior minister say the real number of those killed was as high as 80, with murders and mysterious disappearances stretching over a decade. They say that senior clerics conspired with high-ranking intelligence officials to carry out the murders.

The two journalists and former minister are now in jail. And the judiciary, dominated by conservative clerics, has vowed to prosecute anyone else making "unauthorised revelations" in the case.

Whatever the outcome in the trial, it is clear that the proceedings reflect Iran's troubled political atmosphere more than any quest for the truth.

What began as a promise by President Mohammad Khatami and his allies to clean up the feared ministry of intelligence has largely evaporated in the face of entrenched conservative opposition.

Mystery surrounds the selection of the murder victims, who posed no threat to Iran's Islamic political order. Some reformists have suggested it was part of a proposed reign of terror. But no coherent pattern has emerged to date, although scattered press reports indicate that the plotters worked for months to identify and then eliminate their victims.

In the case of the elderly Farouhar couple, the killers were said to have posed as a film crew making a documentary about their political activities. These same reports say intelligence ministry microphones planted inside their Tehran flat picked up the sound of their brutal murders.

The case began unravelling when the intelligence ministry said renegade agents were responsible for the murders. The announcement shocked the nation and many became hopeful that the murderers would be brought to justice.

But since that time, the case has been fraught with drama, suspicion, and confessions that many believe are fake.

In June 1999 the authorities announced that the ring-leader, a deputy intelligence minister identified variously as Saeed Emami and Saeed Eslami, had died in prison after drinking hair remover. Many remain sceptical of the official ruling of suicide, preferring to see the beginnings of a cover-up.

Two crusading journalists, Akbar Ganji and Emaddedin Baqi, then published a series of allegations that linked the murders to the hardline clerical establishment in what they said amounted to a campaign of state-sponsored terror.

Confusion then set in within the top ranks of the government and the judiciary - special commissions and prosecutors came and went. Charges of torture against the first investigators left most Iranians with little hope that the truth will ever be known.

The presiding judge in the case contributed to the prevailing scepticism by barring the public and the press from court sessions to protect national security interests.

"Who can guarantee that an open court would not provide information to the enemies outside the country?" said Judge Mohammad Reza Aqiqi. The victims' families are boycotting the proceedings to protest at the judiciary's decision to restrict the prosecution to only four murders.

At least five defendants have reportedly confessed, and one said he was aware of the murders but took no active part.

The case, initially regarded as a test of whether President Khatami could keep his promise to cleanse the intelligence ministry of political crimes, now reveals his lack of power.

Two years ago Mr Khatami appointed an independent commission to uncover the truth behind the murders. Its revelations helped to bring the case to trial, but failed to expose conclusive information about the culprits.

webTitle: Please do not remove your seatbelts just yet

fields.headline: Please do not remove your seatbelts just yet
fields.standfirst: It may take more than one rate cut to stop US share prices falling. Patience then, investor
fields.trailText: Equities need a visit from the style gurus. The emergency cut in American interest rates may serve only to highlight their recently rediscovered deficiencies. As the small print always states: prices can go down as well as up.
fields.body:
Equities need a visit from the style gurus. The emergency cut in American interest rates may serve only to highlight their recently rediscovered deficiencies. As the small print always states: prices can go down as well as up.

Last year's 10% fall in the broad US equities market, as measured by the S&P Composite Index, ended a four-year run where annual gains averaged more than 30%. Such advances were three times the long-term average. As such they should properly be labelled "extraordinary".

Investors are only human, however. They have short memories. It is little wonder, then, that expectations for equity returns have become conditioned by the experience of the late 1990s. This is particularly true of private investors. Surveys have revealed - at least until recent months - a "double your money" mentality that is at odds with history.

In the 20th century the S&P posted a calendar year decline 32 times. So one might expect US share prices to fall one year in three. But since1980 the S&P has only dropped one year in five.

The raw data suggest that stock market falls are not necessarily traumatic. Last year's was the worst since 1982 and over the long run was pretty much in the middle of the pack. However, the market does not work on annual cycles and, as in 2000, the top-to-bottom decline can be much greater than theJanuary-December movement. At its worst last December the S&P was 17% off its high.

Falling share prices also have a tendency to dislocate markets and economies. They force rapid and painful reappraisal of expectations with dramatic consequences.

This is the current experience in America. In a matter of months, the Federal Reserve's concern about inflationary bottlenecks has been replaced by fear of a hard landing. Such a high level of fear, in fact, that it has lowered interest rates in an emergency session. This is a measure normally employed only in times of perceived economic crisis.

It seems incredible to me that until very recently many glibly forecast a soft landing for the US without overt help from the Fed. The stonking growth rate of the American economy was built not just on the technology revolution but also on widespread belief in that revolution. The fervour surrounding technology bordered on the messianic and helped turbo-charge the economy.

It would be as foolish now to dismiss technology as a false idol as it was a year ago to hail it as an economic messiah. However, you can be sure that sceptics will have the upper hand in boardrooms throughout the US as tech proposals are put before investment committees. Many tech companies might even suffer sales declines this year.

The first reaction of investors to the 0.5% cut in the Fed funds rate was to mark equity prices up sharply, with particular emphasis on both the battered tech sector and economically sensitive industries.

It takes more than a day to make a trend, however. It might take more than one rate cut to arrest the economic slowdown. A reappraisal of the Fed's action is necessary and likely. Gloom might soon return to stock markets as investors realise that it is far too soon to anticipate the bottom in the corporate profits cycle. Rumours, such as those swirling around Bank of America yesterday, are just the thing to deepen the malaise.

The consensus view of economic prospects in the UK is also far too rosy. Although Bank of England governor Sir Eddie George recently cited a US slowdown as his biggest fear, the Bank continues to accord great weight to inflation risk. I fear it is driving by the rear-view mirror.

The more economists you apply to the interest rate question, the more likely you are to base your decisions primarily on the most recent historic data rather than on a value judgment about how the future will differ from the past. What Britain needs is a "flair" judgment to cut rates now.

Friday's Financial Times carried the results of work it had commissioned from Oxford Economic Forecasting to assess the dependence of the British economy on the US. I do not buy their conclusion that the relationship between the two is not as great as typically believed.

What the OEF's model is unlikely to allow for is the probability that British companies and individuals will determine their behaviour by the trends they perceive to have taken hold in the US. Comparing Britain's trade with the rest of Europe to its trade with America tells only part of the story. When was the last time Britain took its economic lead from the continent?

The European Central Bank chose to leave its short-term interest rate unchanged on Thursday at 4.75%. British rates are 6%. There is little reason for this differential.

Patience, then, investor. Let the trends unfurl a little before staking your portfolio on a continuance of the long term supremacy of equities. The world has not changed. It's just not yet back to normal.

Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities


edmondw@omsecurities.co.uk

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Lloyds presses Abbey case
fields.body:
Lloyds presses Abbey case

Lloyds TSB took its takeover assault on Abbey National to the competition authorities yesterday, asking them to consider the regulatory implications from any bid.

However, Lloyds did not make a formal bid for Abbey, whose merger talks with Bank of Scotland have been left in limbo since the predator pounced six weeks ago.

The office of fair trading, already considering the implications of an Abbey/ BoS tie up, asked for public responses to Lloyds' submission by January 19. Abbey said it would make "factual" submission to the OFT which will recommend to Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, whether to order a competition commission inquiry.

BoS and Abbey could hear as soon as January 18 if their deal will face such examination. But even if they receive the all-clear they might await the outcome of Lloyds' gambit, which could come by February 3.

Jobs shed at Breathe.com

The administrator striving to keep internet service provider Breathe.com afloat has made redundant an undisclosed number of its 140 staff.

A spokeswoman said PricewaterhouseCoopers was still talking to several interested parties as efforts continued to sell what was Britain's fifth-largest ISP as a going concern. "As yet there have been no acceptable offers."

Breathe, which offered unmetered internet access for a flat fee, ran into difficulties last month.

Deal doubts hit EM.TV shares

Doubts about a crucial deal with Kirch group yesterday hit shares in EM.TV and Merchandising, the Munich group which owns the rights to the Muppets and has an interest in television rights to formula one motor racing.

EM.TV, which has seen its share price crash since a profits warning late last year, and Kirch played down fears that the deal would not be completed.

But concerns about the progress of negotiations for Kirch to take a 25% stake in EM.TV and a 49% holding in the offshoot involved in formula one rights saw EM.TV shares fall 14% yesterday.

"The deal is not done and dusted. Kirch is keeping all its options open," according to a source quoted by Reuters.

However both sides insisted that negotiations were proceeding. "When we announced [the deal] we said that it would take at least until the end of January and maybe into February. I think some people had too high expectations that after Christmas it would be settled," an EM.TV spokesman said.

Orange offer date set

France Telecom is expected to announce the terms of its share offering in its mobile unit Orange on January 22, with the IPO to open the next day and trading to start on February 12.

France Telecom, which said last March it would sell 10-15% in New Orange, is still deciding exactly how much to sell and at what price, but aims to raise around£5bn.

Singer joins QXL board

QXL, the struggling online auctioneer, yesterday announced the appointment of Telewest chief executive Adam Singer as a non-executive director.

The auction business hopes Mr Singer's experience at the helm of a FTSE 100 company will help restore its fortunes. QXL shares fell from a peak of 800p to 6.5p at the end of last year. Mr Singer said the company had a "robust business model."

webTitle: Cutting speed limits in rain 'would save lives'

fields.headline: Cutting speed limits in rain 'would save lives'
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Speed limits on motorways should be cut to 50mph when it is raining to save motorists' lives, research on the M4 has revealed.
fields.body:
Speed limits on motorways should be cut to 50mph when it is raining to save motorists' lives, research on the M4 has revealed.

In the rush hour in dry weather, the average speed of cars on the M4 near Cardiff was at the limit of 70mph. At the same time of day in wet weather, drivers slowed by an average of only 3mph, although cars required much longer stopping distances.

Julia Edwards, from the University of Wales college at Newport, said that according to the Highway Code, stopping distances doubled on a wet road. In rain at 70mph cars needed 96 metres (300ft) to stop - not possible on a motorway in the rush hour.

"I am sure that it is ignorance that is causing people to risk their lives. The number of accidents that take place in wet weather far exceeds those in the dry.

"In the south-east, roads are wet for only 7% of the time - yet 17% of all accidents take place in the rain."

In the rest of Europe these problems had been acknowledged, she said. On French motorways the normal limit of 130km an hour was reduced automatically to 110 when it rained - a cut of about 12mph.

She added: "We need a similar system in Britain. It is a matter of stopping distances and saving lives."
