webTitle: Smallweed on the controversy over the UK's bicentenary

fields.headline: The state of the dates
fields.trailText: A great caterwauling has broken out over the lack of a celebration of the 200th anniversary of the birth of the United Kingdom in 1801.
fields.body:
A great caterwauling has broken out over the lack of a celebration of the 200th anniversary of the birth of the United Kingdom in 1801 when Great Britain and Ireland were welded into a single entity. A man called Wills, who appears to have been given the post of minister for inculcating patriotism, says the matter is under consideration - something of an inane observation when the anniversary occurred on January 1.

The Tories, who are making this fuss, are not much better. Most of them only woke up to the issue around midnight on Boxing Day. I blame: 1) the anniversary, for sneaking up on us unannounced; 2) the mandarins of Whitehall, for failing to set up a National Committee for the Proclamation of Impending Anniversaries (which wide-awake readers will no doubt have noticed yields the snappy acronym NCPIA). Since they will no doubt proceed on this issue in their usual dilatory way, here as a public service are some dates for those who govern us to write in their diaries:

2007: 300th anniversary of the Act of Union between England and Scotland (a designation which, as perspicacious readers will have noticed, conceals the name of prominent London suburb, of which more below).

2015: 800th anniversary of the signing of Magna Carta.

2066: 1,000th anniversary of 1066.

2085: 400th anniversary of the revocation of the Edict of Nantes.

January 1 2101: beginning of 22nd century.

January 1 3001: beginning of fourth millennium (please get it right this time).

As for the neglect of this juicy occasion, could it be that most people assume there is not very much to celebrate? Almost half the people of Northern Ireland probably wish the union had never happened, and opinion polls suggest that majorities on the mainland would like to be shot of the union, too. In any case, the union established on January 1 1801 came to an end in 1922 when part of the outfit seceded and formed what is now the Republic of Ireland. So here are two more dates for official diaries:

2022: 100th anniversary of what is now the Republic of Ireland leaving the Union established in 1801, and thus the creation of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland as we know and love it today.

2051: 50th anniversary of Smallweed's proposal for a National Committee for the Proclamation of Impending Anniversaries. Still unimplemented? I thought as much.

A pedant writes: NCPIA is not an acronym. The letters of an acronym must form a pronounceable word.

Smallweed acerbically counters: And so these ones do. They make up the word for a kind of yam which flourishes in the sunlit uplands of Java.

A pedant poignantly comments: I cannot find this word in any of my dictionaries.

Smallweed replies with a cheery smirk: You should get some new dictionaries, then.

I never expected to write these words, but I suspect that we may, at the start of this new millennium, be on the cusp (a word I haven't used for some time) of a great renaissance for the London suburb of Acton. Consider this evidence:

 The president of Syria has married into the town. His bride was until now an Acton resident.

 Travellers from the centre of London can get to Acton Green on the 94 bus - the very route on which the boss of Radio 4 was travelling when the inspiration came to her to surrender her channel to Harry Potter for eight hours on Boxing Day.

As I reported a few weeks ago, the 94 bus has become a kind of mobile Mecca for artists and intellectuals. The cargo when I was aboard this week was a tinge disappointing, but a wiseacre at the bus stop assured me that minutes before I arrived he had seen in the queue Salman Rushdie, Andrew Roberts, Lord St John of Fawsley, AS Byatt, Sir Roy Strong and Sir Harrison Birtwistle.

 The year 2001 marks the 125th anniversary of the escape to Britain of the Russian writer, agitator and nihilist Prince Kropotkin, who lived for a time in Woodhurst Road. It is also the 80th anniversary of his death.

Two further points about Acton before this hymn to its merits concludes. You will have to do without blobs as supplies have run out.

Acton has a cathedral: the cathedral of the Ukrainian Autocephalic Orthodox Church.

South Acton has a district which used to be known as Soapsuds Island, because of its congregation of laundries, drawn to the area by the abundant soft waters of the Stamford and Bollo brooks. This year sees the 102nd anniversary of the year 1899, at which point a mere 19 streets housed 178 laundries - all gone today.

How to get to this area : On leaving Acton Town station (Piccadilly line) turn right and right again down Bollo Lane. Turn left and, taking the famous advice of the song in The Wizard of Oz, follow the Bollo Bridge road, passing the South Acton housing estate, and watching out for the recreation ground. Apparently, it's somewhere round there.

I hope I've convinced the moaners and groaners who are always around in their legions at times like this that Acton's range of attractions is lavish enough to draw the crowds this summer on a scale which will fill the people of neighbouring suburbs with envy. Or as people say in these parts, turn 'em green.

If Andersen Consulting chooses to change its name to Accenture (wide awake readers will have noted, I hope, the opening syllable's subliminal allusion to Acton), there is nothing much the rest of the world can do about it. What I do most strenuously question, though, is the little device they've inserted above the T, which looks like a weary circumflex having a lie-down. No doubt newspaper editors will soon begin to get letters chiding them for printing the name without this kinky symbol on top. I'm told that in this modern world the sign should be read as "greater than". How then should we construe the word Accenture with this gadget hovering over its T? Presumably the message it seeks to convey must be this: "Accent is greater than Ure." Since the only Ures I can trace are rivers in Argyllshire and Yorkshire, I nominate this as the silliest claim made in 2001 so far.

webTitle: Ian Mayes on the language of ageism

fields.headline: Old prejudices
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... how the language of ageism prevails
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... how the language of ageism prevails.
fields.body:
A leader in the Guardian a couple of weeks before Christmas commented on the changing age profile of the population in Britain and other developed countries. It said: "We already live in the oldest society that has existed, but it is going to get older still. Fewer births and longer lives mean the number of people aged 65 and over will increase at 10 times the overall rate of population growth in the next 40 years."

There is still perhaps more awareness of this in the US than in Britain. A cartoon in the New Yorker in the summer of last year had a woman addressing her husband with the words: "Good news, honey - 70 is the new 50." An episode of Frasier, shown on television in Britain a month later, had Dr Frasier Crane remarking: "You sound like my father - a man who believes that burial is a form of age discrimination."

About one-quarter of the Guardian's readers are over the age of 55, more or less equivalent to the proportion on other broadsheets, except for the Daily Telegraph, which has nearly half its readers in that upper-age band.

The Guardian, like all its rivals, makes great efforts to attract young people but still attempts, now and again, a conciliatory nod towards its older readers. Remarkably, in mid-December the paper started a monthly Grandparents page, the advent of which was marked by the editorial quoted above. The editor of the page, a man some long way from becoming a grandparent, pointed out in a persuasive introductory article that 40% of parents admit that their working lives would be impossible without the childcare provided by their own parents. It should be worth watching the page as it explores the implications of that and other aspects of a long life sanctioned by an assumed or assigned role.

My correspondence leaves me in no doubt that many readers, particularly those who are themselves in the upper-age bracket, believe the paper is at best confused in its attitude to age, and at worst ageist. To return to the editorial I was quoting, it continued thus: "The US is already seeing a rising proportion of wrinklies in work." (Collins, "wrinklies": informal, derogatory [term for] old people.)

Several readers combined a welcome for the Grandparents page with a note of dismay at the use of the word. "I don't think the word 'wrinkly' is needed in the language, any more than derogatory nicknames for [other groups]. We need to respect all our fellow citizens, not demean them. Remember what Sophia Loren said about wrinkles: not to retouch photos showing hers because 'it took me so long to earn them'."

Other correspondents made the same point. "To be defined simply by one aspect of our being - one generally considered negative - is totally out of order and... abusively ageist... Shame on the journalist and the editor who passed it."

In the week before Christmas another piece in the Guardian attracted protest, this time the Diary of a Junior Doctor, in which the author cautioned readers against dumping their "grannies" in hospital over the festive season.

A letter began: "I write in some personal distress to protest about an attitude to older people paraded in these columns for the amusement of readers... Try substituting 'blacks' or 'Jews' for the 'grannies' and the piece would have been scrapped on sight.

"And the distress? Well, 35 years ago I changed my medical career to become a full-time advocate for the needs and rights of older people who become sick. At that time attitudes such as these were almost the norm among hospital doctors. It is not pleasant to see such prejudice still in existence and apparently still acceptable enough to be described so shamelessly."

One reader writing in response, not to this but to another piece, threw in an objection to the way that his or her doctor said: "You're not 25 any more, you know," adding: "But the way doctors treat old people is another story, and a distressing one." The main purpose of this reader had been to call for the abandonment of the phrase "the age when men and women pick up their free bus pass", usually used as an oblique compliment to someone still active. "So and so is starting a new career at the age when_"

This falls into the category of thoughtless ageism like that objected to by the writer of the following letter: "As a recently diagnosed osteoporosis sufferer, I begin to understand [the] use of the phrase 'little old ladies'. It is a bad habit grown out of a truism. There are still 'little old ladies', but in the past, before diagnosis and treatment of osteoporosis were possible, there must have been many, many more." It was time, this reader suggested, to stop implying that all old ladies were little.

Times are changing - faster, it sometimes appears, than our language and attitudes. But I'll stop there. It is time for my rest.

fields.headline: The last word on   Consumerism
fields.standfirst: Conspicuous consumption of valuable goods is a means of reputability to the gentleman of leisure -    Thorstein Veblen
fields.trailText: Conspicuous consumption of valuable goods is a means of reputability to the gentleman of leisure - Thorstein Veblen
fields.body:
January sales, or perhaps the avid shoppers rummaging among them, offer an arresting spectacle of consumerism at its nakedest. Sociological orthodoxy says that consumerism is oppression; skilful marketing people have manipulated us into a state of passive victimhood, endlessly and aimlessly consuming ever-increasing amounts at the behest of an advertising industry which creates false desires in us by making us believe that to purchase an object is to purchase paradise. Studies of consumerism and what it involves - marketing, brand names, fashion, shopping, packaging, rubbish, pollution, social rivalry, the throw-away ethos and the commodification of value - therefore make mortifying reading, not least for those just home from the high street.

The orthodoxy tells us that marketing executives turn us into anxious, docile creatures falsely made to believe that the way to find happiness is to buy stuff. A chorus of distinguished commentators, among them Thorstein Veblen, John Kenneth Galbraith, Vance Packard, Ralph Nader, and the philosophers of the Frankfurt School, all condemn the waste, folly, false consciousness and victimhood of consumerist society, which they describe as a conspiracy to force us to labour so that we can purchase the crumbs of pleasure that the system lets fall from the tables of those whose unnecessary products we buy. And in the meantime we are engulfed in waste and pollution as we sit in the blue flicker of television advertisements, eating our unhealthy microwaved TV dinners.

But the evidence in support of this orthodoxy is equivocal. Quite different data suggest that consumers are smart, and that shopping is a profound source of meaning in the modern world. The orthodoxy seems to imply that if only advertisers would leave us alone, we would all begin reading Wittgenstein and listening to Mahler. But we would not. We want Things; we want Stuff; we want to buy and to own. And as the laws of supply and demand suggest, it is the consumers who lead, while the producers and advertisers scamper after them, supplying the consolations and salvations (religious language springs naturally to mind) that brand names and the joys of ownership provide.

Perhaps, therefore, consumers' love of consuming is not so contemptible. There is a theory, amusingly and cogently offered by James Twitchell of Columbia University, that consuming is the passion and the creativity of contemporary life. Through the possession of Things, he says, we define ourselves, interpret our society, and give our lives coherence. We do not wish to drive a car, but a Ferrari; we do not wish to drink champagne, but Veuve Cliquot; we do not wish to wear a suit, but an Armani suit. Owning them gives us meaning. The language of products and services is the shared language of our community. Logos and advertisements are the cultural emblems of our time, signposts that help us navigate our world and evaluate what we meet in it. Both the language and the images offer what religion once did - a common structure. But as a community bond it is, says Twitchell, more democratic and equitable. For consumers are not fools, not victims of dogmas taught by a priesthood. They are their own priests; they know what they want, and they are getting it.

Consider the logic of brand names. Why do people buy and wear expensive, recognisable brands? Because it gives them - it really does give them - a claim to social place, prestige, confidence, purpose. That is the key to consumerism: ownership of precisely these intangibles is what purchase of their tangible vehicles buys.

The argument that consumption is not oppression - that consumers are happy, that consumption is satisfying and gives life meaning - is exhilaratingly robust. But it is hard to suppress the thought that, if happiness is what matters, you could achieve the same degree of it more swiftly and economically by putting heroin in the water supply. And it leaves out of account an insight so familiar that it has long been the very cliche of cliches: that of all the things worth having in life, such as kindness, wisdom, and the human affections, none is on offer in the January sales.

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText:
Christopher Lloyd must be suffering an attack of the Christmas grumps, otherwise he would never have condemned hellebores so harshly (Borderline Decision, December 23). In Westminster Abbey College garden, the Helleborus orientalis flower continuously from December to April, and you never get tired of the greenish white blooms. The foliage is attractive and evergreen. In contrast, hostas require a persistence with slug pellets that is both tiresome and damaging to garden wildlife.
Jan Pancheri
Gardener, Westminster Abbey College garden
London SW1

Would you, I wonder, have given such prominence to the photomontage of a father and son looking scared and then the son being shot dead if they were related to you (The Year In Words And Pictures, December 30)? Would you have printed photos of children being shot dead at Dunblane? These were voyeuristic, unnecessarily disturbing and in extremely bad taste.
Clive Trusson
Beeston, Nottingham

Oh dear. Julie Burchill (December 30) not only misquotes but compounds the felony with an incorrect attribution: '"By making a beast of himself man forgets the pain of being human," said no less than Sam Beckett.' I believe it is actually one of Samuel Johnson's aphorisms: 'He who makes a beast of himself gets rid of the pain of being a man.' It was used quite famously by Hunter S Thompson as the epigraph to Fear And Loathing In Las Vegas.
David Graham
Carlisle, Cumbria

Julie Burchill paid tribute to Joanne Good as a broadcaster, rightly praising her skills and aptitude, but then assassinated her character as an actress (December 16). I have been lucky enough to work with Joanne on several occasions. She's warm-hearted, talented, generous, hard-working and funny. Yes, she can be a luvvie, but only in the way that Dame Maggie is a luvvie, that Simon Callow is a luvvie. They bring a presence that warms the human condition and, in making grandiose gestures, stop us taking ourselves too seriously. Long live the luvvies.
Nick Beddows
Producer, BBC Television

I have tried to make Jeremy Lee's recipe for chocolate fudge three times (December 2) and three times it has failed to set! In one recipe he mentions '1 tin of condensed milk' in another '1 large can of condensed milk'. What is the difference?
Jennifer Formichelli
Cambridge

Jeremy Lee regrets the state of our correspondent's fudge and stresses that the secret of the chocolate fudge lies in 'really cooking' the sugar and water so that it becomes a syrup. The quantity of condensed milk needed (whether in a tin or large can) is 397g.

Please advise your troglodyte-commie-pinko elite-journo staff that President Elect Bush didn't spend eight years killing people in Texas. In the US system of government, only courts can direct executions. It is amusing to watch the likes of Alexander Chancellor under-estimate Bush (December 30). This is exactly where Gore Jr went wrong. The one person who instantly recognised Bush's intelligence and skill as a politician was Clinton who has, of course, an Intel computer chip brain for politics.
LGE
Espenlg@aol.com
Maryland, USA

 Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Email: weekend@theguardian.com. Fax: 020-7239 9935. A postal address must be supplied. Letters should reach us by Tuesday afternoon for inclusion on Saturday, and may be edited.

fields.headline: Citycide
fields.standfirst: 'Brighton and Hove - a city! No matter how many times they say it, it'll never sound right. Can you walk across a city in half an hour?'
fields.trailText: 'Brighton and Hove - a city! No matter how many times they say it, it'll never sound right. Can you walk across a city in half an hour?'
fields.body:
I'm very pleased for the good people of Greenwich, knowing that they'll be going forward into the brave future without that rotten Dome hanging over them; I only wish that my own 'burg was about to rid itself of a flashy, trashy, empty monument to the vanity of politicians. But sadly, the one which I now live in the shadow of is going to last a bit longer than a year, and in fact the only chance of escaping it, ever, would be by moving away and staying away. I refer, of course, to last month's creation of Brighton & Hove as one of the three millennial cities.

A city! No matter how many times they say it, it'll never sound right. Can you walk across a city in half an hour? Is a city a short commuter hop from London, and does half its population need to go to London each morning in order to find gainful employment? Maybe. I don't know. But most of all, I've got real "issues", if you will, with the idea of a City By The Sea, as we're now supposed to think of ourselves. Yes, I know that they've got them in Europe. But they've got rabies and a history of Nazi collaboration in Europe, too. Does that mean it's mandatory for us as well? To citify a seaside town in this country is to totally disregard the special nature of the British coastal resort. From Bournemouth to Blackpool, coarse or genteel, they all have a certain something in common; their gentleness, their outdatedness, their very lack of everything - graft, overcrowding, pollution - that makes a city a city.

And exactly what is so great about living in a city? Every last survey on this subject shows that while around three-quarters each of all town- and country-dwellers express satisfaction with their quality of life, this plummets to around 10% when you ask an urbanite. You don't even have to read about it; you can see them promenading along Brighton seafront every weekend, well into the autumn - thousands of Londoners set free for the day, blinking and smiling with surprise at all this light and space, poor little mole-people above ground at last. And even when the Palace Pier is jammed solid with humanity, there's never the nastiness you sense in similar city situations, simply because the ever-present sea and the incredible horizon reminds us what a big place the world is, and that we are not necessarily condemned to live and die in a rat-run. That's why, albeit shamefully, three out of four Brighton properties are sold to Londoners.

And what have we done about what should be such a great source of local pride? Gaily scampered off to knock ourselves out for a whole year, spending untold thousands of pounds of local taxation to persuade Her Maj to wave her magic wand and turn us into the very thing that everyone wants to escape from. There's logic! Frankly, wanting to be a city seems to me about as sensible and life-affirming as wanting to be a wart. There could even be a new word for such wanton self-immolation; Citycide. Yes, while England's only Grade I listed pier continued to fall into the sea, while the seagulls grew fat and fierce from all the uncollected rubbish left to rot in the streets (attacks on people by seagulls are becoming more frequent all the time), while lidos closed and Brighton comprehensive schools became a byword for bullying and underachievement, money was thrown ceaselessly at the city bid. And why?

A friend of mine had the wit to corner Simon Fanshawe, the idiot figurehead of the bid, fresh from his victory breakfast and ask him what had been the point? Fanshawe glared at the impertinence of the question, then blurted, "Well, Ben, the point is that now we can start talking about Brighton in a whole new, different way!" Hmm, well caught, Simes - I'm sure that'll be a real comfort to the old dears in deep Hove who've just had their hip operations cancelled again. You hero, you!

The excitement of certain local politicians over the city bid was a revelation to behold; people who had been unable to garner any extra enthusiasm or cash in order to improve such bagatelles as health or education were now wetting themselves with righteous fervour at the thought of getting new headed notepaper. I bet a bunch of you are saying by now "What is this? - the Brighton Argus?" but here's where the big picture starts.

Brighton council is a very New Labour council, composed of ex-Maoists and thwarted idealists who, while in the political wilderness of the Thatcher years, mutated into strange beings to whom power was not a means to an end, but an end in itself. They became Pod Politicians; they still went on about social justice and the brotherhood of man, but inside they'd gone all cold and creepy, and all they really cared about was being The Bully's Best Friend - you know, that kid who never gets into trouble but is always there on the sidelines, enjoying every last kick. The Bully in this case, of course, being big business, capitalism or whatever you wish to call it; that thing that ruins people's lives. In order to cosy up to him, they were quite prepared to do a shameless, public 360-degree turn; they even sometimes seemed to get a masochistic kick out of their own humbling. One of Blair's chief enforcers in the Lords, for instance, Lord Bassam of Brighton, started out in the 70s as Steve Bassam, leader of the militant squatters; during his time on Brighton council, he became notorious for his heavy-handed treatment of the travelling community.

The government is full of these people; people who once had real feelings, real ideas about social justice, but withered inside during their wilderness years. Peter Mandelson is the greatest example; in not one word or deed have I been able to discern why he is in politics apart from the fact that he wasn't personable enough to make it in showbiz, which is obviously his first love. Every time I see Dale Winton on TV, I can't help thinking, "You've got Mandelson's life! Give it back to him!"

There is a common wisdom that though politics may be rotten and corrupt or whatever, it is irrevocably a profession for grown-ups; those rare beings among us who were prepared to put fun on the back burner and go to endless dull meetings when the rest of us were dancing around our handbags in the pleasure dome of youth. But more and more I'm beginning to believe that politicians are actually less mature than the rest of us, due to missing out on serious fun at the time when it was appropriate to have it, and seeking to have a bit of show-offy fun now, but at our expense. Spiteful wallflowers, the lot of them: that horrible little bunch of kids who used to say to us, "Go on, then, mess about! But I'm going to be rich and powerful one day and then I'll show you all!" And now they're making us pay, dipping into our pockets to fund their vile vanity projects - the Dome, the city bids, the United States of Europe. We held their heads down the toilets a beat too long - now, God help us, it's our turn.

fields.headline: The outwardly mobile show
fields.standfirst: 3D film has come a long way since the flying crockery cliches of the 1950s, says  Jonathan Romney
fields.trailText: 3D film has come a long way since the flying crockery cliches of the 1950s, says Jonathan Romney
fields.body:
One of the enduring 20th-century images of mass folly is the shot - reproduced on many a jokey retro postcard - of 1950s cinema audiences, wearing cumbersome cardboard glasses as they gawp at some extravaganza in living, in-your-lap 3D: Bwana Devil! House of Wax! Cat Women of the Moon!

Such crowd scenes look to us now like the epitome of passive hickdom. How sheep-like could people be? But that's just the snobbery of historical hindsight. In reality, for all the tawdriness of much of the 1950s 3D cycle, contemporary audiences were enjoying nothing more witless than a dabble in the pleasures of trompe l'oeil illusion. Trompe l'oeil , far from entailing a passive viewer, is an active, critical process - it requires viewers to measure their 2D expectations against the semblance of three dimensions. It's the film equivalent of puzzling over an Escher print.

In fact, seen today, 1950s 3D doesn't look 3D at all -more like a set of 2D planes aligned in an imaginary 3D space, rather like a cardboard pop-up book. Take the forthcoming re-release of the 1953 movie Kiss Me Kate. Despite the Cole Porter songs, it's not a great musical - it is contrived and woodenly theatrical. But what's fascinating is that its theatricality goes together with a bizarre visual flatness. The film makes ample use of one of the great 3D cliches - with characters hurling gloves, dice, goblets directly at the camera - but it's the flatness, the cardboard cut-out aspect, that is really transfixing.

The opening sequence in Howard Keel's apartment is a bizarre construction of diagonals and receding surfaces. There are mirrors everywhere, fragmenting the space into as many flat planes as possible. The scene looks unnerving, almost sinister, and every inch like a stage set. It seems like the locale not for a musical but for a murder mystery. Later, when the characters take to the stage in an impressionistic mock-up of Shakespearean Padua, the two-dimensionality is even more pronounced: the set looks like a Broadway version of De Chirico.

Paradoxically, 3D cinema offers a rare chance to revel in the truly 2D. Films like Kiss Me Kate don't make things more lifelike; quite the contrary. We are in the habit of seeing people and objects on screen as if they were 3D anyway: we assume we are seeing flesh-and-blood actors rather than flat 2D shapes. Seeing a 1950s 3D film in all its awkward cut-out quality allows us to measure the difference between the cinematic illusion we habitually manufacture in our own minds and a different kind of illusion, with limitations that are all too obvious.

But 3D technology has come a long way since then. With 3D productions for the vast Imax screen, we still wear the comical glasses, but the critical distance has diminished. One of the most dazzling, most sense-engulfing spectacles I have ever seen - bigger, brasher, more kitsch than Fantasia, Gladiator, Independence Day, you name it - is the 3D Imax digital animation Cyberworld. A flashy portmanteau of computer-generated clips, Cyberworld displays a level of digital polish that makes Toy Story look homespun. A vast, futuristic space called the Galleria Animatica is the setting for various delights and horrors - sci-fi seascapes, futuristic big top extravaganzas, la Cirque du Soleil, a hideously ornate fantasia featuring the Pet Shop Boys, and (pause for breath and a welcome bit of primary-colour 2D clunkiness) the episode of The Simpsons in which Homer crosses into a 3D universe ("Man, this place looks expensive!").

Where 1950s 3D pelted us with flying cups now and then, the 21st- century variant goes much further. If crockery flew in Cyberworld, it would come in all-enveloping cyclones of intricately-traced willow-pattern china. No space is left unfilled, no surface without a fastidiously mapped texture.

It's not just in front of you but all around. Thanks to a huge screen that allows no peripheral vision outside itself, the aesthetic is one of total immersion, and the immersion is merciless, the bombardment non-stop. When you're not floating through galactic oceans, you have a million bubbles exploding in your face, a million clown-hatted bird-things with the face of Neil Tennant morphing in geometric formation.

The effect is oppressive - this seems to be a form of cinema that makes it almost impossible to react critically. And it may be no accident that Cyberworld's artists favour images of monumental architecture, like the cathedral-like vastness of the Galleria Animatica itself. There is, perhaps, an inherently totalitarian aesthetic to this form of cinema - it involves not imaginative involvement but knee-jerk submission. Perhaps bombastically inclined dictatorships in the coming century need not waste their resources on rallies or cumbersome monuments - state-of-the-art Pet Shop Boys videos may prove a much smarter investment.

 Kiss Me Kate is re-released on January 19. Cyberworld is screening at the BFI Imax, London SE1 (tel: 020-7902 1234).

fields.headline: Sammy and Rosie get laid
fields.standfirst: Dr Johnson's brothel antics leave  Lyn Gardner  unconvinced
fields.trailText: Dr Johnson's brothel antics leave Lyn Gardner unconvinced
fields.body:
Even in this season of goodwill it is hard to find much of merit in Johnson In Love, Charles Thomas's play that imagines an incident in the life of Samuel Johnson, compiler of the first English dictionary. Johnson was fabled as a man of principle and moral rectitude. But Boswell, in his biography, suggests that in his younger, poverty-stricken years and in the company of the self-styled genius, failed poet and playwright Richard Savage, Johnson was sometimes reduced to walking the street at night and may even have strayed from the path of virtue.

Thomas's speculation on what might have occurred on one such night in 1738 in Madam Meg's bawdy house provides the basis of this play, now showing at the BAC in London, in which the unhappily married Johnson is tempted by the charms of Rosie, a young girl who has fled her stepfather's advances and finds refuge at Meg's.

Meg is portrayed as a kind of bawdy, boozy, singing Mother Teresa, a tart who has such a heart that, it is implied, Rosie is still an innocent virgin despite having been in residence for some time. Rosie has a childhood sweetheart, Matthew, who has been transported to America but who has promised to send for her. When Rosie receives a letter from him that no one in the brothel can read, Johnson rides in on his white charger. But his motives are less than pure.

One of the tests of a play based on biography is whether, if you strip the protagonists of their celebrity, the drama remains of any interest at all. Here the answer is a definite no, made all the more resounding by an absurdly improbable sequence of events in which Matthew returns from America in search of Rosie and just happens to turn up in the brothel. Soon both he and Johnson are shown up as hypocrites. The whole thing is supposed to be light-hearted, but it comes across as sentimental, silly and hailing from a school of drama that doesn't just predate 1956 but quite possibly prehistoric times. There is a clunkiness about both its construction and Tim Heath's production that belies the experience of all involved. In the circumstances, it is perhaps not surprising that none of the performances rises above the mediocre.

This is the sort of show that might find an audience in an obscure church hall on the Edinburgh fringe, but in its current state really has no business to be showing its face at this address.

 Until January 14. Box office: 020-7223 2223.

fields.headline: A what made of potatoes?
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
There is always a danger that sending a comedian on a travelogue borders on "aren't foreigners funny" territory. Ah-So Graham Norton (Channel 4) managed to avoid such comedy racism, however, if only because the aspects of Japanese culture highlighted were so darned weird that Norton would have been hard-pressed to make fun of them.

There will be some who tut-tut at his gentle ribbing of his host family's shrine to their dead grandfather (and their choice of breakfast - icky sushi which looked like crème caramel with a beetle in it) as western cultural suprematism, but these people should get out more. His delighted bemusement at the cult of Hello Kitty, his meeting with the seemingly zombified beauty icon Sonoka Suzuki, and his enthusiasm for shops which sold porn DVDs alongside washing lines was genuinely enchanting and not part of some racist agenda. Regardless of where Norton is, he finds weird aspects of the local culture.

He manages it every week in a studio in London, after all, and his incredulity is borne from examining the bizarreness of the human condition, not one culture in particular. That Norton soaked his host family's bathroom with their electronic toilet and went for tea with some line-dancers as an old lady twanged her banjo in the corner of the room were hilarious added bonuses to what was an intelligent documentary which was as much about Norton as it was about Japan.

Wherever he went, Norton was confronted with bizarre sights - the most bizarre, arguably, being the friendly old lady who ran a sex shop and had a dildo made out of potatoes. Even Norton was nearly lost for words.

Mop-top toff Dan Pearson most probably won't be growing potato dildos in The Garden (BBC2). Subtitled A Year at Home Farm, this was the usual romanticised - to the point of fetishised - view of country living and the joys of owning acres of land and green welly boots. Over the course of 13 years, Pearson created a kitchen garden (the most likely site of potato dildo cultivation), a barn garden (which looked like an overgrown garden on a council estate, without the mattress and rusting engine parts) and a woodland garden (this seemed his favourite since, he enthused, it was shady and moist).

The best bit of the garden, Pearson said, was where it looked like the wood has simply encroached and spread naturally. This posed the question of why he had bothered to cultivate it at all and not simply let the woodland spread naturally. A sucker for doing things the hard way, he didn't really provide an answer. Instead, he returned to his favourite theme: shady moistness. Perhaps Pearson needs to stay in more.

Disappointingly, Bill Oddie Goes Wild (BBC2) was not about Oddie dragging up, calling himself Fifi Jordan LaBelle and delighting punters in Blackpool's gay bars with renditions of old Alison Moyet tunes. It wasn't that kind of wild (although you can see him in sequins belting out All Cried Out, can't you?). Rather, he was getting all giddy - this week in Cornwall - exploring woodland and sandy beach, estuary and hillside in search of wildlife.

Oddie met a dormouse handler - you have to have a licence, you know - who promptly undermined the whole notion of skilled, registered handlers by dropping the aforementioned dormouse. And he got crabs. In a bucket. From a rockpool. The best moment, however, was when Oddie should have been swimming with seals. Being petrified of the water, he had to be practically thrown into the sea by the crew and, once in there, he didn't so much swim as bob like a lost inflatable bed.

The seals, curious creatures that they are, first stared at this furry-faced intruder then bit chunks out of his dry suit. fields.bodyText: There is always a danger that sending a comedian on a travelogue borders on "aren't foreigners funny" territory. Ah-So Graham Norton (Channel 4) managed to avoid such comedy racism, however, if only because the aspects of Japanese culture highlighted were so darned weird that Norton would have been hard-pressed to make fun of them. There will be some who tut-tut at his gentle ribbing of his host family's shrine to their dead grandfather (and their choice of breakfast - icky sushi which looked like crème caramel with a beetle in it) as western cultural suprematism, but these people should get out more. His delighted bemusement at the cult of Hello Kitty, his meeting with the seemingly zombified beauty icon Sonoka Suzuki, and his enthusiasm for shops which sold porn DVDs alongside washing lines was genuinely enchanting and not part of some racist agenda. Regardless of where Norton is, he finds weird aspects of the local culture. He manages it every week in a studio in London, after all, and his incredulity is borne from examining the bizarreness of the human condition, not one culture in particular. That Norton soaked his host family's bathroom with their electronic toilet and went for tea with some line-dancers as an old lady twanged her banjo in the corner of the room were hilarious added bonuses to what was an intelligent documentary which was as much about Norton as it was about Japan. Wherever he went, Norton was confronted with bizarre sights - the most bizarre, arguably, being the friendly old lady who ran a sex shop and had a dildo made out of potatoes. Even Norton was nearly lost for words. Mop-top toff Dan Pearson most probably won't be growing potato dildos in The Garden (BBC2). Subtitled A Year at Home Farm, this was the usual romanticised - to the point of fetishised - view of country living and the joys of owning acres of land and green welly boots. Over the course of 13 years, Pearson created a kitchen garden (the most likely site of potato dildo cultivation), a barn garden (which looked like an overgrown garden on a council estate, without the mattress and rusting engine parts) and a woodland garden (this seemed his favourite since, he enthused, it was shady and moist). The best bit of the garden, Pearson said, was where it looked like the wood has simply encroached and spread naturally. Instead, he returned to his favourite theme: shady moistness. Perhaps Pearson needs to stay in more. It wasn't that kind of wild (although you can see him in sequins belting out All Cried Out, can't you?). fields.headline: The secret Caravaggio
fields.standfirst: Gay? Revered in his time? A heretic? About the only thing we do know about the Italian master is that he killed a man. By  Jonathan Jones
fields.trailText: Gay? Revered in his time? A heretic? About the only thing we do know about the Italian master is that he killed a man. By Jonathan Jones
fields.body:
He is wearing a pair of feathered wings, and nothing else. He grins cockily and knowingly, holding a couple of arrows in his hand - he's Cupid, after all. But there's nothing cute about Caravaggio's Victorious Cupid. Painted lifesize in a bright light that picks out his flesh harshly, he looks right at us while his penis and balls hang in full view at the centre of the picture. He's posed in what to educated contemporary viewers was a recognisable parody of Michelangelo's sculpted Victory. At his foot lie the discarded emblems of intellectual and public life - a globe, a book, armour - blown away by desire.

In the 20th century, the creator of this unsettling image - a man of violence and mental instability who was born in about 1565 in Caravaggio, near Milan, and died in shame and ignominy, a known murderer, in 1610 - leapt from obscurity and critical contempt to become probably the most popular of all the great Italian artists of the Renaissance and the Baroque. He is the one we feel is most our own, one of us. The name itself has become sexy, talismanic, namechecked in trendy academic books, such as Quoting Caravaggio or Caravaggio's Secrets. To be different, Peter Robb avoided the familiar name in his recent fictionalised biography and called his hero M, from the painter's birth name, Michelangelo Merisi.

Photographers imitate Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio's light and artists identify with his depravity. In the quiet, serious rooms of the Gemäldegalerie in Berlin, where Caravaggio's Victorious Cupid (1602) hangs, visitors are visibly embarrassed by the boy's naked display. So it's a shame that the gallery has refused to lend it to the Royal Academy's forthcoming exhibition of Baroque art, The Genius of Rome. This Cupid is the supreme embodiment of what this painter signifies today: transgressive sex. There's no doubting what the painting is about, or what the relationship was between artist and model.

Or is there? Scholars, sad to say, do doubt it. They doubt that Caravaggio was even homosexual, as is widely believed. Our only written source for this near-universal assumption, Helen Langdon points out in her spoilsport 1998 biography, is a note made by a 17th-century English visitor to Rome, Richard Symonds, after he saw the Cupid. He reported: "Twas the body and face of his owne boy or servant that laid with him." Langdon and other art historians suggest this is just tourist tittle-tattle, an unreliable bit of hearsay.

Our entire sense of Caravaggio as a modern artist is, according to historians, a fiction. We see what we want to see. It's not even true that Caravaggio was some kind of despised, marginal figure in his lifetime. On the contrary, he was the most famous artist in Rome, the founder of a new kind of sharply illuminated naturalism that influenced every one of Europe's great artists in the 17th century. Caravaggio inspired the early genre paintings of Velazquez in Spain, and the lighting effects of Dutch Golden Age painters. He was recognised as the genius of his age even when he had to flee Rome to escape a murder charge. It was after his death that the critical backlash began; his art was condemned as wild, uncontrolled, gauchely disobedient to the rules of classicism. By the 18th century his influence was downplayed and his low, realist painting was disparaged as an insignificant chapter in the history of art.

Obviously, the Victorians were not the people to reclaim this degenerate artist. It was only with an exhibition of Baroque art in Florence in 1922 that he began to come out of the shadows. As late as the 1950s Ernst Gombrich's The Story of Art treated Caravaggio as a minor figure.

The trouble with our excitement about Caravaggio is that seeing him as modern means ignoring what is so powerful in his art. Peter Robb's M tries to expose some kind of anti-Church radicalism in Caravaggio, but nothing could be further from the truth. You only have to visit some of the churches in Rome where his altarpieces hang to see what Caravaggio's naturalist art, with its use of street people as models, did. It was a weapon of the Counter-Reformation. Caravaggio found a new, more direct way of telling religious stories: he cast urchins and old men off the Roman streets as saints and angels, and he painted martyrdoms as if they were happening here and now.

In the church of Santa Maria del Popolo the founder of the Catholic Church is being executed. St Peter - a man aged and gnarled by labour, taken from an inn in some back alley to have his painting done - has already been nailed to the cross. He looks in fury at the nail holding his left hand in place. But the three younger men in the picture are subjecting him to a final ignominy. They are raising him by the legs, to crucify him upside down. It's hard, ungrateful work. You almost feel sorry for them. These are not the grotesques who crucify Christ in a painting by Bosch. They're ordinary working stiffs, doing their job.

This is who Caravaggio's painting is addressed to: the ordinary people of Rome. You too are part of the story, says Caravaggio - you too have moral choices to make. Will you do good or evil?

Yet there are problems with the view of Caravaggio as an orthodox Catholic artist. If that was the case, why were so many of his religious paintings - about half - rejected by the people who commissioned them? Modern viewers may go too far in dwelling on the sensual, near-nude angel in the foreground of The Rest on the Flight into Egypt (c 1595) - but the angel's sexy presence is an incongruously prominent feature of the painting. And how do you account for all those boys brandishing fruit or wine in a way that seems also to be an offer of sex?

You can't ignore this invitation in Boy with a Basket of Fruit (c1593-4), coming to the RA from Rome's Galleria Borghese. Soft and hedonistic, the boy's face looks at us lingeringly, provocatively, and there is no missing the message that he too is a fruit for us to pick. Art historians may argue that Baroque art was driven by patronage, and that Caravaggio's patrons were men of piety, powerful clerics - but it's hard to talk away the eroticism of a painting like this.

Perhaps Caravaggio's patrons, like him, led double lives. And perhaps the originality of his art is to acknowledge that doubleness, and to unite the two lives - to find the sacred in the profane and the profane in the sacred.

So was Caravaggio both things, the good Catholic and the sexual adventurer ? Or was he a psychopath, as he has been portrayed?

We know very little about Caravaggio, but we do know he was very violent. He had duels and participated in street fights almost constantly; he was the kind of man who would run up behind someone who had annoyed him and hit him on the head with his sword. His friends were always restraining him from doing worse and it didn't surprise anyone in Rome when he finally killed a man and fled the city.

Perhaps the insoluble contradictions of Caravaggio's art are not profound at all but the work of a heartless stylist, a monster able to make sex and religion equally seductive. Yet this cannot be so, because his paintings burn with emotion, with compassion. The street people who pose in his paintings live for ever, and he intended it that way. If he was quick to anger, his art is quick to love.

Caravaggio's lifestyle may never theless be the key to his art, the fact that it does not just veer from the holy to the unholy but explores both with unparalleled intensity. Caravaggio seems to have been addicted to danger; a friend diagnosed this as an excess of courage. It was as if he sought out instability, crisis, moments of risk. This is exactly the quality that all his paintings share - risk. His paintings are alive today because each staged tableau has a sense that it is about to break apart at any second. The men playing disciples are about to start fighting; the boy with the fruit is about to call the painter an old lech and run off; the painter is about to leap on Cupid. These paintings push painting to an edge where it is becoming life, is ending as art.

Caravaggio looks like our contemporary because his scenes are so mesmerically poised in time, dramatising moments of choice and decision in which we ourselves are implicated. Will you accept the boy's offer of fruit? Will you just stand there watching St Peter being crucified upside down, or will you do something about it? These scenes transfix us as they transfixed their original viewers. And we will always walk away from the Victorious Cupid embarrassed and confused, a little relieved to be back among the nativity scenes and landscapes by other Old Masters, which don't have us blushing and wondering where to put our eyes.

 The Genius of Rome 1592-1623 is at the Royal Academy, London W1 (020-7300 8000), from January 20 until April 16.

webTitle: A double dose of magical misery

fields.headline: A double dose of magical misery
fields.trailText: A week in radio
fields.body:
If you are saving yourself for the Archers omnibus tomorrow to discover the fate of Brookfield farm, stop reading now. (But I do have to say that if you have ever doubted that David and Ruth would end up keeping the farm, you might not want to give up the day job just yet.)

Yes, Brookfield stays in their capable hands. What swayed Phil Archer's aching heart was not fiscal good sense, or the emotional pull of his other children wanting their share of the inheritance. Nope, it was seeing "just how committed David is to Brookfield". I think what he meant was that David couldn't walk away from the place even if he wanted to. David agreed. "I love this place, I live and breathe this farm," he said, with a blood-vessel-bursting urgency to his voice. Well, you would too if you were speaking from beneath a big heifer (no, not Ruth) who was crushing your ribs.

In the 50th anniversary episode of The Archers (Radio 4), the world's longest running radio drama, David was missing after a filthy row with Phil. That featured during the previous night's quite superbly miserable double-length episode. It featured family fall-outs to rival Walford's best.

In a mad moment, David and Ruth threatened to move to France (perhaps not the most obvious relocation option for beef farmers just now), and Kate worried that her daughter Phoebe no longer knows who she is. She showered her with "African presents", though not the really sizeable one she's carried from Cape Town: a lovechild she is having with a man called Lucas.

"Is he black?" worried Brian, sounding a bit like David under the heifer. But Kate has far more important questions on her mind. "And when did she become Pheebs?" she wailed (quite rightly on grounds of taste, even if it's off the flipping-cheek scale of maternal behaviour after a year's absence) to Roy and Hayley.

When David and Ruth's good news came ("Aw Dee-vidd," cooed Ruth), even Elizabeth joined in, though through clenched teeth. "The future," she hissed, maybe thinking about spending it with Nigel, the poshest and most asexual man in the world, who owns a horse called Kaiser and has a lovely turn of phrase. He says things like "We've both been working like stink" and nobody laughs or punches him.

But then this is Ambridge, that magical world where a son gets to keep the family farm by getting stuck under the tum of a mooing bone-crushing beast (no, not Lynda Snell) and loving it. It is moments like these that so lend themselves to affectionate send-up.

Dead Ringers and The Archers (Radio 4) did this to devastating effect in an anniversary special. We had a fake Chris Eubanks trying to get cast on the show (the producer gives him a telephone audition: "Be a horny-handed son of the soil!"), yards and yards of Jo Grundy's grumble, and a romantic fiction encounter between Jo and Ann Widdecombe ("Harvest my crop of sugar beet!"). Best was Ruth Archer Reacts to Bad News ("Orh Norh"), available as part of the BBC's audio collection apparently. Can it be long before Jill Archer joins in with her double A-side: "One Egg or Two Phil?" and "I was making a batch anyway"?

fields.headline: Fact and fury
fields.standfirst: The TV drama Rebel Heart has provoked unionist ire because it was written by a republican. But, says  Seamus Deane, it is not political conviction that is the problem, but the lack of it
fields.trailText: The TV drama Rebel Heart has provoked unionist ire because it was written by a republican. But, says Seamus Deane, it is not political conviction that is the problem, but the lack of it
fields.body:
The opening credits have not yet rolled on the four-part BBC drama Rebel Heart and already it has become embroiled in the requisite row over any dramatic portrayal of Irish history.

What differentiates Rebel Heart from any previous television account of the Irish Troubles of 1916-22 is the fact that it gives prominence to the north of Ireland, and especially to the plight of the Catholic minority left stranded within the new, militantly Protestant statelet established by the Anglo-Irish Treaty of 1921. Any treatment of the violent origins of Northern Ireland and, above all, any reminder of the murderous activities of the RUC and their paramilitary allies during those initial years is bound to rouse the ire of unionists, who are presently attempting to ensure that the Patten Report on the RUC is not implemented in full. For were it to be so implemented, then they might be faced with the appalling prospect of having the activities of the RUC over the past 30 years or so impartially investigated.

Several attempts to investigate the RUC's activities since 1969-70 have been aborted; the removal of John Stalker just before the completion of his inquiry, begun in 1984, is the most blatant and notorious of the so far successful campaigns to keep the truth hidden. This is a police force that cannot bear investigation and believes it will always have the political support to keep that spectre at bay.

The reports I have read about Rebel Heart are really about the RUC and Patten, and the unionist anxiety to disguise a long, criminal history of violence, systematic discrimination, and the abuse of law. In addition, they seem to claim (but it is hard to be sure about this, since the commentary is somewhat incoherent) that the writer Ronan Bennett should not have been commissioned to write this drama series since he is known to be a republican, known to dislike or distrust the RUC, and must therefore be understood to be biased.

At this point, the old questions about artistic representation and political partisanship have to be raised. Are Sean O'Casey's "Irish" plays to be dismissed because of their anti-republican bias? Or his socialist plays to be dismissed because of their failure to acknowledge the violence of the Soviet system? If such questions can legitimately be asked, it is difficult to know how the answers to them would avoid promoting censorship. Perhaps the ideal writer should be someone who always believes there is much to be said on both sides, and that such "balance" is the mark of impartiality or of being free of ideology.

Slavoj Zizek reminds us that a basic procedure of Bertolt Brecht in his "learning plays" of the early 30s was to have actors pronounce an "impossible" commentary on their own acts. So one actor announces: "I am a capitalist whose aim is to exploit workers. Now I will try to convince one of my workers of the truth of the bourgeois ideology which legitimises the exploitation." And then he goes up to another actor and does just that. Perhaps that is what all writers should do. It would make writing impossible, but it would at least help hidden ideologies to overcome their shyness.

Otherwise, the dispute would seem to be a battle of atrocities. If Bennett wants to shift by three years the date of the massacre of the McMahon family by the police for the sake of a dramatic effect, does that seriously misrepresent the RUC or the unionist position? That massacre stands for many; it is both specific and representative, in its actual and in its premonitory violence towards the Catholic minority.

Nor can it be said to be an extreme or melodramatic instance of state terror in the land of the B-Specials (later the UDR, then the RIR); the Special Powers Act (envied by white South Africans for its comprehensive demolition of civil rights), which remained in force from 1923-73, and was then replaced by the Emergency Provisions Act; not to mention the alphabet soup of the Protestant paramilitary organisations with which the police so often colluded.

Bennett's emphasis here is on the nature of the state against which the IRA launched its campaign, although there was no IRA when the present killings, initiated by the RUC, began in 1969 in the aftermath of the demand for civil rights. To distrust or dislike the RUC is a perfectly reasonable position, especially for a Catholic, nationalist or republican, in Northern Ireland.

The Daily Telegraph, in its leader article of December 1 2000, describes Bennett as "a biased republican writer", and unblushingly describes Paul Bew, Peter Hart and Liam Kennedy as "non-unionist" scholars. It has none of the directorial drive of Neil Jordan's Michael Collins; it simply enlists a series of incidents to represent a particular reading of the events of those years. Socialism disappears into nationalism; nationalism disappears into capitalism; the Republic disappears into the future, and the North becomes the "carnival of reaction" that James Connolly predicted.

The cast seem to act under an invisible restraint. It is not so much the dialogue, although that can be pretty arthritic at times, as their physical presence that seems to be reluctant. The love scenes are rather painful to watch in this regard. Instead of a tentative delicacy, there is embarrassment. The stereotypes of class and of gender are so potent that there is no opportunity for nuanced development for any one of the individuals.

The series lacks political conviction of the most basic kind. As the Dublin middle-class nationalist-republican hero, Ernie Coyne, and his former working-class Citizen Army friend O'Toole die at one another's hands in the first battle of the civil war, the effect is not really quite so tragic or ironic as it would seem to offer itself as being. Bennett or his director, John Strickland, or both of them, seem to transmit to the narrative and to the cast a scepticism about the political world that runs athwart the aim of the series.

It is difficult to say why this should be so. I'll hazard a guess, but it can be no more than that. Almost all drama and much fiction about the Irish political situation, and especially about the northern situation, has structured itself around the narrative of a collision between the private and the public life that turns out to be catastrophic. Inevitably, whether it is the lovers or the political leaders who take our attention, the analysis almost always finishes by saying that some of the most intimate and treasurable features of human existence simply cannot be accommodated politically. This inevitably assigns politics to the bigots and fanatics, and the private world to the emotionally wounded or the sensitive. That is a long inheritance in Irish writing; it is part of a long inheritance in Irish politics. The division is in part produced by violence; violence will not be replaced by peace, it will be replaced by justice. It is the wish for that, but the belief that it is not to be had, that constitutes Ronan Bennett's bias and that troubles this series.

fields.headline: Honest truth about lottery films
fields.standfirst: Unpopular films have brought British funding and film-making into disrepute.  Andrew Pulver  looks for a way forward
fields.trailText: Unpopular films have brought British funding and film-making into disrepute. Andrew Pulver looks for a way forward
fields.body:
The British film industry is under attack again. Alexander Walker, film critic of the London Evening Standard, has identified 13 films, made with the assistance of national lottery funding, that have under-performed at the British box-office. British film-making, he argues, needs to become more commercial to ensure a return on the public money invested in individual projects. But is that the answer?

In 2000 Britain's film-makers abruptly lost the goodwill and enthusiasm that had sustained them through the latter half of the 90s. Large sums of public money seemed to have been frittered away, Britain's film-making community became increasingly frightened and defensive, and, most crucially, the jump in British film production and cinema audiences coincided with depressing individual box-office figures and undeniable aesthetic debacles.

The new British film industry has not always been mired in such self-doubt. The current mood dates roughly from the release of the embarrassing All Saints movie Honest in May of last year, which suffered the indignity of being yanked from cinemas three days into its run and was greeted with derision from all sides. Until then, following the unexpected international success of Four Weddings and a Funeral in the spring of 1994, a mood of flag-waving we-can-do-it-too infectiousness had taken Britain's film-makers by storm. British production starts jumped - the total of 128 for 1996 was the first time since 1972 that the figure had broken the century mark - and further successes such as Trainspotting and The Full Monty greased the wheels of the industry. Britain puffed up its chest, rolled up its sleeves, and fed reel after reel of celluloid through its camera magazines. Sadly, most of it has proved commercially or aesthetically worthless; quite a lot of it was both.

Walker calls for the chill wind of market reality to blow through the industry, but would that really cure the patient? Of course not. The world's most successful film industry - in the US - exists on the basis of a self-sustaining audience, where box-office figures can routinely match production spend. The British film audience isn't big enough to allow a commercial operation to stand alone.

The only way big-budget British films could recoup their investment would be to sell to international markets, especially the US, but that would not square with Walker's idea of British films for British audiences. When it comes to British cinema, the US is happiest with what Alan Parker memorably called "Laura Ashley film-making".

Just as market forces offer no solution, so sheltering the talent-free behind a wall of public funding is equally dangerous. It is staggering that some of the films castigated by Walker ever got made, let alone made with public money.

There is no denying that British cinema is at a crossroads. But it is a crossroads with no signposts. Having unlocked the funding bonanza, the public agencies are continuing to tinker with the methods by which money filters through. The recently established British Film Council is the latest attempt to professionalise the government's grant-giving. But no one appears confident about what to do with it.

Subsidy contains inherent dangers. It is a truism that staying independent makes for greater creativity, as the committee-generated sludge of the past few years proves. One solution after another - distribution, script development, the cinemas themselves - has been proposed, fiddled with, and proved generally fruitless.

Yet it also remains true that people want to see British films. Give audiences a chance to get behind something and they will. The one constant feature of British cinema in the 1990s was the emergence of an annual in-from-nowhere, entirely unforeseen hit. The Full Monty, Lock Stock, Trainspotting, East is East, Billy Elliot - all by relative tyros, and in retrospect completely unplannable.

These are films whose popular success puts them beyond criticism. Less dramatic, but perhaps more significant, is the Scottish film Ratcatcher, part funded by the lottery, and named in Walker's rollcall of shame. Despite miserable box-office, Ratcatcher is an aesthetic and critical success, and something of a cause célèbre for those who yearn for authentic British art cinema. The principle of cultural defence through subsidy is also well-established, especially in Europe, but in Britain the issue is more complex: language is not a barrier, so audiences and film-makers can slip backwards and forwards from Hollywood.

Isn't high cultural aspiration what publicly funded British film-making should be about? Well, yes and no. If subsidised film-making - of which Ratcatcher is a lonely, if shining example - is designed to complement a commercial sector, then the agencies would appear to be going about their task in a reasonably astute manner. But the film to which Ratcatcher is most often compared - Terence Davies's Distant Voices, Still Lives - was an equally lonely example of subsidised film-making in the pre-lottery era, when different subsidies attempted to prop up an even sicklier industry. Little has changed: successful art movies operate independently of organised funding structures, and take little account of which body is dishing out the cash.

No one sets out to make a useless movie and anticipating the whims of the audience is a thankless task. But anticipate them a producer must, and where should one look for inspiration? The best English-language movies are produced in the US independent sector, itself a much-disputed definition: films such as Rushmore, Happiness, Your Friends and Neighbors, Deconstructing Harry, Flirting with Disaster, The Ice Storm, American Psycho and The Big Lebowski. (Ironically, the last was produced by a British company, and the penultimate by a British director). These films - intelligent, adult and in English - are the targets and models of any self-respecting film-makers, whatever their commercial viability.

Further evidence of our own film-making timidity are foreign films that really ought to be British. Take The Limey, directed by Steven Soderbergh - a complex, astute homage to British 60s cinema. Would it ever have got off the ground if a British director had had the idea?

The American independent system can't be replicated in Britain - it depends on an unholy alliance with its corporate Hollywood enemy. In the end, film-making is about individuals. The best film-makers succeed because they have the drive and ambition to succeed. This applies most obviously to visionary directors - the Coens, Abbas Kiarostami, Ang Lee, Terence Davies - but to producers, too. There is a clutch of production talent in Britain, but much that is pedestrian. Sadly, at the moment funding bodies seem unable to sort out one from the other.

Perhaps we should be more realistic about what can be achieved. Further commercialising the subsidised film sector won't work - civil servants can't, and shouldn't, run film studios. Halting subsidies altogether would be a cultural disaster, worse even than the one taking place already. Instead, the Film Council and other grant-aided outfits ought to be seen as training programmes - massaging future talent into existence. Those talents can then be picked up by commercial operations, either in the UK or US, to create properly commercial products. If, on the other hand, we want auteurs, that may take a little longer.

fields.headline: South Yorkshire
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
The kingfisher sits motionless on the overhanging branch of a small tree, hunched forward, eyes staring intently through the water that laps beneath it.

A flap of wings, a low-angled dive forward, a splash, then a flurry of wing beats as the bird forces its way up from the clinging water, a small fish clamped in its bill. Once back in the tree, there follows a pantomime of head jerks and beating of the fish's head against the trunk, looking rather like Mr Punch attacking the crocodile. Then a clumsy flip of the head, tilted backwards, and the fish disappears head first down the kingfisher's throat. Having swallowed its prey and presumably deciding that its successful lunge into the water had scattered any other fish that might be around, the kingfisher flies fast and low across the open water to the far shore.

We are at Denaby Ings, a Yorkshire Wildlife Trust nature reserve. In this part of the county, "ings" is used to describe shallow standing water in depressions created by mining subsidence. It is claimed by many as a peculiarly Yorkshire word, and there are many ings in South and West Yorkshire, an area riddled with underground mine workings and consequent subsidence.

Denaby Ings is actually a backwater of the River Dearne. Its shallow water is a magnet for wintering wildfowl, but only until the first freeze. Then most of the birds leave to seek warmer, deeper water, and rarely return that winter. Once the big freeze took place just after Christmas, the water emptied. Now we are favoured by a handful of tufted duck, teal and a couple of pochard. Mallard are present, but the most obvious bird on the water are gooseanders.

Now two groups, each of eight or 10 birds, are tacking across the open water, seemingly manoeuvring against each other. When a particular course brings the groups together, altercations occur, with much splashing and lunging, until, quite quickly, the two sides rear away from each other, only to meet up again later, as each flotilla patrols what it sees as its own territory.

fields.headline: Suits you: Made to measure
fields.trailText: Flash Gordon got by with a singlet and hose; even the original Dan Dare was able to venture into space wearing nothing but an air-force uniform, albeit the full-dress version with cap and tie. Those were happy, carefree days, when every alien planet had its full quota of oxygen, and no designer in his right mind was going to let a little thing like zero gravity weigh him down.
fields.body:
Flash Gordon got by with a singlet and hose; even the original Dan Dare was able to venture into space wearing nothing but an air-force uniform, albeit the full-dress version with cap and tie. Those were happy, carefree days, when every alien planet had its full quota of oxygen, and no designer in his right mind was going to let a little thing like zero gravity weigh him down.

But the inescapable truth is that anyone venturing more than 63,000ft from the earth's surface had better be wearing a fully sealed and pressurised space suit. Without it, their body fluids will simply boil away - which is going to leave some awful stains.

And a space suit does more than keep the body pressurised. It enshrouds the wearer in a breathable atmosphere - 100% oxygen in the case of today's astronauts - and provides protection against micro-meteoroids, ultra-violet radiation and temperature extremes (orbiting the earth, you can expect 250F on the side of your body facing the sun and -250F on your dark side).

Early suits, such as those used in the Mercury programme in the early 60s, were little more than beefed-up versions of the pressure-suits worn by US navy pilots. But as missions became more ambitious and astronauts were called upon to leave the confines of their spacecraft, suits were required to provide the wearer with total protection, while at the same time allowing complete freedom of movement.

It is because of the need to combine strength with flexibility that a description of a modern space suit reads like the synopsis of a sci-fi movie, with names such as Kevlar, Teflon and Dacron appearing at every turn. Even the comfy zipper jackets, slippers and sleep shorts worn inside the space shuttle are made from hi-tech, flame-retardant fabrics. But the minute an astronaut steps into the airlock, they are looking at a whole new wardrobe.

The current extravehicular mobility unit (EMU) is built to a modular design with interchangeable, re-usable parts, which means that men and women of different sizes can be equipped without the need for entire suits to be custom-built, as was once the case. Each suit is reckoned to last a minimum of eight years and is made out of several layers, at the heart of which lies a polyurethane-coated nylon pressure bladder.

A complete EMU includes a one-piece, spandex garment that is veined with water-filled cooling tubes and conveniently zippered for front entry. Then there's a cap containing communications equipment, a biomedical instrumentation subsystem to transmit readings back to surgeons on earth, and an in-suit drink bag filled with 21 ounces of water.

Yes, it's okay to drink in space, since the suit incorporates a urine-collection device that stores liquid for transfer to the orbiter waste management system.

The largest size of the entire ensemble weighs 107lb, and that includes not only the helmet and visor, but also an essential gadget for removing odours from the suit's atmosphere. Not the sort of problem Flash Gordon had to contend with, of course.

fields.bodyText: Flash Gordon got by with a singlet and hose; even the original Dan Dare was able to venture into space wearing nothing but an air-force uniform, albeit the full-dress version with cap and tie. Those were happy, carefree days, when every alien planet had its full quota of oxygen, and no designer in his right mind was going to let a little thing like zero gravity weigh him down. But the inescapable truth is that anyone venturing more than 63,000ft from the earth's surface had better be wearing a fully sealed and pressurised space suit. Without it, their body fluids will simply boil away - which is going to leave some awful stains. And a space suit does more than keep the body pressurised. It enshrouds the wearer in a breathable atmosphere - 100% oxygen in the case of today's astronauts - and provides protection against micro-meteoroids, ultra-violet radiation and temperature extremes (orbiting the earth, you can expect 250F on the side of your body facing the sun and -250F on your dark side). Early suits, such as those used in the Mercury programme in the early 60s, were little more than beefed-up versions of the pressure-suits worn by US navy pilots. But as missions became more ambitious and astronauts were called upon to leave the confines of their spacecraft, suits were required to provide the wearer with total protection, while at the same time allowing complete freedom of movement. It is because of the need to combine strength with flexibility that a description of a modern space suit reads like the synopsis of a sci-fi movie, with names such as Kevlar, Teflon and Dacron appearing at every turn. Even the comfy zipper jackets, slippers and sleep shorts worn inside the space shuttle are made from hi-tech, flame-retardant fabrics. But the minute an astronaut steps into the airlock, they are looking at a whole new wardrobe. The current extravehicular mobility unit (EMU) is built to a modular design with interchangeable, re-usable parts, which means that men and women of different sizes can be equipped without the need for entire suits to be custom-built, as was once the case. Each suit is reckoned to last a minimum of eight years and is made out of several layers, at the heart of which lies a polyurethane-coated nylon pressure bladder. A complete EMU includes a one-piece, spandex garment that is veined with water-filled cooling tubes and conveniently zippered for front entry.
