fields.headline: Labour of love
fields.standfirst: Isobel Montgomery on slow burner, Shifts plus A Sweetheart Deal, The Funeral Party and Under The Skin
fields.trailText: Isobel Montgomery on slow burner, Shifts plus A Sweetheart Deal, The Funeral Party and Under The Skin
fields.body:
Shifts
Adam Thorpe
(Vintage, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Although Bins, the first monologue in this collection of a dozen stories, sets off with a winsome nostalgia that brings Alan Bennett uncomfortably to mind, Thorpe's "talking heads" form a collection that swoops between present and past, Britain, Europe and west Africa without a shade of parochialism. The title story tells of a Ghanaian immigrant's experience of London; "Debauchery" of an American in Paris in search of authenticity. The common theme is that of work and identity: the struggle to keep person and position apart, or the way the two merge into one, is the common theme. Thorpe controls well the cadences and impressions of his disparate characters: the voices flow but never meander sluggishly.

A Sweetheart Deal
Ben Richards
(Review, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

On the back cover, Richards leans out from the balcony of a redbrick council block. It is just the kind of place in which one of his Londoners might live: not fashionable but with plenty of hard edges softened by bohemian possibility and affordable rents. Perhaps it is where Mel Holloway lives? She is a union organiser who has fond memories of the GLC but keeps out of the factional fighting between the modernisers and diehards. A lab technician, scape-goated after a blood mismatch leaves a train accident victim dead, draws Mel to the man's widow and to bleak thoughts about work, home and love. Richards, with three London novels behind him, writes with a political bite that newcomers to the genre lack.

The Funeral Party
Ludmilla Ulitskaya
(Indigo, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Alik has spent years in America, yet never quite managed to leave Russia behind him. As his friends - fellow émigrés, Russian Jews and dreamers - gather around his bed during a stifling New York summer to watch over his death, they learn to let go both of Alik and the Russia of their pasts. The first of Ulitskaya's novels to be translated into English, this is a sentimental, overly emotional, black-bread-and-vodka work, but is also opulently lyrical. Irina, Alik's first love, seems almost to have pushed her Russianness away, while his wife, Nina, carries with her always an illogical Slavic mysticism. Only Alik seems to have made peace with his upbringing. Ulitskaya's theme is resonant, though some readers may find her unalloyed "Russian soul" cloying.

Under The Skin<BR. Michel Faber
(Canongate, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

This is a horrific and haunting book, whose images - some repulsive, some shamelessly beautiful - will stay with you forever. Isserley drives along the A9 in the north of Scotland, on the look-out for hitchhikers. They must be men, well-muscled and alone. She picks them up in a little red Toyota and sets off in whatever direction they want to go. The men revolt her, but afford her the happiness of walking the firth and communing with the sheep. Her passengers, meanwhile, find Isserley odd: strange face and odd accent, but an unbelievable pair of tits. Faber's dystopia is, in places, predictable, but its message is conveyed with compelling originality.

fields.headline: Salvation Army Lonely Heart's Club Band
fields.trailText: John Dugdale on Blood and Fire, by Roy Hattersley and The Longest Cocktail Party, by Richard DiLello
fields.body:
Blood and Fire
Roy Hattersley
(Abacus, 9.99)
Buy it at BOL

Hattersley's double biography of the Salvation Army's founders is itself a salvation mission, designed to rescue William and Catherine Booth from oblivion and install them in the "pantheon of great Victorians". This entails saving them from themselves, celebrating the secular, New Labour-like achievements - combating poverty, empowering women - that they regarded as secondary to converting sinners and defeating the Devil. Though perhaps over-long at 470 pages, Blood and Fire is elegantly written and its tone is finely poised, combining amazed admiration for the Booths' guts and energy with a wry willingness to document their foibles.

The Longest Cocktail Party
Richard DiLello
(Mojo, £9.99)

The story of the Beatles' Apple company, seen from 1968 to 1970 through the eyes of a young American dogsbody who watches a daily circus of stoned freeloaders and rock wannabes parade through the press office. The Fab Four are rarely glimpsed as DiLello sticks to what he directly experiences, offering no insight into the growing tension between Lennon and McCartney. So although his vivid reissued journal is billed as "an insider's diary", it views the band's disintegration with the same excluded bafflement with which Stoppard's Rosencrantz and Guildenstern follow the plots of the Danish court.

fields.headline: Reading between enemy lines
fields.standfirst: Ex-SAS man  Andy McNab debriefs Peter Kingston on Operation Bestseller
fields.trailText: Ex-SAS man Andy McNab debriefs Peter Kingston on Operation Bestseller
fields.body:
Andy McNab left school with no qualifications, he doesn't read books, and yet any week now a cash register somewhere will ring up the four millionth UK sale for one of his own books. The literary career of this ex-SAS soldier is truly phenomenal. Crisis Four has shifted nearly 350,000 copies since going into paperback. Firewall, his third and latest thriller, has already shifted 150,000 hardback copies since its publication in October.

His autobiography, Immediate Action, has stormed through the million barrier too. And the book that launched this extraordinarily successful writing streak in 1993, Bravo Two Zero, has sold 1.5m copies in this country alone. Its author shakes his head in happy disbelief. "It's a fantastic life," he exclaims with an engaging shrug. "It was the right time, and luck."

The right time was the aftermath of the Gulf war. (Just as importantly for SAS scribblers, the Iranian embassy siege in London 10 years earlier had brought the regiment to wide public attention.) Three years after the Gulf war, McNab - like Nick Stone, hero of his thrillers - was leaving the Army to take up a job in private security: a popular move, he says, for special-forces members hitting their mid-30s. But first he and the four other survivors of the abortive Bravo Two Zero mission behind enemy lines in the Gulf were invited to a Christmas dinner by General Sir Peter de la Billière, senior British commander in the coalition forces, who was toying with writing a book about the eight-man patrol.

"I thought I'd rather try to do it myself," McNab recalls. He rang John Nichol, the RAF navigator whose book, Tornado Down, about being shot down by an Iraqi missile, had recently been published. "I asked him: 'How do you do this book business?'"

Nichol put him in touch with an agent, Mark Lucas. McNab began writing a proposal. "It was in the third person and it was crap," he remembers. He then tried rewriting it in the first person, after being advised: "Just do it as if you were talking to somebody in a pub."

In fact, he found the first book easier than expected. "Because of the debriefing system and the number of presentations I'd done in the army, I knew the story, even three years later. What I didn't know about was texture. Mark Lucas kept on saying: 'What about the taste, the smell? How did those wet trousers feel?'"

Apart from a taste for medieval history, acquired during the 1980s to help him argue with a comrade who had become a born-again Christian, McNab readily confesses that he does not read books. He left school at 15 to deliver coal in Brixton. The army educated him. He joined the Junior Leaders regiment at 16 and was immediately plonked in a classroom for six months to catch up on the three Rs.

Lucas shrewdly decided that his protégé would do two non-fiction books first to establish a readership - and it worked. Nearly half his readers are women, which surprises and delights McNab. SAS mania peaked in the second half of the 1990s, and the mass readership moved on. But McNab wasn't left behind: he had already prepared the ground for his thrillers.

He is now contracted to write five novels about Nick Stone, an ex-SAS freelance operator hired to carry out deniable operations for British intelligence - the sort of life McNab says he might have led himself if the writing hadn't intervened. The five are to be made into films, and he has spent the last year in Los Angeles learning how to be a producer.

His creative process sounds complex. First he comes up with a selection of plots for Lucas. "I present 100 to 130 storylines, sentences and bullet points." And to grab the vital American market, there must be a strong US element, which is one reason why Lucas rejected McNab's first suggestion for a Bosnian setting. "The Americans aren't too sure where that is."

He typically ends up with a storyline of about 15 pages, usually in bullet points on his laptop. He then starts filling in the scenes around them. (His chief influence, he explains, was not books but the film and TV he watched as a child - from Jackanory and Thunderbirds onwards - which taught him to visualise scenes.)

Once the scenes are in his head, he "talks" them into a tape recorder and transcribes what emerges. The result is a template of about 250 pages, which is then remodelled into about 40 chapter-length chunks.

He tries to start his day with a run and workout before getting down to five or six hours at the keyboard. Currently he prefers lying flat out on a sofa with the laptop propped on a cushion on his stomach.

His rarest gift is authenticity. Everything he writes about - from picking a lock, to climbing a wall, to firing a gun in anger - he has done himself. "K", the deniable operations unit that Stone works and kills for, is based on reality, he says. "All governments have them."

Isn't that disturbing? "Why?" he demands. "It's the way that western culture is. Everybody wants democracy and freedom. Actually, initially it had to be fought for, and it still has to be fought for. So, these things go on."

Although the Ministry of Defence has criticised the genre in public, McNab insists that everything he has written has been submitted for vetting, amended if necessary and then cleared. He says he has never been critical of the military high command in his books, but he does not contradict the accusations in another insider's account of the Iraq mission - Mike Coburn's forthcoming Soldier 5, which recently fought off a legal challenge from the MoD in New Zealand. "The fact is," McNab explains, "that you are paid to do a job and there's a war on. These things happen and that's it."

webTitle: Review: Mr Phillips, by John Lanchester

fields.headline: Hidden virtues?
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard doubts himself when confronted with Mr Phillips, by John Lanchester
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard doubts himself when confronted with Mr Phillips, by John Lanchester
fields.body:
Mr Phillips
John Lanchester
(Faber, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

I had my reservations about this one. Lanchester's previous and first novel, The Debt to Pleasure, I had left mostly unread; there was too much of an odour of Nabokov coming off the book. Still, reviewers loved it, and it won more prizes than I have space to mention. Now this novel is about its eponymous hero's thoughts and feelings as he wanders around London during the course of a single day. Mr Phillips is a reasonably kind-hearted, randy nonentity. What does that remind you of?

If nothing else, one could be impressed by Lanchester's sheer cheek. Lanchester, an intelligent and trustworthy critic himself, cannot be unaware of the possibility of comparison. What on earth could he have been thinking of, apart from, "I know - I'll write a book that isn't as good as Ulysses "?

Still, many critics, including our own, loved this book to bits as well. Adam Phillips, whose opinions on such matters I used to revere, said it was "exceptionally funny"; Allan Massie said its "comedy" was "rich and humane", which is at least a more honestly decipherable way of saying "the kind of comedy which does not actually make you laugh".

I should point out that there may well be something wrong with me that prevents me from finding it as hilarious as everyone else seems to. (I did laugh out loud on page 168.) There are people for whom The Diary of a Nobody is not a comedy but a heartrending, Chekhovian tragedy, a book that cannot be read without hyperventilating with painful compassion; I'm one of them. And this might be the case here. I suggest that you go to a shop and read a couple of its pages of flat, busted English (the prose is almost a textbook example of style indirecte libre), and if you like them, then buy the book: it's like that all the way through.

This doesn't look very much like a recommendation. But while one may be suspicious of the novelist's attitude towards his hero (look at me being even-handed yet at the same time movingly generous about an ordinary person!), I, for my part, am suspicious of my own suspicion. It is the kind of book that may turn out to be very good after all, but whose qualities are only revealed after days, weeks, or even years of thinking about it.

So I may well be missing something here. It reads as if it took about two weeks to write; three, if we include some research on double-entry book-keeping to give Mr Phillips's past as an accountant some plausibility. But that doesn't stop the book from being charming, and, despite its occasionally cowardly attitude to mundanity (Mr Phillips's day is not nearly as ordinary as Bloom's), it does it well nevertheless. This is a winning ending to one chapter: "As Mr Phillips nears the Houses of Parliament he sees a nice little park across the road. For a moment he wonders if this is where politicians are always being interviewed for the telly, then he realizes it isn't."

fields.headline: Distant intimacy
fields.standfirst: Matt Seaton meets Frank Huyler, author of The Blood Of Strangers, and asks what a nice guy like him is doing in the madhouse that is a modern emergency room
fields.trailText: Matt Seaton meets Frank Huyler, author of The Blood Of Strangers, and asks what a nice guy like him is doing in the madhouse that is a modern emergency room. Plus, read an extract from the book
fields.body:
"The emergency room is a very strange, surreal place at times," says Frank Huyler. "You have these very intense moments where you're asking these very personal questions of people who are strangers to you, who often don't know your name and won't remember you, either. There's a facelessness on both sides, and yet you're propelled into moments where you discuss issues that you never would in another world. There is a kind of 'distant intimacy'."

These moments are what Huyler captures in the stories contained in The Blood Of Strangers. Often very short, the individual stories sometimes appear as Weegie-like snapshots of the crash victims, Aids patients, cardiac arrestees and fellow physicians who come through the ER.

Billed, by his British publisher at least, as "true stories", the collection, in fact, has much more the quality of literary fiction - the writing is pared down and precise. The Doctor's Stories of William Carlos Williams was, Huyler says, his closest model, but the flavour of these, in their clinical detachment, is almost Carver-esque. They are not literal truth, but they are based on real events.

"You tend to find," explains Huyler, "that you're witness to an endless procession of similar events - or maybe dissimilar events - but they share in their intensity and tragedy. They kind of blur together; they become this wash. One of the benefits of writing was that it forced me to step back a bit and try to think about the events from a little more distance and perspective."

Huyler describes himself, here and in the book, in self-effacingly nondescript terms: average height, skinny, with short, brown hair - a "jeans-and-sneakers" kind of guy. Yet, what makes The Blood Of Strangers much richer than a merely random selection of sketches is the subtly-drawn self-portrait that emerges through the stories - charting the mark left by these strangers.

"I didn't know what I would use at first to give them some kind of cohesion," he confesses, "but I settled on using the narrator - my own character development, if you like - for that. But I didn't want to make it all confessional, or self-absorbed and narcissistic.

"I wanted the stories to have the primary impact, but I realised I wanted to put myself in enough to show that they had some effect on me - it's a fine line to walk, I guess."

The ER is, Huyler admits, "an environment rich in stories", but one of his concerns in writing about it was to distance himself from the myths. The problem with Mark Greene and company in the TV drama series ER, says Huyler, is that "they are far too competent".

"Most of what we do in the ER are really small moments, not life and death, not big drama. Only some of the time does that happen, and only some of the time, when it does, can we do anything about it. A lot of the time, people who are going to die are going to die no matter what we do."

What The Blood Of Strangers does par excellence is rehabilitate those "small moments". Huyler has a forensic capacity for observation, possibly because he grew up as something of an outsider. He was born, in 1964, in Berkeley, California. His parents were teachers at international schools and the family had an itinerant, globe-trotting existence. Frank actually went to kindergarten in London, but then, in his early teens, the Huylers moved to Iran, a couple of years before the fall of the Shah.

He vividly recalls the lead-up to the revolution: "It was exciting for me as a 13-year-old, but frightening for my parents." The family got out just in time, catching a flight out the same day as Ayatollah Khomeini's return. Huyler went to high school in Brazil and Japan, then to study at Williams College, Massachusetts - a "small, liberal arts college" - where he majored in English. Only then did he decide on a medical training.

Why, I wonder. "I'm not completely sure," replies Huyler, with a sheepish laugh. "I was always, quite honestly, better at the humanities than the sciences, but somehow the path from studying English, into teaching or whatever, struck me as less practical. At the time, I wanted to do something that would have a real effect on people. It was a mix of a little bit of idealism and a lot of pragmatism."

After medical schooling in North Carolina, he toured around looking for a residency, eventually settling on Albuquerque in 1993. He qualified in 1996, and has been there ever since. He married last year - being so settled is a little strange: "Seeing people age is a novelty." One pragmatic element in Huyler's choice of emergency medicine was that, more than any other branch of medicine, it gave him time to write. He is now at work on a novel, but has no plans to give up the day job at the moment.

"It keeps you grounded," Huyler observes. "It reminds you of many elemental forces that we often don't see in the developed world. It's very easy to hide yourself away, but in an ER room you're constantly reminded of those forces."

fields.headline: Dead letters
fields.standfirst: Alex Clark  on the unquiet ghosts of motherhood in The Peppered Moth  by Margaret Drabble
fields.trailText: Alex Clark on the unquiet ghosts of motherhood in The Peppered Moth by Margaret Drabble
fields.body:
The Peppered Moth

Margaret Drabble

392pp, Viking, £16.99
Buy it at BOL

We might imagine that when The Peppered Moth first began to take shape in Margaret Drabble's mind, she wished to reflect on the perils and possibilities of making fiction out of the grimy confusions of real life. If so, she could well have taken into consideration the lugubrious pronouncements of an earlier fictional character, and been considerably put off. "I think that no one has the necessary right to publish what they know - however good it might be for them to write it," cautions Cassandra, the portentously named character in The Game, an early novel by Drabble's sister, AS Byatt. It was published in the same year that Drabble herself wrote Jerusalem the Golden, a novel characterised by a young heroine who seeks to escape the cheerless world of her upbringing.

Cassandra, a don eventually driven to suicide by the fictional borrowings of her novelist sister, detects in the creative process not an inevitable confrontation of truth but a possible means of escape from it: "If we imagine our experience we transmute it - rearrange it, meditate on it, light it differently ... the imagination can be violently dangerous. Not enough - a mere recording - is valueless. Too much is an evasion of truth."

The Peppered Moth is a novel about Drabble's - and, of course, Byatt's - mother. This much is beyond critical fancy, because Drabble states it in uncompromising terms in an afterword that strikes one as very much like the optical illusion that shows at one moment the appearance of a duck, the next a rabbit, but never both at the same time. Invoking the myth of the woman who enters the underworld to search for a loved one, and by way of disguise covers herself in "dead rat water", Drabble confides: "I have made myself smell of dead rat, and I am not sure how to get rid of the smell." Is this melodramatic image self-serving apology or poignant evidence of the novelist's abiding moral dilemma? Can one borrow from the dead without becoming a grave-robber?

It is the novel's obsession with the dead that begins to give answers to these pressing and uncomfortable questions. They pile up on its pages, in the massed ranks of genealogical tables and the individual agonies of deathbeds, in memory and speculation, in inherited possessions and characteristics that torment and thwart the unsuspecting living. Although this novel is deeply flawed - in its fussy construction, its infuriatingly uneven tone, its improbable plotlines - its impressive achievement is to animate the dead and to address, with bold face, their hold over us.

Drabble begins in two places at once. In a Methodist chapel in South Yorkshire, she introduces the representative of the living, "bobby-dazzler" Faro Gaulden, a science journalist whose vitality is undermined by morbid tendencies in the shape of her reluctant attachment to a gloomy, manipulative boyfriend and her simultaneous fascination with and fear of the vertiginous possibilities of genetic research. As she abandons herself to the DNA swabs of the professor who has come to Breaseborough to search for the links between the living and a recently discovered 8,000-year-old skeleton, the camera draws back to reveal tiny Bessie Bawtry, a gifted child seeking sanctuary in private rituals beneath the parlour table in the early years of the 20th century.

Bessie, it quickly becomes clear, is the shade that haunts Drabble; her progression as the novel's living spectre provides its best and worst moments. With an extraordinary sensitivity and acuteness, Drabble recreates Bessie's early life as a precocious child painfully compelled to escape her environment - the unforgiving coal dust and squalor, the obligingly unaffectionate parents - through an enormous effort of will. She patiently evokes the "nightmare of the forced brain trapped in its skullcage" as Bessie sweats over her schoolbooks and battles her way into Cambridge, and delicately anatomises the fatal loss of nerve that consigns her to a lifetime of bitterness and regret.

As a study in the neurosis engendered by the solitary life of the clever child, The Peppered Moth promises to be superb. As Bessie is gifted with intelligence and singlemindedness, she is also cursed with hypersensitivity, emotional imbalance, hypochondria, fearfulness and pride. At each new hurdle, she must overcome the legacy of inertia that, Drabble suggests, has been bred into her, and is engaged in a vicious turf war with her own instabilities.

It is not a battle that she can win. Drabble's powerful theme is that evolution - whether it be a straightforward Darwinian fight for survival or the Lamarckian theory of adaptability favoured by Faro - takes time. If one generation begins to dig the escape tunnel, another will emerge into the daylight; there will be casualties along the way.

This fatalistic observation is also Drabble's undoing, because it allows her to treat Bessie with an almost casual sadism: just when she should take up the responsibilities of the novelist toward her creation, she slips into the comfortable ignorances of the historian. Suddenly Bessie's inner life, so confidently and compassionately nurtured, withers into nothingness. Here she is, marrying her childhood sweetheart, and thus ruining both their lives for ever, and here is Drabble on the subject: "It is not clear why they married at all. But they did ... I have tried - and I apologise for that intrusive authorial 'I', which I have done my best to avoid - I have tried to understand why Joe and Bessie married, and I have tried to invent some plausible dialogue for them that might explain it." This, one is tempted to say, is not good enough; it is passing the buck. If that seems a harsh judgment, then consider what else happens to Bessie, who becomes a monster - a selfish, repressive mother, a bullying, whimpering wife, an overgrown child. It is hard not to see in these passages a hint of retrospective sadism as we encounter Bessie's "deformed and dangling bosom" and the "folds of white tripe flesh above her thighs".

As Drabble throws herself behind the living, her dead characters increasingly begin to resemble Larkin's "fools in old-style hats and coats", which is both support for her arguments about the arrogance of the present and evidence of unfortunate weakness. Although her descriptions of the past appear meticulously researched and painstakingly realised, they are just that: borrowings from the archive that, like many of the scientific subplots - the endless tattoo of DNA and matrilineal descent - function as distractions and alibis.

There are serious problems with The Peppered Moth, but it also displays commendable strengths, not least a proper engagement with our dangerous imperative to create narrative out of the problematic ebb and flow of life. "Descend with me," Faro's sickly lover mawkishly implores, to which she can only think: "People do not talk like that, in the late 20th century. They talk and live in the upper reaches, in the rapid shallows. Nobody goes down there any more, not even the dead and the dying. There is nothing down there any more."

Drabble, of course, knows better.

fields.headline: How was it for us?
fields.standfirst: Robert Hewison  leafs through The Guardian Year 2000
fields.trailText: Robert Hewison leafs through The Guardian Year 2000
fields.body:
The Guardian Year 2000

ed Michael McNay

301 pp, Guardian Books, £12.99
Buy it at BOL

'Acting areas dictate style," observes this paper's drama critic, Michael Billington, in his token appearance in The Guardian Year 2000. Context affects content, and there is a world of difference between reading an article in a daily newspaper and re-reading it in an annual. A well-defined editorial space is needed to show off ephemeral pieces in the changed physical and temporal setting of a book.

The editor, Michael McNay, who retired from the Guardian in 2000, has not provided one. In the 1950s these miscellanies used to be called The Bedside Guardian, with the unfortunate implication that they would send you to sleep. In the 1990s a more aggressive policy changed this to The Guardian Year, suggesting a work of record, but it isn't that either. The publishing schedule means that the selection runs from September 1999 to three months ago, missing key events such as the farcical American Presidential election result and the fuel protests. The Guardian Academic Year would be more accurate.

McNay simply presents "a collection of the finest writing in the Guardian on any subject in that period", bundling his chosen pieces into floppy categories such as "Here and there" and "Wonderful world". Individual items have datelines, but there is no indication of which part of the paper they come from. It is too much to ask for an index, but brief notes on the contributors, who range from Michael Frayn to Peter Tatchell, would have helped. It is not difficult to work out that "Art beat" reflects the arts pages, but McNay's odd selection here reflects them badly.

As to being "the finest writing", there is nothing badly written, but don't expect masterpieces of literary prose. Excepting Simon Hoggart's parliamentary sketches, in which our rulers sound like the Goon Show, the Guardian follows Orwell's principle that good prose should be clear, like a window pane. The outstanding piece is Nick Davies's essay-length "The great divide" on the cruel differences between Roedean and a failing comprehensive school nearby. Angry and despairing, it still manages to be sympathetic to both.

What does gradually emerge is a self-portrait of the Guardian itself, that "candid, often awkward, friend" of the Labour Party, as one of the leaders here puts it. The most explicitly political section brings together four witty pieces on the monarchy that were plainly leading up to the paper's republican outburst at the end of last year, but the climax missed the selector's deadline, spoiling the effect. Similarly, the best thing the Guardian did last year, the three special sections on the dumbing down (or not) of society, are unmentioned.

McNay might have done better if he had consciously tried to reflect the many different specialist sections of the paper. Why nothing from Jonathan Glancey, who has helped to bring architecture into popular discussion? Where is Larry Elliott from the business pages, or Roy Greenslade from the media section?

The most embarrassing re-read is Polly Toynbee's attack on Bob Gavron for accepting a Labour peerage while chairman of the Guardian Media Group, which owns the paper. The attack is acute, but Toynbee also explains how Gavron could have no influence, so the piece becomes a puff for the paper's independence. Her righteous conclusion is that "it would be unthinkable for any other newspaper to print criticism of its own chairman or owner". I hope the same applies to criticism of the Guardian 's publications.

 Robert Hewison is the author of Culture and Consensus: England, Art and Politics since 1940 and was co-curator of the Ruskin centenary exhibition at Tate Britain in 2000. He is a Professor at Lancaster University and writes on arts for the Sunday Times.

fields.headline: Big in crime
fields.standfirst: Maxim Jakubowski picks up a magnifying glass and snoops for the best new crime books
fields.trailText: Maxim Jakubowski picks up a magnifying glass and snoops for the best new crime books
fields.body:
When an author dredges up characters from books past for a new outing, the reader is prepared for a Reichenbach Falls apotheosis in which some of the heroes will meet an untimely fate. Such is the cloak of noir that surrounds Michael Connelly's A Darkness More Than Night (Orion, £16.99), in which the outstanding Californian writer brings on not only brooding cop Harry Bosch but also heart-transplant survivor Terry McCaleb of Blood Work . Though McCaleb is out of the police force, he hasn't lost his nesting instinct for the roots of evil. In a complicated case, he is soon assaulted by undeniable evidence that makes the often unpopular Bosch the prime suspect. Did he or didn't he go over to the dark side? The plot rattles along in fifth gear, with upsets galore on every page. A thrilling, challenging read, as one has come to expect from Connelly.

Buy it at BOL

Russell James is a British author who has for years enjoyed critical praise and disappointing sales, suffering from the public's prejudice against home-grown talent of the hard-boiled variety. Painting in the Dark (Do-Not Press, £7.50) is his masterpiece to date, eclipsing much of contemporary British mystery writing with its compassion, meticulous plotting, historical relevance and chilling subject matter. A complex tale of art treasures in which the present has to face the horrors of the past, in particular those of Nazi Germany, this is a courageous and ambitious novel.
Buy it at BOL

Also on the fast track to the first division is Scottish writer Carol Anne Davis, whose third novel, Noise Abatement (Do-Not Press, £7.50), is an Edinburgh thriller with much wicked irony and dark chills to spare. webTitle: Review: The Floating Brothel by Sian Rees

fields.headline: Ark life
fields.standfirst: Frances Wilson  experiences the vivid smells of a seaborne prison in Sian Rees's  The Floating Brothel
fields.trailText: Frances Wilson experiences the vivid smells of a seaborne prison in Sian Rees's The Floating Brothel
fields.body:
The Floating Brothel

Sian Rees

248pp, Headline, £14.99
Buy it at BOL

In July 1789, five years after the philosopher Immanuel Kant heralded the beginnings of modernity with the magnificent claim that "We do live in an age of Enlightenment", the Lady Julian, a convict ship crammed with 237 "disorderly" female prisoners, set sail from Portsmouth on a 13,000- mile journey to Parts Beyond the Seas. Its cargo was a surplus of prostitutes, shop-lifters and pick-pockets taken from equally crammed and disease-infested gaols.

While the supposed object of this transportation was to rid the country of its unwanted while clearing the prisons to make room for more, the real motive was not reduction but production. The cargo of the Lady Julian was destined to control the "irregular" urges of the inhabitants of Botony Bay in New South Wales, the fledgling, and as yet male, penal colony housing England's marginalised, discarded, and dispossessed. While for the most part the term of imprisonment for the women in this brave new world was only seven years, it was obvious to all that none would return home after serving their time. Not only would the cost of a passage prohibit it, but few would be willing to leave new husbands and children to endure another 11 months of discomfort at sea in order to try search for those they had left behind.

The Floating Brothel is a story of bodies and their waste, expulsion and overflow. It is about the late 18th century's attempt to control what is undesirable and about how those expelled then lived in the company of each other's waste. The story Sian Rees tells is, among other things, a vivid, visceral, and riveting account of noxious stenches. Smells are becoming a respectable part of historical writing: Peter Ackroyd devotes a chapter of London: A Biography to bad odours, and Sian Rees gives us an ark of "dead rats, dead cats, compost of mounds of vegetable peelings, faeces, urine, rotting fabric and decomposing sick". Those pregnant on board (and there were many, both before and after the journey began) went through morning sickness as well sea sickness, to be followed by labour in a heaving ship, while the others suffered menstrual cycles in which all the soiled sanitation was stored on board. When not expelling, bodies were variously itching. Sexual diseases were hard to avoid given the relations between prisoners and sailors, while the salt in the water used for washing made for irritable groins and other rashes.

Such primitive conditions contrast strikingly with the navigational feat of the journey itself, the way in which the ship was drawn "by an invisible thread of calculations and sights through months of empty horizons - into the mouth of a river [the navigator] had never seen". Rees is fascinated by the nuts and bolts of sailing; she describes well the vertiginous experience of being aboard ship for the first time, the deafening sound of wind in sails, and the strangeness of the ship's ports of call (Tenerife, Rio de Janeiro, Cape Town) to those who had never left East London, or Lincoln, or Southampton.

Many of these women were teenagers (for procreational reasons, the bulk of women were young adults), leaving behind weeping parents, children and lovers, to travel to God only knows where, aboard a creaking, leaking vessel, accompanied by cows they were expected to milk while the waves were as high as mountains (this task was given to cattle thieves) and sailors they were expected to provide with sex. John Nicol, the ship's steward, wrote in his memoirs (republished this month by Canongate as The Life and Adventures of John Nicol, Mariner ): "Every man on board took a wife from among the convicts, they nothing loath."

He chose for himself Sarah Whitlam, sent for seven years to Parts Beyond the Seas for stealing a cloak which she claimed to have borrowed from a friend with whom she frequently shared clothes. "I fixed my fancy on her from the moment I knocked the rivet out of her irons upon the anvil," Nicol wrote. But the day after the Lady Julian had begun her return journey, with John Nicol on board grieving for his helpless lover and their newborn son and plotting ways of returning to the colony to rescue her, Sarah Whitlam married another. Like other prisoners, she was determined to cement for herself a viable future.

The prisoners Sian Rees has unearthed have uniformly similar names (Sarah, Mary, and Elizabeth) and tales: seduction and abandonment leading to poverty and prostitution; the theft of a yard of material, the theft of a lover's clothes while he enjoyed his postcoital sleep. The most colourful character is Elizabeth Barnsley, the First Lady of the ship, distinguished shoplifter and sister of a dashing highwayman. She wore her own finery during the package and treated her peers to Canary wine when they docked in Tenerife. No doubt she, like Sarah Whitlam, would have made much of her future in Sydney, and not put up long with a life fighting off the sex-starved inhabitants, sleeping in a wattle and daub shack while "grubbing along the shoreline for bits of oyster shell to grind into lime" to hold it together.

Sian Rees wears her considerable learning lightly, and there is not a dull moment in what is, paradoxically, a wonderfully earthy read.

webTitle: Review:  Half in Love by Justin Cartwright

fields.headline: Things can only get better
fields.standfirst: Justine Jordan  on love in the time of New Labour in Justin Cartwright's Half in Love
fields.trailText: Justine Jordan on love in the time of New Labour in Justin Cartwright's Half in Love
fields.body:
Half in Love

Justin Cartwright

309pp, Sceptre, £14.99
Buy it at BOL

Sometimes the small-print caveat that prefaces every novel (any reference to real persons living or dead is purely coincidental, so don't bother suing, Mum and Dad) isn't worth the paper it's printed on. But the never-named Prime Minister in Half in Love, with his "not-too-formal grey suit and his slightly raffish haircut", still "throbbing with conviction" after three years in power, is a blisteringly accurate caricature of Tony Blair.

We meet him through the descent into scandal of his oldest friend and minister Richard McAllister, who observes the beaching of Labour's "great endeavour" on the shores of realpolitik and public indifference with unease. There is wicked fun with the on-message rhetoric and vacuous ad-speak of New Labour: charged to come up with a slogan for the next election, Richard supplies the horribly plausible "You can feel the difference. And there's more to come". Cartwright has a fine historical sense of parliament and power, and sets up fertile parallels between the vanished England of self-deluding colonial certainties and New Labour's attempts to resurrect citizenship through the tarnished institutions of church and state.

In newly classless Britain, citizens are supposed to be able to move seamlessly from the terraces of Wembley to tea at the Ritz. Horse-riding, Oxford-educated Richard's troubles begin when he goes to a football match and asks the chubby thug beside him who is howling for Ingerland to shut the fuck up for five minutes. Shortly afterwards he is stabbed in the throat, the locus of his offence: those commanding, upper-class vowels.

The assault crystalises his growing sense of guilt and dislocation from the people he is supposed to represent, and from the modern world itself. He flees to the ghost town of Mafeking and research into his ancestor's account of the horse in warfare, contrasting the "nobility" of real battle with the tawdry attack which has made him into a story for the press to pick over. And then the story gets juicier: his affair with married actress Joanna Jermyn is revealed, and their secret "Olympian" love is dragged down to "street level".

Like Richard, Joanna is cast as a relic of mythic, vanished Albion; a Hollywood star "playing a type that no longer existed outside films and plays". As she drifts unmoored into the heady stratosphere of celebrity in America and he flounders for authenticity in England, their love is battered by politics and celebrity - and by the more usual demons of loneliness and infidelities.

Sadly, though Cartwright retains his impressive range of reference and eye for telling detail, this is mostly a very bad book. We flit between the lovers in a strange mixture of steely third-person and rambling interior monologue, rehearsing issues familiar from the last few years of the newspaper comment pages: the travesty of Englishness, the triumph of feeling over intellect in politics and the possible link to the death of Diana, the Boys' Own ennui of being part of a generation never to see active service.

The landscape of the novel is a clearly signposted "real" world; Joanna appears in medical soap Lake Practice and courts acting cred semi-nude at the Almeida. This makes Cartwright's bad calls - such as the sub-Amis names of his working-class thugs, Carl Panky and Denny Tongle - appear laughably novelistic. The style ranges from clogged portentousness ("If he hadn't known it before, he knew it now: to be human is to be only partly rational") to faint risibility ("Sophie opened the champagne expertly. Joanna imagined that she applied the same dexterity in her sex life").

Cartwright's previous novel, the Whitbread Award-winning Leading the Cheers, also dealt with dislocation and inauthenticity, and achieved resonant truths; here the truisms on offer range from the familiar (actors are emotionally needy) to the familiarly distasteful (Jews are "more in touch with elemental things"). The raggedness extends to the drifting grammar and glaring typos. On the very first page ethics are described as lodging in the body "like holly, living on a tree" (some festive confusion with ivy or mistletoe, perhaps), and we are told that Richard's scar "lay on his neck now", prompting one to wonder where it was the week before. If no one involved with a book has read it properly, why should the public bother?

webTitle: Review:  The School of Night by Alan Wall

fields.headline: Pipe-smoking maggots
fields.standfirst: Ian Sansom  enjoys  The School of Night, a teeming history tutorial  by Alan Wall
fields.trailText: Ian Sansom enjoys The School of Night, a teeming history tutorial by Alan Wall
fields.body:
The School of Night

Alan Wall

304pp, Secker & Warburg, £10

Buy it at BOL

What you get with an Alan Wall novel is everything, and more: history, philosophy, poetry, crime, social commentary, love, sex and death. His content exceeds the form. The books teem with plots and ideas, like tapeworms in a gut, or maggots feeding on a corpse. And maggots, as he usefully reminds readers in his latest, typically self-excelling novel, "are clean as cats, but they do sweat. Any place that contained them was soon pervaded by a lingering and slightly suffocating smell, as though the air itself were being subtly eaten away." The books want light and air.

The School of Night is the latest in a series in which Wall concocts a plot from a historical curiosity. In last year's The Lightning Cage, he gave us Richard Pelham, 18th-century poet, rediscovered and reinterpreted by a 20th-century scholarly narrator whose researches lead him into various realms of mystery and a painful process of self-discovery. Here he gives us the 16th-century School of Night, the fabled group of writers around Walter Ralegh, and a 20th-century scholarly narrator whose researches lead him into various realms of mystery and a painful process of self-discovery. Sufficient unto the day is the story thereof; what matters, what's really good, is the quality of the disquisition.

The story, such as it is, concerns Sean Tallow, a Northern scholarship boy who goes to Oxford and then gets a job working for the BBC. He spends his free time researching the School of Night - a group of men including Christopher Marlowe, Thomas Nashe and George Chapman who "entrusted to one another thoughts so startling and illegal that each held the life of the others in his hand and on his tongue". Sean's childhood friend Daniel Pagett is now a successful businessman. The two men meet in later life, and their destinies become linked. The plot possesses a neat symmetry, and there is a host of interesting minor characters - dons, sculptors, models, thieves and Shakespeare, creatures of the night, one and all - but Wall would be the first to admit that he's no master story-teller. He's an intelligencer. What he specialises in is information.

Here he covers not only the highways and byways of 16th- and 17th-century history, politics and literature, but also Wittgenstein, Benjamin, Freud, Jung and the fringes of Catholic theology. His sagacity finds expression in pipe-smoking dialogue: "'What exactly is intellectual ascesis?' I asked my confessor in his room in Blackfriars one day." Comes the reply, from Sean's portly pet Dominican: "Simply the stripping away of the inessential from the world of thought, so as to enable the true perception of reality."

Even Sean's relationship with his girlfriend seems to be an excuse for a discourse on theories of the unconscious. A typical exchange runs like this. Sean: "But presumably the age of unconscious desire must be related to the age of the host? I can't be a one-year-old with a 50-year-old unconscious, can I?" Dominique: "The unconscious doesn't recognise chronology either, only desire. That's its only rule, the one law that governs it." This isn't really conversation. It's a tutorial, and reading Alan Wall is an education. The only thing that could possibly improve his work is an index.

webTitle: Review: Clerical Errors by Alan Isler

fields.headline: Turbulent priest
fields.standfirst: Steven Poole  on the comic mistakes in Alan Isler's Clerical Errors
fields.trailText: Steven Poole on the comic mistakes in Alan Isler's Clerical Errors
fields.body:
Clerical Errors

Alan Isler

279pp, Jonathan Cape, £15.99
Buy it at BOL

Father Edmond Music thinks the Vatican wants to kill him. Or if not the Vatican, at least his old enemy, Father Twombly. Many years ago, a unique Shakespeare manuscript vanished from the library of Beale Hall, the scholarly Catholic retreat that Music runs; now, perhaps, the hated Twombly has evidence linking him to the crime. Meanwhile, Music's mistress, Maude, is giving up the gin and embracing the Catholic faith. Father Music himself has never believed in any of that god nonsense. Oh, and on top of that, he's Jewish.

The TV-sitcom title masks a fundamental tension: does the novel want to be a Father Ted-style knockabout or a deeper comic examination of faith? There is, of course, a healthy, innocent amusement to be had from the spectacle of drunken, fornicating priests, and this is well handled in Father Music's narration. Among the story's minor characters, meanwhile, is a wonderful old Major, all irreligious spleen and twinkling eyes; and a visit from the local bishop makes for an exquisitely toe-curling set piece.

The broadest comic brush is used on Music's researches into an 18th-century Jewish mystic called the Pish, or the Ba'al Shem of Ludlow, a Hungarian émigré who befriended the local aristocrat and became renowned for his cabbalistic wisdom and elixirs of virility. Isler provides pastiche contemporary reports of the Pish's miracles that, frankly, are rather baffling in their zany unfunniness.

Interleaved with these varyingly sophisticated comic themes is a much darker story: that of Music's own family. His Hungarian-Jewish parents moved to France in 1923. At the outset of war, they had their son confirmed a Catholic to try to save him; his mother eventually died in Auschwitz. After the war, Music finds his father in Tel Aviv, but old Konrad is incensed that his son is now a Christian priest and kicks him out. The last time we see Konrad, he is a broken man, sitting in his squalid garden, laughing repetitively at chickens.

This thread, unfortunately, seems rather embarrassed by its own solemnity. Music is given to deflatory flippancies such as "This was a major recognition scene, after all, the stuff of which romantic fiction is made", before finally coming to explain, rather clunkily, what his father had taught him. In becoming a Catholic to save his own skin, Music tells us, "I betrayed the six million." By the end of the book, we are draped in a cosy gloom. The moral lesson is that Music has learned to accept his own identity, but a suspicion remains that the tragic materials were never thoroughly integrated into the fiction - as they are in, for instance, Tibor Fischer's Under the Frog .

And yet Clerical Errors is, overall, a very amiable read. The author has a talent for scholarly Shakespearean jokes (as in his first novel, The Prince of West End Avenue) and, on occasion, a quite brilliant comic rhythm. Two examples must suffice of deferred gratification by comma. Music says of his father: "he usually wore, apart from a thick serge suit and a shirt with celluloid collars, a meaningless scowl"; of the Major: "He had married shortly after the war a woman whose post-natal depression could be traced back, seemingly, to her own birth." Anyone who can write sentences like that must be watched.

fields.headline: Sporting chance
fields.trailText: Booker contender Matthew Kneale, Zadie Smith, poet John Burnside and memoirist Lorna Sage will all compete for the 30th Whitbread Book of the Year
fields.body:
 Booker contender Matthew Kneale, Zadie Smith, poet John Burnside and memoirist Lorna Sage will all compete for the 30th Whitbread Book of the Year, to be announced on January 23. The Loafer notes with interest that the phenomenon of the celebrity judge has not faded, with chairman Tim Rice to be joined by sports commentator Clare Balding and Olympian Matthew Pinsent. Which is all very well, as long as we can be assured that, in reciprocal fashion, Julian Barnes and Beryl Bainbridge will have a hand in selecting the next England team.

 To another enjoyable sporting treat - the Bookseller's annual invitation to editors to explain away conspicuous failures of the previous year. This year the challenge was taken up by, among others, the publisher of Robert Mawson's The Lazarus Child (Transworld), which notched up sales "not commensurate with the advance" (£420,000), and the editorial director of Little, Brown, Anthea Turner's publishers. So where did it all go wrong? For Transworld, Patrick Janson-Smith reveals the moment of truth - when Geri Halliwell came into the office, scanned the blurb and pronounced herself unimpressed. That's certainly censure enough for us. As for Anthea, Alan Samson ponders whether that chocolate bar proved "the negative tipping point", and goes on to reveal the extent of his disillusionment: "Until this book was published I broadly believed the maxim that all publicity was good publicity. I don't believe that any longer." And the Loafer finds it very hard to believe that.

 Perhaps Janson-Smith and Samson might decide to turn authors themselves and follow the example of Gabrielle Mander, editorial director of Michael O'Mara. Having clocked a trend developing, she quickly knocked up Wan2talk?, the text messager's bible that took off over Christmas and has now sold over 85,000 copies in two months. If you want something doing ...

 Our most humble apologies to the puritanical Nicholas Blinco, who has shopped the Loafer to the Guardian reader's editor on the grounds of impertinent over-familiarity - to whit, for referring to him as "Nick". Blanco is quite right: these heinous lapses in politesse are a pernicious threat to the future of letters, and must not be allowed to pass unnoticed.

fields.headline: Shooting the works
fields.standfirst: Depressed about going back to your desk? There's nothing more harmful to your happiness than watching office-based movies in January, says Joe Queenan
fields.trailText: Depressed about going back to your desk? There's nothing more harmful to your happiness than watching office-based movies in January, says Joe Queenan
fields.body:
Social scientists and psychologists are not agreed on why people get so depressed during the holidays. Obviously, a fresh set of completely useless Christmas gifts cannot be the only explanation. One theory is that people know that they have to go back to work, which is enough to depress anyone.

What can be done to make this transition from the festive holidays to the glum realities of the workplace less stressful? A worthwhile suggestion is to avoid watching movies that deal with work and instead rent films like The Blair Witch Project and Braveheart, which have no obvious socio-economic overtones. In the following paragraphs, I will signpost several work-oriented films that should be given a wide berth as the holidays draw to a close.

In the past two years, Hollywood has devoted a great deal of attention to the subject of work. Innocuous piffle like Office Space and Clockwatchers have concentrated on generic working environments, whereas films such as American Beauty, Bringing Out The Dead, Boiler Room, Being John Malkovich, High Fidelity, The Company of Men and Croupier have addressed specific problems associated with specific industries, thus targeting a narrower audience. Hollywood is to be congratulated for its increasing sensitivity to the emotions of the public, many of whom work for a living.

Obviously, movies depicting the spiritual desolation of the workplace are not new. Charlie Chaplin's Modern Times meticulously delineated how machines dehumanized the urban work force, and films such as The Grapes of Wrath painted a searing portrait of life in the agricultural sector. Numerous motion pictures of the 1940s excoriated efficiency experts whose impersonal mathematical models were turning ordinary human beings into automata. But not until Billy Wilder's 1960 The Apartment did anyone in Hollywood get around to addressing the explosive issue of workplace romances.

In The Apartment, Jack Lemmon plays a brown-nosing junior executive who gets ahead by allowing his bachelor pad to be used as a trysting place by his unscrupulous superiors and their inane mistresses. One day, a spurned floozie played by Shirley MacLaine gets so upset at being two-timed that she tries to take her life, using a vial of pills she finds in Lemmon's medicine cabinet. Lemmon arrives home to find the comely young elevator operator at death's door. He is devastated. The responsibility of nursing a mentally unhinged person back to full health would be daunting enough, but what further complicates matters is that MacLaine has been dating Lemmon while simultaneously sleeping with Fred MacMurray, who happens to be Lemmon's boss. The moral of the story seems to be that office romances are fatal, because if your boss's girlfriend winds up dead or even near-dead in your apartment, he is unlikely to give you a raise anytime soon.

Revenge themes have long been a staple of movies dealing with the workplace. In Nine to Five, three clerical workers resort to clever stratagems in an effort to punish their superior for years of insensitivity. In Swimming with Sharks, a good-hearted factotum is so humiliated by his boss that he abducts him and tortures him until his demands for a more respectful work environment are met. And in Working Girl, a complete idiot played with remarkable conviction by Melanie Griffith triumphs over her haughty female superior by using her jaw-dropping lack of intelligence to seduce head honcho Harrison Ford and get a promotion.

All of these movies succeed on their own merits, but none make it any easier to go back to work after the holidays. That's because the characters played by Dabney Coleman, Kevin Spacey and Sigourney Weaver are so much like real-life bosses that they erase the illusion between reality and fantasy. Spacey so closely resembles a man I worked for when I started out in this business that every time I see his photo I want to punch out his lights. This is equally true of the scummy co-conspirators who seduce a lovely, innocent deaf girl in In The Company Of Men. They are vile, they are odious, they are beyond the pale. But most of all, they are instantly recognizable.

One interesting development in contemporary motion pictures is the rise of industry-specific movies. For example, in Bringing Out the Dead, which depicts in chilling detail the unrewarding side of the otherwise glamorous ambulance-driving profession, Martin Scorsese has served up the latest installment in the Cruddy Jobs Tetrology that began with Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore (why would anyone want to be a waitress?), Taxi Driver (what kind of a jerk would want to drive a cab?) and Goodfellas (you think being a mobster is all glitz and glamour? Fugheddaboutit).

But Scorsese is not alone in this milieu. In Glengarry Glen Ross, David Mamet pitilessly unveiled the horrors of the real estate business, much as Sam Mendes would later do in American Beauty. The ethical conflicts that lie at the heart of the brokerage business give Boiler Room, The Last Seduction and Wall Street their special power, just as Clerks derives its strength from its merciless dissection of the monotony endemic in the suburban retail sector. In an even more proletarian setting, films such as Hoffa deal with the effect of strained interpersonal relationships on the work force.

Over the years, Hollywood has produced a steady stream of movies showing how stressful it is to be a policeman (Fort Apache, Serpico, The French Connection), a doctor (The Hospital, Madame Bovary, The Island of Dr. Moreau), a lawyer (Philadelphia, The Firm, The Devil's Advocate), a rock star (This Is Spinal Tap, A Star Is Born, Airheads) or an astronaut (Mission to Mars, Red Planet, The Astronaut's Wife). Frankly, these subjects have gotten a bit stale.

What a relief it is to see Hollywood narrowing its focus to examine less glamorous industries. For example, buried beneath the clever humour of Being John Malkovich is a searing indictment of workplace environments that do not conform to even the most minimal ergonomic standards. And once one gets past the cloying love story that dominates High Fidelity, it is possible to discern a dispassionate yet clinical analysis of the way unresolved tensions may contribute to storewide unhappiness in a downscale retail environment.

In the end, what I am trying to suggest is that this genre of movies succeeds all too well at the task it has set itself. Because these films come so close to the texture of reality, they deny the filmgoer the opportunity to escape into a fantasy world where he can find the relaxation and amusement that cinema customarily provides. In my own office experience - buried years in the past - I found that an astonishingly large percentage of my co-workers were at least as annoying as Jack Lemmon in Glengary Glen Ross, at least as predatory as Demi Moore in Disclosure, at least as ruthless as Michael Douglas in Wall Street, and at least as dumb as Melanie Griffith in Working Girl. That's why I don't have a job anymore.

The only way you can really enjoy these movies is if you don't have to work for a living. If you do, stay away from them. Especially around the New Year.

 The Apartment is on general release

fields.headline: Houllier admits Fowler may leave
fields.standfirst: Second attack in a year may be last straw for Robbie admits Liverpool boss
fields.trailText: Second attack in a year may be last straw for Robbie admits Liverpool boss.
fields.body:
Gérard Houllier has conceded for the first time that Robbie Fowler's ties with Liverpool could be broken after he fell victim to an unprovoked street attack, for the second time in 20 months, which has enforced his withdrawal from the FA Cup third-round weekend.

Fowler has been given the weekend off to recover after suffering minor facial injuries when he was attacked outside a bar in Liverpool in the early hours of Wednesday.

Given that he went on record last year as stating that he had considered leaving Merseyside after being attacked at a city hotel in April 1999, Houllier is realistic enough to know this latest assault may well act as the catalyst for the player's departure.

"I just don't know if he has now reached the stage where he feels he has to go away," said Houllier. "We will see when he comes back. He must decide what happens next."

Although the likelihood is that Fowler will remain at Anfield until the end of the season, it is conceivable he could move before then, with no shortage of buyers both at home and abroad. Arsenal, Chelsea and Aston Villa are all monitoring the situation.

Houllier's sorrow at Fowler's plight has been tinged by a sense of irritation about his player's role in the incident. The Frenchman admitted as much yesterday when he described himself as having been "surprised by the time and place it happened."

Manchester City have signed the goalkeeper Carlo Nash from Stockport County for £100,000. Nash was valued at around £2m when Leeds made an inquiry last year but the 27-year-old would have become a free agent in the summer.

Leeds United's captain Lucas Radebe has agreed to extend his contract until 2004.

Egypt's veteran striker Hossam Hassan will equal the world record of Lothar Matthäus when he wins his 150th international cap today in a friendly against United Arab Emirates in Cairo.

Sir Alan Sugar has claimed he is "absolutely astounded" at Sol Campbell's claims that Tottenham had not made moves to keep him at White Hart Lane.

"His latest comments make me, David Pleat and George Graham come across as idiots or, even worse, liars. Everyone in football knows we have been desperately trying to keep him," Sugar said.

webTitle: The Frenchman and a Fulham revolution

fields.headline: The Frenchman and a Fulham revolution
fields.standfirst: Jon Brodkin examines the changes Jean Tigana has imposed on and off the pitch in pursuit of perfection at Craven Cottage
fields.trailText: In a special report Jon Brodkin examines the dramatic changes Tigana has imposed on and off the pitch in pursuit of perfection.
fields.body:
Fitness

If Fulham's players were unsure whether their new manager Jean Tigana was more Butlins or Barlinnie, they found out soon enough. Hauled in two weeks early from their summer break, they were quickly carted off to France for pre-season training which included 6.30 wake-up calls, dawn starts and up to three sessions a day. The tone was set.

The Frenchman arrives for work at Fulham's Motspur Park training ground at 7.30 each morning and although the players pitch up rather later, two sessions a day remain common. Not that the idea is to run people into the ground.

"The intensity level of training is controlled so the players are peaking for each game," says Steve Kean, the youth academy director who has been working closely with Tigana and his coaches.

Swimming may be used for post-match recovery if there are fixtures in quick succession, and the day before a game training is invariably low intensity and held as close as possible to the kick-off time, to mould the players' body clocks. Not always easy in winter without floodlights.

Under the fitness coach Roger Propos, everything from power and strength to agility and flexibility is worked on. "The training programme put together by Roger is detailed to a level I've never seen before," says Kean, who played at Celtic and in Portugal and has coached at Reading. "The height of benches they jump from in some of the power sessions is measured in centimetres."

In the newly updated gym players have personal programmes. Those returning from injury are never rushed back and, after a pre-season which was calculated and gradual rather than gruelling, the team feel fitter than ever. It is surely no coincidence Fulham have scored 21 times in the last 10 minutes of matches.

No coincidence either that Tigana is so fitness obsessed. "In all the running we did he was always at the front," says his former Marseille team-mate Chris Waddle.

Diet

Whether Tigana has spies in every west London fast-food outlet is uncertain, but with body fat and weight tests every month or so, his players know they cannot afford to mess around.

Nutritional education at Fulham has included not only what to eat and drink but when. If alcohol is out, water and carbohydrates are definitely in, with food to be consumed within an hour of the end of training so the body can absorb more energy from it.

Not surprisingly, plenty of pasta, potatoes and rice can be found in the training ground canteen, and breakfast - cereals and toast rather than hash browns - is laid on for those who want it.

The importance of rehydrating and refuelling (not in the Gazza sense) before, during and after training has been clearly stressed. Water is taken before training and at 15- or 20-minute intervals throughout; Lucozade is saved for after to avoid blood sugar levels rising and dropping suddenly mid-session.

"The players take more care than they did in the past and because of that they are better players," says Alex Court, the first-team exercise physiologist. "Their injury levels have reduced, they have more energy and have reduced their body-fat levels, so they are leaner and more athletic."

Tests are carried out regularly. Body-fat levels are expected to be around 7-8% (some have fallen 4% from last season) and blood is taken every six weeks or so.

"From the blood tests you can see levels of fatigue," Court explains, "and the doctor will look and see if they are too fatigued or if they need more work, and increase or reduce training accordingly."

Drinking, naturally, is discouraged, though Tigana was not averse to a tipple in his playing days. "He wasn't on it every day," says Waddle, "but I can guarantee after a game we used to sit at the back of the plane and have two or three beers."

Technique

"It's plain to see," Kean says, "that at first-team level everyone has improved to a man." Given the amount of time which is devoted to ball-work that is hardly a shock. The technical improvement is a tribute not just to Tigana but to the coach Christian Damiano, who spent many years at the French National Academy at Clairefontaine and has been chief scout and assistant coach of France.

Damiano devises and oversees the routines required by Tigana, who frequently takes part in them. Almost every aspect of training involves a ball. "Players will have probably 2,500 to 3,000 touches of the ball per session," Kean says. "If you analyse other clubs' training they might not have so many. Significantly, the main exercises have not just technical but tactical importance. "We do not do exercises for the sake of exercises," Damiano says. "It is always so it can be transferred into a game." The idea is to build understandings and passing patterns which become instinct. Players work in their natural positions.

"If you are [Steve] Finnan and you play right-back, you work in the session in your zone, building a relationship perhaps with [Andy] Melville, Sean Davis and Bjarne Goldbaek. Tigana's quick grasp of English has helped him settle but his success runs deeper. "Jean has gained the trust of every player," Kean says. "Even the guys who are not in the team are happy because they can look in the mirror and say they are better footballers."

Tactics

Movement, patience and passing form such an integral part of Fulham's approach that dribbling sounds frowned upon. "Don't run with the ball," Damiano says. "Perhaps when you are 20 metres from goal and you have a chance to score. But when you are far from the opponent's box take your time. Give and move, give and move . . ."

The patterns worked on in training have become so ingrained that Kean believes "when you play tapes of our goals it's just our sessions screaming out at you". The change from the days of Kevin Keegan and Paul Bracewell is marked.

"There is much more emphasis on playing out from the back and keeping possession," says the goalkeeper Maik Taylor. "We never really did a lot of teamwork before. Kevin Keegan just had us feeling we were the best players in the world and we went out and managed to get results."

Tigana has stuck to 4-4-2 featuring a midfield diamond, and allied to the patience are mobility and pace. Luis Saha and Luis Boa Morte have been brought in to offer that now while Geoff Horsfield has been moved on.

Players are taught not to be afraid of losing the ball but Tigana demands that they work to win it back. "He was a great player," Arsenal's Henry says, "but he used to fight for every ball and he expects that."

Beneath Tigana's calm exterior there lies a fierce competitor. Taylor says they have felt the "full force of his unhappiness"; Damiano, who taught his current boss on coaching courses in France, recalls how Tigana wanted to be the best at everything: "Jean knows that at the highest level you win on the smallest details."

As with all opponents, Tigana has had Manchester United studied carefully. Damiano will give his usual analysis to the players. "No matter who we play [Tigana] doesn't want us to change the way we approach games," says Rufus Brevett. United, knocked out of the Champions League by Tigana's Monaco in 1998, know what awaits them.

The exciting prospect for Fulham is that the best is almost certainly yet to come. Tigana's stints at Lyon and Monaco were notable not just for their success but for the way the former postman pushed on youths such as Thierry Henry and David Trézéguet. Tigana has brought in Saha and improved Sean Davis, a 21-year-old midfielder, significantly.

"What I like best is bringing on young players," Tigana has said. Kean concurs: "He believes that the academy is the backbone of the club. When you work at clubs who have that sort of belief in young players you start to spit out Beckhams and Scholes and these type of talents."

Tigana will look not just for talent but for physical and mental strength. "He likes young players but he is very tough with them," Henry says.

"I remember after I won the World Cup [in 1998] he made me clean the balls with my hands and carry the goalposts in training and take the players' bags to the plane. He said when he was young he had to do that, and because I was young I had to do the same."

fields.bodyText: Fitness If Fulham's players were unsure whether their new manager Jean Tigana was more Butlins or Barlinnie, they found out soon enough. Hauled in two weeks early from their summer break, they were quickly carted off to France for pre-season training which included 6.30 wake-up calls, dawn starts and up to three sessions a day. The tone was set. The Frenchman arrives for work at Fulham's Motspur Park training ground at 7.30 each morning and although the players pitch up rather later, two sessions a day remain common. Not that the idea is to run people into the ground. "The intensity level of training is controlled so the players are peaking for each game," says Steve Kean, the youth academy director who has been working closely with Tigana and his coaches. Swimming may be used for post-match recovery if there are fixtures in quick succession, and the day before a game training is invariably low intensity and held as close as possible to the kick-off time, to mould the players' body clocks. Not always easy in winter without floodlights. Under the fitness coach Roger Propos, everything from power and strength to agility and flexibility is worked on. "The training programme put together by Roger is detailed to a level I've never seen before," says Kean, who played at Celtic and in Portugal and has coached at Reading. "The height of benches they jump from in some of the power sessions is measured in centimetres." In the newly updated gym players have personal programmes. Those returning from injury are never rushed back and, after a pre-season which was calculated and gradual rather than gruelling, the team feel fitter than ever.
