webTitle: An old route to the new romance as United return with intent

fields.headline: An old route to the new romance as United return with intent
fields.standfirst: Cup regains its soul as minnows dream of glory, writes  David Lacey
fields.trailText: Cup regains its soul as minnows dream of glory
fields.body:
The FA Cup is dead, long live the FA Cup. If ever there was a chance for football's oldest competition to be revived by a spot of shock therapy it is surely this weekend.

Last season's competition was stunned by the withdrawal of Manchester United to compete in the Fifa world club championship, which clashed with the fourth round, and did not fully regain consciousness.

The Cup meandered on myopically, producing such moments of passing interest as Leicester City's removal of Arsenal on penalties after 3 goalless hours and the hat-trick by Aston Villa's Benito Carbone which did for Leeds United. But an anodyne final between Chelsea and Villa still left the game wondering if the tournament had any life left in it.

This weekend's third-round ties will surely prove the pessimists wrong. For the next three years the road to Wembley may carry diversion signs to the Millennium stadium in Cardiff but this is the FA Cup's opportunity to demonstrate that the essential spirit of the exercise remains strong.

Manchester United's decision to book accommodation in Cardiff during the second week in May is not just a sign of self-confidence; it is also a gesture of intent. If United's mood has been read correctly, Sir Alex Ferguson still regards the Cup as an important accessory, a chalice to the Champions League grail and the Premiership goblet.

Tomorrow's tie at Craven Cottage will, therefore, be about something more than an attempt by Fulham, the runaway leaders of the Nationwide League First Division, to unsaddle the thoroughbreds who are again leaving the rest behind in the Premiership. For here are two teams, outstanding at their respective levels, who can set the tone for the rest of the Cup this season by providing a match of distinction.

With Jean Tigana, the Fulham manager, as devoted to a quick, accurate, imaginative passing style as Ferguson, it is difficult to believe that the game will fail as a spectacle. And, if Ferguson decides to bring the full attacking force of Ryan Giggs, David Beckham and Paul Scholes into the action from the start, so much the better. Teddy Sheringham, newly recovered from injury, is expected to be on the bench.

For Fulham, losing Chris Coleman, their most influential defender, after a car accident this week is a blow which may prove too much of a handicap to bear. But two seasons ago United beat them only 1-0 at Old Trafford on the way to winning the Cup for the 10th time and, if all else fails, older Cottagers will always have memories of 1958 to sustain them.

Then, too, Fulham were knocked out of the FA Cup by Manchester United but only in a semi-final replay at Highbury which they lost 5-3 after drawing 2-2 at Villa Park. United, of course, were fielding the side cobbled together in the wake of the Munich air crash while Fulham's attack included Johnny Haynes and Jimmy Hill, who scored six goals in the Cup that season.

Forty-three years ago the FA Cup became a symbol of Old Trafford's determination to recreate the qualities which had perished with the Busby Babes. Now another tie against Fulham should mark Old Trafford's pledge to re-embrace the competition ignored last sea son as a matter of convenience.

Yet for the Cup properly to regain its previous status something more than a renewal of interest by Manchester United is required. This afternoon those contesting the other two Champions League places in the Premiership, most notably Arsenal and Liverpool, need to demonstrate by their actions that the Millennium stadium in May holds as much attraction as Wembley ever did.

Arsène Wenger may have Tony Adams restored to his defence for the tie at Carlisle but will the Arsenal manager be thinking of fielding a below-strength side against the Third Division's bottom team? And to what extent will Gérard Houllier regard the visit of Rotherham to Anfield as a serious business? As it is, Emile Heskey, Gary McAllister and Markus Babbel may be unfit.

Sunderland and Ipswich, third and fourth in the Premiership and closing on Arsenal, may take a stronger interest in the Cup this time. While a Champions League place would be the biggest reward for both clubs, neither will shrug aside the FA Cup and Sunderland have particular reason for seeing off Crystal Palace, who have already knocked them out of the Worthington Cup.

Ipswich, on the other hand, could still be one of the first of the Millennium stadium's English finalists; on Tuesday they open their Worthington Cup semi-final against Birmingham at Portman Road. In the meantime George Burley's side visit Morecambe for one of several ties which represent the true soul of the FA Cup at this stage.

For all its offhand treatment by some of the big clubs, the competition still means a great deal to the small fry in terms of finance and prestige. Last season Rushden and Diamonds took Sheffield United to a third-round replay before going out on penalties, while the season before they lost 3-1 at Elland Road after holding Leeds to 0-0.

So who will take up the baton this time? Probably not Morecambe, given the excellence of Ipswich's passing game, or Dagenham and Redbridge, considering Charlton's home form. A better bet could be Kingstonian, who face Southend United of the Third Division having already beaten Brentford of the Second. Or maybe Yeovil, those giantkillers of old, will surprise Bolton.

The Premiership sides most in danger of embarrassment would appear to be Tottenham, who make the short journey to Leyton Orient, and Everton, who visit Watford in a reprise of the 1984 final. Then again Leeds, lions in Europe but lost lambs domestically, may be surprised by Barnsley, whose away record is bad enough to satisfy the delicious illogicality on which the FA Cup has always thrived.

David Lacey's guide to the pick of the ties

Carlisle Utd v Arsenal

Before 1992 'Walsall' was written on Arsenal hearts in the FA Cup. Then that giantkilling act of 1933 was surpassed by Wrexham, who beat George Graham's team 2-1 at the Racecourse. The Welsh side were last in the league in 1990-91, so comparisons with today's tie at Brunton Park are inevitable. Carlisle are in last place by some distance, Arsenal's away form is poor and Arsène Wenger has more injury problems than usual. A replay is possible but to win Carlisle need to reach heights previously unscaled.

Scorecast: Carlisle 1 Arsenal 3

Morecambe v Ipswich Town

While the spirit of Eric Morecambe will be supporting Luton Town in the Cup today presumably his statue on Morecambe's promenade will allow itself a silent giggle should Ipswich be beaten. This is unlikely since George Burley's side are winning regularly away from home and are already in sight of the Worthington Cup final. Morecambe's best chance would appear to be to turn this afternoon's tie into the sort of scrap Ipswich might not relish with their Worthington semi-final with Birmingham City only 72 hours away.

Morecambe 0 Ipswich 3

Leyton Orient v Tottenham

Should Tottenham perform as ineptly as they did at Ipswich last Saturday the only surprise will be if Orient fail to win today's game. As it is, the Brisbane Road club are omnipotent at home this season, unbeaten with 20 goals scored and only nine conceded. Spurs' confidence drains away when they are on the road. An early goal for Orient and another black mood will surely descend on George Graham's team. This tie, then, could see the upset of the weekend - and Orient did knock out Chelsea on their way to the semi-finals in 1978.

Orient 1 Tottenham 0

Charlton Athletic v Dagenham

No one at the Valley will complain if this afternoon's tie produces the extravaganza of D&R's first-round tie with Leyton Orient eight years ago, which the O's eventually won 5-4. Dagenham's biggest FA Cup triumph was a first-round victory over Cambridge United, then in the Fourth Division, in 1985, but a share of the gate receipts is likely to be their only reward today. As their victory over Arsenal showed, Charlton have become hard to beat at home and Alan Curbishley's players should wrap this one up long before the finish.

Charlton 6 Dagenham 1

Fulham v Manchester Utd

Far from regarding the FA Cup as an impediment to their promotion ambitions Fulham have tended to use it as a touchstone for what they hope to achieve in the Premiership. Two years ago they went out narrowly to United, Andy Cole scoring the only goal at Old Trafford. Cole will not be around tomorrow but whatever side Sir Alex Ferguson puts out will surely be tested by a quick-passing pattern of play which mirrors their own. Ferguson hates replays but may have to put up with one if the opposition are on song.

Fulham 1 Man Utd 2

webTitle: Sing a song of Brady and the boom-town Robins

fields.headline: Sing a song of Brady and the boom-town Robins
fields.standfirst: Savvy saviour has Swindon looking to life after death and Coventry
fields.trailText: Savvy saviour has Swindon looking to life after death and Coventry.
fields.body:
Football allegiances can tear families apart, literally divide households into red and blue rooms. The Bradys are not yet at war but they could be, just could be, given the quixotic nature of the FA Cup.

Terry Brady, Swindon Town's chairman and a former Orient player, and his daughter Karren, the managing director of Birmingham City, will not be overly concerned with the other's progress this afternoon. But they will be if both clubs survive against Premiership opposition and tomorrow are drawn together in the fourth round. The odds, of course, are very long.

But they are no longer than the chances of a determined young woman becoming a member of the Birmingham board in 1993 and rapidly showing she was smart enough and tough enough to succeed in a so-called man's world; and no longer than those of Swindon, locked in a Doomsday scenario last year, being saved from extinction, thanks largely to Karren's father.

Swindon, under their manager Andy King, are still struggling, way down in the Second Division, fighting a second successive relegation battle. But most of the near-capacity 14,000 crowd at the County Ground this afternoon are delighted to have a club still to support. The visit of Coventry, albeit with problems of their own, is being billed as the biggest match in the old town for seven years, when Wiltshire was briefly on the Premiership map.

Cup tradition insists that this is a life-or-death match for the Robins. It is a testament to the club's recovery under their multimillionaire printer chairman that, financially, it is not. Peter Rowe, their chief executive, says: "A tie with a Premiership is a bonus as, obviously, would be a win. But it is not make or break for us." It is a far cry from last February when disaster stared Swindon fully in the face.

Eleven months ago Swindon, embroiled in the worst-case scenario, called in the administrators. The club had debts of around £1.5m and were losing £20,000 a week. Gates were plummeting after a 15-match run without a win including an FA Cup defeat at home to Charlton. When the cry for help went out, Swindon were eight points adrift in the First Division.

Surely this was a portfolio to deter even the best-intentioned investor - but not Brady, a man with experience of fire-fighting in football as a former Portsmouth director. "He was looking for an interest to get back into the game," said Rowe, "and an opportunity presented itself." But Swindon?

Brady "saw the positives", according to Rowe, amid the club's freefall. "It may be seen as a family club but it is one in a growing area. Swindon is one of the boom towns in England, arguably the fastest growing in Europe.

"Terry also appreciated that we are a club for the region and not just for the town. Our catchment area is probably half-a-million people and half our season-ticket holders do not live in Swindon. There is high potential."

To realise that potential a move to a new stadium from the County Ground, home for 105 years, is essential. It is central to Brady's takeover which, with the chairman eventually taking a 70%-plus stake, is ultimately worth around £10m. But they will be if both clubs survive against Premiership opposition and tomorrow are drawn together in the fourth round. The odds, of course, are very long. But most of the near-capacity 14,000 crowd at the County Ground this afternoon are delighted to have a club still to support. fields.headline: Villa deal for Angel collapses
fields.standfirst: Fingers point at player's agent as Villa's record signing falls through
fields.trailText: Fingers point at player's agent as Villa's record signing falls through.
fields.body:
Aston Villa's bid to break their transfer record and sign the Colombian striker Juan Pablo Angel for £9.5m from the Argentine club River Plate collapsed last night.

Villa blamed the South American end for the breakdown and said in a statement that the deal's financial structure contravened Fifa regulations. "Fifa refused to accept the structure and methods of payment required by the owner of the player's registration," said the statement. "Aston Villa have acted in the utmost good faith throughout and both the board and the manager are extremely disappointed at this turn of events."

Doubts regarding the financial structuring of the transfer were raised earlier in the week and they resurfaced again yesterday when it was revealed the agent handling the deal, Gustavo Muscardi, was demanding Villa pay him a commission fee of £800,000.

Indeed, Fifa's spokesman Keith Cooper admitted last night that the whole saga had caught the world governing body by surprise and he laid the blame squarely with Muscardi and River Plate. "Article IV of the Fifa statutes clearly states that 'a licensed agent cannot hold any position in a club'," said Cooper. "In this instance it would appear that the agent in question actually owns half of River Plate.

"We will have to speak with the Argentine Football Association to see how this situation has occurred. People have questioned Aston Villa's competence over this issue but that is slightly unfair. This whole situation is an absolute minefield and it is hasty and unfair to criticise them."

Villa's manager John Gregory alluded to problems yesterday before the FA Cup tie at Newcastle United tomorrow. "There have been hitches in all of our transfers," he said. Three hours later the deal was in ruins.

Gregory's day was made worse by the news that West Ham's manager Harry Redknapp had revealed he was interested in buying the Villa defender Gareth Southgate in a London newspaper. "I'm surprised Harry Redknapp has made these comments without talking to me," he said. "Chelsea offered £6m for Southgate and that was unacceptable. So there's no chance of West Ham having any success with a bid of that size."

West Ham's Steve Lomas will hold talks with Manchester City and Everton over the weekend after both clubs had £3.6m bids accepted by West Ham yesterday.

Redknapp hopes he can secure a deal to buy the Rangers defender Lorenzo Amoruso for around £3m early next week. "The deal is on with Rangers, I have spoken to David Murray, the chairman, a few times and it's just whether Amoruso fancies it and we can do a deal with him," Redknapp said.

Two St Johnstone players have been sacked after they were reported for using drugs in a Perth bar. George O'Boyle and Kevin Thomas have had their contracts terminated for gross misconduct. "It was alleged that they were in possession of a white substance, possibly cocaine or another illegal substance," said the club's executive director Stewart Duff after a hearing at the club.

The Brazilian defender Edu confirmed last night he is flying to London today for a medical at Arsenal - six months after he was turned back at Heathrow with a false Portuguese passport. Edu said he would fly to Lisbon next week to receive an authentic Portuguese passport.

webTitle: Aberdeen's answer to a Fergie flyer

fields.headline: Aberdeen's answer to a Fergie flyer
fields.trailText: Alex Ferguson may be offered Aberdeen FC as a retirement gift, setting him the most tricky of ethical conundrums - whether or not to fake gratitude.
fields.body:
Technically they are called flyers, articles in newspapers that appear to bear little relation to any known fact but sound like a jolly good yarn. As a tale, the Telegraph's excited revelation this week that Sir Alex Ferguson is to be offered most of Aberdeen Football Club as a retirement gift would have gained in credence had not everyone associated with the story denied it.

Ferguson told the television news he had not been approached, while representatives of Aberdeen said they had no plans to make any offer. Such is Ferguson's prominence that he can't even turn up to a football match (he was in the stands for Aberdeen's game on Tuesday) without a conspiracy theory being woven around his attendance. Besides, would Ferguson really want to join a board as bizarre as that at Aberdeen?

Last season, as the club cast itself adrift from the bottom of the Scottish Premier League, toings and froings in the boardroom provided far more entertainment for the locals than was ever on offer down on the pitch. First there was the strange case of the aptly named chief executive Gordon Bennett. After being discovered twice driving around checking out the kerbs in the city's red light district, Bennett disappeared southwards to take up a new career. As a postman in Norfolk.

Then there was that other recent departure: the coiffure of the chairman Stewart Milne. A multi-millionaire property dealer, Milne was renowned, as his club crumbled around his ears, for a hairstyle which never did. Milne's was a style which refused to waver in length or any lateral movement.

Rumour has it, so intrigued by the barnet were members of Aberdeen's first team squad, that at a barbecue thrown by the chairman at his house, one of them, under the influence of a bet, made a grab for it. Imagine the player's surprise when it came away in his hands and flew on to the barbecue. Last month Milne suddenly came clean, eschewing the tailor's dummy look for a William Hague stubble cut.

During Grampian TV's end-of-year sports review this week, an intrepid investigative reporter asked Milne about the most famous wig in Scottish football.

"I took a bit of flak about it for a week or two," said Milne of its removal. "But the bulk of the reaction has been very positive." Now the syrup has been flung out of the window permanently. Which is what you call a real flyer.

fields.headline: Reliving the beautiful game
fields.standfirst: Jon Brodkin meets Ricky Villa, still revered at Tottenham 20 years after  that  final-winning goal
fields.trailText: Jon Brodkin meets Ricky Villa, still revered at Tottenham 20 years after that final-winning goal.
fields.body:
Ricky Villa is easing himself out of a sofa in the bar of a hotel in Cheshunt when a stranger strides purposefully towards him. Before the Argentine has time to think he is shaking hands. "Ricky," the man says reverently, "thank you for the greatest night of my life."

The stranger, needless to say, is a Tottenham fan. The night was the replay of the 100th FA Cup final, played in front of 92,000 people at Wembley. The memory may be painful for Manchester City supporters but, 20 years on, the mazy dribble and dreamy finish with which Villa won the Cup for Spurs is still fresh in the mind.

Certainly no one at White Hart Lane has forgotten. Villa marked his first trip to England for five years by walking on to the pitch when Newcastle visited last Tuesday and the reception made his knees, never mind Ossie Ardiles's, go all trembly. "Twenty years ago I scored a goal and everyone remembers me," he says. "It's unbelievable."

One might expect Villa to be tired of reliving that goal. His life, after all, has moved on to coaching in Argentina and in June he hopes to team up with Ardiles once more in Japan. Yet mere mention of the game lights up his face, instantly recognisable even if the beard is greyer and the hair thinner. At his ranch back home the video must be wearing out.

"It is my son," he stresses. "For every friend who comes into my house he puts on the video and says: 'You see, this is my father who scored that goal at Wembley in the FA Cup final.' I don't do it often because I feel embarrassed and I know in my memory what I did. I don't need to watch it as a reminder."

He must have seen his magic on Tuesday as it flashed on the big screens at Spurs, as before every match. To the right Steve Archibald is unmarked in front of goal, yet Villa goes on, past one, two, three defenders before slipping the ball under Joe Corrigan.

"I didn't realise that goal was superb at the moment I scored," he says. "In Argentina we try all the time to do something special and very often it does not come off. I tried at Wembley and it came off." He points at his chest and laughs: "This is a lucky boy."

Even in his homeland he is remembered for it. "Wembley is the house of football," he explains. "Everyone in Argentina says: 'You scored a goal at Wembley.' I believe I have scored better goals but that was the right goal in the right place at the right time."

A better goal is hard to imagine but Villa proceeds to demonstrate. It was against Norwich, he says, zig-zagging his hand before flashing it towards the ceiling. "I cut and cut and cut again," he says, "and shot into the top of the goal." Another broad smile.

What tends to be forgotten about Villa is not only that he scored earlier in the replay against City but that he was substituted in the first match. Spurs were 1-0 down and he traipsed off devastated, thinking the game was lost and his chance of glory gone.

"I walked around the pitch thinking fuck Keith Burkinshaw," he later revealed. But Spurs salvaged a replay, Burkinshaw gave him another chance and Villa made amends as he had promised himself he would.

Such reminiscences must have filled the air at Ardiles's London home this week, where Villa stayed until his friend returned to Japan where he coaches Yokohama Marinos. Perhaps they recalled their home debuts in 1978, when an Argentine flag flew at White Hart Lane and the fans gave them a ticker-tape welcome.

"We talk all the time about the old years," Villa says, "sometimes about the difficult time we had at first. We did not speak the language and the football was very different from Argentina. Now we are looking to coach together and we have talked about the possibility of me joining Ossie in Japan."

This morning Villa flies to Madrid to visit Jorge Valdano, Real's sporting director, and study the coaching at the Bernabeu. His dream is to manage "Tottingham" and two Spurs shirts are stuffed in his luggage for his teenage son.

The 48-year-old follows the club via the internet but what he saw live on Tuesday did not remind him of the Spurs he played for. Then, with Villa, Ardiles and Glenn Hoddle in midfield, Tottenham oozed fantasy. "The style was different," he says, "but it is not just Spurs who have lost that quality. It is the same for many teams. Everything now is about hard work and pace. It's very difficult to have precision with that speed.

"It's hard for me to make a valid opinion about the team because I have only seen one match but they showed great spirit and played well. For me the No9 [Les Ferdinand] did really well and I respect George Graham. I think differently but I respect that he makes the decisions."

At Defensa y Justicia, a small second division club who went into the winter break in mid-table, Villa is preaching the beautiful game. There 5,000 constitutes a big crowd - "The people are not going to matches in Argentina; I believe it is because the clubs are not playing nice football" - and he drives around 100 miles to work every day from his ranch. "I enjoy that life," he says. "I have goats and lambs and, when I walk around there, I feel great. I love the peace. I prefer that to the big cities."

Villa's departure from London for Fort Lauderdale Strikers in 1983 came after the Falklands War had interrupted his career. At the time he missed the sun among other things. Now he admits it was a mistake to leave and he is touched by the warmth shown for him.

"I say to myself, maybe soon everyone will forget, but when I come back it's always the same," he says. "In Argentina this would be impossible. My friend had never been to England and he said: 'Ricky, the people love you.'"

One magical moment has guaranteed him a place in Tottenham hearts. "I read in the programme on Tuesday that I played 223 games for Spurs and scored 41 goals [official club records show 167 and 25]," he says, "but nobody remembers another goal. I only scored one goal in England."

More memories of Villa's golden goal

City's Ray Ranson

'I was on the edge of the box and he went on the outside. I thought, if I lunge in he's going to go over and it would be a penalty, so it was like a half-hearted attempt, knowing he was going away from goal. Then I turned round to see Tommy Caton lunging in behind me when he cut inside. And by that time he was back in front of goal.'

Tottenham striker Steve Archibald

'I knew either he was going to score or it would come to me at the back post, where it would have been a simple tap-in. I had my arms up and was shouting for it. He saw me but he knew what he was doing and I was left waiting for the pass that never came. But I'm glad it didn't because it was a magnificent goal that will never be forgotten.'

City striker Kevin Reeves on why he failed to stop Villa

'It was a brilliant game, even if the highlight was that goal. I'd given away a penalty on my debut and after that I thought "There's no way I'm going back there again".'

John Motson

'City played really well and Steve MacKenzie scored with a cracking volley. It would have been remembered in any other Cup final but for Villa topping it.'

webTitle: Change as good as a rest if pitch and punter come first

fields.headline: Change as good as a rest if pitch and punter come first
fields.standfirst: Moving the final to Cardiff may break with the tradition which is the life-blood of the world's oldest club competition, but there's plenty of room for optimism says David Lacey
fields.trailText: "Maybe Cardiff will get the final off to a fresh start. Perhaps the old Wembley, with its unreasonably high expectations, had become too much of a cliché for new epics."
fields.body:
For the FA Cup, then, the Dai has been cast. Exit one old grey elephant, enter a rekindled red dragon.

To some extent the success of moving the final to the Millennium stadium in Cardiff while Wembley stadium is rebuilt will be judged by how few punters Will Hay's railways leave stranded in the Severn Tunnel come kick-off time. That and the length of the tailbacks on the M4 and the M5 as queues form at the two toll bridges into Wales.

Either way, for football traditionalists, this is going to be a strange year, what with the England team destined to be handed over to a Swede. It is just as well the quasi-national side has no plans to leave Old Trafford.

Yet cup finals in Cardiff should be a welcome experience. The Millennium stadium is everything the relic in north-west London is not and, while the only multi-storey car park where the rain falls inside will be missed, the Cardiff curries are as hot as they are in Wembley High Street and drivers will get a break from the Neasden underpass.

The FA Cup final is due to return to the new Wembley in 2004 but no wise person would bank on it. Having abandoned Ken Bates's dream of recreating Shangri-La just off the North Circular (in any case Ikea had thought of it first), the Football Association is considering more modest alternatives. But, if the present timescale applies, Cardiff will still be staging the final in 2008.

By then, at least, the transport system may have more or less learned to cope with the task of getting rather more non-Welshmen to the Millennium stadium than would normally attend a rugby international. Logistically this should be no more complicated an exercise than, say, playing the Swedish cup final across the Kattegat in Copenhagen, and at least the locals will be marginally less hostile.

Nevertheless the oldest and most quintessentially English football competition is going to reach its climax in a state which has its own parliament, its own language and, so far as votes on Fifa are concerned, is a foreign country.

Enough fuss was made 74 years ago when Cardiff City took the FA Cup out of England for the first and, until now, only time by beating Arsenal 1-0 at Wembley. The goal came 15 minutes from the end when Dan Lewis, the Arsenal goalkeeper, fumbled a half-hit 20-yard shot from Hugh Ferguson, allowing the ball to trickle over the line.

According to a contemporary report, the Cardiff supporters included a group which had tickets but "declined to enter the stadium unless their foreman, as they called him, could be admitted also, and he had lost his ticket". The Wembley stewards let them in, foreman included. Now it would be presumed he had sold his ticket to a tout.

Since the first Wembley final in 1923 the FA Cup has only once been presented away from the stadium, in 1970 when the final went to a replay at Old Trafford where Chelsea beat Leeds United 2-1. In view of the state of the Wembley pitch for the original match, any misgivings about staging the final on a rugby field need to be kept in perspective.

A combination of the Horse of the Year Show and a bad winter meant a normally superior playing surface being so heavily sanded that it must have been like running across the Goodwins. Yet Leeds United's Eddie Gray still managed to achieve what remains one of the best individual performances seen in any final.

No doubt the Cardiff groundstaff will transform the pitch in the Millennium stadium from a lumpiness suitable for loose mauls to a field fit for measured passes. Wembley, however, has had an atmosphere all of its own which has not been entirely due to the state of the urinals or the strength of the onions in the average hotdog.

Just how far the sense of occasion always guaranteed in the Stadium of Legends can be recreated in an arena which as yet has barely a legend to call its own can only be guessed at but it is to be hoped that the organisers do not try too hard. No fireworks, please, and no funny Welsh dragons - and do leave the chatterbox with the mike in London unless you want Wales to secede altogether.

Anyone with a clear memory of the last FA Cup final not to be played at Wembley, 1970 excepted, will shortly be receiving a congratulatory telegram from the Queen. Not that the 1922 encounter between Huddersfield Town and Preston North End at Stamford Bridge appears to have been that memorable, one report describing the game as "a perfect nightmare" which left a crowd of 53,000 feeling they had been "badly used and badly entertained".

That sounds a bit like last season's final between Chelsea and Aston Villa. In fact Wembley has not witnessed a properly entertaining FA Cup final since Liverpool beat Everton 3-2 in 1989 and that game was overshadowed by Hillsborough.

Maybe Cardiff will get the final off to a fresh start. Perhaps the old Wembley, with its unreasonably high expectations, had become too much of a cliché for new epics.

Certainly this is one Millennium experience which should not prove a flop - always provided those with tickets can get there. Another final between Arsenal and Ipswich might be more accessible played in Brussels.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: How to cope with tax returns

fields.headline: A form guide to calm the nerves
fields.standfirst: As the tax return deadline approaches, David Brodie gives tips on how to minimise the panic
fields.trailText: As the tax return deadline approaches, David Brodie gives tips on how to minimise the panic.
fields.body:
Have you completed your tax return for the year to April 2000? The Inland Revenue says that over 3m forms are still outstanding, and threatens a £100 fine if you don't file by the end of this month.

Tax returns are issued to just over 9m people - or one-third of all taxpayers - typically those who are self-employed, company directors and higher paid employees, and other people with untaxed income such as rents from property.

If your return is still in its pristine blue wrapper, you had better open it, gather your financial records, and get to work. If you need help in wading through the form, you may phone your tax office, or the Revenue's helpline at evenings and weekends (0845 9000 444). And as you may also need to ask for extra pages - see page 2 of the form - you should not delay.

Some people put off filing because they do not have all the information needed. If you are unsure of the income received from your bank or building society, you may ask them for a certificate of interest paid to you. They must provide this free of charge.

If you had a salary or occupational pension, income and tax details should be on your P60 or P45, with taxable benefits-in-kind reported on form P11D. If you have mislaid these, your employer or pension administrator should hold the relevant details (although they will not normally offer duplicate certificates). If they won't offer you the information you need for your return, it may help to know that they should have reported it directly to the Revenue last summer and your tax office may agree to give it to you.

Sometimes it is impossible to obtain exact figures before the deadline. For example you may not have kept records of some trading income or expenses, or you may be awaiting details of income from a trust or deceased estate which has not completed its accounts. The Revenue says you should not allow such difficulties to delay the return and that you should use an 'estimate' or 'provisional figure', explained on page 27 of the Tax Return Guide.

The most important distinction between these two terms is that if you enter a provisional figure you will need to submit further information within a specified period.

If your form was issued to you on or before October 31, 2000 you must file by January 31. Normally you should post it to your own tax office but, if you are running late, you could take it by hand to any local office. Defaulters are threatened with a £100 fine but, due to a flaw in the legislation, no charge can be made if the form is received by the Revenue on February 1, or found in a tax office letter box at 7am on the following morning. If the form was issued after 1 November, you may file up to 3 months after the date of issue shown on the front page.

Whatever date you send it, it is vital that you take a photocopy of the return. This provides some evidence that you have filed, and will also help you to check the Revenue's figures.

Although self assessment was introduced four years ago, there is still confusion over the obligation to calculate your tax. The Revenue promised to do this in good time if you filed by September 30, giving the impression that people filing now must calculate their tax for themselves. This is not true; the taxman will do the sums whenever you send in the form, although it may take a few months. So if you believe that you still owe some tax for 1999/2000, which will fall due on January 31, you may want to make an estimated payment this month to avoid interest (as well as the 5 percent surcharge added to tax paid after 28 February).

While most taxpayers keep their affairs up to date, a minority are in serious arrears. About 10% of self assessment taxpayers have not yet filed their tax returns for 1998/99 and earlier years. When a return is long overdue, the taxman may make a 'determination' (ie estimate) of your tax for the year concerned, and take action for payment through the courts. There is no right of appeal, although the determination is withdrawn as soon as the return is filed.

 David Brodie is director of TaxAid, the charity which provides free tax advice to people who cannot afford professional fees. Phone 020 7624 3768 between 10 am and 12 noon, Mondays to Thursdays. More information is available on TaxAid.

fields.headline: Outstanding choice on cards
fields.trailText: Credit card customers with balances outstanding have a choice. They could pay £115 in interest over the next six months on a constant £1,000 or they could pay nothing and spend the £115 saved.
fields.body:
Credit card customers with balances outstanding have a choice. They could pay £115 in interest over the next six months on a constant £1,000 or they could pay nothing and spend the £115 saved.

The expensive deals come from Clydesdale and Yorkshire Banks - both part of the National Australia Group. For the zero interest rates click on to the Boots, Cahoot or Egg websites on Bootsadvantage, Cahoot or Egg.

You have to apply for a new card if you want a fresh deal. Once you do so - and provided the credit scoring is fine - it's easy to switch.

Ultra low or zero rates do not last for ever. Creditworthy cardholders can keep on switching, taking advantage of new come-on rates. But interest is not the only issue. So ask these questions!

How long is the introductory period?

Vital for big debts. But watch out for tricks such as "x% until 01.04.01" - the time it takes to receive the card and move the balance will eat up a chunk of the low cost period.

What is the continuation or "go-to" rate?

Ignore this one if you're a serial card switcher. But if you're not geared up for plastic promiscuity, the go-to rate paid after any deal is essential information. Northern Rock and Intelligent Finance both weigh in well at 10.5% and 10.8%.

What about an affinity card?

Only a good idea if a) you really need to display the football team, charity or political party you support and b) you never run up an interest bill. Most affinity cards charge high rates. Try switching and giving money saved to the good cause.

What about late payment fees?

Paying £18 for being a day late with a £5 payment at MBNA International and many other American-based cards is a real downer. Barclaycard charges nothing. Most high street banks take last-minute debit card payments on the phone. MBNA and some others won't.

How long is the interest free period?

Boots has 45 days, Sainsbury's 50 days, and Tesco 56.

webTitle: TUC claims firms overreact by sacking staff for lewd office emails

fields.headline: TUC claims firms overreact by sacking staff for lewd office emails
fields.standfirst:
Work Unlimited
Special report: privacy on the net
fields.trailText: Workers who send lewd emails around the office were being targeted unfairly by their employers, the Trades Union Congress yesterday claimed.
fields.body:
Workers who send lewd emails around the office were being targeted unfairly by their employers, the Trades Union Congress yesterday claimed.

It warned there had been a "significant rise" in sackings and cautions for staff caught in possession of sexually explicit emails, but said the disciplinary action taken was often out of proportion to the offence.

Legislation introduced this year allowing companies to monitor office emails had provided a "green light to go after employees with a heavy hand".

The TUC's claim follows the sacking of 10 staff and the disciplining of up to 80 others this week by the Royal and SunAlliance insurance company after pictures of the cartoon characters Bart Simpson and Kermit the Frog each performing a sex act, and of a naked man being chased by a donkey, were sent around its Liverpool office.

The action was taken although an investigation by the company had yet to be completed. The firm said that many other pornographic emails were also uncovered.

In other recent cases, more than a dozen City workers from various companies were suspended for distributing an email sent by internet worker Claire Swire to a friend at the bank Norton Rose, which included a joke about a sperm bank; 15 other City traders, including seven women, at the bank Merrill Lynch lost their jobs instantly for circulating soft-porn emails, although the company admitted they were not illegal.

Unions believe several hundred office workers have been disciplined or sacked for email offences over the last year.

Sarah Veale, a senior policy official at the TUC, said that it believed companies were making an example of some employees in order to score public relations points.

"We believe distributing sexually explicit emails is abhorrent, but companies are sometimes acting out of proportion," she said.

"We suspect there has been a significant increase in the number of sackings and disciplinaries since the introduction of the Regulation of Investigatory Powers [RIP] Act in the autumn.

"The act has been a psychological boost for the companies, giving them a green light and considerable latitude to go after employees with a heavy hand. The companies are keen to demonstrate thay they will deal very severely with cases such as these, but really they are courting publicity and are keen to be seen to be taking a tough line."

The Confederation of British Industry said that the laws were needed to "reinforce the companies' ability to police emails and protect staff from being offended".

However, the act is likely to be softened by guidance in the spring, in the form of a data protection code which the government is drafting after ending consultation with companies and unions yesterday.

The code is expected to open the door to legal challenges to the blanket surveillance of emails.

Ms Veale commented: "Companies will need to be very careful because the code will impose important restrictions on what they can get away with."

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Guide to shares

fields.headline: Brokers go back to basics for this year's share tips
fields.standfirst:
Star performers this year must have stability, demonstrate robust output and provide earnings momentum. Tony Levene reports

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Star performers this year must have stability, demonstrate robust output and provide earnings momentum. Tony Levene reports.
fields.body:
Picking shares to back has never been harder. The technological sure things which stock selectors tipped a year ago now only have one certainty - the smell of burnt investor flesh.

And there is no clear theme to replace these fallen stars. Some brokers have opted for recession-proof 'defensive' shares - stakes in companies such as breweries, tobacco companies or supermarkets whose products always remain in demand.

Others are choosing "consumer cyclicals" - companies such as restaurant chains or general retailers such as department stores, clothing shops or furniture firms, where buying can always be put off if purchasers are hard up. Here the rationale is that these companies are trading on share price levels as low as the worst days of the short-lived Asian crisis in 1998, while expected mortgage rate cuts could have us all scurrying to high street shops.

Brokers HSBC favour "financials" - banks and insurers which should profit from lower interest rates, expected mergers and takeovers, and further cost squeezes. They also like utilities - water, gas and electricity firms. But they're telling clients to downgrade companies in chemicals and other basic industries, engineering, and telecoms.

NatWest Stockbrokers, whose research is largely targeted at private investors, admits there is no one concept this year after plumping for technology in January - and doing rather badly after the dot.com blowout.

However, NatWest research head Jeremy Batstone believes his ten top picks for 2001 have themes in common. "We've opted for stocks with characteristics that should provide a solid base if the present economic uncertainty here and in the US turns into a hard recession. Therefore all our equity picks have to show:

 stability - the ability to produce profits through good and bad times

 robust outlook - companies which are unlikely to be hit by profit downgrades

 earnings momentum - the likelihood that profits will grow year on year." So here's NatWest's naps - and their start 2001 prices.

AB Ports: Britain's largest dockside operation has new management intent on developing the core ports business and selling off peripheral assets. Last year, it raised £154m from sales. And now it is expected to bank a further £100m from disposals. At 366p per share, the company is valued at £1.25bn.

BAE Systems: The hope is for a strong recovery backed by military contracts for the Hawk and Eurofighter aircraft plus benefits from acquisitions. The £37bn order book offers solid backing. BAE is worth £11.5bn at 382p a share.

Berkeley Group: A housebuilder whose ability to grow margins impresses. It scores on urban development skills as well as the low acquisition costs of its landbank. At 755p, Berkeley is valued at £960m.

BG Group: Now focusing on gas exploration and production, there are high hopes of big gas field finds in Egypt and the Caspian Sea. It is one of the purest gas plays. At 262p, BG is worth £9.2bn.

Cobham: Designs and manufactures specialist systems and components for the aerospace and defence industries where the outlook looks firmer than many other areas. A £1.3bn order book inspires confidence. And brokers expect 15% profits growth a year. It has a £1bn value at 1046p per share.

GlaxoSmithKline: A triple barrelled world leader in pharmaceuticals with huge research and marketing muscle. Fans expect to see replacements for Zantac - now off patent - as well as cost savings and 15% annual growth. It's worth £117bn at 1892p.

Marconi: Poor trading results from competitors and the wash from the tech share meltdown have short circuited confidence. But it has transformed itself from a defence industry conglomerate to a company with products ranging from home appliances and satellite communication to medical imaging. At 719p per share, Marconi is worth £20bn.

Mitie: Supplies skilled and unskilled labour through 65 subsidiaries and has notched up 30% annual growth with more to come. Management is highly motivated through shares. At 380p, the group is worth £530m.

Royal Bank of Scotland: Owns NatWest so this tip has to be cleared by lawyers. Cost savings and revenue growth in a sector wracked by competition should bolster earnings increases. At 1582p, the UK's most valuable domestic bank is worth £42.3bn.

Vodafone: With a £150bn market value at 245p per share, the mobile phone operator is the UK's biggest firm. It had a poor 2000 but has little debt compared with rival phone firms and could easily afford to snap up assets from cash-strapped competitors.

But what happened to NatWest's stock picks for 2000? Only one, investment trust 3i, which specialises in venture capital, ended up in positive territory with Dixons picking up the wooden spoon thanks to a slump in value at former subsidiary Freeserve.

But investors who bought all the stocks and sold in March 2000 would have made huge profits. The problem was NatWest went heavily into technology but thought it had avoided difficulties by opting for companies with a proven business model and a real customer base rather than dot.coms which had neither.

BAE Systems: The hope is for a strong recovery backed by military contracts for the Hawk and Eurofighter aircraft plus benefits from acquisitions. The £37bn order book offers solid backing. BAE is worth £11.5bn at 382p a share. Berkeley Group: A housebuilder whose ability to grow margins impresses. It scores on urban development skills as well as the low acquisition costs of its landbank. At 755p, Berkeley is valued at £960m. BG Group: Now focusing on gas exploration and production, there are high hopes of big gas field finds in Egypt and the Caspian Sea. It is one of the purest gas plays. At 262p, BG is worth £9.2bn. Cobham: Designs and manufactures specialist systems and components for the aerospace and defence industries where the outlook looks firmer than many other areas. A £1.3bn order book inspires confidence. And brokers expect 15% profits growth a year. It has a £1bn value at 1046p per share. GlaxoSmithKline: A triple barrelled world leader in pharmaceuticals with huge research and marketing muscle. Fans expect to see replacements for Zantac - now off patent - as well as cost savings and 15% annual growth. It's worth £117bn at 1892p. Marconi: Poor trading results from competitors and the wash from the tech share meltdown have short circuited confidence. But it has transformed itself from a defence industry conglomerate to a company with products ranging from home appliances and satellite communication to medical imaging. At 719p per share, Marconi is worth £20bn. Mitie: Supplies skilled and unskilled labour through 65 subsidiaries and has notched up 30% annual growth with more to come. Management is highly motivated through shares. At 380p, the group is worth £530m. Royal Bank of Scotland: Owns NatWest so this tip has to be cleared by lawyers. Cost savings and revenue growth in a sector wracked by competition should bolster earnings increases. At 1582p, the UK's most valuable domestic bank is worth £42.3bn. Vodafone: With a £150bn market value at 245p per share, the mobile phone operator is the UK's biggest firm. It had a poor 2000 but has little debt compared with rival phone firms and could easily afford to snap up assets from cash-strapped competitors. But what happened to NatWest's stock picks for 2000? Only one, investment trust 3i, which specialises in venture capital, ended up in positive territory with Dixons picking up the wooden spoon thanks to a slump in value at former subsidiary Freeserve. But investors who bought all the stocks and sold in March 2000 would have made huge profits. The problem was NatWest went heavily into technology but thought it had avoided difficulties by opting for companies with a proven business model and a real customer base rather than dot.coms which had neither.

fields.headline: Grunge gets a good teenage kicking
fields.standfirst:
Twist
Camden Palace, London
***
fields.trailText:
Twist
Camden Palace, London
***
fields.body:
There was a time when young girls aspired not to adopt the yoga positions of Madonna or wear the faux-sexy grin of Britney but instead pull on a baby-doll night-dress and walk and talk like Courtney Love. And while the original riot grrrls of the 1990s now take their tips from Vogue, Twist have arrived to pick up the discarded grunge guitar sound and give it a good teenage kicking.

The four girls start the sprawling, bawling rock of Feed with their scowls firmly in place. Not that the perma-glares hide the fact that right from the first screech they're having the time of the lives.

Because, although their mates are doubtless back in their home town of Birmingham shaking off cider-induced hangovers, Twist are reclaiming the sub-pop sound as their own, dressed in regulation T-shirts and jeans and staring at their guitars intently. All except singer Emma Fox, who stares wilfully into the crowd, her fingers finding the frets of her low-slung guitar on their own, her voice Lolitaesque above a melody that could almost be pop until it's smeared with riffs and menacing drums.

Twist make songs for broken-hearted girls who aren't content to sit in a corner and cry, but choose instead to shriek and plead, determined that if they're going to hurt, you're going to know about it. And this time the angst is for real. "I hope you all had a good new year," Fox tells us. "I didn't. I ended up beating my boyfriend up, then dumping him."

If anyone is picture perfect to become a poster girl for riot grrrl power, it's Fox.

With her long blonde hair alternately framing her face or hiding it as she staggers around the stage, bent forward, her head almost touching her guitar strings during Lay Low, she has the baby face of Debbie Harry, the hoarse vocals of Love and the scratchy attitude of Justine Frischmann, yet is still enough of a schoolgirl to smile sweetly at the crowd jumping at her feet. And, along with her bandmates, she's a confident and intense performer.

Lead guitarist Vanessa White is all midriff and feedback, her jarring notes during My Love for Amber providing interest among the jagged rock. And while sometimes Twist veer too close to Hole territory for comfort, Fourteen provides a glimpse of a more "chilled-out" route, as Fox calls it, the stage flooded in blue light as her vocals become softer and Lisa Lavery's basslines get darker.

It proves that if Twist deviate just a little further from the grunge blueprint, they could leave all the comparisons and competition behind.

fields.headline: Glasgow pops down Memory Lane
fields.standfirst:
Electric City
Lighthouse, Glasgow
***
fields.trailText:
Electric City
Lighthouse, Glasgow
***
fields.body:
The great thing about pop is its ephemeral quality. This is what makes curating an exhibition of pop memorabilia tricky. Put bluntly, if you were there, part of the scene, old ticket stubs, posters and rudimentary merchandise mean the world. If you weren't, they mean less than nothing.

Getting round this deftly, the curators of Electric City - an exhibition about the Glasgow music scene - have included atmospheric installations with a universal appeal between and beneath the teenage bedroom-like display boards that make up the exhibition. A Jim Lambie floor installation, all psychedelic stripes in sweetie colours, is like a classic album sleeve underfoot.

There's a bar too - a dark, menacing thing where you'd be scared to ask for anything too fancy - and a bare stage set. If installation supremo Mike Nelson had been involved, we'd have stains and smells and fag ash everywhere; this is all a bit on the clean side but still remains evocative.

The memorabilia on show is less so, unless you find old Glasgow Herald cuttings about Simple Minds riveting. There are, as there should be, some grotesquely big bad haircuts along the way - step forward Jesus and Mary Chain - and some sweet moments too: the Who and the Sensational Alex Harvey Band on the same bill for £4.

There are some of those horrible white silk scarves with coloured tassles at each end (one for Slik, one for Wet Wet Wet) and a rather puzzling blow-up of a Sun front page story from 1999 about Brit award vote-rigging and Belle and Sebastian. The front page itself isn't the weird bit - it's the tailor's dummies sporting the exact outfits Belle and Sebastian wore to the Brits standing next to it. This is silly enough when it's the Beatles at Tussauds; it looks very strange indeed here, especially as the figures are headless.

Best of all are the displays showing the gradual move into club culture and the items relating to less well known bands like Yummy Fur, where fanzines, scraps of paper and ironic merchandising (a very cheap pair of knickers) dominate.

Even though the displays themselves might leave you wanting more, together they make a compelling case for the liveliness of the city's music scene over the years, from Donovan to Deacon Blue, Archbishop Kebab to Texas, Superstar to Primal Scream. That such a scene should exist, now largely in dance music, shouldn't surprise us. Glasgow has had all the vital ingredients for fine, ephemeral music making: gloomy weather, great hardship, a thriving art school and, thanks to that Celtic influence, generally fine singing voices.

 Until February 25. Details: 0141-221 6362.

webTitle: Review: Theatre: Black Bread and Cucumber

fields.headline: Black Bread and Cucumber
fields.standfirst:
Jermyn Street Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText:
Jermyn Street Theatre, London
***
fields.body:
If you designed a show to repel anyone with reservations about the very idea of theatre, it would be something like Black Bread and Cucumber. In this one-woman show, we are warned: "Caroline Blakiston shares the laughter and love, tears and frustrations encountered while making history as the first British actress to play Chekhov in Russia, in Russian. It is not a play. It is a story shared with an audience. An adventure story. A love story."

This sounds worse than being forced to look at someone else's holiday snaps. Why are thespians so fascinated with their own CVs? Why should Blakiston expect us to care about her tussles with The Cherry Orchard and the Russian language's rolled Rs? As Morrissey once sang: "It says nothing to me about my life."

And why, while we're on the subject, does the Jermyn Street Theatre expect us to give a toss about its own history? Why does the programme inform us: "You are standing in what was once the changing rooms for the male staff of the Spaghetti House restaurant"?

And yet, however much you want to hate this show, you soon warm to it. Blakiston has anticipated most of our objections. She makes that clear from the moment she arrives onstage, spouting Russian for several minutes before finally switching to English with the words: "Good evening. Worried?"

She is a thin woman with a touch of the bird about her. Lithe, too, as she shows with some high kicks that bring to mind the guards who goose-step outside Lenin's mausoleum on Red Square (she visited it, of course). She has few props, and provides her own soundtrack with a Walkman connected to the theatre's speakers. But she has no problem holding the audience's attention.

The minutiae of Chekhov's place in Russia are, frankly, of minority interest. Far more appealing are the economical yet vivid sketches of the characters she met on her two visits in the early 1990s, like one of her directors - "a short, bearded man from Astrakhan with an emperor's head".

For most of this 100-minute show, Blakiston seems clear, genuine and self-aware. Only the final quarter disappoints, bringing back all those preconceptions about over-emoting luvvies, as she weeps over the death of a Russian actor she barely knew. You want to shake her by the shoulders and tell her to pull herself together. But perhaps it's not fair to criticise an actor for coming over all theatrical.

• Until January 13. Box office: 020-7287 2875.

fields.headline: Scott Hamilton Quartet
fields.standfirst:
Pizza Express, London
***
fields.trailText:
Pizza Express, London
***
fields.body:
Who says jazz musicians have an easy life? While the rest of us were living it up over Christmas, Scott Hamilton and his men took a measly three nights off from their Soho residency, which Hamilton himself had kicked off by guesting for the singer Jane Monheit.

Nearing the end of the stint, he showed only the smallest touches of tiredness, but these were swallowed up in his fluent, laid-back style, which itself engenders a creeping relaxation. The jumpier numbers stood out in a set that preferred to move more slowly through wistful and occasionally soporific ballads.

The quartet eased us into the evening with Billy Strayhorn's tune Raincheck, then sped up just a fraction with a pleasing rendition of the Gershwin standard Love Is Here to Stay. Hamilton, who emerged from the 1970s as one of swing's brighter latter-day stars, had John Bunch as his right-hand man on piano, together with Dave Green on double bass and the marvellous Allan Ganley on drums.

Bunch was born at a time when the Original Dixieland Jazz Band were the new musical anarchists and is pushing 80 this year. But he doesn't appear to let age trouble him in the least. Duke Ellington's tune All Too Soon saw the pianist dapple his way over a bed of rustling drums before Hamilton emerged, bringing to mind a sleepier version of Ben Webster's original vibrant solos on the piece as he reached deftly for lower tones.

Often the pianist employed a barely-there approach, shadowing the bass and drums as if in rehearsal, but always alert and capable of pitching in when the mood got blustery. Hamilton sat out while Bunch traced a musing mood piece, ending in sharp Oriental style.

Other numbers saw Hamilton and Bunch working in buoyant harmony, particularly effective in a sequence of descending thirds, and coming together in a blowsy, razzmatazz ending. The second set included a Dave Brubeck piece, In Your Own Sweet Way, which again demonstrated the beauty of the piano's delicate connective tissue under Hamilton's warm tones.

Sometimes elegant and bassoon-like, sometimes a bit more bolshie, Hamilton's always-fluid saxophone playing, coupled with a relaxed and personable style of direction, made the tunes seem deceptively artless.

 The Scott Hamilton Quartet play the Pizza Express Jazz Club again tomorrow. Box office: 020-7439 8722

webTitle: Price cutting boosts car sales to near record

fields.headline: Price cutting boosts car sales to near record
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Car manufacturers were congratulating themselves yesterday on near record sales in Britain last year. The boom was achieved after price cuts triggered a last-minute flood of orders from previously reluctant private motorists.
fields.body:
Car manufacturers were congratulating themselves yesterday on near record sales in Britain last year. The boom was achieved after price cuts triggered a last-minute flood of orders from previously reluctant private motorists.

The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders said 2,221,647 cars were registered last year, a total exceeded only in 1989 and 1998. Commercial vehicle registrations, at 298,043, were the best for 11 years.

MG Rover, rumoured to be struggling to meet its production target of 200,000 vehicles a year, comfortably exceeded it with global registrations of 205,000. However, the uncertainty about its future during BMW's drawn out sale of the group, hit British sales, which at 103,663, were 5.87% down on the previous year.

The industry's result for 2000 was achieved despite low sales in the earlier part of the year when many private motorists in effect boycotted the market.

Their action was triggered by reports, later confirmed by the office of fair trading, that manufacturers were charging more for their models in Britain than in continental Europe.

An OFT investigation concluded British customers were being overcharged by an average £1,100 per car. The OFT report, coupled with government action, led many manufacturers to cut prices by several thousand pounds.

The top three manufacturers were Ford, Vauxhall and Peugeot.

Jaguar yesterday gave the go-ahead for its smaller, more affordable, F-type roadster.

fields.headline: Homes market 'worst since 1995'
fields.standfirst:
Halifax still optimistic despite 'blip' in statistics

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Confidence in the housing market suffered a sharp blow yesterday with publication of figures showing that 2000 was the worst year for the property market since 1995.
fields.body:
Confidence in the housing market suffered a sharp blow yesterday with publication of figures showing that 2000 was the worst year for the property market since 1995.

Halifax, Britain's largest mortgage lender, said prices rose by an average of just 3.1% last year, the worst performance since 1995 when the housing market was still struggling to recover from recession.

The drop in the annual rate of house price inflation from 7.1% in November and 13.8% in December 1999 followed a steep fall in values in the month before Christmas, when they declined by 1.1% - the biggest monthly drop for more than six years.

Halifax played down the fall in the annual rate, saying it was a statistical blip. Since prices rose dramatically in December 1999, even a small increase in prices last month would have translated into a fall in the annual rate.

However, the bank agreed that real economic factors had slowed the market during the course of 2000, including higher interest rates, the abolition of mortgage tax relief and steep prices rises early in the year deterring potential buyers.

Halifax group economist Martin Ellis acknowledged that the deteriorating outlook for global economic growth meant the market could worsen during the course of the year.

"The fundamental factors underlying the market are in good shape. Affordability levels are in line with long term averages, the economy is growing well and there is the prospect later in the year of interest rates coming down," Mr Ellis said.

"If the US economy were to go into recession then inevitably, that would have a knock-on effect on the UK economy and housing market. I accept that risk but overall we are still pretty optimistic about what is going to happen this year."

George Buckley, UK economist at Deutsche Bank in London, backed the Halifax's sanguine assessment, predicting that UK house prices would rise by 6.4% in 2001 and 6% in 2002.

"I think you should be very cautious about reading too much into the Halifax's figures. The housing market appears to be reassuringly robust. In November we had the highest ever mortgage approvals and net lending," he said.

Other figures published yesterday suggested consumer confidence remains high. John Lewis said its department store sales rose strongly by almost 12% in the week to December 30 and the Royal Bank of Scotland said a record £500m had been withdrawn from its cash machines nationwide over the Christmas period, suggesting that overall withdrawals could have topped £12bn.

More than 40 of the Royal Bank of Scotland's machines pumped out over £1m each, with the bank's cashpoint at London's Liverpool Street station issuing almost £1.7m during December.

Meanwhile supermarket chain Tesco announced record sales over the Christmas period for its online home delivery service.

The company said it had dispatched over 30m grocery and non-food items to UK customers, an increase of four times on last year's figures.

webTitle: How can I fight off these false allegations?

fields.headline: How can I fight off these false allegations?
fields.trailText: I have been repeatedly bullied and harassed in the seven years I have worked for a housing management company. Allegations have been made of sexual harassment of a female colleague, consorting with a known criminal, shoplifting and then selling cigarettes to colleagues. My employers have not followed disciplinary procedures and I believe I am the victim of racial harassment. What can I do?

The fact that your employer has not sacked you suggests it has been unable to prove the allegations. You have the right to look at your personnel file and to insist that unproven allegations are removed. And much behaviour outside work should be irrelevant to whether you can do your job (unless you are in a role where absolute financial rectitude is required).

It is best to chat with someone in authority that you respect - someone high up in personnel or a boss. If that does not work, you could start grievance procedures against anyone victimising you. You can probably be accompanied at these hearings by a representative from your union. Finally, you could launch a claim of racial discrimination - by consulting a citizens advice bureau, for example - while continuing to work. Damages are theoretically unlimited.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Guide to Tessas

fields.headline: Alternative homes for mature Tessas
fields.standfirst:
People looking for good returns on transferred accounts should follow five simple rules, say Nick Pandya and Patrick Collinson

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: People looking for good returns on transferred accounts should follow five simple rules, say Nick Pandya and Patrick Collinson.
fields.body:
Ten years ago John Major unveiled Tessas - tax free savings accounts - and billions of pounds poured in. This year a total of £26bn in Tessa money will be pouring out and looking for a new home.

How much will you receive, what should you do, and what are you allowed to do with the money now?

Firstly, of course, you can simply spend it, or pay off other debts. Economists expect the flood of Tessa money, rather like demutualisation windfall payouts, to have a significant impact on the wider economy.

Alternatively, you can re-invest it, and do so in another tax-free environment, without having to eat into your annual individual savings account allowance, by investing in a "Tessa-only Isa".

Anyone with a Tessa coming to the end of its five-year term should remember the following five rules:

There are three tax-free options; put the money in a mini cash ISA (maximum investment £3,000), use the cash component of a maxi ISA (£3,000 maximum), or (and this will be the wisest move for most savers) take out a Tessa-only Isa (maximum investment £9,000).

You only have six months to move your savings tax-free to another vehicle after your Tessa has matured. After that, you lose your tax-free Tessa allowance forever.

You can only invest the maturing capital of your Tessa into a Tessa-only Isa. It is not possible to reinvest the interest into the Tessa-only Isa, even if you have less than £9,000 in your Tessa.

Transferring your Tessa capital to a Tessa-only Isa has absolutely no effect on your annual Isa allowance of £7,000. That means that someone with a Tessa maturing this year is in the fortunate position of taking advantage of up to £16,000 in tax-free savings.

You don't have to invest the Tessa-only Isa with your current bank or building society.

Janine Starks of Chase de Vere Investments, which has produced a handy guide to maturing Tessas, says: "If there's one message you take away, it should be to shop around for the best offers."

Picking the wrong Tessa can cost you thousands of pounds in lost interest. Chase De Vere found that the difference between the best and the worst performing Tessas in the five years since January 1996 works out at almost £4,000.

Its study reveals that the small number of stockmarket-linked Tessas did best, earning interest of around £6,000 on the £9,000 invested over five years. Second best were fixed-rate Tessas, which averaged a gain of £4,000, while trailing in third place were the variable rate Tessas who have come out the poorest with average payouts below £3,500.

Jubilant savers with money in Bristol & West's Tessa, where returns were linked to the performance of the UK stockmarket over the last five years, have seen their original deposit of £9,000 lifted by £6,942 to £15,942, a return on investment of 77% But savers with £9,000 on deposit in a variable rate Tessa, provided by Flemings Premier Bank, will have seen their capital grow by £3,050 to £12,050.

So which Tessas currently offer the best rates of interest? One way is to check with financial data experts Moneyfacts. Moneyfacts currently lists Portman Building Society's 7.3% paying Tessa-only Isas as its best buy. But note that the account needs a minimum balance of £1,000 and 45 days notice before making a withdrawal. For savers who prefer instant access to their funds Britannia is paying 6.85% on deposits of at least £1.

These rates compare well with some of the big high street names. Halifax is currently only offering 5.45% on its Tessa-only Isa, the lowest of any of the big providers. Bradford & Bingley (5.6%) and Abbey National (5.95%) also have uncompetitive products.

Moving your Tessa to an alternative provider is relatively painless. Firstly withdraw your Tessa savings at maturity, asking your old bank to give you a cheque made payable to your new bank. Secondly, ask your old bank for a Tessa maturity certificate, then go to the bank or building society where you want to open a new Tessa-only Isa. Remember, they may want extensive identification because of anti-money laundering regulations.

But the message from the experts is not to rush in just yet, as banks and building societies will begin to re-jig their savings account rates over the next couple of months to attract savers with maturing Tessa funds.

 For further information on the Chase de Vere Tessa league table and a guide to maturing Tessas, call its Moneyline team on 0845 609 2001.

webTitle: P&D is bearing up in decline

fields.headline: P&D is bearing up in decline
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The average pension fund ended last year no better off than it started, fund management group Phillips & Drew said yesterday as it pinned its hopes on a recovery in its own fortunes.
fields.body:
The average pension fund ended last year no better off than it started, fund management group Phillips & Drew said yesterday as it pinned its hopes on a recovery in its own fortunes.

Renowned for calling the bear market in stocks four years too soon, P&D is hoping that the negative sentiment sweeping through the stock market will help it win back clients.

Robin Hindle Fisher, chief executive of the Swiss-owned fund management group, yesterday refused to admit how many clients, often local authority pension funds, it had lost in recent years when its performance nose-dived.

However, Mr Hindle Fisher said 2000 had been a "great year" for P&D, which is expected to emerge as the top performing pension fund manager when influential league tables are published in the coming weeks.

He said the bear market which its former top fund manager Tony Dye predicted four years ago had begun and that the bull market would take some time to return.

At the end of only one of three years in which the FTSE 100 index ended lower than it started, P&D says it offered a 5.5% return for its clients. However, it believes the "average" return for the pension fund industry was zero.

The decision by P&D, which terms itself a "value" investor, to shun the volatile dot.com sector last year is one of the reasons for its above average performance. It decided to invest in stocks which it deemed undervalued, such as publishing group Reed, oil company Lasmo and retailer GUS.

However, Mr Hindle Fisher said P&D had started to buy dot.com stocks, naming Dimension Data as one of its recent investments.

fields.headline: Check out pick of the Isas
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Investors who fell for last year's technology hype and plunged their full £7,000 Isa allowance into the Framlington NetNet fund now have units worth closer to £3,000 after the dot.com bubble burst in March.
fields.body:
Investors who fell for last year's technology hype and plunged their full £7,000 Isa allowance into the Framlington NetNet fund now have units worth closer to £3,000 after the dot.com bubble burst in March.

It was the second worst performing unit trust or OEIC over the past year, according to Standard & Poors. But had they ignored the publicity machine, and bought Framlington Health fund, their fortune, on the same basis, would have soared to more than £14,000.

The investment management firm is the same, the charges are identical and there are similar risk profiles - but an £11,000 wealth gap. Many other discount broker recommendations went the same way as NatWest- downwards. The CGU (now Norwich Union) Monthly Income Plan was hyped - and also disappointed.

So which way should you plump this year? Unfortunately, advisers are in disarray and have failed to come up with a strong theme, either because they cannot think of one or because they believe investors have become cynical about their recommendations. And to that, prospective investors must add genuine uncertainty.

Was this week's 0.5% surprise reduction in US interest rates from Alan Greenspan's Federal Reserve the kickstart the American economy needs to avoid slow down and recession, or a placebo drug designed to keep the victim's spirits up before an inevitable hard landing?

No one knows - and it is never wise to invest in unit or investment trusts on the back of what could be a kneejerk stock market reaction.

Arch shares pessimist David Kauders of Kauders Portfolio Management reckons that "a bear market grows ever more likely. For those who prefer to hold on to their capital, equities could become a no-go area".

He says the best way to take advantage of falling interest rates and a developing recession is to buy US Treasury bonds - Kauders expects the pound to weaken.

"Investors should be willing to pay income tax and reinvest net income to achieve secure steady growth in capital," he adds.

But one expert who does not share his gloom and doom, financial adviser Brian Dennehy, who operates Isa top ten, believes savers can prosper by opting for the right equity funds. Dennehy gives discounts although, unlike many rivals, he does not canvass for, or accept payments from, fund managers for inclusion in recommendation lists.

"Our research is based on a statistical analysis of growth, risk and consistency so we can screen out funds where an apparently good past performance has been a matter of luck or taking unacceptable risks," he says.

Dennehy believes that the "global trend towards old economy recovery will continue", which could indicate some of the newer funds which buy top companies from across the world.

His advice consists of chasing good managers rather than concepts and of matching funds to purchasers' personal risk profiles.

ABN Amro's Growth Fund and a similar trust from Solus - there is a degree of management in common - stand out as the clear choice for higher risk investors.

But, says Dennehy, Schroder UK Growth is showing up strongly for those who believe in the enduring powers of the old economy. Highly recommended Newton Income falls somewhere in between these extremes.

Some advisers fancy Europe - a stronger currency and merger action hopes are two plus points. Isa-topten.com warns against European funds from Deutsche and the highly rated Invesco - preferring Threadneedle, the lesser known Singer & Friedlander and Pearl and out of favour Scottish Widows.

Japan has had a bad year with the Nikkei index bumping along the bottom. Merrill Lynch suggests those hoping for recovery there could try investment trusts such as Fleming Japanese, Schroder Japan Growth and - for smaller company fans - Atlantis Japan Growth.

Among mainstream investment trusts, Monks, which invests in big companies globally, has potential for comfort-seeking investors, says NatWest stockbrokers which also likes UK-oriented City of London, big international trust Witan despite a disappointing year and, for those willing to bet that the Far East cannot record a second year of misery, Edinburgh Dragon.
