webTitle: Banks and insurers stymie stakeholder plans

fields.headline: Banks and insurers stymie stakeholder plans
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: High street banks and insurers yesterday blew a hole in the government's hopes for the succesful launch of stakeholder pensions in April by snubbing proposals for stakeholder "supermarkets" in every branch.
fields.body:
High street banks and insurers yesterday blew a hole in the government's hopes for the succesful launch of stakeholder pensions in April by snubbing proposals for stakeholder "supermarkets" in every branch.

The Treasury is rushing through a major shake-up in the way financial products are sold to allow banks to distribute a wide range of stakeholder pensions. Rather than selling just its own brand pension, a bank could sell the pensions of, say, Standard Life or Norwich Union.

But yesterday Abbey National, one of the key players in the lower to middle income market, where the government is targeting stakeholders, rejected the idea of "multi-tied" pension selling.

A spokeswoman said: "We have no plans to sell anybody's stakeholder pension other than our own, bearing in mind that that the ones we have seen so far from competitors are all pretty similar." Lloyds TSB also said it was lukewarm about the proposals.

Standard Life, the biggest pension seller, also said it had no plans to sell its stakeholder product through bank branches. "Multi-tying is not the most ideal way forward. We believe the clarity of independent advice is preferable," said assistant general manager of sales, Paul Matthews. Under present rules, known as "polarisation", financial sellers such as banks can either be tied to one provider or sell the full range of deals across the market and earn the title "independent".

But yesterday the financial services authority outlined new rules, due to come into force in April, allowing multi-tying as a new halfway house between tied and independent. Initially multi-ties will be allowed only for stakeholder pensions and certain types of Isas, but yesterday the FSA promised "more radical change" over the longer term.

Independent advisers criticised the proposals, which they claim will cause "muddle and chaos". Paul Smee of the Association of Independent Financial Advisers said: "Nobody has identified how banks will select the right stakeholder for you and whether you get the best product."

fields.headline: Pinocchio wins it by a nose
fields.standfirst:
Adventures of Pinocchio
Lyric Hammersmith, London
***
fields.trailText:
Adventures of Pinocchio
Lyric Hammersmith, London
***
fields.body:
For some time now, the opening pages of Lyric programmes have included quotes about the theatre, including one from Mr JM Levy, outfitter, of King Street, Hammersmith, who in 1895 declared happily: "The Lyric dramas are well acted and produced. The plays illustrate the terrible consequences of a life of sin. Virtue always triumphs over evil."

I can't help feeling that Mr Levy would have wholeheartedly approved of The Adventures of Pinocchio, Carlo Collodi's moralising tale about the little carved wooden puppet that becomes a substitute son for the poor woodcarver Geppetto.

Marcello Magni's appealingly rough-and-ready production, which combines puppetry with live actors, concentrates on the medium rather than the message. Even so - and despite Lee Hall's easy, entertaining dramatisation, which revels in Pinocchio's sheer naughtiness and children's love of rude words - there are times when it feels like sugared medicine.

This is certainly a most imaginative version of Pinocchio. But too often it is almost magic, not total enchantment. This is in part because, with the exception of some brilliant sequences - such as Pinocchio's flight on a bird's back over a green sheet field - the production suffers from the strongly episodic nature of the narrative. It is also because, unlike the best fairytales, Collodi's story is much stronger on morality than on metaphor. This makes it hard to make such scenes as the one in which Pinocchio and the runaway schoolboys are transformed into donkeys theatrically fantastical rather than merely plodding.

But the wit of the script and the good humour and generosity of the performers give the evening a feel-good factor despite the dark nature of some of material. This is a genuinely ensemble piece, but Eric Mallett's stiff- jointed Pinocchio and Paul Hunter's compassionate, comic Geppetto deserve special mention.

 Until January 13. Box office: 020-8741 2311.
